What causes Jaw Pain During Pregnancy: Why It Happens and What You Can Do?

Why Can Pregnancy Cause Jaw Pain?

 

 Several factors during pregnancy can affect the jaw joint:

 1. Hormonal Changes

 During pregnancy, the body produces increased amounts of the hormone relaxin. This hormone loosens ligaments to prepare the body for childbirth - but it affects all joints, including the jaw joint:

 
 Increased joint mobility can cause instability

 Ligaments in the jaw become looser

 Increased risk of clicking and discomfort

 

 Estrogen also affects pain perception and can make the jaw joint more sensitive.

 2. Stress and Worry

 Pregnancy is a time with many thoughts and worries:

 
 Increased stress levels often lead to teeth grinding

 Sleep problems worsen bruxism

 Jaw tension as a response to uncertainty

 

 3. Postural Changes

 As the belly grows:

 
 Center of gravity shifts forward

 Many compensate with increased lower back curve

 Shoulders pull forward, neck extends

 Forward head position strains the jaw joint

 

 4. Sleeping Position

 
 Side lying (recommended in last trimester) can press on the jaw

 Restless sleep increases nighttime grinding

 Frequent waking disrupts the sleep cycle

Describe Why Is This So Confusing? for Sciatica, Disc Herniation or Lumbago?.

Why Is This So Confusing?

 

 
 Most people with back pain google their symptoms. The terms "lumbago", "disc herniation" and "sciatica" appear interchangeably - often used as if they mean the same thing. They don't.
 

 
 The problem is that symptoms can overlap, and many believe they have a serious injury when the pain is actually caused by something far less dramatic. Around 85-95% of all back pain is non-specific, meaning without a detectable structural cause (WHO, 2023). True disc herniation with nerve involvement accounts for less than 5% of cases (StatPearls, 2024).
You are a clinical documentation assistant for chiropractors. Generate professional medical documentation.
Describe What Is Lumbago? for Sciatica, Disc Herniation or Lumbago?.

What Is Lumbago?

 

 
 Lumbago is what most people have when their back "locks up". The medical term is acute lumbago or non-specific low back pain. The pain comes suddenly, often after an awkward movement, lift or twist - but can also occur seemingly without reason.
 

 
 Characteristics of lumbago:

 
 Localized pain in the lower back

 Pain may radiate diffusely to the buttocks or thighs, but never below the knee

 Stiff back with limited mobility

 Worst in the first few days, then gradual improvement

 No tingling, numbness or muscle weakness

 
 

 
 With lumbago, no specific structural cause is found. MRI or X-ray often shows "normal" age-related changes that don't explain the pain. This is actually good news: it means your body isn't damaged.
 

 
 Most people improve significantly within 6 weeks. Pain scores typically fall from around 56/100 to 26/100 during this period (Pengel et al., BMJ 2003). However, we must be honest: 33-73% experience recurrence within one year, and some develop chronic symptoms.

Describe What Is Disc Herniation? for Sciatica, Disc Herniation or Lumbago?.

What Is Disc Herniation?

 

 
 Disc herniation (slipped disc or disc prolapse) occurs when the soft core of an intervertebral disc bulges out or pushes through the outer layer. Think of the disc as a jelly donut - with disc herniation, the "jelly" is pushed out.
 

 
 Important to know about disc herniation:

 
 Disc herniation is rarer than people think. Less than 5% of back pain is caused by symptomatic disc herniation. The vast majority of herniations occur at the two lowest levels: L4-L5 and L5-S1, which together account for 95% of cases.
 

 

 
 Here's the real surprise: You can have a disc herniation without knowing it. A large review of MRI studies (Brinjikji et al., AJNR 2015) showed that many healthy, pain-free people have disc herniations on MRI:

 The good news: 66-77% of disc herniations resolve on their own (Zhong et al., 2017). In fact, research shows that the most dramatic herniations - where the disc has completely detached (sequestration) - have the highest resorption rate at 88% (Zou et al., 2023).

Describe What Is Sciatica? for Sciatica, Disc Herniation or Lumbago?.

What Is Sciatica?

 

 
 Sciatica (or lumbar radiculopathy) is not a diagnosis in itself, but a symptom pattern. It describes pain that radiates along the sciatic nerve - from the lower back, through the buttock, down the back of the thigh and often all the way to the foot.
 

 
 Characteristics of true sciatica:

 
 Sharp, burning or electric pain that radiates past the knee

 Often worse than the back pain itself

 Tingling or numbness in specific areas

 May have weakness in the foot or toes

 Worsens with sitting, coughing and sneezing

 Positive "straight leg raise" test by practitioner

 
 

 
 Sciatica affects 5-10% of those with back pain. So it's far more common than disc herniation, but still uncommon compared to simple muscle pain.
 

 
 Can you have sciatica without disc herniation? Yes. Other causes include piriformis syndrome (0.3-6% of sciatica cases), spinal stenosis and spondylolisthesis.

Identify red flags for Sciatica, Disc Herniation or Lumbago?.

Red Flags - When You Must Seek Medical Help Immediately

 

 
 Cauda equina syndrome is an emergency requiring immediate help. Call emergency services if you experience:

 
 Sudden urinary retention (cannot urinate) or incontinence

 Numbness in the "saddle area" (around genitals, inner thighs, buttocks)

 Bowel incontinence or reduced control

 Progressive weakness in both legs

 Extensive and increasing numbness in both legs

 
 
 Cauda equina affects approximately 1:33,000-100,000 in the population and accounts for about 2% of all disc herniations. The condition requires decompressive surgery within 24-48 hours to avoid permanent damage.

Describe When Do You Need MRI or X-ray? for Sciatica, Disc Herniation or Lumbago?.

When Do You Need MRI or X-ray?

 

 
 Short answer: Less often than you think.
 

 
 International guidelines do not recommend routine imaging in the first 6 weeks for back pain without red flags.
 

 
 Why? Because MRI findings correlate poorly with symptoms - up to 97% of asymptomatic adults have "abnormal" findings. Early MRI is linked to 8 times higher surgery rate without better outcomes (Webster et al., 2010).

Treatment - What Can Help?

 

 
 For acute back pain, you can get help immediately - you don't need to "wait and see" for several weeks. Early treatment can contribute to faster pain relief and return to normal activities.
 

 What can the chiropractor do?

 
 Joint mobilization and manipulation

 Soft tissue treatment of tight muscles

 Nerve mobilization techniques for radiating pain

 Guidance on activity and exercises

 Gradual rehabilitation

 

 What can you do yourself?

 
 Keep moving. Bed rest is discouraged in all guidelines.

 Avoid prolonged sitting. Change positions often, stand up and walk regularly.

 Pain relief as needed. Paracetamol or ibuprofen for short periods.

 Don't catastrophize. Back pain is common and usually resolves.

What is the prognosis for Sciatica, Disc Herniation or Lumbago??

Prognosis - What Can You Expect?

 

 
 Lumbago: Most people improve significantly within 6 weeks. About 82% are back to work within a month.
 

 
 Disc herniation: Surprisingly good prognosis without surgery. 66-77% of herniations resorb spontaneously over 3-6 months.
 

 
 Sciatica: 60% improve within 3 months, and 70-75% within one year with conservative treatment.
 

 
 
 Expected Treatment Course

 For acute low back pain, clinical guidelines (CCGPP) typically recommend 6-12 treatments over 2-4 weeks, depending on response. For sciatica, the course may be longer. The treatment plan is always tailored to your individual situation.

 If there's no improvement after 4-6 weeks, the diagnosis is reassessed and further measures discussed.

Frequently Asked Questions

 

 
 Can I have a disc herniation without knowing it?

 Yes, absolutely. Studies show that 30-50% of healthy, pain-free people have visible disc changes on MRI. Disc herniation is only a problem when it causes symptoms.

 

 
 Do I need surgery if I have a disc herniation?

 No, most people don't need surgery. Conservative treatment gives equally good long-term results for most. Surgery is considered for cauda equina syndrome, progressive paralysis, or persistent severe symptoms despite treatment.

 

 
 How long does lumbago last?

 Most people experience significant improvement within 2-6 weeks. Some have mild residual symptoms longer. Pain lasting over 12 weeks is considered chronic back pain.

 

 
 Is it dangerous to see a chiropractor for sciatica?

 No, chiropractors are trained to assess and treat sciatica. If a serious underlying cause is suspected, you will be referred. Early treatment can actually contribute to faster recovery.

 

 
 Can stress cause back pain?

 Yes. Psychosocial factors such as stress, anxiety and depression are strong predictors of chronic back pain. Body and mind are connected - muscle tension and altered pain perception during stress are real phenomena.

 

 
 What's the difference between a chiropractor and physiotherapist for back problems?

 Both professions treat back problems. Chiropractors have particular expertise in joint manipulation and diagnosis of musculoskeletal conditions, and have primary contact s...

Why Does Stress Settle in the Jaw?

 

 When you experience stress, the "fight or flight" response is activated, and the body prepares for action:

 
 Jaw muscles tighten automatically

 Teeth are pressed together - often unconsciously

 Shoulders raise and neck tenses

 Breathing becomes faster and shallower

 

 In a normal stress scenario (e.g., avoiding danger), this tension would be released through physical activity. But in modern everyday stress (work pressure, worries, conflicts), the tension stays - and the jaw takes the hit.

Describe Strategies to Break the Cycle for Stress and Jaw Pain: How Stress Settles in the Jaw.

Strategies to Break the Cycle

 

 
 1. Awareness - The Most Important First Step

 You can't change something you're not aware of:

 
 Set reminders: Use your phone or post-it notes to remind yourself to check the jaw

 Body scanning: Several times daily - is the jaw relaxed?

 Trigger situations: Notice when you clench (screen work, driving, stressful conversations)

 
 

 
 2. Rest Position for the Jaw

 Teach your jaw a new default setting:

 
 "N technique": Say the letter "N" and hold the jaw in that position

 Mantra: "Lips together, teeth apart"

 Tongue: Rest against the palate, just behind the front teeth

 
 

 
 3. Breathing Techniques

 Breathing and jaw are closely connected:

 
 4-7-8 breathing: In for 4, hold for 7, out for 8

 Diaphragmatic breathing: Breathe deeply into the belly

 Breathe through the nose: Calmer than mouth breathing

 
 

 
 4. Progressive Muscle Relaxation

 
 Press teeth hard together for 5 seconds

 Release completely and feel the contrast

 Let the jaw hang heavy for 10 seconds

 Repeat 3-5 times

 
 By tensing first, you learn to feel the difference between tense and relaxed.

 

 
 5. General Stress Management

 
 Regular physical activity: Releases tension from the body

 Sleep hygiene: Stress and poor sleep reinforce each other

 Breaks: Short breaks throughout the workday

 Boundary setting: Say no to overload

 Mindfulness/meditation: Documented effect on stress response

Describe Why does stress settle in the neck? for Stress Neck and Trigger Points.

Why does stress settle in the neck?

 

 When you experience stress, the brain sends signals that activate the musculature. This is part of the body's "fight or flight" response. The problem is that modern stressors rarely require physical action - but the muscle tension remains.

 
 EMG studies document the connection

 Electromyography (EMG) measures electrical activity in muscles. Studies have consistently shown that the trapezius muscle is activated during mental load, even without physical work:

 
 Lundberg and colleagues (1994) found that mental stress tests gave significant increase in trapezius EMG activity

 70% of those with neck pain had higher EMG activity at work

 During stress, trapezius gets fewer rest breaks

Describe What is Subtle BPPV? for Subtle BPPV: When Dizziness Doesn't Spin.

What is Subtle BPPV?

 

 Subtle BPPV - also called "subjective BPPV" or "Type 2 BPPV" - is the same condition as regular BPPV: Loose calcium crystals in the balance organ's semicircular canals send incorrect signals to the brain. The difference lies in how symptoms are experienced.

 
 Typical Symptoms of Subtle BPPV

 
 A vague nausea or "seasickness on land"

 Fatigue that can't be explained by lack of sleep

 Brain fog and concentration problems

 A feeling that something is "wrong," without being able to pinpoint it

 Mild unsteadiness, especially when turning around or looking up

 
 

 Harmat and colleagues' study from 2022 estimated that about one in three BPPV patients has this Type 2 variant.

How is Subtle BPPV: When Dizziness Doesn't Spin diagnosed?

Why Standard Examination Misses These Patients

 

 Standard examination for BPPV - the Dix-Hallpike test - is typically performed in normal lighting, where the patient can fixate their gaze. This suppresses the characteristic eye movements (nystagmus).

 Frenzel goggles, light on66%
 Frenzel goggles, darkness83%
 Videonystagmography (VNG) in darkness100%
 
 
 
 Important to Know

 Examination in normal lighting misses about 60% of eye movements that would be visible with proper equipment.

Why Do You Get So Tired?

 

 When the balance organ sends incorrect signals, the brain must work overtime to compensate. This process - vestibular compensation - requires significant neural resources.

 
 Compensation Timeline

 According to research from 2016, it takes up to 3 months for postural compensation (posture and stability), and up to 1 year for perception of vertical to normalize.

 

 
 The consequence? 75% of patients with chronic BPPV were on 50-100% sick leave in one study (median illness duration over 5 years before adequate treatment).

What Is Text Neck?

 

 "Text neck" (tech neck) refers to neck and head problems arising from prolonged use of mobile devices with a bent head. When you look down at your phone, your neck bends forward and your head moves in front of the line of gravity.

 This is not just a modern phenomenon - the same posture is seen with:

 
 Desk work with a low screen

 Reading books in your lap

 Handicrafts

 Gaming on tablets

 

 But smartphones have dramatically increased the time spent in this position.

Describe How Text Neck Affects the Jaw for Text Neck and Jaw Pain: How Mobile Use Affects the Jaw.

How Text Neck Affects the Jaw

 

 The connection between forward head posture and jaw problems is well documented:

 
 1. Biomechanical Change

 When the head moves forward:

 
 The lower jaw is pulled backward and down by gravity

 The jaw muscles must work to keep the mouth closed

 The jaw joint is loaded asymmetrically

 The posterior part of the joint is compressed

 
 

 
 2. Muscular Compensation

 
 Masseter and temporalis are activated unnecessarily

 Constant low-level tension leads to fatigue

 Increased risk of trigger points

 Tension headaches in the temples

 
 

 
 3. Nerve Connections

 
 The trigeminocervical complex connects neck and jaw

 Tight neck muscles can cause referred pain to the jaw

 Suboccipital tension affects jaw muscles reflexively

 
 

 
 Research Confirms the Connection

 Studies show that 70-90% of TMD patients have concurrent neck problems, and that treatment of the neck often improves jaw symptoms - even without direct jaw treatment.

Describe What is text neck? for Text Neck and Phone Neck - Neck Pain from Screen Use.

What is text neck?

 

 The term was first used by American chiropractor Dean Fishman in 2008. When you hold your head in neutral position, it weighs approximately 4.5-5.5 kg. A biomechanical study from 2014 showed that the load on the neck increases dramatically with forward bending:

 
 Load at different angles

 
 15 degrees: 12 kg load

 30 degrees: 18 kg load

 60 degrees (typical when texting): 27 kg load

 
 

 Norway has the highest prevalence of neck pain in the world, with 1,145 per 100,000 inhabitants. Meanwhile, surveys show that 97% of children between 9-18 years have their own mobile phone, and 74% use screens more than 3 hours daily outside of school.

What causes Text Neck and Phone Neck - Neck Pain from Screen Use?

Causes and Risk Factors

 

 
 Prolonged screen use in forward-bent position (most common)

 The clearly most common cause of text neck is simply the time spent with the head bent over the phone, tablet or PC. A meta-analysis from 2025 found that excessive smartphone use gives 2.34 times higher risk of neck pain. Among office workers, the risk was even higher - 6 times increased risk.

 

 
 Poor workplace ergonomics

 Screen placed too low, chair without support, or lack of height adjustment contributes to the neck being held in unfavorable positions hour after hour.

 

 
 Lack of breaks and movement

 Static work without micro-breaks overloads the neck musculature. Health guidelines recommend varied activity, different work positions and frequent micro-breaks.

Symptoms

 

 
 Neck pain and stiff neck: Aching, nagging pain that worsens throughout the day

 Pain in upper back and between shoulder blades: Forward-bent posture strains the musculature in the entire upper part of the back

 Tension headache: Tight musculature in the neck can cause headache that starts at the back of the head

 Reduced mobility: Stiffness when turning the head to the sides or looking up toward the ceiling

 Shoulder pain: Shoulder musculature compensates for weak neck musculature

 

 A Norwegian study based on the Ungdata survey (253,968 adolescents) showed that 24% of Norwegian youth had neck and shoulder pain, and among girls with such problems, 70% also had headache.

Describe treatment options for Text Neck and Phone Neck - Neck Pain from Screen Use.

Treatment

 

 
 What can the chiropractor do?

 A systematic review from 2023 found that the combination of manual therapy and stabilization exercises gave better results than training alone for patients with forward head posture and chronic neck pain.

 
 Joint mobilization and manipulation: Treatment of stiff joints in neck and upper back

 Soft tissue treatment: Treatment of tight and overloaded musculature

 Exercise instruction: Targeted exercises to strengthen the deep neck flexors

 Ergonomic guidance: Concrete advice about screen height, chair, work position and break routines

 
 

 
 What can you do yourself?

 
 Adjust screen height: The screen should be at eye level. Use stands for tablet and laptop.

 Take frequent breaks: Follow the 20-20-20 rule: Every 20 minutes, look at something 20 meters away for 20 seconds.

 Chin tucks: Pull your chin straight back as if making a "double chin", hold 5-10 seconds, and repeat 10 times.

 Stretch chest and neck muscles: Stretch pectoralis and upper trapezius daily.

 
 

 
 Studies on forward head posture show that exercise programs typically last 4-10 weeks with good results. For acute text neck problems, I often see improvement within 2-4 weeks with treatment and self-effort.

Describe What Is IBS? for TMD and IBS: The Surprising Connection Between Jaw and Gut.

What Is IBS?

 

 Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) is a functional gastrointestinal disorder characterized by:

 
 Abdominal pain or discomfort

 Changed bowel patterns (diarrhea, constipation, or both)

 Bloating

 Symptoms that worsen with stress

 
 Approximately 10-15% of the population has IBS, and women are affected more often than men.

Describe Why Do They Occur Together? for TMD and IBS: The Surprising Connection Between Jaw and Gut.

Why Do They Occur Together?

 

 There are several explanations for the overlap between TMD and IBS:

 
 1. Central Sensitization

 Both TMD and IBS can involve central sensitization - a condition where the central nervous system becomes hypersensitive to signals:

 
 The brain interprets normal signals as pain

 Pain thresholds are lowered throughout the body

 Explains why people can have pain in multiple locations simultaneously

 
 

 
 2. Stress and the Autonomic Nervous System

 Stress affects both jaw and gut through the autonomic nervous system:

 
 Fight-or-flight: Activates jaw muscles AND affects gut function

 Vagus nerve: Connects brain, jaw, and gut system

 Chronic stress: Maintains activation of both systems

 
 

 
 3. The Gut-Brain Axis

 The so-called "gut-brain axis" explains communication between gut and brain:

 
 The gut has its own nervous system (the enteric nervous system)

 Gut flora affects mood and pain perception

 The brain can affect gut movements and sensitivity

 The same mechanisms can affect jaw function

 
 

 
 Serotonin Connection

 95% of the body's serotonin is found in the gut. Serotonin affects gut function, mood, AND pain modulation. Imbalance in the serotonin system can contribute to both IBS and TMD.

 

 
 4. Shared Psychological Factors

 Both conditions are associated with:

 
 Anxiety

 Depression

 Catastrophizing

 Sleep problems

 Feeling of lack of control

What is myofascial pain syndrome and trigger points?

 

 A trigger point in the upper trapezius can, for example, cause headache up toward the temple. In pain clinics, up to 85% of patients have a myofascial component.

 
 Important to know

 MPS occurs most often in the 27-50 age group. Women are affected more often than men - 65% versus 37% among middle-aged adults.

What causes Trigger Points and Myofascial Pain Syndrome in the Neck?

Causes and Risk Factors

 

 Trigger points develop when muscle fibers become overloaded or damaged. The most common causes:

 
 Static loading and poor ergonomics

 Prolonged desk work, screen use with forward head posture, and repetitive work are by far the most common causes. Office workers have an average of 6 active and 10-11 latent trigger points.

 

 
 Muscular overload

 Repetitive movements, heavy lifting, or sudden increased training load.

 

 
 Stress and tension

 Psychological stress often leads to chronic muscle tension, especially in the neck and shoulders.

 

 
 Other factors

 
 Sleep problems and fatigue: Poor sleep reduces the muscles' ability to recover

 Vitamin D deficiency: Approximately one-third of MPS patients have low vitamin D levels

 Trauma: Among whiplash patients, 55-65% have trigger points in the levator scapulae

 Strength training: Exercises for deep neck muscles and shoulder blade stabilizers

 Self-massage: Use a tennis ball or lacrosse ball against the wall for gentle pressure on tender points. 30-60 seconds per point

 Stress management: Chronic stress maintains muscle tension. Consider breathing techniques or mindfulness

 towards the wrist. You notice it particularly with gripping and lifting - lifting the coffee pot,

 Carpal tunnel syndrome is the most common nerve compression in the body. Women are affected
 three times more often than men, with peak between 45 and 60 years. The condition occurs when
 the median nerve is compressed in the narrow passage through the wrist.

 Classic symptoms: Numbness and tingling in the thumb, index finger, middle finger and
 half the ring finger. Symptoms are typically worst at night - many wake up with a
 "sleeping" hand and instinctively shake it to get the feeling back.

Describe What Can You Do Yourself? for Pain in Arm, Elbow and Hand.

What Can You Do Yourself?

 

 Three principles apply to most problems in arm, elbow and hand:

 
 
 1

 Stay active within pain limits

 Complete rest usually worsens the condition. Move the arm, but avoid movements that cause clear pain.
 Adapted activity keeps blood flow up.

 

 
 2

 Adjust ergonomics

 Small changes in how you work can make a big difference. Check mouse height, screen position and how
 you hold tools. Active breaks are more effective than passive ones.

 

 
 3

 Seek help early

 If you wait too long, acute problems can become chronic. Early treatment gives faster improvement. If
 problems last over 2-3 weeks, get in touch.

 

 

 
 Eccentric Wrist Extension (for tennis elbow)

 Hold a light weight (0.5-1 kg) with your arm on a table, wrist over the edge. Slowly lower the weight over 3-4 seconds. Use your other hand to lift back up. 3 sets of 15 repetitions, 2x daily.

 

 
 Nerve Gliding (for carpal tunnel)

 Straighten your arm, palm up. Make a fist, then open your fingers and extend the wrist back. Hold 2-3 seconds. 10 repetitions, 3x daily. Stop if symptoms worsen.

Carpal tunnel syndrome

 2-3% of population
 

 Go to full article on carpal tunnel syndrome 

 Carpal tunnel syndrome is the most common nerve compression in the body. Women are affected
 three times more often than men, with peak between 45 and 60 years. The condition occurs when
 the median nerve is compressed in the narrow passage through the wrist.

 Classic symptoms: Numbness and tingling in the thumb, index finger, middle finger and
 half the ring finger. Symptoms are typically worst at night - many wake up with a
 "sleeping" hand and instinctively shake it to get the feeling back.

 Risk factors: Overweight (8% increased risk per BMI unit), repetitive hand work,
 pregnancy, type 2 diabetes and low metabolism.

 
 Treatment

 A night splint that keeps the wrist straight provides improvement in 50-70% within 2-3
 months. In severe cases with muscle weakness, surgery may be relevant - with 90% success
 rate.

A Controversial Topic

 Anterior canal BPPV remains a debated topic in medical literature. The Barany Society still classifies it as an "emerging and controversial entity." The challenge lies in the fact that characteristic downbeat nystagmus can also be caused by central causes such as cerebellar disease.

What causes Anterior Canal BPPV: The Rare Variant?

Causes and Risk Factors

 

 A large study with 3,975 BPPV patients found that only 28 (0.7%) had anterior canal involvement (Bhandari 2023). Other studies report prevalence between 1-3%.

 From Most Common to Rarest:

 
 Idiopathic (60-70%)

 No known triggering cause. Natural aging and degeneration of the otolith organs is assumed to play a role.

 

 
 Head Trauma (10-20%)

 Traumatic BPPV is more often bilateral and can involve multiple canals.

 

 
 Conversion from Other BPPV (5-10%)

 Can occur as a complication of treatment for posterior canal BPPV.

 

 
 Secondary to Ear Disease (5%)

 Vestibular neuritis, Meniere's disease, or labyrinthitis.

 

 Risk Factors for BPPV in General:

 
 Vitamin D deficiency (levels below 20 ng/mL are associated with increased risk)

 Age (incidence increases by 38% per decade)

 Female sex (2-3 times higher risk)

 Hypertension and diabetes

 Osteoporosis and migraine

Symptoms

 

 Characteristic Presentation:

 
 Dizziness When Bending Forward and Backward

 Typical dizziness when tilting the head backward (looking up at shelves) or forward (picking something up from the floor). This differs from posterior canal BPPV, which is primarily triggered by lying down.

 

 
 Shorter Duration

How is Anterior Canal BPPV: The Rare Variant diagnosed?

Diagnosis

 

 Characteristic Nystagmus

 Downbeat nystagmus: The main characteristic of anterior canal BPPV is a vertical downbeat nystagmus. This fundamentally differs from posterior canal BPPV, which produces upbeat nystagmus.

 Weak torsional component: Unlike posterior canal BPPV where the torsional component is prominent, it is often weak or absent in anterior canal BPPV.

 Diagnostic Tests

 
 Supine Head Hanging Test

 This test is considered most sensitive for anterior canal BPPV. The patient lies with the head hanging 30 degrees below the horizontal plane, held in the midline. Observe for downbeat nystagmus.

 

 
 Dix-Hallpike Test

 Can also provoke anterior canal BPPV, but is less specific. Downbeat nystagmus on both sides may indicate anterior canal involvement.

 

 
 Differential Diagnosis - Critically Important!

 CENTRAL CAUSE MUST ALWAYS BE CONSIDERED: Downbeat nystagmus is a characteristic finding in cerebellar lesions. One study found that 72% of patients with positional downbeat nystagmus had central disorders.

 
 Peripheral cause: Latency before nystagmus onset, habituation, duration under 60 seconds, response to treatment

 Central cause: No latency, persistent nystagmus, no habituation, lack of response to treatment

Describe treatment options for Anterior Canal BPPV: The Rare Variant.

Treatment

 

 What Can the Chiropractor Do?

 Treatment of anterior canal BPPV involves repositioning maneuvers intended to move the crystals out of the semicircular canal. A systematic review found an overall treatment success of 85.6% (Anagnostou 2015).

 
 Yacovino Maneuver - First Choice

 Particularly suitable for anterior canal BPPV because it does not require identification of the affected side. Success rate: 78.8% (Anagnostou 2015).

 

 
 Epley Maneuver (Reversed)

 Reversed Epley from the unaffected side has shown 75.9% success. Requires identification of the affected side.

 

 Treatment Course and Realistic Expectations

 
 60-70% achieve symptom relief after 1-2 treatments

 20-30% need 3-5 treatments

 10% may require longer follow-up or alternative approach

Describe Frequently Asked Questions for Anterior Canal BPPV: The Rare Variant.

Frequently Asked Questions

 

 
 Can anterior canal BPPV be confused with neck-related dizziness?

 Yes, this is a common differential diagnosis. A positive response to the Supine Head Hanging Test with characteristic downbeat nystagmus suggests anterior canal BPPV. Cervicogenic dizziness typically produces no specific nystagmus.

 

 
 Why is anterior canal BPPV so rare?

 The anterior canal's vertical orientation makes it difficult for crystals to enter the canal against gravity. The same orientation also promotes spontaneous drainage of any crystals.

 

 
 Is downbeat nystagmus always anterior canal BPPV?

 No. Downbeat nystagmus can also be caused by central causes (cerebellar disease), apogeotropic posterior canal BPPV, or vestibular migraine. Correct differential diagnosis is essential.

 

 
 Can I get anterior canal BPPV after treatment for posterior canal BPPV?

 Yes, this is called canal conversion and can occur when crystals move to another canal during treatment.

Describe The Two Main Variants for Horizontal Canal BPPV.

The Two Main Variants

 

 
 Geotropic Variant (60-70%)

 The crystals float freely in the posterior part of the canal. When you turn your head to one side, the crystals move toward the ground. Dizziness is typically strongest when lying on the affected side. This is the most common and easiest variant to treat.

 

 
 Apogeotropic Variant (30-40%)

 The crystals are located either in the anterior part of the canal near the ampulla, or they are attached to the sensory cells (cupulolithiasis). Eye movements beat away from the ground. Confusingly, dizziness is often strongest on the unaffected side. Treatment is more challenging.

Describe symptoms and signs of Horizontal Canal BPPV.

Symptoms

 

 Horizontal canal BPPV differs from the posterior canal variant in several ways:

 
 Sideways dizziness: The feeling that the room is rolling sideways, often described as being "in a tumble dryer"

 Longer duration: Episodes may last longer than posterior canal BPPV - often over 60 seconds

 More severe nausea: Autonomic symptoms are often more pronounced

 Triggered from both sides: Can be triggered when turning to either side in bed

 Shorter or no latency: Dizziness may start immediately with head movement
You are a clinical documentation assistant for chiropractors. Generate professional medical documentation.
How is Horizontal Canal BPPV diagnosed?

Diagnosis

 

 Supine Roll Test (The Gold Standard)

 The patient lies on their back with the head elevated 30 degrees. The head is quickly turned 90 degrees to one side and held for 30-60 seconds while eye movements are observed. The test is then repeated to the opposite side. The test's sensitivity is reported at 89.5% (Barany Society Guidelines).

 
 With Geotropic Variant

 Eyes beat toward the ground on both sides, but strongest on the affected side.

 

 
 With Apogeotropic Variant

 Eyes beat away from the ground, and the weakest response is on the affected side.

 

 
 Important Sequence

 The supine roll test should ideally be performed before the Dix-Hallpike test, as Dix-Hallpike can move crystals and affect the results.

 

 
 Red Flags - Contact a Doctor Immediately for:

 
 Dizziness lasting continuously over 2 minutes (BPPV causes brief episodes)

 Sudden hearing loss or severe tinnitus

 Double vision or other visual disturbances

 Severe headache unlike any previously experienced

 Facial paralysis, numbness, or speech difficulties

 Coordination problems or unsteady gait

Describe treatment options for Horizontal Canal BPPV.

Treatment

 

 What Can the Chiropractor Do?

 Treatment of horizontal canal BPPV requires specialized repositioning maneuvers:

 
 BBQ-Roll (Lempert Maneuver)

 The patient is rotated 360 degrees in four steps of 90 degrees each, with head elevated 30 degrees. Each position is held for 30-60 seconds. A systematic review from 2025 concluded that BBQ-roll is an effective treatment. Studies show 74% improvement after one treatment and 85% within three treatments.

 

 
 Gufoni Maneuver

 A systematic review from 2024 with 10 studies and 1,025 patients showed that the Gufoni maneuver is effective. For geotropic variant, success rate is 71-92%, while apogeotropic variant has lower response at 63-78%. The advantage is that it is easier to perform on elderly patients.

 

 
 TRV Chair

 For complex cases, a TRV chair (a specialized treatment chair) can be used. This method provides precision control over speed, angle, and amplitude.

 

 Treatment Course - Realistic Expectations

 
 Best case (approx. 40-50%): Symptom-free after 1-2 treatments. 75% are symptom-free after the first consultation

 Typical case (approx. 30-40%): Requires 3-5 treatments over 2-3 weeks

 Complicated cases (approx. 15-20%): Bilateral involvement or apogeotropic variant may require 6+ treatments

How is Posterior Canal BPPV: When the World Spins Backwards diagnosed?

Diagnosis

 

 Dix-Hallpike Test (The Gold Standard)

 The patient sits on the examination bench with the head turned 45 degrees to one side. The patient is quickly laid backward so that the head hangs over the edge of the bench. The examiner observes the eyes for nystagmus (involuntary eye movements).

 A positive test shows characteristic upbeat and rotational nystagmus that begins after a few seconds, reaches a peak, and then subsides within one minute.

 
 Precise Diagnostics at the Chiropractor

 At Chiropractor Mads Finstad, VNG glasses (videonystagmography) and TRV chair are used for precise diagnostics. VNG glasses provide a magnified image of eye movements and remove the patient's ability to fixate their gaze, making nystagmus more visible.

 

 
 Red Flags - Seek Emergency Care or Call 113 for:

 
 Acute dizziness with muscle weakness or numbness in arm/leg

 Speech or swallowing difficulties

 Double vision or visual disturbances

 Severe headache, especially "the worst headache of your life"

 Constant dizziness not triggered by head movements

 Loss of consciousness

 What Can the Chiropractor Do?

 Posterior canal BPPV is treated with repositioning maneuvers that move the loose crystals out of the semicircular canal and back to the utricle. The most commonly used and best documented method is the Epley maneuver.

 
 Effect and Evidence

 
 75-95% of patients become symptom-free after one or more treatments (Cochrane Review, 2014)

 32-90% experience improvement after the first treatment

 Success rate increases to nearly 100% after 3-4 treatments

 The Epley maneuver is significantly more effective than placebo

 
 

 What Can You Do Yourself?

 After treatment:

 
 Avoid lying flat for the first few hours after treatment

 Consider sleeping with your head slightly elevated the first night

 Avoid sudden head movements for the first few days

 

 Treatment Course

 1-3 treatments are usually sufficient. Many become symptom-free after one treatment. Follow-up 1-4 weeks after treatment is recommended.

Describe Frequently Asked Questions for Posterior Canal BPPV: When the World Spins Backwards.

Frequently Asked Questions

 

 
 What is the difference between posterior canal BPPV and horizontal canal BPPV?

 Posterior canal BPPV is the most common form (60-90%) and is typically triggered by lying down or rolling over in bed. Horizontal canal BPPV accounts for 5-30% and is often triggered by turning the head from side to side while lying down. Treatment is different.

 

 
 How long does an episode last?

 A typical episode lasts 10-60 seconds. If the dizziness lasts for minutes, hours, or days, other causes should be considered.

 

 
 Can BPPV be dangerous?

 BPPV is a benign condition that is not dangerous in itself. However, the intense dizziness can lead to falls, especially in the elderly.

 

 
 Can vitamin D prevent BPPV?

 Research shows that vitamin D supplementation combined with calcium can reduce the recurrence rate in patients with proven vitamin D deficiency (Jeong et al., 2020).

Describe How Does the Condition Develop? for BPPV (Crystal Disease).

How Does the Condition Develop?

 

 Inside the inner ear lies the balance organ with three semicircular canals that register head movements. Additionally, there are the utricle and saccule which contain small calcium carbonate crystals (otoliths). These crystals normally sit attached to a gel membrane and help register gravity and linear acceleration.

 BPPV occurs when some of these crystals loosen and float into one of the semicircular canals. When you move your head, the loose crystals move the fluid in the canal in an unexpected way. This sends error signals to the brain that the head is spinning - even though it is not. The result is intense, brief dizziness.

 symptom-free after 1 treatment
 

 
 2.4%
 lifetime prevalence

Causes and Risk Factors

 

 From most common to rarest:

 
 Idiopathic/Unknown Cause (50-70%)

 Most cases occur without an identifiable triggering factor.

 

 
 Age

 The incidence increases with age. People over 60 have almost seven times higher risk.

 Trauma to the head can physically dislodge crystals from their attachment - see also whiplash and dizziness.

 

 
 Previous Ear Infection/Vestibular Neuritis (10-15%)

 Viral infection in the inner ear can trigger BPPV.

 

 
 Meniere's Disease (0.5-31%)

 Patients with Meniere's have higher incidence of BPPV.

 

 
 Vitamin D Deficiency

 Studies show a connection between low vitamin D levels and increased risk.

Describe symptoms and signs of BPPV (Crystal Disease).

Symptoms

 

 The most characteristic symptom is short episodes of intense spinning dizziness (vertigo) lasting from seconds to a maximum of one minute. The dizziness is typically triggered by:

 
 Turning over in bed

 Getting up from lying position

 Looking up at the ceiling or high shelves

 Bending forward

 

 The episode usually comes after a few seconds delay (latency) from when you move your head. It is most intense at the beginning and gradually subsides. Between episodes, many feel completely normal.

 
 Symptoms That Do NOT Belong to BPPV

 
 Hearing loss or tinnitus

 Persistent dizziness that never stops - may indicate PPPD or vestibular hypofunction

 Headache, speech problems or vision disturbances

Describe Which Semicircular Canal Is Affected? for BPPV (Crystal Disease).

Which Semicircular Canal Is Affected?

 

 The inner ear has three semicircular canals on each side:

 
 Posterior Canal (80-90% of cases)

 By far the most common form. Diagnosed with the Dix-Hallpike test and treated with the Epley or Semont maneuver.

 

 
 Horizontal/Lateral Canal (5-30%, possibly up to 46%)

 May be underdiagnosed. Treated with Barbecue roll (Lempert) or Gufoni maneuver.

 

 
 Anterior Canal (1-3%)

 The rarest form. Crystals rarely fall upward due to anatomical position.

How is BPPV (Crystal Disease) diagnosed?

Diagnosis

 

 The diagnosis is primarily made through medical history and clinical examination. The most important tests are:

 
 Dix-Hallpike Test

 The patient sits on the bench with head turned 45 degrees toward the suspected side, then is quickly laid back until the head hangs 20 degrees below the horizontal plane. With posterior canal BPPV, upbeating, rotational nystagmus is seen after a few seconds delay.

 

 
 Supine Roll Test

 The patient lies flat on their back and the head is quickly rolled from side to side. Tests for horizontal canal BPPV.

 

 Do I Need MRI or CT?

 In the vast majority of cases, clinical examination is sufficient. Imaging is only relevant if symptoms do not match BPPV, you have red flags (headache, neurological symptoms), or treatment fails repeatedly without explanation.

Describe treatment options for BPPV (Crystal Disease).

Treatment

 

 What Can the Chiropractor Do?

 Treatment consists of specific repositioning maneuvers that move the loose crystals out of the semicircular canal and back to the utricle where they belong.

 
 Epley Maneuver

 The most used and studied treatment for posterior canal BPPV. A meta-analysis showed symptom relief in 74-75% of patients after one treatment - over six times better than the control group. With repeated treatments, over 90% achieve improvement.

 

 Other Maneuvers

 
 Semont Maneuver: Alternative to Epley, especially useful for cupulolithiasis

 Gufoni Maneuver and Barbecue Roll: Used for horizontal canal BPPV

 

 What Can You Do Yourself?

 Once the diagnosis is confirmed and you have learned the correct technique, you can perform repositioning maneuvers at home during new episodes. Other measures that can help include vitamin D supplements if blood tests show deficiency, avoiding rapid head movements in the acute phase, and continuing normal activities as soon as possible.

 Treatment Course

 Most patients need 1-3 treatments. Median duration of symptoms is 2 weeks. Early treatment often leads to faster improvement.

What is the prognosis for BPPV (Crystal Disease)?

Prognosis

 

 BPPV is a benign condition with very good prognosis. Repositioning maneuvers provide immediate improvement for most.

 Residual Dizziness After Treatment

 31-61% of patients report persistent mild dizziness or unsteadiness after successful treatment, even though nystagmus and positional vertigo are gone. This residual dizziness usually lasts a median of 10 days and typically resolves within 3 months. In some cases, this can develop into PPPD (Persistent Postural-Perceptual Dizziness).

 Recurrence Is Common

 
 Approximately 15-23% experience recurrence within the first year

 5-year recurrence rate is around 40%

 Up to 50% may experience a new episode within 5 years

 

 Prevention of Recurrence

 Vitamin D supplementation in patients with documented deficiency can reduce the risk of new episodes. A meta-analysis showed significant reduction in recurrence rate (relative risk 0.37).

Describe Frequently Asked Questions for BPPV (Crystal Disease).

Frequently Asked Questions

 

 
 How quickly can I expect improvement?

 Most notice immediate improvement after the first treatment. Some experience complete relief on the treatment table. Others need 2-3 treatments.

 

 
 Can BPPV come back?

 Yes. Approximately 15-23% experience recurrence within one year, and up to 40-50% within 5 years. The risk increases with age, vitamin D deficiency and previous episodes.

 

 
 Do medications help?

 No. BPPV is a mechanical problem that requires a mechanical solution. Vestibular suppressant medications can be used briefly for nausea, but they do not cure the condition.

 

 
 Is it dangerous to do the maneuvers?

 No, repositioning maneuvers are very safe. Temporary dizziness during the maneuver itself is normal. Caution should be exercised with severe neck stiffness or recent neck trauma.

 

 
 Can I fly with BPPV?

 Yes, BPPV is not dangerous and flying does not worsen the condition. You may experience discomfort with rapid head movements.

How Does It Differ from Other Types of Dizziness?

 

 Cervicogenic dizziness typically feels like:

 
 A swaying or floating sensation ("like walking on a boat")

 Spatial disorientation - difficulty orienting yourself

 Unsteadiness that worsens with neck movements or prolonged sitting

 Symptom duration from minutes to hours (not seconds like with BPPV)

 

 The classic spinning dizziness - the room spinning around - is less typical of cervicogenic dizziness and often points to other causes such as BPPV (crystal disease) or vestibular migraine.

What causes Cervicogenic Dizziness (Neck-Related Dizziness)?

Causes and Risk Factors

 

 From most common to rarest:

 
 Myofascial Dysfunction and Trigger Points (most common)

 58.5% had myofascial pain syndrome, and 59.7% of these had dizziness. Tight muscles - especially in the suboccipital muscles, upper trapezius and sternocleidomastoid - can disturb proprioceptive signaling.

 

 
 Joint Stiffness in the Upper Neck

 The upper cervical joints (C0-C1-C2) contain a very high density of proprioceptive sensors. When these joints become stiff, inaccurate signals are sent to the brain.

 

 
 Whiplash and Neck Injuries

 Dizziness is reported in 20-58% of patients with whiplash-associated injury.

 

 
 Prolonged Poor Head Posture

 "Tech neck" - constantly leaning head forward in front of screens.

 

 Risk Factors

 
 Gender: Women have 1.64 times higher risk

 Occupation: Office work with lots of screen time

 Stress: Increases muscle tension in neck and shoulders

 Previous neck injury: Whiplash, falls, sports injuries - including concussion

Describe symptoms and signs of Cervicogenic Dizziness (Neck-Related Dizziness).

Symptoms

 

 Typical Presentation:

 
 Diffuse unsteadiness or swaying feeling lasting minutes to hours

 Feeling that the head is "heavy" or "clumsy"

 Worsening with prolonged sitting, especially in front of a computer screen

 Neck pain or stiffness occurring together with the dizziness

 Headache starting in the neck and radiating forward

 Mild nausea (rarely severe vomiting)

 

 What Does NOT Fit with Cervicogenic Dizziness:

 
 Short, intense spinning attacks (10-60 sec): Suggests BPPV

 Hearing loss or tinnitus: Points to vestibular pathology like Meniere's disease or vestibular neuritis

 Severe attacks with light/sound sensitivity: Vestibular migraine

 Neurological symptoms: Double vision, speech difficulties - requires immediate evaluation

How is Cervicogenic Dizziness (Neck-Related Dizziness) diagnosed?

Diagnosis

 

 Cervicogenic dizziness is a diagnosis of exclusion - other causes such as BPPV, vestibular hypofunction and PPPD must be ruled out first. There is no gold standard test, but the combination of medical history, clinical examination and specific tests provides good diagnostic accuracy.

 Clinical Tests

 
 Cervical Torsion Test

 The body is rotated while the head is held still. Specificity 92%, sensitivity 72%.

 

 
 Cervical Repositioning Test

 The patient should return the head to neutral position with closed eyes. Deviation over 4.5 degrees suggests disturbed proprioception.

 

 
 Flexion-Rotation Test

 Sensitivity 91%, specificity 90% for C1-C2 dysfunction.

 

 
 Red Flags - Seek immediate medical help for:

 
 Double vision (diplopia)

 Slurred speech (dysarthria)

 Swallowing difficulties (dysphagia)

 Sudden falls without warning

 Severe nausea with vomiting

 Numbness in face, arms or legs

 Weakness in arms or legs

 Severe headache of new type

Describe treatment options for Cervicogenic Dizziness (Neck-Related Dizziness).

Treatment

 

 What Can the Chiropractor Do?

 A systematic review from 2022 (De Vestel et al.) concluded that there is moderate evidence that manual therapy reduces dizziness symptoms, and that the effect is enhanced when manual therapy is combined with exercises.

 
 Manual Therapy

 Reid et al. (2014, 2015) conducted several randomized controlled trials showing that both Mulligan SNAGs and Maitland mobilizations gave significant improvement compared to placebo - effects that persisted at 12-month follow-up.

 

 Exercise Program

 
 Deep neck flexors: Strengthening the deep stabilizing muscles

 Eye-neck coordination: Recalibrating the cooperation between vision and neck

 Balance training: Progressive challenge of the balance system

 

 What Can You Do Yourself?

 
 Chin Tuck Exercise

 Pull the chin straight back. Hold 5 seconds, repeat 10 times.

 

 
 Ergonomic Adjustments

 Screen at eye level, breaks every 30 minutes.

 

 
 Stress Management

 Breathing techniques, good sleep hygiene.

 

 Treatment Course

 
 Acute cases: Noticeable improvement within 2-4 treatments

 Typical course: 4-8 treatments over 4-6 weeks

 Chronic cases: 8-12 weeks

 

 
 Treatment Response

 60-85% of patients respond well to combined manual therapy and exercises (Lystad et al., 2011).

Describe Frequently Asked Questions for Cervicogenic Dizziness (Neck-Related Dizziness).

Frequently Asked Questions

 

 
 Can the neck really cause dizziness?

 Yes. The neck contains a high density of proprioceptive sensors. When these send inaccurate signals, a "sensory mismatch" can occur that is experienced as dizziness. The Barany Society (2022) acknowledges that this can probably occur in a subset of patients.

 

 
 How do I distinguish cervicogenic dizziness from BPPV?

 BPPV causes short (10-60 sec), intense spinning attacks. Cervicogenic dizziness causes a more persistent unsteadiness that worsens with neck movements and is often accompanied by neck pain.

 

 
 Do I need an MRI of my neck?

 Usually not. MRI is primarily relevant for red flags or lack of treatment response after 8-12 weeks. Degenerative findings are very common even in symptom-free people.

 

 
 How long until I get better?

 Most notice improvement within 4-6 weeks. Acute cases can respond faster (2-4 treatments), chronic cases may require 8-12 weeks.

Prolonged Poor Head Posture

 "Tech neck" - constantly leaning head forward in front of screens.

 

 Risk Factors

 
 Gender: Women have 1.64 times higher risk

 Diffuse unsteadiness or swaying feeling lasting minutes to hours

 Feeling that the head is "heavy" or "clumsy"

 Worsening with prolonged sitting, especially in front of a computer screen

 Neck pain or stiffness occurring together with the dizziness

 Cervicogenic dizziness is a diagnosis of exclusion - other causes such as BPPV, vestibular hypofunction and PPPD must be ruled out first. There is no gold standard test, but the combination of medical history, clinical examination and specific tests provides good diagnostic accuracy.

 Clinical Tests

 
 Cervical Torsion Test

 The body is rotated while the head is held still. Specificity 92%, sensitivity 72%.

What causes Mal de Debarquement Syndrome (MdDS)?

Causes and Risk Factors

 

 Triggering Factors - From Most Common to Rarest

 
 Motion-Triggered MdDS (Most Common)

 
 Cruise or boat travel - by far the most common trigger

 Air travel

 Long car journey or train ride

 Elevator ride or walking on a pier

 
 

 Temporary "mal de debarquement" after sea travel occurs in 73-86% of people, even among experienced sailors. Longer trips and rough seas can increase the risk, but the duration of exposure does not seem to determine severity.

 
 Spontaneous/Non-Motion-Triggered MdDS (Rarer)

 
 Hormonal changes - studies show that ~44% had symptom onset during perimenopause or menopause

 Psychological stress or major life events

 Surgical procedures

 Head injury

 Without identifiable cause

 
 

 Who Is Affected?

 MdDS has a clear demographic profile:

 
 Women make up 80-90% of cases

 Average onset age: 43-50 years

 Sex ratio: Women:men approximately 9:1

 Migraine: People with migraine have increased risk of developing MdDS. These patients may also experience vestibular migraine

Describe symptoms and signs of Mal de Debarquement Syndrome (MdDS).

Symptoms

 

 Main Symptoms

 The characteristic symptom is a persistent oscillating dizziness - a sensation of:

 
 Rocking

 Swaying motion

 Bobbing (up-down movement)

 
 Symptoms are present continuously or most of the day. They are not accompanied by the spinning sensation (vertigo) seen in BPPV (crystal disease).

 Associated Symptoms

 Many with MdDS develop additional symptoms:

 
 Spatial disorientation

 Fatigue

 Intolerance to visual motion (busy environments, escalators)

 Headache - often migraine-like

 Anxiety and depression

 Cognitive difficulties ("brain fog")

 Concentration problems

 Sleep difficulties

 Neck and back pain

 

 
 The Paradox: Better in Motion

 An important characteristic of MdDS is that symptoms often improve when in passive motion - such as driving a car or sitting on a train. But symptoms return - and may temporarily worsen - when the motion stops.

 This distinguishes MdDS from PPPD (Persistent Postural-Perceptual Dizziness), where symptoms typically worsen with motion.

How is Mal de Debarquement Syndrome (MdDS) diagnosed?

Diagnosis

 

 Clinical Diagnosis

 MdDS is diagnosed based on medical history and symptom profile. There is no blood test, MRI or other test that can confirm the diagnosis. In 2020, the Barany Society published international diagnostic criteria:

 All five criteria must be met:

 
 Non-spinning dizziness with oscillating sensation (rocking, swaying, bobbing) - present continuously or most of the day

 Symptom onset within 48 hours after ending passive motion

 Symptoms improve temporarily with new exposure to passive motion (e.g., car driving)

 Symptoms last >48 hours

 Symptoms are not better explained by another disease or condition

 

 Classification by Duration

 
 MdDS "in evolution": Symptoms less than 1 month, still under observation

 Transient MdDS: Symptoms resolve within 1 month

 Persistent MdDS: Symptoms last more than 1 month

 

 
 Red Flags - When to See a Doctor Quickly

 
 Hearing loss in one or both ears

 Double vision or vision disturbances

 Numbness or tingling in face/arms/legs

 Muscle weakness in arms or legs

 Speech or swallowing difficulties

 Sudden, severe headache ("worst headache of my life")

 Fever combined with dizziness

 Consciousness disturbances

Describe treatment options for Mal de Debarquement Syndrome (MdDS).

Treatment

 

 Important to Know

 MdDS is a challenging condition to treat. Research is limited, and there is no standard treatment that helps everyone. A scoping review from 2023 identified improvement with several treatment methods, but emphasized that evidence is still limited.

 
 Specialized Treatment - VOR Readaptation (Dai Protocol)

 The most promising treatment is optokinetic VOR readaptation, developed by Dr. Mingjia Dai at Mount Sinai Hospital. The treatment involves visual stimulation with moving stripes in the visual field, while passively rolling the head from side to side, over repeated sessions.

 Results:

 
 ~70% achieved significant improvement immediately after treatment

 After 1 year, 52% of motion-triggered cases were still significantly improved

 Patients treated within 1 year of symptom onset had better prognosis (62%) than those with symptom duration over 3 years (30%)

 
 

 What Can the Chiropractor Do?

 Honest expectation management: Research shows that chiropractic and physiotherapeutic treatment has no documented effect on the MdDS symptoms themselves.

 However, the chiropractor can contribute with:

 
 Thorough assessment - Many with dizziness have other causes that can be treated

 Rule out mechanical causes - Neck problems can cause dizziness, but this is a different condition than MdDS

 Refer to the right specialist - ENT doctor or neurologist for further assessment

 Transient Cases

 Most people who experience "mal de debarquement" after a boat trip become symptom-free within 24-48 hours. Even without treatment, most improve within one year.

Describe Frequently Asked Questions for Mal de Debarquement Syndrome (MdDS).

Frequently Asked Questions

 

 
 Can MdDS become chronic?

 Yes, for some the symptoms persist for many years. Studies show that the longer symptoms have lasted, the more difficult they can be to treat. Early treatment (within 1 year) gives better results.

 

 
 Is MdDS the same as motion sickness?

 No. Motion sickness occurs during movement, while MdDS occurs after the movement has stopped. With MdDS, one often feels better in motion - the opposite of motion sickness.

 

 
 Can a chiropractor help with MdDS?

 Chiropractic treatment has no documented effect on the MdDS symptoms themselves. But a chiropractor can help rule out other causes of dizziness, treat associated neck/back pain, and refer to the right specialist.

 

 
 Is MdDS a psychiatric condition?

 No. MdDS is a neurological condition that probably involves maladaptation in the brain's balance centers. Anxiety and depression can follow prolonged illness, but are not the cause of MdDS. Another functional dizziness disorder is vestibular hypofunction, which is due to actual damage to the balance organ.

Describe How Common is Meniere's Disease? for Meniere's Disease.

How Common is Meniere's Disease?

 

 Meniere's disease is relatively rare. Prevalence varies between studies, but estimates are 50-200 per 100,000 adults. The disease most often affects people between 40 and 60 years old, with a peak in the 40s and 50s. Women are somewhat more commonly affected than men, with a ratio of approximately 1.5-1.9:1. Less than 3% of cases occur in people under 18 years old.

Describe What Happens in the Ear? for Meniere's Disease.

What Happens in the Ear?

 

 The underlying mechanism is believed to be endolymphatic hydrops - an accumulation of fluid (endolymph) in the inner ear. The inner ear consists of a labyrinth system filled with fluid that must have the right pressure and chemical composition to function normally.

 In Meniere's disease, too much fluid is produced, or drainage does not work properly. This causes the pressure to rise. At high pressure, a thin membrane (Reissner's membrane) can rupture, and fluids with different chemical compositions mix. This disrupts the signals to the brain and triggers the characteristic attack.

 
 Genetic Component

 Approximately 7-10% of patients with Meniere's disease have a family history of the condition.

Describe symptoms and signs of Meniere's Disease.

Symptoms

 

 The Classic Symptoms:

 
 1. Vertigo (Rotational Dizziness)

 
 Sudden, intense attacks where the world "spins"

 Duration typically 20 minutes to 12 hours

 Often accompanied by nausea and vomiting

 
 

 
 2. Hearing Loss

 
 Fluctuating, sensorineural hearing loss

 Typically affects low frequencies first ("bass loss")

 May be temporary initially but often becomes permanent over time

 
 

 
 3. Tinnitus (Ear Ringing)

 
 Usually low-frequency, "humming" or "buzzing" sound

 May become stronger before and during attacks

 Often becomes constant over time

 
 

 Additionally, many experience a feeling of pressure or "fullness" in the affected ear, aura before attacks (changed tinnitus, increasing pressure), and extreme exhaustion after attacks.

 Phases of the Disease

 
 Early phase: Intense vertigo attacks. Hearing often normalizes between attacks

 Middle phase: Attacks continue. Hearing loss becomes more permanent. Tinnitus often becomes constant

 Late phase ("burn-out"): The violent dizziness attacks decrease or disappear. About 34% experience spontaneous remission from episodic vertigo
You are a clinical documentation assistant for chiropractors. Generate professional medical documentation.
How is Meniere's Disease diagnosed?

Diagnosis

 

 There is no single test that can confirm Meniere's disease. The diagnosis is made clinically based on international criteria (Barany Society/AAO-HNS, 2015/2020). It is important to distinguish Meniere's from other conditions such as vestibular migraine, vestibular neuritis and BPPV (crystal disease).

 Criteria for Definite Meniere's Disease:

 
 At least two spontaneous vertigo episodes lasting 20 minutes to 12 hours

 Audiometrically documented low- to mid-frequency sensorineural hearing loss in the affected ear

 Fluctuating symptoms (hearing loss, tinnitus or pressure sensation) in the affected ear

 Other causes excluded

 

 
 Red Flags - Seek medical help immediately for:

 
 Sudden, total hearing loss

 Dizziness with double vision, swallowing or speech difficulties

 Fainting or loss of consciousness

 Severe headache with dizziness

 High fever with dizziness and ear symptoms

 Frequent falls without warning (drop attacks)

Describe treatment options for Meniere's Disease.

Treatment

 

 There is no cure for Meniere's disease. The goal of treatment is to reduce attack frequency, relieve symptoms and improve quality of life.

 Conservative Treatment and Lifestyle

 
 Salt Reduction

 A stable, low salt intake (<1500-2000 mg sodium daily) is often recommended as first-line treatment. The theory is that this can stabilize the fluid balance in the inner ear. The Cochrane review from 2018 found no randomized studies supporting this, but many patients report improvement.

 

 Medical Treatment

 
 Betahistine (Betaserc)

 The most commonly used medication in Europe. The BEMED study (2016) found no significant difference between betahistine and placebo, but the medication is well tolerated and is often tried for 3-6 months.

 

 Vestibular Rehabilitation

 AAO-HNS recommends vestibular rehabilitation for patients with chronic unsteadiness between attacks. A meta-analysis from 2023 found moderate effect on quality of life.

 
 Important About Vestibular Rehabilitation

 Vestibular rehabilitation is not recommended during acute attacks - it is well-documented when vertigo episodes are under control.

Describe What is Post-Concussion Syndrome? for Persistent Symptoms After Concussion.

What is Post-Concussion Syndrome?

 

 Post-Concussion Syndrome (PCS) occurs when symptoms after a concussion persist longer than expected. In medical terminology, the condition is defined as symptoms lasting more than 3 months after a mild traumatic brain injury. PCS is one of several causes of persistent dizziness and can resemble other vestibular conditions.

 The important thing to understand: A concussion is a functional injury, not a structural injury. Therefore, nothing is visible on regular CT or MRI. Think of it as an energy crisis in the brain - the nerve cells are stretched during impact, which triggers a massive release of chemicals and disrupts the brain's normal energy production.

Symptoms

 

 Physical Symptoms (Most Common)

 Dizziness that worsens with head movements

 Difficulty focusing vision during movement

 Balance difficulties especially on uneven surfaces or in darkness

 Increased sensitivity to visual stimulation like escalators or busy environments

Who is Most at Risk?

 

 High Risk (Strong Evidence)

 
 Female Gender

 Women have 2-3 times higher risk of PCS than men. Adult women have an odds ratio of 2.57 for elevated symptom burden.

 

 
 Previous Concussions

 Multiple previous head injuries significantly increase risk. Median number of concussions in PCS patients is 3.3, but 23% develop PCS after just one concussion.

 

 
 Neck Problems at Time of Injury

 Neck pain at initial evaluation is strongly associated with delayed recovery.

 

 
 Dizziness at Time of Injury

 Gives 6.3 times higher odds of prolonged recovery.

Describe Types of Dizziness After Concussion for Persistent Symptoms After Concussion.

Types of Dizziness After Concussion

 

 
 Crystal Dizziness (BPPV) - 10-57%

 Here, small calcium crystals have loosened from their normal position in the balance organ and ended up in the semicircular canals. Post-traumatic BPPV often behaves differently than regular BPPV - it more often affects multiple canals simultaneously and can be more resistant to treatment.

 

 
 Vestibulo-ocular Dysfunction - Over 50%

 Problems with the reflex that keeps your gaze stable when the head moves. Symptoms are often blurred vision during head movements, difficulty reading, and dizziness in visually demanding environments.

 

 
 Neck-Related Dizziness - 20-58%

 Occurs in people with whiplash and often appears together with vestibular complaints. The neck contains many sensitive receptors that give the brain information about head position.

Treatment

 

 The latest international consensus (Amsterdam 2022) has turned previous treatment advice upside down. Complete rest is outdated and can actually prolong symptoms.

 Graded Activity and Early Exercise

Frequently Asked Questions

 

 
 How long does dizziness last after concussion?

 For most, dizziness resolves within days to a few weeks. With vestibular rehabilitation, most are significantly better within 4-8 weeks. Around 10-15% develop persistent problems beyond 3 months, and some may develop PPPD (chronic dizziness).

 

 
 Can a chiropractor treat symptoms after concussion?

 Yes, chiropractors with expertise in vestibular rehabilitation can provide effective treatment. The combination of vestibular rehabilitation and neck treatment has strong research support.

 

 
 Should I avoid activity if I'm dizzy after concussion?

 No, prolonged inactivity can actually delay recovery. After 24-48 hours of relative rest, you should gradually resume activity adapted to your symptoms.

 

 
 Do I need an MRI or CT?

 In typical concussion and PCS, imaging shows normal findings - the injury is functional, not structural. MRI/CT is indicated for red flag symptoms to rule out bleeding or structural damage.

Describe What is POTS? for POTS and Orthostatic Dizziness.

What is POTS?

 

 POTS belongs to the group of dysautonomias - conditions where the autonomic nervous system does not function as it should. The autonomic nervous system controls functions you normally do not think about: pulse, blood pressure, sweating, digestion and temperature regulation.

 When you stand up, gravity pulls 500-800 ml of blood down toward the legs and abdomen. Normally, sensors in the carotid artery detect this and send signals to the brain to increase the pulse slightly and tighten the blood vessels in the legs. In POTS, this mechanism does not work as it should.

 Increased Prevalence After COVID-19

 After the COVID-19 pandemic, the prevalence has increased significantly. A study showed that the incidence rate increased from 1.42 to 20.3 per million persons.

What causes POTS and Orthostatic Dizziness?

Causes and Triggering Factors

 

 POTS has no single cause, but is often triggered by an "immunological stressor." The most common triggering factors are:

 
 Viral Infection (most common)

 About 50% of POTS cases start after a viral infection - especially mononucleosis (glandular fever), influenza and COVID-19. Among patients with long COVID, 2-14% report POTS symptoms.

 

 
 Physical Trauma

 Whiplash injuries, concussion and other trauma to head and neck are known triggers. There is a documented connection between neck injuries and POTS development.

 

 
 Associated Conditions

 POTS often occurs together with other conditions: Hypermobile Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (25% of POTS patients), mast cell activation syndrome (MCAS), migraine (40%), irritable bowel (30%), and ME/CFS (21%).

How is POTS and Orthostatic Dizziness diagnosed?

Diagnosis

 

 Diagnostic Criteria (Heart Rhythm Society 2015)

 To receive a POTS diagnosis, you must meet:

 
 Pulse increase of >=30 beats/min (>=40 for ages 12-19) within 10 minutes of standing

 Or pulse over 120 beats/min when standing

 Absence of orthostatic hypotension (blood pressure drop >=20 mmHg)

 Symptoms have lasted more than 3 months

 No other condition that explains the symptoms

 

 
 Active Standing Test (can be done in clinic)

 A simple test: You lie flat for 5-10 minutes, pulse and blood pressure are measured, you stand up and stay still, and measurements are taken at 1, 3, 5 and 10 minutes. Pulse increase >=30 without blood pressure drop suggests POTS.

 

 
 Red Flags - Seek medical help immediately for:

 
 Chest pain or pressure in the chest

 Severe shortness of breath

 Repeated fainting

 Irregular heartbeat

 Symptoms that worsen rapidly

 Neurological symptoms (vision loss, speech difficulties, one-sided weakness)

 
 POTS itself is not dangerous, but the symptoms can mimic other conditions that require acute treatment.

Describe treatment options for POTS and Orthostatic Dizziness.

Treatment

 

 There is no cure for POTS, but most people experience significant improvement with the right treatment. Non-pharmacological measures are first-line treatment.

 Non-Pharmacological Treatment

 
 Fluids and salt: Drink 2-3 liters of water daily, start the day with 500 ml water BEFORE getting up. For POTS (without high blood pressure), increased salt intake is often recommended (6-10 grams daily). Always consult a doctor

 Compression: Class 2 compression stockings, best effect with stockings that go to the waist

 Diet: Eat small, frequent meals. Avoid large carbohydrate-rich meals

 

 
 The Levine Protocol: Exercise as Medicine

 Exercise is the well-documented treatment for POTS, but must be done correctly:

 
 Phase 1 (month 1-2): Horizontal exercise: rowing machine, recumbent bike, swimming

 Phase 2: Gradual introduction of upright exercise

 Phase 3: Maintenance with combined training

 
 

 
 Results from Research

 In Fu and Levine's study from 2011, 3 months of training showed that 53% of participants no longer met POTS criteria. Exercise was more effective than beta-blockers for reducing pulse and improving quality of life.

 

 What Can the Chiropractor Do?

 POTS is primarily a medical condition that requires evaluation by a doctor. But the chiropractor can play a role in several areas:

Describe What is PPPD? for Chronic Dizziness and PPPD.

What is PPPD?

 

 PPPD stands for Persistent Postural-Perceptual Dizziness. The condition was formally defined by the Barany Society in 2017 and is now included in the WHO's International Classification of Diseases (ICD-11 code AB32.0).

 PPPD is a functional disorder. This means the problem is not in the balance organ itself - the ear and nerves often function completely normally during testing. The problem lies in how the brain processes and responds to the signals it receives. This distinguishes PPPD from conditions like vestibular hypofunction, where there is measurable damage to the balance organ.

How is Chronic Dizziness and PPPD diagnosed?

The Five Diagnostic Criteria (Barany Society, 2017)

 

 
 1. Duration

 Dizziness, unsteadiness or non-rotational vertigo present most days for at least three months

 

 
 2. Aggravating Factors

 Symptoms worsen with upright posture, active or passive movement, and visually complex or moving stimuli

 

 
 3. Triggering Event

 The condition started after an acute vestibular disorder, other medical illness, or psychological stress

 

 
 4. Symptom Impact

 Symptoms cause significant distress or functional impairment

 

 
 5. No Better Explanation

 Symptoms cannot be better explained by another disease

Describe Why the Brain "Forgets" to Turn Off the Alarm for Chronic Dizziness and PPPD.

Why the Brain "Forgets" to Turn Off the Alarm

 

 Imagine a burglar alarm in your house. After an actual break-in (an acute dizziness episode), you adjust the sensitivity to maximum. Suddenly the alarm goes off every time the wind blows. This is how PPPD works.

 After an acute event - such as crystal disease, vestibular neuritis, concussion or a period of intense stress - the brain enters "crisis mode." In PPPD, the brain forgets to turn off this crisis mode.

 Three Things Happen:

 
 Visual Dependence

 The brain no longer trusts the balance system in the ear, so it clings to vision. That's why you become dizzy in the supermarket or when scrolling on your phone. This is also common in vestibular migraine.

 

 
 Body Stiffness

 You unconsciously tense muscles in your neck and legs to "hold on." This causes secondary neck pain and a stiff gait, similar to what is seen in cervicogenic dizziness.

 

 
 Anxiety Loop

 Every time you feel unsteady, the brain thinks "Danger!" and turns up the alarm even more.

 

 
 What Happens in the Brain with PPPD?

 Neuroimaging studies have shown that this is not "imagination" - there are measurable changes in brain function. Reduced activity in the parieto-insular vestibular cortex (PIVC), and increased activity in visual areas. The good news is that the brain is plastic - with proper treatment, these patterns can be reversed.

Describe symptoms and signs of Chronic Dizziness and PPPD.

Symptoms and Characteristics

 

 Main Symptoms:

 
 Non-rotational dizziness: It doesn't spin, but it rocks, sways or feels like being on a boat

 Brain fog: Concentration difficulties, mental fatigue - reported by about 81%

 Exhaustion: Extreme tiredness, worst in the afternoon - reported by about 85%

 Visual hypersensitivity: Worsening in busy environments (shopping centers, supermarkets)

 Movement intolerance: Symptoms worsen with both active and passive movements (car, bus)

 

 Mental Health and PPPD

 60% of PPPD patients have clinically significant anxiety and 45% have depression, but 25% have no psychiatric condition at all. This underscores that PPPD is a neurological condition - not "just anxiety." Similar mental health challenges are also seen in other chronic dizziness conditions like Meniere's disease and MdDS.

 
 Red Flags - Call 113 or go to emergency room for:

 
 Acute dizziness with headache - especially "the worst headache ever"

 Double vision, visual disturbances or visual field loss

 Speech difficulties or swallowing problems

 Numbness, weakness or paralysis in face, arm or leg

 Sudden one-sided hearing loss

 Dizziness with chest pain or palpitations

Describe treatment options for Chronic Dizziness and PPPD.

Treatment

 

 Treatment rests on three pillars. Recent research shows that the combination gives the good results.

 
 1. Vestibular Rehabilitation (VRT) - The Cornerstone

 A recent meta-analysis from 2025 (Li et al., Frontiers in Neurology) showed significant improvement: DHI-total improved by 21.84 points.

 
 Gaze stabilization exercises: Teaches the brain to trust vestibular signals again

 Habituation exercises: Gradual, repeated exposure to movements that provoke symptoms

 Balance training: Challenges the balance system to reduce over-control

 Visual desensitization: Gradual exposure to visually "noisy" environments

 
 Timeline: Improvement often starts after 6-8 weeks. Maximum effect may require 3-6 months.

 

 
 2. Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT)

 Because fear-avoidance behavior is part of the mechanism that maintains PPPD, it is often valuable to work on thought patterns. A 2024 meta-analysis showed that CBT combined with other treatment gives significantly better results.

 

 
 3. Medication (SSRI/SNRI)

 Antidepressants of the SSRI or SNRI type are used for PPPD - not primarily for depression, but because they stabilize the nervous system. A 2025 study showed sustained improvement over 3 years.

Describe Exercises You Can Do at Home for Chronic Dizziness and PPPD.

Exercises You Can Do at Home

 

 
 Gaze Stabilization Exercises (VOR x1)

 
 Hold a finger or a letter at arm's length

 Focus on the target

 Move your head slowly from side to side while keeping your gaze on the target

 Start with 10 repetitions, 3 times daily

 Gradually increase speed over weeks

 
 

 
 Balance Exercises

 
 Level 1 - Romberg: Stand with feet together, arms at sides, hold for 30 seconds. Progression: Open eyes - Closed eyes - Soft surface

 Level 2 - Tandem stance: Stand with one foot in front of the other (heel-to-toe), hold for 30 seconds on each side

 Level 3 - Single leg stance: Stand on one leg, goal: 30 seconds on each side

 
 

 
 Important Principles

 
 Consistency is key: Daily practice gives better results than intense, sporadic training

 Mild symptom provocation is the goal: Exercises should cause mild-moderate dizziness that resolves within 15-20 minutes

 Document progress: Keep a diary of symptoms and exercises

Describe symptoms and signs of Superior Canal Dehiscence Syndrome (SCDS).

Why Does the Hole Cause Symptoms?

 

 The inner ear normally has two "windows" - the oval window where sound enters, and the round window that provides pressure equalization. When a hole develops in the semicircular canal, an abnormal "third window" is created that changes how sound and pressure affect the balance organ.

 This third window causes:

 
 Air-conducted sound is diverted away from the cochlea, causing hearing loss in low frequencies

 Bone-conducted sound gets enhanced access to the inner ear fluid, explaining hypersensitivity to internal body sounds

 Sound and pressure changes create abnormal fluid movement that stimulates balance cells

Who Is Affected?

 

 SCDS typically debuts at 40-60 years of age (average 50 years) and affects women slightly more often than men with a ratio of approximately 1.2:1. Anatomical dehiscence is bilateral (both sides) in up to 50% of patients, but usually one ear is more symptomatic than the other.

 In approximately half of patients who undergo surgery, a triggering trauma or pressure-increasing event is reported before symptoms started - with an average of 5.6 years between the event and symptom onset.

Describe symptoms and signs of Superior Canal Dehiscence Syndrome (SCDS).

Symptoms

 

 Vestibular Symptoms (Balance Disturbances)

 
 Sound-Induced Dizziness (Tullio Phenomenon)

 Occurs in 42-43% of patients. Loud sounds (typically 500 Hz-2 kHz at 100-110 dB) trigger spinning dizziness or unsteadiness. Examples include loud music, barking dogs, or construction noise.

 

 
 Pressure-Induced Dizziness (Hennebert Sign)

 Affects 37% and is triggered by Valsalva maneuver (straining), coughing, sneezing, heavy lifting or nose blowing.

 

 Chronic unsteadiness and balance problems affect many, and up to 50% report mental fatigue and brain fog.

 Auditory Symptoms (Hearing Disturbances)

 
 Autophony

 The most characteristic symptom, affecting 42-60% of patients. Patients describe their own voice as sounding distorted or "metallic," and many hear their own body sounds abnormally loud - such as eye movements, footsteps, heartbeat and even bowel sounds. This is almost diagnostic for SCDS when present.

 

 
 Pulsatile Tinnitus: Occurs in 20-50% and is experienced as a "whooshing" sound synchronous with pulse

 Hearing Loss in Low Frequencies: Affects approximately 40%, typically in the 250-1000 Hz range
