Describe Differential Diagnoses - What Can It Resemble? for Superior Canal Dehiscence Syndrome (SCDS).

Differential Diagnoses - What Can It Resemble?

 

 SCDS is called "the great imitator of the ear" because symptoms can resemble several other conditions:

 
 Meniere's Disease

 Also causes hearing loss and dizziness, but attacks come spontaneously and last 20 minutes to several hours. In SCDS, symptoms are temporally related to specific sound or pressure triggers.

 

 
 BPPV (Crystal Disease)

 Triggered by head movements and causes brief spinning dizziness that diminishes with repeated movements. SCDS is triggered by sound and pressure, not head position.

 

 
 Otosclerosis

 Also causes hearing loss in low frequencies, but in otosclerosis the stapedius reflex is absent - in SCDS it is normal. This difference is important because stapedectomy (surgery for otosclerosis) is contraindicated in SCDS.

How is Superior Canal Dehiscence Syndrome (SCDS) diagnosed?

Diagnosis

 

 Clinical Questions That Can Reveal SCDS

 When SCDS is suspected, the following questions can be revealing:

 
 "Can you hear your eyes moving?"

 "Do you get dizzy when straining or having a bowel movement?"

 "Does blowing your nose give you a spinning sensation?"

 "Do you hear your own voice abnormally loud in one ear?"

 

 Diagnostic Criteria (Barany Society, 2021)

 For the diagnosis of SCDS, all three of the following are required:

 
 A. At Least One Characteristic Symptom

 Bone conduction hypersensitivity (autophony for internal body sounds), sound-induced dizziness/oscillopsia, pressure-induced dizziness/oscillopsia, or pulsatile tinnitus.

 

 
 B. At Least One Physiological Finding

 Nystagmus in the plane of the superior canal triggered by sound or pressure, negative bone conduction thresholds on audiometry in low frequencies, or enhanced VEMP responses.

 

 
 C. High-Resolution CT

 Showing dehiscence with 0.5-0.63 mm slice thickness or less and reformatted images in Poschl and Stenvers planes.

 

 
 Red Flags - When to Contact an ENT Specialist

 
 Dizziness triggered by loud sounds

 You hear your own eye movements, footsteps or heartbeat abnormally clearly

 Dizziness when straining, coughing or blowing your nose

 Pulsatile tinnitus combined with balance problems

 Hearing loss with preserved acoustic reflexes

 Position-triggered dizziness that doesn't respond to Epley maneuver

Describe treatment options for Superior Canal Dehiscence Syndrome (SCDS).

Treatment

 

 Conservative Treatment

 For patients with mild to moderate symptoms, conservative treatment is often first choice. Approximately 80% of diagnosed patients do not undergo surgery. Conservative measures include:

 
 Conservative Measures

 
 Avoid triggering factors (loud sounds, straining, heavy lifting)

 Hearing protection in noisy environments

 Reduced salt and caffeine intake

 Acetazolamide (diuretic) which showed 78% symptom reduction in one study

 
 

 Surgical Treatment

 For debilitating symptoms that significantly affect quality of life, surgery may be considered. Transmastoid approach (TMA) has significantly lower revision rate (3.8% vs 33.3%), shorter hospital stay and better results for autophony (95% vs 80%) compared to middle fossa craniotomy.

 Total surgical success rate is 94%. At long-term follow-up (average 5.3 years), 95% of patients reported improvement.

Describe Unilateral vs. Bilateral - What's the Difference? for Vestibular Hypofunction: The Complete Guide.

Unilateral vs. Bilateral - What's the Difference?

 

 Vestibular hypofunction is divided into two main types, and the differences are significant - both regarding symptoms, causes and prognosis.

 
 Unilateral Vestibular Hypofunction (One-sided)

 In unilateral hypofunction, the balance organ is damaged on only one side. This is the most common form and is most often caused by vestibular neuritis (virus on the balance nerve).

 How does it work? The balance organs in the right and left ear normally function as a "push-pull" system. When you turn your head to the right, the signal from the right ear increases while it decreases from the left. With one-sided damage, an imbalance occurs that the brain interprets as constant rotation. The good news is that the brain is remarkably good at compensating for one-sided damage.

 

 
 Bilateral Vestibular Hypofunction (Two-sided)

 In bilateral hypofunction, the balance organs function poorly or not at all on both sides. This is a rarer and more serious condition.

 How does it work? When both sides are "silent," the brain receives no information about the head's movements. It's like driving a car without a speedometer and without windows - you have no idea how you're moving.

 Prevalence: Approximately 28 per 100,000 adults. The average age at diagnosis is 58-64 years, and men are somewhat more often affected than women.

What causes Vestibular Hypofunction: The Complete Guide?

Causes and Risk Factors

 

 Causes of Unilateral Vestibular Hypofunction

 Most common:

 
 Vestibular neuritis/labyrinthitis - Viral infection that attacks the balance nerve or inner ear. The most common cause of acute unilateral vestibular hypofunction

 Age-related weakening - Gradual loss of function due to natural aging

 
 Less common:

 
 Meniere's disease - Chronic condition with episodic vertigo, hearing loss and tinnitus

 Head injuries - Can damage the balance organ or balance nerve, as in post-concussion dizziness or whiplash-related dizziness

 Vestibular schwannoma - Benign tumor on the balance nerve

 

 Causes of Bilateral Vestibular Hypofunction

 
 1. Unknown Cause (Idiopathic) - 31-51%

 In approximately half of cases, no clear cause is found. Interestingly, around 50% of these patients have migraine, which can also cause vestibular migraine.

 

 
 2. Ototoxic Medications - 12-35%

 Aminoglycosides (especially gentamicin) are the most common identifiable cause. Damage can occur with any dose.

 

 
 3. Hereditary Conditions - 17-31%

 DFNA9 (mutation in the COCH gene) is most common in Europe. CANVAS syndrome accounts for 2-5% of cases.

 

 
 4. Meniere's Disease (Bilateral) - 2-17%

 When Meniere's disease affects both ears over time.

 

 
 5. Meningitis - 5-11%

 Meningitis can spread to both inner ears.

 Bilateral hypofunction gives a characteristic symptom triad:

 The main complaint, especially on uneven surfaces, in darkness or with head movements. Many describe feeling like they're "walking on a boat."

Describe treatment options for Vestibular Hypofunction: The Complete Guide.

Treatment

 

 Vestibular rehabilitation is the main treatment for both unilateral and bilateral hypofunction. The APTA guidelines from 2022 give a strong recommendation based on high-quality evidence.

 What Does Vestibular Rehabilitation Involve?

 Treatment is not about "repairing" the balance organs - they can rarely be restored. The goal is to train the brain to compensate.

 
 Treatment Methods

 
 Gaze stabilization exercises (VOR training): Trains the eyes to maintain focus while the head moves

 Habituation: Gradual exposure to movements that trigger dizziness

 Balance training: Exercises on uneven surfaces, with closed eyes, with head movements

 Sensory substitution: Learns to use vision and sensation in the feet more actively for balance

 20-40 min/day + lifelong

Prognosis

 

 In Unilateral Hypofunction

 Most experience significant improvement. Average handicap score decreases from around 52 to 27 points after treatment - a clinically meaningful improvement. However, 29-66% have persistent symptoms with rapid head movements. In some, incomplete compensation can lead to development of PPPD (chronic dizziness).

 In Bilateral Hypofunction

 The prognosis for regaining vestibular function is limited - only about 4% improve enough to no longer meet diagnostic criteria. However, quality of life can improve significantly with rehabilitation and adaptations.

 
 Fall Risk

 Patients with bilateral hypofunction have 31 times higher fall risk than the normal population.

Describe Frequently Asked Questions for Vestibular Hypofunction: The Complete Guide.

Frequently Asked Questions

 

 
 Is vestibular hypofunction the same as crystal disease?

 No. Crystal disease (BPPV) causes short episodes of intense spinning dizziness triggered by specific head positions. Vestibular hypofunction is a persistent weakening of balance function. Treatment is also different.

 

 
 Can vestibular hypofunction fully recover?

 In unilateral cases, the brain often compensates well, and many experience near-full function. In bilateral cases, full recovery is rare (about 4%), but quality of life can improve significantly with proper treatment.

 

 
 Should I avoid activity when I'm dizzy?

 No, quite the opposite! Early activity promotes brain compensation. Prolonged bed rest can delay recovery. Activity should be adapted to your abilities and increased gradually.

 

 
 Can a chiropractor help with vestibular hypofunction?

 Yes. Chiropractors with expertise in vestibular disorders can evaluate, diagnose and treat with evidence-based vestibular rehabilitation. In Norway, chiropractors have primary contact status, so you don't need a referral.

Describe What Is Vestibular Migraine? for Vestibular Migraine: When Dizziness Takes Over Your Life.

What Is Vestibular Migraine?

 

 Vestibular migraine is a neurological condition where migraine mechanisms in the brain affect balance centers in the brainstem and cerebellum. Contrary to what many believe, you don't need to have headache during an attack. In fact, only about 25% of patients experience headache simultaneously with dizziness.

 The condition affects 1-3% of the population and is far more common than Meniere's disease, which many are mistakenly diagnosed with. In specialized dizziness clinics, vestibular migraine accounts for up to 25% of all newly referred patients. Women are affected more often than men, with a ratio of approximately 3-5:1.

 
 
 1-3%
 of population
 

 
 25%
 of dizziness clinic patients
 

 
 7-8 yrs
 average time to diagnosis
 

 

 
 Why Is the Condition So Often Missed?

 Headache and dizziness rarely occur simultaneously. The patient may have had migraine in youth that "disappeared," only to develop unexplained dizziness 10-20 years later. In an American survey, only 10% of patients who met criteria for vestibular migraine had been told that migraine was the cause.

What causes Vestibular Migraine: When Dizziness Takes Over Your Life?

Causes and Risk Factors

 

 Pathophysiology - What Happens in the Brain?

 During an attack, CGRP (calcitonin gene-related peptide) is released - a signaling substance that plays a key role in migraine. CGRP is found both in the trigeminal system and in vestibular ganglia. When released, it disrupts normal signal processing in balance centers.

 Risk Factors (from most common to rarest):

 
 Previous Migraine

 With or without aura - the most important risk factor

 

 
 Female Sex

 3-5 times higher risk than men

 

 
 Family History

 40-70% have family history of migraine or vertigo

 

 
 Anxiety and Depression

 Often co-existing conditions that can worsen symptoms

 

 
 Previous Head Injury

 Increases risk significantly, see also post-concussion dizziness

 

 Triggers That Can Provoke Attacks:

 
 Stress: Both acute stress and "let-down" stress (when you finally relax)

 Sleep: Too little, too much, or irregular sleep schedule

 Hormones: Menstrual cycle and menopause

 Food and drink: Red wine, aged cheese, chocolate, caffeine

 Sensory overstimulation: Bright light, loud sounds, strong smells

 Main Dizziness Symptoms:

 
 Spontaneous Rotational Vertigo (45%)

 The room spins, typically lasting 1-4 hours. So intense you cannot continue activities.

 

 
 Position-Triggered Dizziness (25%)

 Triggered by head movement, but lasts minutes to hours (not seconds as in crystal disease).

 Worsens in busy visual environments (shopping centers, escalators). Scrolling on screens triggers symptoms.

 

 Accompanying Symptoms:

Diagnosis

 

 Barany Society/IHS Diagnostic Criteria:

 For the diagnosis "Definite Vestibular Migraine" the following must be met:

 
 At least 5 episodes with vestibular symptoms of moderate to severe intensity

 Duration from 5 minutes to 72 hours

 Current or past history of migraine (with or without aura)

 At least 50% of attacks must have at least one migraine feature: headache, light/sound sensitivity, or visual aura

 Symptoms cannot be better explained by another diagnosis

Describe treatment options for Vestibular Migraine: When Dizziness Takes Over Your Life.

Treatment

 

 Preventive Medications

 A systematic review ranked effectiveness as follows (Frontiers in Pharmacology, 2023):

 
 First-Line Choice

 
 Propranolol (beta blocker): 60% achieve complete symptom control

 Topiramate (antiepileptic): Moderate evidence

 
 

 
 Second-Line Choice

 Venlafaxine, Valproate, Amitriptyline

 

 CGRP Inhibitors - New Treatment Option

 The new CGRP monoclonal antibodies (erenumab, galcanezumab, fremanezumab) show promising results. A prospective study showed that 90% achieved at least 50% reduction in vertigo frequency. Average number of dizziness days fell from 10.3 to 0.8 days per month after 12 months.

 Vestibular Rehabilitation

 
 Treatment Includes:

 
 Eye movement exercises (VOR training)

 Balance training

 Habituation for visual hypersensitivity

 Gradual exposure to trigger situations

 
 

 Important: Training must be dosed carefully. Too hard training can actually trigger new attacks.

 Manual Treatment and the Neck

 Neck pain is very common in patients with vestibular migraine. A case series from 2024 showed that manual treatment of upper cervical vertebrae gave rapid and sustained improvement. The background is trigeminocervical convergence - nerve pathways from the upper neck (C1-C3) converge with pathways from the vestibular system.

 What Can You Do Yourself?

 
 Sleep: Go to bed and get up at the same time every day. Aim for 7-8 hours

 Diet: Eat regularly. Identify and reduce food triggers (keep a diary)

What is the prognosis for Vestibular Migraine: When Dizziness Takes Over Your Life?

Prognosis

 

 With proper treatment, most experience significant improvement. Patients on preventive treatment get reduction in both frequency, intensity and duration of attacks.

 Realistic Expectations:

 
 Relapse is common: Even with good treatment, many will experience periods with more attacks

 Treatment takes time: It can take 2-3 months before preventive medications have full effect

 Individual variation: What works for one person doesn't necessarily work for another

 

 The positive thing is that many find attacks become less intense and less frequent over the years, especially with good treatment and trigger management. In some cases, prolonged vestibular migraine can develop into PPPD (chronic dizziness), which requires a different treatment approach.

 For the diagnosis "Definite Vestibular Migraine" the following must be met:

Second-Line Choice

 CGRP Inhibitors - New Treatment Option

 The new CGRP monoclonal antibodies (erenumab, galcanezumab, fremanezumab) show promising results. A prospective study showed that 90% achieved at least 50% reduction in vertigo frequency. Average number of dizziness days fell from 10.3 to 0.8 days per month after 12 months.

 Vestibular Rehabilitation

 
 Treatment Includes:

 
 Eye movement exercises (VOR training)

 Balance training

 Habituation for visual hypersensitivity

 Gradual exposure to trigger situations

 
 

 Important: Training must be dosed carefully. Too hard training can actually trigger new attacks.

 Manual Treatment and the Neck

 Neck pain is very common in patients with vestibular migraine. A case series from 2024 showed that manual treatment of upper cervical vertebrae gave rapid and sustained improvement. The background is trigeminocervical convergence - nerve pathways from the upper neck (C1-C3) converge with pathways from the vestibular system.

 What Can You Do Yourself?

 
 Sleep: Go to bed and get up at the same time every day. Aim for 7-8 hours

 Diet: Eat regularly. Identify and reduce food triggers (keep a diary)

 Stress: Regular physical activity. Mindfulness or breathing exercises

 
 

 
 
 6
 Prognosis

 

 With proper treatment, most experience significant improvement. Patients on preventive treatment get reduction in both frequency, intensity and duration of attacks.

 Realistic Expectations:

 
 Relapse is common: Even with good treatment, many will experience periods with more attacks

 Treatment takes time: It can take 2-3 months before preventive medications have full effect

 Individual variation: What works for one person doesn't necessarily work for another

 

 The positive thing is that many find attacks become less intense and less frequent over the years, especially with good treatment and trigger management. In some cases, prolonged vestibular migraine can develop into PPPD (chronic dizziness), which requires a different treatment approach.

What is Vestibular Neuritis?

 

 This condition is the third most common cause of peripheral dizziness, after BPPV (crystal disease) and Meniere's disease. It affects approximately 3.5-15.5 per 100,000 people annually, and most commonly occurs in adults between 30 and 60 years old.

 
 
 3.5-15.5
 per 100,000 annually
 

 
 30-60 yrs
 most common age group

What causes Vestibular Neuritis?

Causes and Mechanisms

 

 The exact cause is not fully understood, but several factors have been identified:

 
 Viral Cause (Main Hypothesis)

 Reactivation of herpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV-1) in the balance nerve ganglion is the most accepted theory. HSV-1 - the same virus that causes cold sores - has been found in approximately two-thirds of human vestibular ganglia in autopsy studies. The virus can lie dormant in the nerve for years, then reactivate and create inflammation and swelling.

 

 Since the balance nerve passes through a narrow bony canal in the skull, even moderate swelling can compress the nerve fibers and stop signal transmission. Most patients have had a viral infection in the weeks before symptom onset.

Describe symptoms and signs of Vestibular Neuritis.

Symptoms

 

 Symptoms typically come on acutely over a few hours, reach near-maximum intensity within 24 hours, and gradually subside over days to weeks.

 Typical Symptom Presentation:

 
 Rotational vertigo: Intense feeling that the room is continuously spinning

 Spontaneous nystagmus: Involuntary, rapid eye movements beating toward the healthy ear

 Nausea and vomiting: Can be so severe that hospitalization is necessary

 Balance problems: Tendency to fall toward the affected side

 Oscillopsia: Feeling that the visual field "jumps" during head movements

 

 
 Important Diagnostic Point

 Vestibular neuritis does not cause hearing loss. If you have dizziness combined with reduced hearing, it may indicate labyrinthitis or other conditions requiring different evaluation.

 

 Time Course:

 
 Acute phase (0-3 days): Intense dizziness, often bedridden

 Subacute phase (1-2 weeks): Gradual improvement, can walk upright but becomes dizzy with rapid movements

 Compensation phase (3-12 weeks): The brain adapts and learns to compensate

 
 Most experience significant improvement within 10 weeks.

How is Vestibular Neuritis diagnosed?

Diagnosis

 

 Vestibular neuritis is primarily a clinical diagnosis. The most important thing is to distinguish it from stroke in the cerebellum or brainstem, which can cause very similar symptoms. Approximately 25% of patients with acute vestibular syndrome may have central nervous system causes.

 The HINTS Examination

 HINTS (Head Impulse, Nystagmus, Test of Skew) is a three-step eye examination that, in cases of acute dizziness, has proven more sensitive than MRI for detecting stroke in the first 24-48 hours. Performed by trained clinicians, HINTS is 96.5% sensitive and 84-96% specific.

 
 Head Impulse Test

 Rapid passive head rotation while the patient focuses. In vestibular neuritis, the gaze will "slip" and must be corrected.

 

 
 Nystagmus

 In vestibular neuritis, nystagmus is unidirectional - the eyes beat the same direction regardless of gaze direction.

 

 
 Test of Skew

 Alternating covering of the eyes. Vertical readjustment indicates brainstem lesion.

Describe treatment options for Vestibular Neuritis.

Treatment

 

 Acute Phase (0-3 days)

 In the first days, the goal is to relieve symptoms and ensure fluid balance. Anti-nausea medications and vestibular suppressants can be used, but should only be used for the first 1-3 days. Prolonged use "sedates" the brain and delays the natural compensation process.

 Vestibular Rehabilitation - Core Treatment

 Vestibular rehabilitation is the most important treatment and has strong evidence (Cochrane 2015). A systematic review of 39 studies with over 2400 participants showed that vestibular rehabilitation was significantly better than no treatment.

 The brain compensates for the functional loss in three ways:

 
 Adaptation: The brain adjusts the strength of signals from the healthy ear

 Substitution: The brain begins to rely more on vision and body sense (proprioception)

 Habituation: The brain learns to ignore the disturbing signals

 

 
 Exercises - Start Day 3-4

 1. Gaze stabilization (VOR x1): Hold a finger in front of you. Focus sharply on the target. Rotate your head calmly from side to side while gaze is locked. Start slowly, increase speed gradually. 1-2 minutes, 3-5 times daily.

 2. Balance training: Stand with feet together, hold onto a chair back if needed. Try closing your eyes. Progression: Stand on one leg, walk on soft surface.

 3. Movement provocation: Perform movements that make you dizzy. Repeat in a controlled manner until dizziness decreases.

 It should make you slightly dizzy - that's how the brain lea...

What is the prognosis for Vestibular Neuritis?

Prognosis

 

 Vestibular neuritis is a self-limiting condition with generally good prognosis:

 
 
 2-3 weeks
 significant improvement
 

 
 3-6 mo
 full compensation
 

 
 50-70%
 full recovery
 

 

 
 Most experience significant improvement within 2-3 weeks

 Full compensation (can run, turn quickly without problems) can take 3-6 months

 Approximately 50-70% achieve full or near-full recovery

 30-50% develop persistent, milder dizziness

 

 
 Interesting Finding

 Long-term prognosis does not depend on how much nerve function is restored. Even if caloric testing still shows significant asymmetry, patients can become completely symptom-free because the brain compensates effectively.

 

 Factors Predicting Poorer Recovery:

 
 High degree of anxiety at disease onset

 Strong visual dependency (relying too much on vision for balance)

 Avoidance behavior (lying still for too long)

 Prolonged use of vestibular suppressants

 
 In some cases, persistent symptoms can develop into PPPD (persistent postural-perceptual dizziness), especially with strong anxiety or avoidance behavior. Patients with vestibular migraine may also have increased risk for poorer outcomes.

 Risk of Recurrence

 
 Recurrence in the same ear is rare - the nerve is often permanently damaged

 Risk of getting it in the other ear is approximately 2-4% over a lifetime

WAD Classification (Whiplash Associated Disorders)

 

 90% of whiplash injuries are classified as WAD grade I-II, meaning neck complaints with or without musculoskeletal findings, but without neurological signs.

What causes Whiplash and Dizziness?

Why Does Whiplash Cause Dizziness?

 

 The connection between whiplash and dizziness is stronger than many expect. Studies show that 40-70% of those with persistent whiplash symptoms report dizziness.

 
 
 40-70%
 experience dizziness
 

 
 242
 muscle spindles/gram in suboccipital
 

 
 C1-C3
 most proprioceptive sensors
 

 

 To maintain balance, the brain depends on three systems: the eyes (vision), the inner ear (vestibular system) and proprioception (body sense). The neck - especially the upper part (C1-C3) - is packed with proprioceptive sensors that tell the brain where the head is located.

 With whiplash, these sensors can be damaged. The suboccipital muscles have extremely high muscle spindle density - 242 spindles per gram compared to only 2.2 per gram in the trapezius. When these are damaged, the neck sends error signals to the brain.

 
 Sensory Mismatch

 The eyes say "you're standing still", the ear says "you're standing still", but the neck says "the head is moving!". The brain interprets this as dizziness - like being seasick on land.

 This is perhaps the most important question to answer. Cervicogenic dizziness (neck dizziness) is a diagnosis of exclusion - other causes must first be ruled out.

 
 Signs of Cervicogenic Dizziness (neck)

 
 Dizziness increases with neck movements or when sitting still for long periods

 Feels like "swaying" or "unsteadiness" - not spinning

 You have concurrent neck pain

 Dizziness lasts minutes to hours (not seconds)

 Negative Dix-Hallpike test

 Triggered by specific head positions (turning in bed, looking up)

 Positive Dix-Hallpike test

 Not necessarily neck pain

 
 

 
 Signs of Concussion

 
 Problems with memory or concentration

 Light or sound sensitivity

 "Foggy" feeling in the head

 Becomes dizzy from screens or busy environments

 
 

 
 Important

 In car accidents, up to 40% may have both whiplash and concussion simultaneously. Then both must be treated.

Describe treatment options for Whiplash and Dizziness.

Treatment

 

 What Can the Chiropractor Do?

 Systematic reviews show that multimodal treatment - the combination of manual therapy, exercises and patient education - has the strongest evidence base.

 
 Treatment Methods

 
 Manual therapy: Gentle joint mobilization, soft tissue treatment of tight muscles. A meta-analysis found significant pain relief in the medium term.

 Deep neck muscle training: The small muscles that stabilize the neck often "switch off" after injury. Motor control training has strong evidence.

 Sensorimotor training: Exercises that train the coordination between eyes and neck. Approximately 75% improve with this approach.

 Information and reassurance: Explanation of the condition and realistic expectations for recovery.

 
 

 What Can You Do Yourself?

 
 Self-Help

 
 Stay active: Early mobilization is important. Take walks - arms swing naturally and help loosen the neck.

 Avoid static positions: Don't sit with your phone in your lap for long periods, especially in the first weeks.

 Move your neck gently: Move your neck within pain-free range several times daily.

 Avoid neck collar: Studies show that neck collars are not only ineffective but can hinder recovery.

What is the prognosis for Whiplash and Dizziness?

Prognosis

 

 The first three months are critical. Most who will recover do so during this period - then the recovery curve flattens out.

 
 
 50%
 improve within 3-6 months
 

 
 64%
 report improvement at 1 year
 

 
 25-40%
 persistent symptoms at 1 year
 

 

 
 Important to Know

 A study showed that 86% of patients who still had symptoms at 3 months still had complaints at 2 years - while 93% of those symptom-free at 3 months remained healthy. This underscores the importance of early and effective treatment.

 

 Risk Factors for Chronic Symptoms:

 
 High initial pain intensity (over 5.5/10)

 High functional disability at start

 Post-traumatic stress symptoms

 Catastrophizing thoughts and passive coping strategies

 Poor expectations for recovery

 Presence of dizziness - which can develop into PPPD or vestibular hypofunction

Describe Frequently Asked Questions for Whiplash and Dizziness.

Frequently Asked Questions

 

 
 Should I use a neck collar?

 No. Systematic reviews conclude that neck collars are not only ineffective but can actually hinder recovery. Both Norwegian and Nordic guidelines recommend against use.

 

 
 How long before the dizziness goes away?

 This varies significantly. Many experience improvement within 6-12 weeks with proper treatment. With cervicogenic dizziness, approximately 75% improve with conservative neck treatment. For some, it may take longer to rebuild fine motor control in the neck.

 

 
 Can I have both whiplash and concussion?

 Yes, and this is actually quite common. In car accidents, up to 40% may have both at the same time. Treatment must then be adapted to both conditions.

 

 
 Do I need X-ray or MRI?

 Not necessarily. For most whiplash injuries (grade I-II), imaging is not necessary. Clinical examination is often more important. MRI may be relevant with neurological deficits or lack of improvement.

 

 
 Can I exercise with whiplash?

 Yes, movement is medicine - but it must be the right movement. Start with pain-free movements and increase gradually. Avoid activities that worsen symptoms. Walking is often a good starting point.

Describe Self-Help in the context of Whiplash and Dizziness.

Self-Help

 
 Stay active: Early mobilization is important. Take walks - arms swing naturally and help loosen the neck.

 Avoid static positions: Don't sit with your phone in your lap for long periods, especially in the first weeks.

 Move your neck gently: Move your neck within pain-free range several times daily.

 Avoid neck collar: Studies show that neck collars are not only ineffective but can hinder recovery.

 
 

 Treatment Course

 In the acute phase (0-2 weeks) more frequent treatment may be useful, with focus on early mobilization. In the subacute phase (2-12 weeks) it typically decreases to 1-2 treatments per week. Improvement should be seen within 4 weeks; without improvement, diagnosis and treatment should be reconsidered.

 When Chiropractic Helps - and When It Doesn't

 Chiropractic treatment is often effective for mechanical neck dizziness - when dizziness comes because the joints in the neck aren't moving as they should, or when muscle pain triggers symptoms.

 
 Chiropractic alone is not sufficient if:

 
 You have an active concussion (need rest/pacing first)

 You have BPPV/crystal disease (need Epley maneuver, not neck treatment)

 You have PPPD (need cognitive approach and gradual exposure)

 
 This is why a thorough examination is crucial before I start treatment.

Describe What is Dizziness? for Dizziness - Complete Guide.

What is Dizziness?

 

 Dizziness isn't one thing. It's an umbrella term covering several different experiences:

 
 Three Types of Dizziness

 
 Vertigo: The sensation that you or your surroundings are rotating. The room spins,
 or you feel like you're spinning even though you're standing still. This almost always stems from
 disturbances in the balance organ.

 Unsteadiness: Often described as a swaying or rocking feeling - like standing on a
 boat deck. You don't feel quite stable on your feet.

 Light-headedness: A diffuse feeling of being "foggy" in the head. Some describe it
 as almost fainting.

 
 

 How Balance Works

 Three systems continuously send information to the brain:

 
 
 

 Balance Organ

 In the inner ear - registers the head's movements and position

 

 
 

 Eyes

 Tell the brain where you are in relation to your surroundings

 

 
 

 Body Sense

 Sensors in muscles, tendons and joints report the body's position

 

 

 When all three systems send matching signals, you feel stable. When one system sends incorrect
 information - or the systems send conflicting signals - dizziness occurs.

Treatment Methods

 

 Repositioning Manoeuvres for BPPV

 
 Common Manoeuvres

 
 Epley manoeuvre for posterior canal: A series of controlled head and body movements
 that guide the crystals back to the utricle

 Semont manoeuvre - alternative for posterior canal

 Barbecue manoeuvre (Lempert) for horizontal canal

 Vestibular Rehabilitation

 A training programme that helps the brain compensate for vestibular dysfunction:

 
 Gaze stabilisation: Exercises where you keep your gaze fixed on a point whilst moving
 your head

 Habituation: Gradual exposure to movements that provoke dizziness

 Balance training: Exercises on unstable surfaces, with eyes closed, or with head
 movements

Identify red flags for Dizziness - Complete Guide.

Red Flags - When You Must Seek Emergency Help

 

 
 CALL 113 IMMEDIATELY IF:

 
 Sudden severe dizziness together with speech difficulties, facial paralysis, paralysis in arm/leg,
 or double vision

 Unusually severe headache ("thunderclap headache") together with dizziness

 Dizziness with chest pain or breathing difficulties

 Disturbances of consciousness or severe confusion

 
 These symptoms may indicate stroke or other serious
 condition.

 

 
 The "Five Ds" that warn of central problem:

 
 Diplopia (double vision)

 Dysarthria (slurred speech)

 Dysphagia (swallowing difficulties)

 Dysmetria (clumsy movements)

 Drop attacks (sudden falls)

 
 

 Book appointment with doctor or chiropractor if:

 
 Dizziness lasting over 3 days without improvement

 Repeated dizziness attacks that disrupt daily life

 Dizziness with hearing loss or tinnitus

 Falls or repeated near-falls

Describe treatment options for Dizziness - Complete Guide.

Prevention and Self-Treatment

 

 
 Measures You Can Do Yourself

 
 Move: The myth of bed rest for dizziness has been debunked. Adapted movement
 stimulates the balance system and helps the brain recalibrate.

 Vitamin D: Several meta-analyses show a connection between low vitamin D levels and
 BPPV. Supplementation may reduce relapse risk (Yang, J Neurol, 2020).

 Hydration: Drink sufficient fluids. Dehydration can worsen dizziness symptoms.

 Ergonomics: Screen at eye level, avoid forward-leaning head posture, take breaks
 every 30 minutes.

 Stress management: Stress worsens many forms of dizziness. Simple breathing
 exercises can calm an overactive nervous system.

 Secure your home: Remove loose rugs, ensure good lighting, use support handles in
 the bathroom.

Frequently Asked Questions

 

 
 Do I need a referral from a doctor?

 No. Chiropractors have had primary contact status in Norway since 2006. You can book an appointment
 directly. I can also refer you onwards to a specialist if necessary.

 

 
 How many treatments do I need?

 For BPPV: Often 1-3 treatments. Most notice improvement after the first session. For other conditions:
 Usually 4-8 weeks with treatment and exercises.

 

 
 Can dizziness come back?

 Yes, especially BPPV. Around 30% experience new episodes within 1 year, and up to 50% within 5 years
 (Brandt, J Neurol, 2006). Vitamin D supplementation and home exercises can potentially reduce the risk.
 

 

 
 Do I need MRI or CT?

 In most cases clinical examination is sufficient. Diagnostic imaging is only necessary with red flags,
 suspected central cause, or when treatment doesn't give expected results.

 

 
 Do medicines help?

 Medicines don't cure BPPV - it's a mechanical problem requiring a mechanical solution. Vestibular
 suppressants can be used briefly in the acute phase, but delay the brain's compensation.

 

 
 Is neck treatment dangerous?

 Vertebral artery dissection is a very rare but serious complication. Before treatment I conduct
 screening for vascular risk factors. If I suspect vascular problems I refer without treating.

 

 
 Can I exercise with dizziness?

 Yes, adapted activity is important. Only avoid movements that cause severe worsening. Light cardio
 training (walking, cycling) is...

Describe What is carpal tunnel syndrome? for Carpal Tunnel Syndrome: Complete Guide.

What is carpal tunnel syndrome?

 

 Carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS) occurs when the median nerve is compressed in the carpal
 tunnel - a narrow passage on the inside of the wrist. This tunnel is surrounded by the wrist bones on
 three sides and a tight band (the carpal ligament) on top.

 When pressure in the tunnel increases, the nerve is compressed. This causes the characteristic symptoms:
 tingling, numbness and pain in the fingers supplied by the nerve - the thumb, index finger, middle finger
 and half of the ring finger.

 
 The little finger is the key

 If the little finger is also affected, it is not carpal tunnel syndrome - it's
 supplied by the ulnar nerve (see cubital tunnel syndrome).
 This is an important diagnostic sign.

 

 
 
 2.7%
 of population affected
 

 
 3x
 more common in women
 

 
 40-60 years
 most common age group

What causes Carpal Tunnel Syndrome: Complete Guide?

Causes and risk factors

 

 Carpal tunnel syndrome occurs when pressure in the tunnel becomes too high. This can be caused by:

 
 Swelling of the tendons (most common)

 Repetitive strain or overuse can cause swelling in the tendon sheaths passing through the tunnel,
 reducing space for the nerve.

 

 
 Hormonal factors

 Pregnancy, menopause, hypothyroidism and diabetes increase risk through fluid retention and tissue
 swelling.

 

 
 Anatomical factors

 Some people naturally have narrower carpal tunnels. Previous wrist fractures can also narrow the
 tunnel.

 

 
 Repetitive work

 Office work, cashier work, production work - anything with repeated hand movements over time. See also
 mouse arm.
 

 

 Important risk factors

 
 Gender: Women are affected 3 times more often than men

 Pregnancy: Common in the last trimester (fluid retention)

 Diabetes: Increased risk of nerve disease in general

 Obesity: BMI over 30 significantly increases risk

 Arthritis: Inflammation can affect the tendon sheaths

 Hereditary: Tends to run in families

Describe symptoms and signs of Carpal Tunnel Syndrome: Complete Guide.

Symptoms

 

 The symptoms of carpal tunnel syndrome are often characteristic:

 
 Typical symptoms

 
 Tingling and numbness in thumb, index finger, middle finger and half of ring finger
 

 Night symptoms - waking up with "sleeping" hand

 Pain that can radiate up into the forearm

 Weakness - dropping things, problems with buttons

 "Electric shocks" in the fingers

 
 

 Why is it worst at night?

 Most people sleep with bent wrists, either under the head or curled toward the chest. When the wrist is
 bent, pressure in the carpal tunnel increases significantly - up to 10 times normal. This
 compresses the nerve and causes symptoms.

 
 Symptoms that worsen over time

 Without treatment, carpal tunnel syndrome can lead to:

 
 Constant numbness (not just at night)

 Muscle wasting at thumb base (thenar atrophy)

 Permanent nerve damage

 
 The earlier treatment starts, the better the prognosis.

 

 Where are your symptoms?

 
 
 
 Condition
 Fingers affected
 
 
 
 
 Carpal tunnel syndrome
 Thumb, index, middle, half ring finger
 
 
 Cubital tunnel syndrome
 Little finger, half ring finger
 
 
 Cervical radiculopathy
 Varies with nerve root, often entire arm

How is Carpal Tunnel Syndrome: Complete Guide diagnosed?

Diagnosis

 

 Diagnosis is primarily based on medical history and clinical examination. Provocation tests can confirm
 suspicion:

 
 Phalen's test

 Hold wrists flexed for 60 seconds. Positive test: symptoms in the median nerve area are triggered.

 

 
 Tinel's sign

 Tapping over the carpal tunnel causes "electric shock" in the fingers.

 

 
 Nerve conduction studies (EMG/NCV)

 Nerve conduction velocity studies. Can confirm diagnosis and grade severity. Particularly important for
 surgical evaluation.

 

 
 Important differential diagnosis

 Symptoms in the hand can also come from:

 
 Neck: C6-C7 radiculopathy can give similar symptoms

 Thoracic outlet syndrome: Nerve entrapment at ribs/shoulders

 Peripheral neuropathy: Diabetes-related nerve disease

 
 A thorough examination rules out other causes.

Evidence-based treatment

 

 AAOS (American Academy of Orthopaedic Surgeons) updated their guidelines in 2024. Here's what the
 research shows:

 
 First choice: Night splint

 
 50-70% experience improvement with nightly use of wrist splint

 Keeps the wrist in neutral position during sleep

 Significantly reduces night symptoms

 Recommended as first-line treatment (AAOS 2024)

 
 

 
 Manual therapy matches surgery short-term

 An important study (Fernandez-de-las-Penas et al.) showed that manual treatment gave equally
 good results as surgery at 1 and 3 month follow-up. This included:

 
 Nerve gliding exercises

 Myofascial release of forearm and hand

 Mobilization of wrist bones

 
 

 Treatment plan at Chiropractor Mads Finstad

 
 1. Night splint (first choice)

 Guidance on proper use of wrist splint. Must be used every night for at least 3-4 weeks to evaluate
 effect.

 

 
 2. Nerve gliding exercises

 Structured exercises that mobilize the median nerve through its path, to reduce adhesions and improve
 nerve mobility.

Describe Frequently Asked Questions for Carpal Tunnel Syndrome: Complete Guide.

Frequently Asked Questions

 

 
 Why do my hands go numb at night?

 When you sleep, the wrist is often bent, which significantly increases pressure in
 the carpal tunnel. This compresses the median nerve and causes tingling and numbness. A night splint
 that keeps the wrist in neutral position can help 50-70% of patients.

 

 
 Do I need surgery?

 Not necessarily. Many recover with conservative treatment such as night splint and
 manual therapy. AAOS 2024 recommends trying conservative treatment first. Surgery is considered for
 severe symptoms or no effect after 3-6 months.

 

 
 Can carpal tunnel syndrome go away on its own?

 Mild cases can improve spontaneously, especially if there's a temporary cause
 (like pregnancy). But without treatment, most cases worsen over time. The earlier you start treatment,
 the better the prognosis.

 

 
 Is it dangerous to wait with treatment?

 Long-term, untreated carpal tunnel syndrome can cause permanent nerve damage with
 constant numbness and muscle wasting. Early treatment prevents this.

 

 
 Can I continue working at a computer?

 Yes, but you should consider ergonomic adjustments. Keyboard height, mouse type,
 and frequent breaks are important. An ergonomic assessment can identify problems.

 in thumb, index, middle and ring finger. Cubital tunnel

Describe What is Cubital Tunnel Syndrome? for Cubital Tunnel Syndrome: Everything You Need to Know.

What is Cubital Tunnel Syndrome?

 

 Cubital tunnel syndrome occurs when the ulnar nerve becomes compressed or irritated at
 the elbow. The nerve passes through a narrow tunnel (the cubital tunnel) on the inside and back of the
 elbow - exactly where you feel it when you hit your "funny bone".

 The ulnar nerve supplies the little finger, half of the ring finger, and several small muscles in the
 hand that control fine motor skills. When the nerve is compressed, you get symptoms in exactly these
 areas.

 
 Second Most Common After Carpal Tunnel

 Cubital tunnel syndrome is the second most common peripheral nerve entrapment
 syndrome. It affects about 25 per 100,000 people annually, but is likely underdiagnosed.

 

 
 
 #2
 most common nerve entrapment
 

 
 50-90%
 recover without surgery
 

 
 82%
 improvement with splint
You are a clinical documentation assistant for chiropractors. Generate professional medical documentation.
What causes Cubital Tunnel Syndrome: Everything You Need to Know?

Causes

 

 The ulnar nerve is vulnerable at the elbow for several reasons:

 
 Bent ElbowMost Common

 When the elbow is bent, the ulnar nerve is stretched and compressed. Prolonged elbow flexion (sleeping,
 phone, keyboard) is the main cause.

 

 
 Leaning on the Elbow

 Leaning your elbow on armrests, tables, or car door armrests over time puts direct pressure on the
 nerve.

 

 
 Anatomical Factors

 Some people naturally have a narrow cubital tunnel or a nerve that "jumps" out of its groove when the
 elbow bends.

 

 
 Previous Injuries

 Elbow fractures, dislocations, or arthritis can narrow the tunnel and irritate the nerve.

 

 Important Risk Factors

 
 Office work: Prolonged keyboard use with bent elbows (see also mouse arm)

 Sleeping habits: Sleeping with arms under head/pillow

 Phone use: Long conversations with bent elbow

 Rheumatoid arthritis: Can cause swelling around the nerve

 Diabetes: Increases the risk of nerve problems in general

Describe treatment options for Cubital Tunnel Syndrome: Everything You Need to Know.

The Towel Trick and Treatment

 

 Most people with cubital tunnel syndrome recover without surgery. The key is to keep the elbow
 straight, especially at night.

 
 The Towel Trick - Simple and Effective

 
 Roll a towel into a cylinder

 Place it on the inside of the elbow (in the elbow crease)

 Secure loosely with tape, bandage, or stretch wrap

 Use every night during sleep

 
 Result: Studies show 82% improvement with this simple method combined
 with activity modification.

 

 Treatment Plan with Chiropractor Mads Finstad

 
 1. Activity ModificationMost Important

 Identify and modify activities that worsen symptoms. Avoid prolonged elbow flexion and leaning on the
 elbow.

 

 
 2. Night Splint / Towel Trick

 Keeps the elbow in a straight position during sleep. Often all that's needed for mild to moderate
 symptoms.

 

 
 3. Nerve Glide Exercises

 Gentle exercises that mobilize the ulnar nerve through its path from neck to hand.

 

 
 4. Manual Treatment

 Soft tissue treatment of surrounding muscles, mobilization of elbow and neck.

 

 When is Surgery Considered?

 
 Symptoms that persist despite 3-6 months of conservative treatment

 Constant numbness

 Visible muscle wasting

 Significant weakness in the hand

Describe Frequently Asked Questions for Cubital Tunnel Syndrome: Everything You Need to Know.

Frequently Asked Questions

 

 
 Why does my little finger fall asleep at night?

 When you sleep with bent elbows, the ulnar nerve is stretched and compressed. This
 causes tingling and numbness in the little finger and ring finger. Keeping the elbow straight at night
 (e.g., with a towel) can help significantly.

 

 
 What's the difference between cubital and carpal tunnel syndrome?

 Cubital tunnel syndrome affects the ulnar nerve at the ELBOW and causes symptoms
 in the little finger and ring finger. Carpal tunnel syndrome
 affects the median nerve at the WRIST and causes symptoms in the thumb, index, middle and ring fingers.
 

 

 
 Do I need surgery?

 Most people don't. 50-90% recover with conservative treatment such as the towel
 trick and activity modification. Surgery is only considered for severe or prolonged symptoms without
 improvement.

 

 
 How long does it take to get better?

 Mild symptoms can improve within weeks. Moderate symptoms typically take 2-3
 months with consistent treatment. The earlier you start, the faster the improvement.

 

 
 Can symptoms come from the neck?

 Yes, C8 nerve root irritation from the neck can cause similar symptoms. A thorough
 examination can distinguish between these. Some have both conditions simultaneously ("double crush").

Describe What is golfer's elbow? for Golfer's Elbow: Everything You Need to Know.

What is golfer's elbow?

 

 Golfer's elbow, or medial epicondylitis, is a painful condition that affects the tendon attachment on the
 inside of the elbow. This is where the muscles that flex the wrist and fingers attach -
 the muscles you use when gripping, squeezing, and twisting.
 

 Just like tennis elbow, golfer's elbow is not an inflammation, but a degenerative
 condition (tendinosis). The tendon gradually breaks down over time due to overuse, without sufficient time
 to repair itself.

What causes Golfer's Elbow: Everything You Need to Know?

Causes and risk factors

 

 Over 90% of golfer's elbow cases are caused by work-related factors - not golf. The most
 common causes are:

 
 Repetitive manual work Most common

 Manual labor like carpentry, plumbing, painting. Repetitive gripping and twisting movements over time.
 

 

 
 Office work

 Prolonged mouse and keyboard use, especially with poor ergonomics. Often combined with tennis elbow.
 See our article on mouse arm.

 

 
 Throwing sports

 Baseball, handball, javelin throwing. Repetitive throwing motions strain the inside of the elbow.

 

 
 Golf (5-10% of cases)

 Actually only a small proportion. Most common in beginners with incorrect technique.

Describe The ulnar nerve - the hidden factor for Golfer's Elbow: Everything You Need to Know.

The ulnar nerve - the hidden factor

 

 What distinguishes golfer's elbow from tennis elbow is its proximity to the ulnar nerve
 - the nerve that goes to the little finger and ring finger. This nerve passes right behind the bony
 prominence on the inside of the elbow (where it hurts when you hit your "funny bone").

 
 Important to know

 Studies show that 20-60% of patients with golfer's elbow also have symptoms from the
 ulnar nerve. This can affect treatment choices and prognosis.

 

 
 Signs of ulnar nerve involvement

 
 Tingling or numbness in little finger and ring finger

 Weakness in grip - things "slip out of your hand"

 Difficulty spreading fingers apart

 Symptoms that worsen with bent elbow (e.g., during sleep)

 
 

 If you have these symptoms in addition to elbow pain, it's important to get a thorough examination that
 includes nerve tests. Treatment must then also address the nerve irritation.

 
 Cubital tunnel syndrome

 When the ulnar nerve is significantly involved, it's called cubital tunnel syndrome.
 This is the second most common nerve entrapment syndrome after carpal tunnel. Read more in our article on cubital tunnel syndrome.

Describe treatment options for Golfer's Elbow: Everything You Need to Know.

Evidence-based treatment

 

 The good news: 85-96% of patients with golfer's elbow recover with conservative
 treatment. Surgery is rarely necessary.

 
 Gold standard: Eccentric training

 
 Gradual strengthening of the flexor tendons

 Stimulates collagen production and tendon building

 Eccentric "wrist curls" with light weight

 3 sets x 15 repetitions, 2 times daily

 
 

 Treatment plan at Chiropractor Mads Finstad

 
 1. Thorough examination

 Assess whether the ulnar nerve is involved, rule out differential diagnoses, and map provoking factors.
 

 

 
 2. Manual treatment

 Soft tissue treatment of trigger points in the flexor muscles,
 mobilization of elbow and wrist, possibly nerve gliding for the ulnar nerve.

 

 
 3. Eccentric training Most Important

 Structured training program focusing on eccentric loading of the flexors. Reverse wrist curls with
 gradually increased resistance.

 

 
 4. Ergonomic guidance

 Identify and modify provoking activities at work and leisure.

 

 
 Eccentric wrist curl for golfer's elbow

 
 Sit with your forearm on a table, palm up, wrist over the edge of the table

 Hold a light weight (0.5-1 kg) in your hand

 Start with wrist flexed up

 Lower the weight slowly (3-4 seconds) until wrist is extended

 Use the other hand to lift back to start

 Repeat 15 times, 3 sets, 2 times daily

 
 Tip: Some discomfort is OK, but stop at sharp pain.

Describe Frequently Asked Questions for Golfer's Elbow: Everything You Need to Know.

Frequently Asked Questions

 

 
 What's the difference between golfer's elbow and tennis elbow?

 Golfer's elbow causes pain on the INSIDE of the elbow and affects the flexor
 muscles (that flex the wrist). Tennis elbow causes pain on the OUTSIDE and affects the extensor muscles
 (that extend the wrist). The treatment principles are similar.

 

 
 Can I have both golfer's and tennis elbow at the same time?

 Yes, this is not uncommon, especially with office work. Both flexors and extensors
 can become overloaded simultaneously. Treatment must then address both sides.

 

 
 Why are my fingers tingling?

 Tingling in the little finger and ring finger indicates that the ulnar nerve is
 involved. This occurs in 20-60% of patients with golfer's elbow. The nerve passes right by the tender
 area and can become irritated.

 

 
 Should I use an elbow brace?

 A golfer's elbow brace can provide symptomatic relief. It should be placed about
 2-3 cm below the elbow on the inside. Use it as a supplement to training, not as the a key treatment approach.
 

 

 
 Can I continue to exercise?

 Yes, but avoid exercises that provoke pain. Bicep curls and pulling exercises can
 be problematic. Focus on rehabilitation exercises and temporarily modify strength training.

 

 
 Do I need surgery?

 Rarely. 85-96% recover without surgery. Surgery is only considered for prolonged
 problems (over 12 months) without effect from thorough conservative treatment.

What is Mouse Arm?

 

 Mouse arm is a collective term for pain and problems in the arm, wrist, and hand related to computer
 work. Medical terms include:

 
 WRULD: Work-Related Upper Limb Disorders

 RSI: Repetitive Strain Injury

 Overuse injuries: Overuse problems in the upper extremities

 

 The condition can include everything from diffuse pain without a specific diagnosis, to defined
 conditions such as tennis elbow, golfer's
 elbow, carpal tunnel syndrome, or De Quervain's tenosynovitis.

What causes Mouse Arm and Office Injuries: What Actually Works?

Causes

 

 Mouse arm develops gradually through a combination of factors:

 
 Static Muscle Work (Main Cause)

 Holding the arm in the same position hour after hour creates constant low-intensity strain on the
 muscles - this is more damaging than previously thought.

 

 
 Repetitive Movements

 Thousands of small movements daily - mouse clicks, keystrokes - accumulate strain over time.

 

 
 Poor Ergonomics

 Wrong height of chair, screen, or keyboard increases the strain. But ergonomics alone doesn't solve the
 problem.

 

 
 Lack of Breaks

 Working for long periods without breaks doesn't give the tissue time to rest and repair itself.

Describe The Myth About Ergonomics for Mouse Arm and Office Injuries: What Actually Works.

The Myth About Ergonomics

 

 Here comes the surprising truth: ergonomics alone does not have strong evidence for preventing or
 treating mouse arm.

 
 What the Research Shows

 Systematic reviews (Cochrane) have examined all available research and conclude:

 
 Ergonomic adjustments alone have insufficient evidence for effect

 Ergonomic equipment (mouse, keyboard, chairs) provides no documented improvement in
 symptoms

 The combination of ergonomics + training gives better results than ergonomics alone

 
 

 This doesn't mean ergonomics is unimportant - it means you need more than just
 ergonomics.

Describe What Actually Works for Mouse Arm and Office Injuries: What Actually Works.

What Actually Works

 

 
 Strength Training - Only Strong Evidence

 
 Strength training for neck, shoulders, and arms is the only intervention
 with strong evidence

 Increases muscle capacity to tolerate static strain

 Reduces pain and increases function

 Recommended 2-3 times weekly

 
 

 Effective Combination Treatment

 
 1. Strength Training (Most Important)

 Specific exercises for neck, shoulders, forearm, and hand. Gradual increase in load.

 

 
 2. Micro-breaks

 Short breaks (30-60 seconds) every 20-30 minutes. Shake out your arms, move your fingers, look away
 from the screen.

 

 
 3. Variation

 Alternate between sitting and standing work, switch between mouse and keyboard, use both hands.

 

 
 4. Ergonomics (as a Supplement)

 Correct screen height, keyboard position, and chair settings - as an addition to training, not instead
 of it.

 

 
 5. Manual Treatment

 Soft tissue treatment of trigger points, joint mobilization,
 nerve glide techniques.

 Does an ergonomic mouse help?

 alone doesn't prevent or treat mouse arm. It should be combined with strength training and breaks.

 

 
 How often should I take breaks?

 Ideally a short micro-break (30-60 seconds) every 20-30 minutes, and a longer
 break (5-10 minutes) every hour. Move around and shake out your arms during the breaks.

 

 
 Which exercises help?

 Strength exercises for neck, shoulders, and arms are most important. Examples:

Describe What is tennis elbow? for Tennis Elbow (Lateral Epicondylitis).

What is tennis elbow?

 

 Tennis elbow, or lateral epicondylitis, is a painful condition that affects the tendon attachment on the
 outside of the elbow. This is where the muscles that extend the wrist and fingers attach - the same
 muscles you use when lifting, gripping, and twisting.

 But here's the important thing: tennis elbow is not an inflammation. Modern research has
 shown that the condition is a degeneration (wear) of the tendon, not an inflammatory process. That's why
 the term "tendinosis" has replaced "tendinitis" in professional circles (Coombes et al., 2015).

 Who is affected?

 Despite the name, ironically only 5-10% of cases are caused by tennis. Most cases arise from:

 
 Repetitive work with mouse and keyboard (mouse arm)

 Manual labor (carpentry, painting, plumbing)

 Housework and gardening

 Other sports (strength training, golf, badminton)

 

 
 
 1-3%
 of the population affected
 

 
 35-54 years
 most common age group
 

 
 90%
 dominant arm

What causes Tennis Elbow (Lateral Epicondylitis)?

Causes and risk factors

 

 Tennis elbow develops when the strain on the tendon exceeds its ability to repair itself. Over time, this
 leads to:

 
 Micro-tears in the tendon

 Small tears in the tendon tissue that accumulate over time from repetitive strain.

 

 
 Neovascularization

 Abnormal growth of blood vessels and nerve fibers - this explains why the condition is so painful.

 

 
 Collagen degeneration

 The structural fibers in the tendon break down and are replaced by disorganized, weaker tissue.

 

 Important risk factors

 
 Repetitive strain: Same movement many times a day

 Forceful gripping: Work requiring hard gripping over time

 Poor ergonomics: Wrong work position or tools

 Smokers: Have worse prognosis and longer healing time

 Age 35-54 years: Natural aging of tendon tissue

Describe The cortisone myth for Tennis Elbow (Lateral Epicondylitis).

The cortisone myth

 

 Cortisone injections have long been a popular treatment for tennis elbow. But what does the research
 actually say?

 
 The research is clear

 A landmark study from Bisset et al. (2006) showed surprising results:

 
 72% recurrence rate within 12 months after cortisone injection

 Those who received cortisone had worse long-term results than those who waited

 Cortisone provides short-term relief (2-6 weeks), but worsens the prognosis

 
 

 Why does cortisone fail?

 When we understand that tennis elbow is degeneration, not inflammation, it becomes clear why
 anti-inflammatory treatment doesn't work:

 
 Cortisone inhibits collagen synthesis - the tendon doesn't build up

 Pain relief creates false security and increased strain

 The tissue becomes weaker, not stronger

 Recurrence is almost inevitable

 

 
 What if you've already had cortisone?

 Don't despair. Many get better anyway, but it's important to start active rehabilitation as soon as
 possible. Avoid repeated injections - each new injection weakens the tendon further.

Describe The Tyler Twist Exercise for Tennis Elbow (Lateral Epicondylitis).

The Tyler Twist Exercise

 

 The Tyler Twist is the most studied and effective exercise for tennis elbow. It's performed with a
 FlexBar (rubber bar) and focuses on eccentric loading of the extensor muscles.

 
 How to do the Tyler Twist

 
 Hold the FlexBar vertically in front of you with the affected hand up (overhand grip)

 Grip around the top with the healthy hand

 Twist the FlexBar with the healthy hand while the affected hand holds against it

 Extend both arms in front of you (90 degrees)

 Slowly release with the affected hand - this is the eccentric phase

 Repeat 15 times, 3 sets, 1-2 times daily

 
 Tip: Some discomfort is normal, but sharp pain means you need to reduce the intensity.
 

 

 
 
 81%
 experienced improvement
 

 
 6-8 weeks
 for noticeable improvement
 

 
 3x15
 daily dose
 

 

 
 Don't have a FlexBar?

 You can start with "reverse wrist curls" with light weight (0.5-1 kg). Sit with your forearm on your
 thigh, wrist outside the knee, and slowly lower the weight down. This provides similar eccentric
 loading.

 Sudden onset, intense pain after trauma

 Night pain that wakes you up

Describe Frequently Asked Questions for Tennis Elbow (Lateral Epicondylitis).

Frequently Asked Questions

 

 
 How long does it take for tennis elbow to heal?

 Most people (89%) experience significant improvement within 12 months with
 conservative treatment. With active rehabilitation and eccentric exercises, improvement can be seen as
 early as 6-8 weeks.

 

 
 Should I use an elbow brace/bandage?

 A tennis elbow brace can provide symptomatic relief and make it easier to function
 in daily life. It should be placed about 2-3 cm below the elbow, not over the tender spot. Use it as a
 supplement to training, not as the a key treatment approach.

 

 
 Does cortisone help with tennis elbow?

 Cortisone often provides short-term relief (2-6 weeks), but studies show a 72%
 recurrence rate. Patients who receive cortisone often have worse long-term results than those who choose
 active rehabilitation. I recommend avoiding cortisone.

 

 
 Can I continue to exercise?

 Yes, but avoid exercises that provoke pain. Pull exercises and gripping can be
 problematic. Focus on eccentric rehabilitation exercises and temporarily modify strength training.

 

 
 What's the difference between tennis elbow and golfer's elbow?

 Tennis elbow (lateral epicondylitis) causes pain on the outside
 of the elbow and affects the extensor muscles. Golfer's elbow (medial
 epicondylitis) causes pain on the inside and affects the flexor muscles. The treatment
 principles are similar.

 

 
 Do I need surgery?

 Rarely. Only 5-10% with prolonged problems (over 12 months) without...

Describe What is thumb arthritis? for Thumb Arthritis (CMC-1): Complete Guide.

What is thumb arthritis?

 

 Thumb arthritis (CMC-1 arthritis, basal arthritis) is osteoarthritis in the joint at the base of the
 thumb - where the thumb meets the first metacarpal bone (carpometacarpal joint). This joint is
 particularly vulnerable because it gives the thumb its unique mobility, but also exposes it to great
 strain. The condition is sometimes confused with De Quervain's
 tenosynovitis or trigger finger, which also cause thumb problems.
 

 The joint has a "saddle shape" that allows movement in multiple planes. This enables gripping and
 squeezing powerfully, but also makes the joint unstable and vulnerable to wear over time.

Causes and risk factors

 

 
 Genetics (39-65% hereditary)

 Heredity is by far the most important factor. If your mother has thumb arthritis, your risk is
 significantly increased.

 

 
 Gender

 Women are affected 2-3 times more often than men. Hormones and joint laxity play a role.

 

 
 Age

 Most common after 50, but X-ray findings can be found as early as the 40s.

 

 
 Load

 Heavy manual work and repetitive gripping movements over time increase risk somewhat. This is similar
 to the causation pattern for mouse arm and other overuse conditions in the arm.

Describe What is trigger finger? for Trigger Finger: Complete Guide.

What is trigger finger?

 

 Trigger finger (stenosing tenosynovitis) occurs when the flexor tendon in the finger becomes too thick to
 glide freely through the tendon sheath. The tendon "catches" at the A1 pulley at the finger base, and the
 finger locks in a bent position. A similar mechanism is seen in De Quervain's
 tenosynovitis in the thumb.

 When you try to straighten the finger, the tendon must pass the narrowing - and this causes the
 characteristic "triggering" or clicking sound.

 
 
 2-3%
 of population affected
 

 
 6x
 more common in women
 

 
 Thumb
 most commonly affected

What causes Trigger Finger: Complete Guide?

Causes and risk factors

 

 
 Repetitive gripping (Most common)

 Repeated gripping movements over time irritate the tendon sheath and cause thickening. Same mechanism
 as in mouse arm and other overuse conditions.

 

 
 Diabetes

 Significantly increased risk - up to 10% of diabetics develop trigger finger. Diabetes also increases
 risk of carpal tunnel syndrome.

 

 
 Rheumatoid arthritis

 Inflammatory joint diseases increase risk of tendon disease.

 

 
 Hormonal factors

 Women are affected 6 times more often than men, especially during menopause.

Symptoms

 

 
 Clicking/locking when bending and straightening finger

 Morning stiffness - often worst first hour after waking

 Tenderness at finger base (A1 pulley)

 Nodule that can be felt where tendon is thickened

 Locked finger in severe cases - must be straightened with other hand

 

 
 KANAVEL'S SIGNS - EMERGENCY

 
 Swollen, red, warm finger

 Intense pain on passive extension

 Finger held in semi-flexed position

 Tenderness along entire tendon

 
 These signs may indicate infectious
 tenosynovitis (pyogenic flexor tenosynovitis) - a surgical emergency. Call emergency services
 immediately.

Treatment

 

 
 Prognosis is good

 
 52% of mild cases resolve spontaneously

 63-80% recover with cortisone

 Surgery has >90% success rate for the rest

 
 

 Treatment ladder

 
 1. Rest and splinting

 Finger splint that keeps finger straight at night. Often sufficient for mild cases.

 

 
 2. Cortisone (Effective)

 Cortisone injection into tendon sheath has 63-80% success rate. Can be repeated 1-2 times.

 

 
 3. Surgery

 A1 pulley release - a simple outpatient procedure with >90% success.

 

 
 Shockwave therapy (ESWT)

 A systematic review from Brancaccio et al. (2024) concludes that ESWT has no proven

What are trigger points?

 

 Trigger points are hypersensitive areas in muscle fibers - often described as "knots" or "tightness."
 When you press on a trigger point, it causes characteristic pain, and often also referred
 pain - pain that radiates to other areas.

 There are two main types:

 
 Active trigger points Cause symptoms

 Cause spontaneous pain and referred pain. Can disturb sleep and affect daily function.

 

 
 Latent trigger points

 Only tender when pressed. Can limit mobility and weaken the muscle, but don't cause spontaneous pain.

Describe Why do trigger points develop? for Trigger Points in Arm and Forearm.

Why do trigger points develop?

 

 Trigger points develop when muscle fibers become overloaded or damaged. The most common causes in arm and
 forearm:

 
 Repetitive movements: Mouse use, keyboard, manual work
 

 Static loading: Holding arm in same position over time

 Acute overload: Lifting, unaccustomed activity

 Poor ergonomics: Wrong work position at computer

 Stress and tension: Elevated muscle tension over time

 Cold: Drafts or cold exposure

 

 
 What happens in the muscle?

 Trigger points develop when motor end plates (where nerve meets muscle) become overactive. This leads
 to sustained contraction of muscle fibers, reduced blood flow, and accumulation of waste products. The
 result is a tender, tight knot.

Describe Referred pain - pain in the wrong place for Trigger Points in Arm and Forearm.

Referred pain - pain in the wrong place

 

 The most confusing thing about trigger points is referred pain: pain is felt in a
 completely different place from where the problem is. This explains why many get the wrong diagnosis.

 
 Common referred pain patterns in the arm

 
 Extensors (top of forearm): Referred pain to elbow and back of hand - resembles tennis elbow

 Flexors (underside of forearm): Referred pain to wrist and fingers - resembles carpal tunnel

 Brachioradialis: Referred pain to thumb base and wrist

 Scalene muscles (neck): Referred pain down into arm and fingers - resembles
 radiculopathy

 Subscapularis (shoulder): Referred pain to wrist and back of upper arm

 
 

 
 Common misdiagnoses

 Because of referred pain, trigger points are often misdiagnosed as:

 
 Tennis elbow (lateral epicondylitis)

 Carpal tunnel syndrome

 Cervical radiculopathy (neck nerve root)

 De Quervain's tenosynovitis

 Frozen shoulder

 Effective treatment methods

 Self-massage technique

 The condition is divided into two main types based on where in the tendon the problem is located:

 
 
 Mid-portion tendinopathy

 2-6 cm above the heel attachment. Accounts for about 64% of cases and is most common
 in runners and athletes.

 

 
 Insertional tendinopathy

 At the attachment to the heel bone. Accounts for about 28% of cases and is more
 often associated with heel spur (Haglund's deformity). Can be confused with plantar fasciopathy which also causes heel pain.

 65% of cases occur independently of sports activity (de Jonge 2011). This means it's
 not just a "sports injury". Prevalence increases from 2% under 18 years to 8% over 45 years.

Symptoms

 

 The classic symptom picture in Achilles tendinopathy is quite characteristic:

 
 Morning stiffness - stiffness and discomfort in the tendon for the first few minutes
 after getting up, which gradually decreases with movement

 "Warm-up phenomenon" - pain when starting activity that decreases after a few
 minutes, then returns after rest

 Localized tenderness - when palpating the tendon, either 2-6 cm above the heel
 (mid-portion) or at the attachment

 Pain with loading - especially with heel raises, stair climbing, running or jumping
 

 Possible swelling - visible thickening of the tendon in some cases

 

 
 Important distinction

 Symptoms typically develop gradually over weeks to months. Sudden onset of pain with an audible
 "snap" indicates rupture and requires acute evaluation.

What causes Achilles Tendinopathy?

Causes and Risk Factors

 

 Achilles tendinopathy occurs when the load on the tendon exceeds its adaptation capacity over time.

 Risk factors ranked by strength of evidence

 
 Sudden increase in training load - the clearly most common triggering factor. Classic
 example: From couch potato to half marathon in 8 weeks

 Age over 30 years - prevalence increases from 2% under 18 years to 8% over 45 years
 

 Previous tendon injury - significantly increased risk of new episodes

 Overweight (BMI > 25) - moderate evidence for association. Overweight is also a risk
 factor for other foot problems like metatarsalgia

 Metabolic conditions - diabetes and high cholesterol negatively affect tendon health
 

 Fluoroquinolone antibiotics - increase the risk of tendon problems by a
 factor of 3.14. Especially important in patients over 60 years
 

 

 
 Gender differences

 Research shows no significant difference between men and women when it comes to
 tendinopathy. This contrasts with Achilles tendon rupture, where men dominate with a ratio of 3.5-5.5:1.

Treatment

 

 The cornerstone of Achilles tendinopathy treatment is progressive loading training. This
 may sound counterintuitive - why load a painful tendon? However, the research is clear: tendons need
 controlled loading to adapt and become stronger.

 Finding the right balance between activity and rest, with gradual progression

 Assessment and treatment of ankle joint with reduced mobility

 

 

 
 5

 May be considered for chronic cases, especially in combination with exercises

 

 

 

 The two gold standard protocols

 
 1. Alfredson Eccentric Protocol (Sweden, 1998)

 Eccentric heel drops from a stair edge:

 
 3 sets x 15 repetitions, with both straight and bent knee

 Twice daily (total 180 repetitions)

 Exercises performed in the pain zone (0-5/10)

 Weight increased gradually

 
 60% success after 4 months vs 24% for "wait and see" (Rompe 2007)

 

 
 2. Heavy Slow Resistance (Denmark, 2015)

 Three exercises with heavy loading:

 
 Seated heel raise, leg press heel raise, standing heel raise

 3 times per week

 Slow movements (3 sec up, 3 sec down)

 Progression from 15RM to 6RM over 12 weeks

Describe Frequently Asked Questions for Achilles Tendinopathy.

Frequently Asked Questions

 

 
 Can I continue to exercise with Achilles tendinopathy?

 Yes, in most cases. Silbernagel's pain monitoring model (2007) shows that
 continued activity is safe as long as pain stays below 5/10 during exercise and doesn't worsen the next
 day. You may need to adjust type, duration or intensity temporarily.

 

 
 Is there inflammation in my tendon?

 No, despite many calling it "tendinitis". Modern research shows that Achilles
 tendinopathy is primarily a degenerative process with changes in tendon structure, not classic
 inflammation. This is also why anti-inflammatory medications have limited effect.

 

 
 Do I need an MRI or ultrasound?

 Rarely. The diagnosis is made clinically, and imaging usually doesn't change the
 treatment plan. Important to know: 46% of symptom-free runners have tendon changes on ultrasound.
 Imaging is primarily done when rupture is suspected, for uncertain diagnoses, or for surgical
 evaluation.

 

 
 Do heel lifts or orthotic insoles help?

 The evidence is limited. Heel lifts can provide temporary pain relief by reducing
 the stretch on the tendon, but should be viewed as a supplement to - not a replacement for -
 exercise-based treatment.

 

 
 How long until I recover?

 It depends on duration and severity. Acute cases (< 6 weeks) can improve in 6-12
 weeks, while chronic cases often require 3-6 months - sometimes up to a year. The key is patience and
 consistent completion of the exercise program.

What is chronic ankle instability?

 

 Chronic ankle instability (CAI) is defined as repeated episodes where the ankle "gives way," persistent
 feeling of instability, and/or repeated sprains - at least 12 months after the original injury.

 
 Mechanical Instability

 Loose ligaments that allow abnormal movement in the ankle joint. Detected by clinical tests such as
 anterior drawer and talar tilt.

 

 
 Functional Instability (most common)

 Damaged proprioception (position sense), delayed muscle reaction and reduced neuromuscular control. Can
 occur without mechanical laxity.

What causes Chronic Ankle Instability?

Causes and Risk Factors

 

 Chronic ankle instability usually develops after one or more ankle sprains that have not healed
 optimally. The condition can also occur in connection with other foot problems such as Achilles tendinopathy or tibialis posterior tendinopathy.

 What happens in the ankle?

 
 Damaged proprioception: The receptors in ligaments and joint capsule that register
 position and movement function poorly

 Delayed muscle reaction: The peroneal muscles (on the outside of the lower leg) don't
 react quickly enough when off balance

 Weak muscles: Reduced strength in stabilizing muscles

 Altered movement patterns: Compensatory gait patterns and posture

 

 
 Risk Factors for Developing CAI

 
 Inadequate rehabilitation after first sprain

 Too early return to activity

 Previous sprains (risk increases with each injury)

 High BMI

 General hypermobility (overly flexible joints)

 Sports with quick direction changes

Treatment

 

 Conservative treatment is the first choice and gives good results in most people.

 
 Evidence-Based Treatment

 
 Balance training: Gold standard - rebuilds proprioception and neuromuscular control
 

 Strength training: Focus on peroneal and calf muscles

 Functional training: Sport-specific exercises with increasing difficulty

 Manual therapy: Mobilization of stiff joints, soft tissue treatment

 Taping/orthoses: Can provide extra support during the rehabilitation phase

 
 

 
 Home Exercise: Single-leg Balance

 
 Stand on the affected leg with a slight bend in the knee

 Hold balance for 30 seconds

 Progression: Close your eyes, stand on a pillow, throw a ball

 Do 3 sets, 2-3 times daily

 
 Tip: Start near a wall for safety. The goal is to make it challenging but achievable.
 

 

 When is surgery considered?

 Surgery is only considered after at least 6 months of failed conservative treatment. The most common
 procedures are:

 
 Brostrom procedure: Reconstruction of lateral ligaments

 Anatomical reconstruction: For severe instability

Injury Grading

 

 Ankle sprains are classified into three grades based on severity:

 
 
 Grade I (mild)

 Mild stretching, minimal swelling, can bear weight1-3 weeks healing

 

 
 Grade II (moderate)

 Partial tear, moderate swelling, reduced stability3-6 weeks healing

 

 
 Grade III (severe)

 Complete tear, significant instability6-12 weeks or more

 

 

 
 Diagnosis

 Clinical examination is the cornerstone. Ottawa Ankle Rules have 97.6% sensitivity for
 detecting fractures and are used to determine if X-ray is necessary. This approach reduces unnecessary
 X-rays by 30-40%.

 X-ray is only indicated with bone tenderness along the posterior edge of the
 ankle bones or inability to take four steps. With persistent pain after a sprain, stress fracture should be ruled out.

Describe treatment options for Ankle Sprains.

Treatment: The POLICE Protocol

 

 In 2012, Bleakley and colleagues published a paradigm shift in acute treatment: The POLICE
 protocol replaces traditional RICE. The main difference is that "rest" is replaced with
 "protection" and "optimal loading".

 A randomized study from 2023 showed that POLICE provides faster and better functional recovery than
 PRICE.

 
 The POLICE Protocol

 
 P
 
 Protection

 Use elastic bandage or aircast for support

 

 

 
 OL
 
 Optimal Loading

 Gentle movement within pain limits from day 1

 

 

 
 I
 
 Ice

 15-20 minutes with ice pack in towel, 3-4 times daily

 

 

 
 C
 
 Compression

 Elastic bandage (not too tight)

 

 

 
 E
 
 Elevation
 Keep the foot higher than heart level when resting

 

 

 

 
 What can the chiropractor do?

 Manual therapy and joint mobilization have moderate evidence for ankle sprains.
 Systematic reviews show improved dorsiflexion and reduced pain perception.

 
 Assess the severity of the injury

 Rule out fractures using Ottawa Ankle Rules

 Provide manual treatment to improve mobility

 Guide through a tailored rehabilitation program

Rehabilitation: Three Phases

 

 
 1 Mobility and Pain Control (week 1)

 
 Ankle alphabet: Write the letters A-Z with your foot, 3-4 times daily

 Ankle rotations: 10-15 circles in each direction

 Isometric exercises: Press the foot against a wall without movement, hold 5-10
 seconds

 
 

 
 2 Strength and Proprioception (weeks 2-6)

 
 Resistance band exercises: In all directions, 3 sets x 15 repetitions

 Single-leg balance: Start with 20 seconds, gradually increase to 60 seconds

 Heel raises: 3 sets x 15 repetitions

 
 

 
 3 Functional Training (week 6+)

 
 Balance on unstable surface (BOSU ball, balance pad)

 Side movements and lateral shuffle

 Gradual return to running and sport-specific training

 
 

 
 Important: Balance training prevents recurrence

 Proprioceptive training reduces the risk of new sprains by 35% according to a
 meta-analysis of 7 studies with 3726 participants. Continue with balance exercises even after the pain
