What is the prognosis for Ankle Sprains?

Prognosis

 

 With proper rehabilitation, most ankle sprains have a good prognosis. Approximately 90% of grade
 III injuries achieve good results with conservative treatment. Surgery is reserved for
 persistent instability after 3-6 months of failed conservative treatment.

 
 Chronic Ankle Instability (CAI)

 Without adequate rehabilitation, 40% of patients develop chronic ankle instability within 12 months of the first
 sprain. CAI is characterized by recurrent sprains, giving way episodes, and persistent functional
 impairment.

 

 Prevention of Recurrence

 
 Balance training: 35% reduction in risk of new sprains

 Ankle brace or taping: 69-71% reduction in previously injured athletes

 Continue with strength and balance exercises even after the pain is gone

 

 
 Long-term Perspective

 At 1-4 year follow-up, 74% have at least one residual symptom. Post-traumatic ankle osteoarthritis is a
 serious long-term complication - lateral ankle sprains are the main cause of ligamentous ankle
 osteoarthritis. Long-term loading abnormalities can also lead to secondary problems such as tibialis posterior tendinopathy.

 Grade I: 1-3 weeks. Grade II: 3-6 weeks. Grade III: 6-12 weeks or more. Healing

 Can I exercise with a sprained ankle?

 Modern treatment (POLICE protocol) recommends early, gentle movement within pain
 limits from day 1. Complete rest is no longer recommended. You can often continue with activities that
 don't load the ankle, such as cycling or swimming, relatively early in the process.

 

 
 How do I prevent new sprains?

 Balance training provides 35% reduction in risk of new sprains. Ankle braces or
 taping provide 69-71% reduction in previously injured athletes. Continue with strength and balance

What is hallux rigidus?

 

 Hallux rigidus is osteoarthritis in the big toe's base joint - the joint where the big toe attaches to
 the midfoot. This joint is essential for normal walking, as it bends up to 60 degrees with each step.

 When the cartilage in the joint wears down, inflammation, pain and eventually bone spurs (osteophytes)
 develop around the joint. These bone spurs further restrict movement and can cause a visible bump on top
 of the joint.

 Grade 2

 Symptoms typically develop gradually over time, but can also occur more acutely after injury or overuse.

 of the joint. X-rays confirm the diagnosis and show the degree of arthritis.

 Differential diagnoses include gout, infection and

 Osteoarthritis in the base joint

 Big toe angles toward the other toes

 Can hallux rigidus improve without surgery?

 Yes, many experience significant improvement with conservative treatment,
 especially in early stages (grades 1-2). Mobilization, proper footwear, insoles and exercises can
 substantially reduce pain and improve function. The condition isn't "cured," but symptoms can be well
 controlled.

 

 
 What is the difference between hallux rigidus and hallux valgus?

 Hallux rigidus is osteoarthritis with stiffness in the big toe's base joint - the
 toe usually remains straight but becomes stiff. Hallux valgus (bunion) is a malalignment where the big
 toe bends toward the other toes and causes a bump on the inside of the foot. Both can cause pain, but
 the causes and treatment are different.

 

 
 Which shoes are best for hallux rigidus?

 Choose shoes with a stiff sole (rocker-sole), roomy toe box and low heel. The
 shoes shouldn't bend much at the big toe. Avoid high heels and flexible soles that force the joint to
 bend. Special insoles (Morton's extension) can be helpful.

 

 
 How long does it take for hallux rigidus to get worse?

 Progression varies greatly from person to person. Some remain stable for many
 years, while others experience gradual worsening over months to years. Early treatment, activity
 adaptation and proper footwear can significantly slow the progression.

 

 
 Can I exercise with hallux rigidus?

 Yes, but choose activities that don't stress the big toe's base joint too much...

What causes Hallux Valgus (Bunion)?

Causes and Risk Factors

 

 Hallux valgus is caused by an interplay between genetic factors and external influences. Research shows
 that heredity plays a significant role, but footwear and loading affect the progression.

 
 Genetics (63-90% heritability)

 Twin studies show a strong hereditary component. If parents have hallux valgus, the risk is
 significantly higher.

 

 
 Footwear

 Tight, pointed shoes and high heels significantly increase risk. High heels shift 70-80% of body weight
 to the forefoot.

 

 
 Ligament laxity (hypermobility)

 Allows increased movement in the MTP joint that predisposes to deformity.

 

 
 Flat foot (pes planus)

 Overpronation leads to increased loading on the inside of the big toe. See also tibialis posterior tendinopathy which can cause
 acquired flat foot.

 

 
 Why are women affected more often?

 Women are affected 2-3 times more often than men. This is probably due to a combination of:

 
 Higher use of tight shoes and high heels

 More loose ligaments (hypermobility)

 Hormonal factors affecting connective tissue

 Anatomical differences in foot structure

 
 

 Severity Grading

 Hallux valgus is graded by the angle between the big toe and metatarsal bone axis (HVA):

 
 
 Mild

 HVA under 20 degreesMinimal visible deformity

 

 
 Moderate

 HVA 20-40 degreesClear bump visible

 

 
 Severe

 HVA over 40 degreesBig toe overlaps 2nd toe

 Progressive Condition

 Without intervention, hallux valgus tends to gradually worsen. Studies show the angle increases by
 about 1-2 degrees per year in untreated cases. Early intervention with conservative measures can slow or

 Proper Footwear

 Protective Padding

 Metatarsalgia is not a specific diagnosis, but a collective term for pain located in the forefoot - the
 area under the metatarsal heads (ball of the foot). This is where the long midfoot bones (metatarsals)
 meet the toes.

 The pain usually occurs when this area becomes overloaded. Over time, this can lead to soft tissue
 irritation, joint capsule inflammation, or stress reactions in the bone.

 metatarsal most often affected

 affected more often than men

 improve conservatively

What causes Metatarsalgia?

Causes and Risk Factors

 

 Metatarsalgia develops when the forefoot is exposed to abnormally high or prolonged loading.

 Common Causes

 
 Improper FootwearMost common cause

 High-heeled shoes, too tight shoes, or shoes without adequate cushioning significantly increase the
 load on the forefoot.

 

 
 Biomechanical Factors

 High arch (pes cavus), stiff ankle, long 2nd toe (Morton's toe), or hypermobile joints can lead to
 uneven load distribution.

 

 
 Overuse

 Too rapid increase in activity, prolonged standing work, or intensive running training can overload the
 forefoot.

 

 
 Hallux ValgusOften
 concurrent

 A crooked big toe causes weight to shift to the 2nd and 3rd metatarsal, which become overloaded. Hallux rigidus can cause similar loading changes.

 

 
 Risk Factors

 
 Overweight (increased load per step)

 Age over 50 (thinner fat pads under the foot)

 High heels (shift weight forward)

 Diabetes (altered sensation and blood flow)

 Rheumatoid arthritis

 Sports with lots of running and jumping - can also lead to Achilles tendinopathy or stress fracture

Prognosis and Prevention

 

 With proper treatment, the vast majority with metatarsalgia have a good prognosis. Over 90% improve with

Describe Frequently Asked Questions for Metatarsalgia.

Frequently Asked Questions

 

 
 Can I exercise with metatarsalgia?

 Yes, but avoid activities that provoke the pain. Swimming and cycling are often
 well tolerated. For running: consider surface, shoes, and reduce distance until pain subsides.

 

 
 Do insoles help?

 Yes, insoles with a metatarsal pad can significantly offload the forefoot. The pad
 is placed behind (proximal to) the metatarsal heads to lift them and reduce pressure.

 

 
 Do I have to stop wearing high heels?

 High heels shift weight forward and dramatically increase the load on the
 forefoot. Limit use, especially during prolonged standing or walking. Consider wider heels rather than
 stilettos.

 

 
 Do I need X-ray or MRI?

 Usually not for typical metatarsalgia. Imaging may be relevant if stress fracture,
 neuroma, or if treatment doesn't help after 6-8 weeks.

 

 
 Can metatarsalgia come back?

 Yes, if the causative factors are not corrected. Continue with good shoes,
 maintain foot muscles with exercises, and avoid sudden increases in activity.

What causes Morton's Neuroma?

Causes and Risk Factors

 

 Tight shoes with narrow toe box - main cause

 Repeated compression of the nerve between the metatarsal bones during walking causes microtrauma,
 subsequent fibrosis and demyelination. Biomechanical studies show that high heels shift 28% of
 body weight to the forefoot in flat shoes, versus 66% in high heels.

 Other risk factors

 
 Hallux valgus (bunion): Up to 80% of patients with
 Morton's neuroma have concurrent hallux valgus

 Hammer toes and other toe deformities: Create back pressure against the forefoot

 Flat foot and high arch: Associated with altered forefoot mechanics (see also tibialis posterior tendinopathy)

 Sports and activity: Running, ballet, tennis, skiing and climbing - these activities
 can also cause Achilles tendinopathy or stress fracture

Describe symptoms and signs of Morton's Neuroma.

Symptoms

 

 Typical symptoms include burning, stinging or electric pain in the forefoot - most often
 between the 3rd and 4th toe. Similar symptoms can be seen with metatarsalgia, but with a different cause.

 Common symptoms

 
 "Stone under the foot" feeling - classic symptom (43-53%)

 Numbness or tingling radiating into the toes (33-60%)

 Pain worsened by tight shoes and relieved when shoes are removed (81-89%)

 Pain during walking has high sensitivity (91%)

 Symptoms can be intermittent or constant

 Night pain occurs in only about 25% with Morton's neuroma. If night pain is prominent,

How is Morton's Neuroma diagnosed?

Diagnosis

 

 The diagnosis is made primarily clinically. Two tests are particularly useful:

 
 Mulder's sign

 Lateral compression of the forefoot while palpating the interspace. A positive test produces a palpable
 "click" sensation. 62% sensitivity and 100% specificity - very reliable when positive.
 

 

 
 Thumb-index finger squeeze test

 Shows well-suited diagnostic accuracy with 96% sensitivity and 100% specificity. A
 negative test practically rules out Morton's neuroma.

 

 Imaging

 Ultrasound is the first choice when imaging is needed, with 90-91% sensitivity. Neuromas
 >3 mm are considered significant, and lesions >5 mm are more often symptomatic.

 MRI is preferred when there is a need to rule out other pathology or for surgical planning.

Prognosis

 Recurrence

Describe Frequently Asked Questions for Morton's Neuroma.

Frequently Asked Questions

 

 
 Can Morton's neuroma go away on its own?

 The condition develops gradually and rarely resolves completely without
 intervention. With early intervention (footwear change, adapted pads), however, many can achieve symptom
 control without further treatment.

 

 
 How long does it take for treatment to work?

 With manual treatment, many see improvement within 4-6 treatments. 79% achieved
 complete pain relief within 6 treatments. Footwear changes and orthotics often need 4-6 weeks for full
 effect.

 

 
 Do I need an MRI or ultrasound?

 Not necessarily. Clinical examination with thumb-index finger squeeze test has 96%
 sensitivity and can often confirm the diagnosis. Imaging is most relevant for uncertain diagnoses,
 injection planning, or possible surgery.

 

 
 Can I continue to exercise?

 Activities that don't provoke pain can often be continued. Running and activities
 with high forefoot loading may need to be modified temporarily. Shoes with wide toe box are especially
 important during exercise.

 

 
 Does cortisone help?

 Ultrasound-guided cortisone injection can provide short-term relief (1-3 months),
 but long-term effectiveness is limited. About 30% eventually need surgery despite injections.

 

 
 What about surgery?

 Surgery is considered after 6-12 months without sufficient effect from
 conservative treatment. The success rate is high (74% complete pain relief), but involves expected
 numbness in the supplied toes.

Describe Exercise 1: Short Foot for Foot Exercises That Work: Exercises for Stronger Feet.

Exercise 1: Short Foot

 

 Short foot is the most fundamental exercise for foot health. It activates the intrinsic muscles that support the arch - muscles that are often "switched off" after years in supportive shoes.

 
 How to Perform Short Foot

 
 Starting position: Sit on a chair with your foot flat on the floor

 Movement: Draw the forefoot toward the heel by "shortening" the foot

 Focus: Lift the arch without curling the toes

 Hold: 5 seconds

 Repetitions: 10-15 reps

 Sets: 2-3 sets per foot

 
 
 Progression:

 
 Seated with both feet

 Standing with both feet

 Standing on one leg

 Standing on unstable surface (cushion, balance board)

 
 

 

 
 Important Tip

 Many try to "cheat" by curling their toes. The toes should lie flat on the floor the entire time - it's the arch muscles that should do the work. Imagine trying to grip the floor with the middle of your foot.

Exercise 2: Toe Spreading

 

 After years in narrow shoes, many have lost the ability to actively spread their toes. Toe spreading reactivates the abductor muscles and improves forefoot stability.

 
 How to Perform Toe Spreading

 
 Starting position: Sit or stand with your foot flat on the floor

 Movement: Spread the toes as far apart as possible

 Focus: Especially try to spread the big toe away from the others

 Hold: 5-10 seconds

 Repetitions: 10-15 reps

 Sets: 2-3 sets per foot

 
 

 
 Tip: Use Toe Spacers

 If you struggle to spread your toes, toe spacers can help. Use them passively while sitting or sleeping to gradually regain toe mobility. Start with 15-30 minutes and increase gradually.

Exercise 3: Towel Curls

 

 A classic exercise that strengthens the flexor muscles under the foot. This exercise is particularly useful for those with plantar fasciitis.

 
 How to Perform Towel Curls

 
 Starting position: Sit with your foot on a towel on the floor

 Movement: Use your toes to pull the towel toward you

 Focus: Grip with all toes, including the big toe

 Repetitions: Pull in the entire towel, 2-3 times

 Variation: Pick up marbles or small objects with your toes

 
 

 
 Marble Variation

 Place 10-20 marbles (or other small objects) on the floor and pick them up one by one with your toes. This trains both grip and precision. A good variation to keep training interesting.

Describe Exercise 4: Focused Heel Raises for Foot Exercises That Work: Exercises for Stronger Feet.

Exercise 4: Focused Heel Raises

 

 Heel raises (calf raises) are a well-known exercise, but with proper focus they become powerful foot training. The key is to keep the arch active throughout the movement.

 
 How to Perform Focused Heel Raises

 
 Starting position: Stand with feet hip-width apart

 Preparation: Activate the short foot position first

 Movement: Slowly lift the heels while keeping the arch active

 Top position: Hold 2-3 seconds at the top

 Lowering: Lower down in a controlled manner (3-4 seconds)

 Repetitions: 10-15 reps, 2-3 sets

 
 
 Progression:

 
 Two legs on flat floor

 Two legs on stair edge (full range)

 One leg on flat floor

 One leg on stair edge

 
 

 

 
 Avoid This Mistake

 Many "roll out" over the little toe at the top of the movement. Keep weight evenly distributed and focus on pressing up through the big toe. The ankle should be stable, not tilting in or out.

Exercise 5: Single-Leg Balance

 

 Functional training that dynamically challenges the entire foot. This exercise bridges the gap between isolated foot exercises and daily function.

 
 Four Levels of Single-Leg Balance

 
 Level 1: Stand on one leg with eyes open, 30-60 seconds per side

 Level 2: Stand on one leg with eyes closed, 30-60 seconds per side

 Level 3: Stand on one leg on unstable surface (cushion, foam mat), 30-60 seconds

 Level 4: Stand on one leg while performing movements with arms or the free leg

 
 

 
 Functional Challenge

 Try doing daily activities on one leg: brush your teeth, wait for the bus, stand in line. Every opportunity to challenge balance is free foot training.

Describe Barefoot Walking and Minimalist Shoes for Foot Exercises That Work: Exercises for Stronger Feet.

Barefoot Walking and Minimalist Shoes

 

 The Liverpool study (Curtis 2021) showed that 6 months in minimalist shoes increased foot strength by 57% - without specific exercises. Simply by letting the foot work naturally.

 
 Safe Transition to Minimalist Shoes

 An abrupt transition can lead to injuries. Follow this protocol:

 
 Week 1-2: 10-15 min per day in minimalist shoes, indoors

 Week 3-4: 20-30 min per day, short walks outside

 Week 5-8: Gradual increase to 50% of daily use

 Week 9-12: Increase to 75% if the foot tolerates it

 After 3 months: Full transition possible for most people

 
 

 
 Important Warning

 If you have diabetes, neuropathy, or open wounds, you should NOT walk barefoot without consulting a doctor first. Loss of sensation in the feet means you won't notice injuries.

Describe Frequently Asked Questions for Do You Really Need Orthotics?.

Frequently Asked Questions

 

 
 Can a chiropractor help with foot problems?

 Yes. Chiropractors assess the entire musculoskeletal system and can identify whether foot complaints are due to local conditions or compensations from hips, pelvis, or back. Treatment often includes joint mobilization, soft tissue work, and targeted foot training.

 

 
 Should I stop using my orthotics?

 It depends on why you use them. Do you have diabetes, rheumatoid arthritis, or severe deformities? Then you should continue. Are you using them for non-specific pain or "overpronation"? Then gradual weaning combined with foot training may be a good alternative. Consult a professional.

 

 
 Are expensive orthotics better than cheap ones?

 Research suggests not. Several meta-analyses (Whittaker 2018, CADTH 2022) find no significant difference between custom-made and prefabricated orthotics - despite custom orthotics costing 5-10 times more.

 

 
 How long does it take to strengthen the feet?

Describe Why Do Minimalist Shoes Strengthen the Feet? for Minimalist Shoes and Barefoot Training: What Does the Research Say?.

Why Do Minimalist Shoes Strengthen the Feet?

 

 There are four main mechanisms that explain why minimalist shoes result in stronger feet:

 
 
 1. The Arch Must Stabilize Itself

 Without artificial support from shoes or orthotics, the foot's own muscles must activate to maintain the arch with each step.

 

 
 2. Natural Shock Absorption

 Without thick cushioning, the body learns to land softly on the forefoot/midfoot, which activates foot muscles as natural shock absorbers.

 

 
 3. Adaptation to Terrain

 A flexible sole allows the foot to adapt to irregularities, stimulating small muscles and proprioceptors.

 

 
 4. Toes Get to Work

 Wide toe box allows toes to spread and grip, activating toe muscles that otherwise remain passive in narrow shoes.

 

 

 
 Comparison: Shoes vs. Cast

 Modern shoes with stiff soles, narrow toe boxes, and high drop do much of the same as a cast: they immobilize structures and allow muscles to atrophy. Minimalist shoes do the opposite - they allow the foot to move freely and build strength.

 For Daily Use

 
 Gradual Adaptation to Minimalist Shoes for Everyday Life

Describe Frequently Asked Questions for Orthotic Dependency: How to Wean Off.

Frequently Asked Questions

 

 
 How long does the weaning process take?

 Most people can complete full weaning over 6-8 weeks. Some need longer, especially if they have used orthotics for many years. The most important thing is to listen to your body and not rush the process.

 

 
 Can I exercise during the weaning process?

 Yes, but consider using your orthotics during intensive training at first. As your feet get stronger, you can also train without them. Start with low-intensity activities first.

 

 
 What if the pain returns?

 Go back one step in the protocol and stay there until the pain has been gone for at least a week. Increase focus on foot exercises. If the pain persists, seek professional evaluation.

 

 
 Do I need special shoes during the weaning process?

 Start with regular, comfortable shoes with moderate support. Avoid both very rigid shoes and minimalist shoes at the beginning. Over time, you can gradually transition to shoes with less support.

 

 
 What if I've used orthotics for many years?

 The longer you've used orthotics, the longer your feet need to adapt. Consider doubling the time intervals in the protocol, and be extra patient with progression.

 

 
 Can children wean off orthotics?

 Children often have great adaptability. Norwegian guidelines recommend avoiding treatment of symptom-free, flexible flat feet in children. Discuss with your child's healthcare provider before starting.

How is Overpronation: Myth or Medical Fact? diagnosed?

A Diagnosis Born in the Shower

 

 The story of overpronation begins in 1954, in a shower in California. Dr. Merton Root, a podiatrist, observed his own feet and developed a theory that there is an ideal foot position - what he called subtalar neutral.

 Root believed that deviations from this neutral position were the cause of foot problems, and that correction with orthotics could prevent injuries. The theory sounded logical and was quickly adopted by the shoe industry and healthcare system.

 
 The Problem: Never Scientifically Validated

 Root's theory was never tested in controlled studies before it was put into practice. Over 70 years later, research has consistently failed to confirm that:

 
 There is a measurable neutral foot position

 Deviations from this position predict injuries

 Correcting deviations prevents injuries

 
 

 Dr. Kevin Kirby, himself a podiatrist and former student of Root, has said: "Subtalar neutral has never been scientifically validated. It was an idea that sounded good, but the research doesn't support it."

Describe Dr. Benno Nigg: From Believer to Skeptic for Overpronation: Myth or Medical Fact?.

Dr. Benno Nigg: From Believer to Skeptic

 

 Dr. Benno Nigg is perhaps the world's most respected researcher in biomechanics and running shoes. He founded the Human Performance Laboratory at the University of Calgary and has studied running movements for over 40 years.

 Nigg started his career believing in the overpronation theory. But after decades of research, he completely changed his mind.

 
 Nigg's Conclusion

 
 "There is no evidence that overpronation causes injuries. And there is no evidence that motion control shoes reduce injuries."
 - Dr. Benno Nigg, 2015
 
 

 Nigg's research showed that:

 
 The body naturally adapts to the surface

 Forcing the foot into a certain position can actually increase stress

 Comfort is a better indicator for the right shoe than pronation measurement

Describe What is Pronation Really? for Overpronation: Myth or Medical Fact?.

What is Pronation Really?

 

 Pronation is a natural rotational movement in the foot that occurs when you land during walking or running. The foot rolls inward, and the arch flattens somewhat. This is not a flaw - it is the body's built-in shock absorption system.

 
 Professor Gert-Peter Bruggemann

 Former head of research at Adidas and one of the world's leading experts on foot biomechanics:

 
 "There are no normal values for pronation. We have never been able to define what is too much pronation, because it varies enormously from person to person."
 
 

 The Function of Pronation

 
 Shock absorption: Absorbs impact upon landing

 Adaptation: Allows the foot to adapt to uneven terrain

 Energy storage: The arch functions as a spring that stores and releases energy

 

 When we restrict pronation with stiff shoes or orthotics, the energy must be absorbed elsewhere - often in the knees, hips, or back.

Elite Athletes with "Problematic" Feet

 

 If overpronation and flat feet were really so harmful, we would expect elite athletes to have perfect feet. But reality is quite different.

 
 Usain Bolt

 The world's fastest man has documented flat feet. He also has a significant leg length difference and scoliosis. Yet he dominated sprinting for over a decade.

 

 
 East African Runners

 Kenya and Ethiopia dominate long-distance running. Studies show that many of these runners have what we in the West would call flat feet or overpronation - often after a lifetime of barefoot running.

 

 
 What This Tells Us

 The foot's shape and movement vary extremely between individuals. What looks abnormal on a scanner or in a running store may be perfectly functional for that person.

 The orthotics industry is enormous. Manufacturers, retailers, and practitioners have significant economic interests in maintaining the belief that many people need foot correction.

 Tradition and Education

 The overpronation theory has been taught in healthcare education for decades. Many practitioners learned this as established science and have not updated themselves on newer research.

 Visual Logic

 It looks wrong when the foot rolls inward. We are programmed to think that what looks abnormal must be harmful. But the body is more robust and adaptable than we often think.

 Placebo Effect

 Many experience improvement with orthotics. But studies show that this effect is often placebo - sham insoles provide the same effect as expensive custom-made orthotics.

Describe Frequently Asked Questions for Overpronation: Myth or Medical Fact?.

Frequently Asked Questions

 

 
 Is all pronation normal?

 Yes, pronation is a completely natural movement. The foot is designed to pronate upon landing - it is the body's built-in shock absorption. The problem arises when normal variation is pathologized as overpronation. There is no scientifically defined limit for what is too much pronation.

 

 
 Do children with flat feet need orthotics?

 No, in the vast majority of cases. Research concludes that there is no evidence base for orthotics in children with flat feet. Flexible flat feet in children is a normal variant that usually develops normally. Unnecessary treatment can actually hinder natural foot development.

 

 
 Why do practitioners still prescribe for overpronation?

 Several factors are at play: tradition from education, economic incentives (the orthotics market is worth billions), visual logic (it looks wrong), and lack of updated knowledge on newer research. Many practitioners are genuinely convinced because they learned this as established science.

 

 
 Should I stop using my motion control shoes?

 If they are comfortable and you have no problems, there is no reason to switch immediately. But if you are considering new shoes, research suggests that comfort is a better guide than pronation measurement. A gradual transition to more neutral shoes may be appropriate for many.

What causes Weak Feet: The Root Cause Most People Overlook?

An Overlooked Cause of Foot Problems

 

 When someone complains about foot pain, flat feet, or poor balance, the usual response is to offer more support: insoles, stability shoes, or orthotics. But this can be like giving crutches to someone with weak legs - it helps in the moment but doesn't address the underlying problem.

 
 The Vicious Cycle

 Weak feet need support. Support makes feet even weaker. Weaker feet need even more support. The cycle continues - and the feet become increasingly dependent on external help.

 

 The foot is not a passive foundation that just needs to be held in place. It is an active, dynamic system with over 20 intrinsic muscles, 26 bones, 33 joints, and over 100 ligaments that must work together for optimal function.

Describe The Foot's Built-in Support System for Weak Feet: The Root Cause Most People Overlook.

The Foot's Built-in Support System

 

 The arch of the foot is not held up by passive structures alone. It has an active, dynamic support system consisting of four main components:

 
 1. Intrinsic Foot Muscles

 The small muscles inside the foot itself that provide active, dynamic support to the arch. These respond to the surface texture and adapt in real time.

 

 
 2. Plantar Fascia

 The strong connective tissue membrane under the foot that functions as a passive spring - it stores and releases energy with each step.

 

 
 3. Ligaments

 The ligaments that hold the bones together and provide passive stability to the foot's structure.

 

 
 4. Extrinsic Muscles

 The muscles in the lower leg that send tendons down to the foot (like tibialis posterior) and provide powerful, global control.

 

 
 The Key Point

 When the intrinsic muscles are weak, the passive structures (plantar fascia, ligaments) must take over the job. Over time, these become overloaded - and this is how conditions like plantar fasciopathy develop.

Describe How Modern Life Weakens the Feet for Weak Feet: The Root Cause Most People Overlook.

How Modern Life Weakens the Feet

 

 Modern lifestyle attacks foot strength from multiple fronts simultaneously:

 Shoes as a Cast

 Supportive shoes with arch support, heel cushioning, and stiff soles function like a kind of cast for the foot. They take over the muscles' job - and muscles that aren't used become weak.

 
 The Protopapas Study (2020)

 Just 12 weeks with custom-made orthotics led to 9-17% muscle atrophy in the foot's intrinsic muscles. This shows how quickly feet adapt to reduced loading.

 

 Reduced Sensory Input

 Thick soles block the thousands of sensory receptors in the sole of the foot. Without this information, the brain cannot activate the foot muscles correctly - they simply don't know what to do.

 Sedentary Lifestyle

 We sit an average of 9-10 hours daily. Our feet are designed to bear body weight and move across varied terrain - not rest under a desk.

 Flat, Hard Surfaces

 Asphalt, concrete, and tile floors provide no variation. Foot muscles need uneven surfaces to train - without this stimulus, they become lazy and weak.

Describe What Barefoot Populations Teach Us for Weak Feet: The Root Cause Most People Overlook.

What Barefoot Populations Teach Us

 

 Research on populations that still go barefoot or use minimal sandals provides valuable insight into how feet function naturally:

 
 The Sachithanandam Study (India)

 Compared Indian children who walked barefoot with those who wore shoes. Result: Barefoot children had half the rate of flat feet compared to shoe wearers. The earlier children started wearing shoes, the higher the incidence of flat feet.

 

 
 The Hollander Study (2017)

 Compared foot structure in minimalist shoe users and conventional shoe users. Result: The minimalist group had significantly higher arches and stronger intrinsic muscles.

 

 
 D'Aout's Research

 Studied footprints in barefoot populations and found that naturally developed feet have wider forefeet, stronger toes, and more flexible arches than shoe-wearing populations.

 

 
 The Tarahumara Indians

 This indigenous people of Mexico are known for running ultramarathons in simple sandals. They have extremely low rates of running injuries - and research shows they have exceptionally strong and well-coordinated foot muscles.

 

 The common thread is clear: Feet that get to work become strong. Feet that are protected become weak.

Describe How to Get Started for Weak Feet: The Root Cause Most People Overlook.

How to Get Started

 

 Building stronger feet doesn't require complicated equipment or a lot of time. Here are the most important steps:

 1. Walk Barefoot at Home

 Start by eliminating slippers and shoes indoors. This alone gives your feet hundreds of extra "training minutes" daily on natural surfaces.

 2. Short Foot Exercise

 Stand or sit with your foot flat on the floor. Try to "shorten" the foot by raising the arch without curling the toes. Hold for 5 seconds, repeat 10-15 times per foot. This is the most studied foot exercise.

 3. Toe Curls

 Place a towel on the floor and use your toes to pull it toward you. Alternatively: pick up small objects (marbles, pencils) with your toes.

 4. Toe Spreading

 Try to spread your toes apart as far as you can. Most people who have worn shoes their whole lives find this surprisingly difficult - it shows how little we use our toe muscles.

 5. Single-Leg Balance

 Stand on one leg for 30 seconds, preferably with eyes closed when it becomes too easy. This activates the entire foot stabilization system.

 
 Gradual Progression

 Feet that have been in a "cast" (supportive shoes) for years need time to adapt. Start carefully and increase gradually. Expect noticeable improvements after 4-8 weeks of consistent effort.

 Noticeable improvements are typically seen after 4-8 weeks of consistent training. The Liverpool study showed 57% strength increase after 6 months with minimalist shoes. Foot training should be viewed as maintenance - just like any other exercise.

 

 
 Is barefoot walking safe?

 For most people, gradual barefoot walking is safe and beneficial. Start indoors on soft surfaces and increase gradually. People with diabetes, neuropathy, or reduced sensation in their feet should be careful and consult a healthcare professional first.

 

 
 Can I train my feet even if I have flat feet?

 Yes, absolutely. Research (Huang 2022 meta-analysis) shows that foot training can increase arch strength and improve function even in people with flat feet. Flexible flat foot often responds well to strength training.

 

 
 Should I throw away my orthotics?

 Not necessarily. If you have diabetes, severe deformities, or specific medical indications, orthotics may still be important. For non-specific problems, gradual weaning combined with foot training may be a good alternative. Discuss with a professional.

Describe Orthotics Are Not Always Wrong for When Orthotics Actually Help.

Orthotics Are Not Always Wrong

 

 While many articles focus on the overuse of orthotics, it's important to acknowledge that there are legitimate indications. For certain patient groups, orthotics can be a valuable - sometimes lifesaving - aid.

 The key is to distinguish between:

 
 Conditions with strong evidence - where orthotics have documented effect in randomized controlled trials

 Conditions with moderate evidence - where orthotics may have a temporary role

 Conditions with weak/no evidence - where orthotics are often prescribed without scientific basis

 

 
 The problem is overprescription

 A survey showed that 72-93% of podiatrists prescribe orthotics for knee, hip and back pain - despite no evidence for effect in these conditions. This undermines trust in the entire field.

Describe Conditions With Strong Evidence for When Orthotics Actually Help.

Conditions With Strong Evidence

 

 Diabetic Neuropathy

 
 Why it works

 In diabetic neuropathy, the patient loses sensation in their feet and can develop foot ulcers that in the worst case lead to amputation. Custom pressure-relieving orthotics can prevent ulcer formation.

 
 
 71%
 fewer ulcers (Lancet 2019)
 

 
 IWGDF
 recommends in 2023
 

 
 Medicare
 covers the cost
 

 

 Lancet Digital Health (2019) showed 71% reduction in ulcer formation with custom orthotics. International Working Group on the Diabetic Foot (IWGDF 2023) recommends pressure-relieving orthotics as standard treatment for high-risk patients.

 

 Rheumatoid Arthritis

 
 Why it works

 In rheumatoid arthritis, the immune system attacks the joints, including those in the feet. Orthotics can offload inflamed joints and reduce pain.

 
 
 ~20%
 pain reduction
 

 
 ~30%
 function improvement
 

 

 Woodburn et al. (2002) in Journal of Rheumatology showed significant pain reduction and improved function. Cochrane reviews give good/moderate quality assessment of the evidence.

 

 Symptomatic Pes Cavus (High Arch)

 
 Why it works

 In pes cavus, the foot arch is abnormally high, causing increased pressure on the heel and forefoot. Orthotics can redistribute pressure and reduce pain.

 
 
 ~75%
 pain reduction
 

 

 Cochrane reviews show good effect for symptomatic pes cavus. Note: this only applies when the condition causes symptoms - asymptomatic high arch does not require treatment.

Conditions With Moderate Evidence

 

 Acute Injury Offloading

 
 Temporary use during healing

 For acute injuries such as stress fractures, tendinitis or joint injuries, orthotics can be used temporarily to offload the injured area while it heals.

 Important: Orthotics should be weaned after healing. Long-term use can lead to muscle atrophy and dependency.

 

 Postoperative Rehabilitation

 
 After surgery

 After certain foot surgeries, orthotics may be indicated during the rehabilitation period:

 Joint replacements in the foot

Conditions Where Evidence Is Weak

 

 For the following conditions, evidence is weak or absent - despite orthotics being frequently prescribed:

 
 "Overpronation"

 Nielsen et al. (2013) randomized 927 novice runners to shoes based on foot type versus neutral shoes. Result: No difference in injury rates. Overpronation as a diagnosis lacks scientific basis.

 Flexible Flat Foot Without Symptoms

 Choosing Wisely (2023): "Avoid treatment of the normal variant asymptomatic flexible flat foot." Up to 26% of adults have flat feet - most without complaints. Treatment is unnecessary and potentially harmful.

 

 
 Nonspecific Foot and Heel Pain

 Whittaker et al. (2018) meta-analysis: Orthotics are no better than placebo in the long term. APTA (2023) does NOT recommend orthotics as isolated treatment for plantar fasciitis.

 

 
 Knee, Hip or Back Pain

Describe Frequently Asked Questions for When Orthotics Actually Help.

Frequently Asked Questions

 

 
 Who benefits from orthotics?

 Patients with diabetic neuropathy, rheumatoid arthritis and symptomatic pes cavus have strong evidence for benefit. Additionally, orthotics can be used temporarily for acute injuries and postoperative rehabilitation.

 

 
 Are custom orthotics worth the price?

 For most conditions, research shows no difference between custom and prefabricated orthotics. The exception is complex deformities or special medical needs where precise customization is critical.

 

 
 Do orthotics work for overpronation?

 Evidence is weak. Large studies (Nielsen 2013) showed no difference in injury rates when runners got shoes matched to foot type versus neutral shoes. "Overpronation" as a diagnosis lacks scientific basis.

 

 
 Can I wean off orthotics?

 Yes, for many people gradual weaning combined with foot exercises is a good alternative. But it should be done gradually over several months. If you have diabetes, rheumatoid arthritis or severe deformities, you should continue with orthotics.

 

 
 Why do so many prescribe orthotics without evidence?

 Several factors are at play: tradition, commercial interests, and genuine misunderstandings about foot biomechanics. Many practitioners learned that orthotics were standard treatment - research has since shown this is often not the case.

Describe What is Plantar Fasciopathy? for Plantar Fasciopathy.

What is Plantar Fasciopathy?

 

 Why fasciopathy and not fasciitis?

 The suffix -itis means inflammation, but histological studies actually show absence of
 inflammatory cells in the tissue. What happens is degenerative changes: breakdown of collagen
 fibers, thickening of the fascia, and reduced blood supply. Therefore, many professionals now use the term
 plantar fasciopathy - a more precise description of what is actually happening in the tissue (Riel et al.,
 BJSM 2017).

 
 
 10%
 lifetime risk
 

 
 40-60
 most common age group
 

 
 2.5x
 higher risk for women
 

 
 83%
 in working adults 25-65 years
 

 

 The condition primarily affects people between 40-60 years, and 83% of cases occur in working adults
 between 25-65 years (StatPearls 2024). Women have 2.5 times higher incidence than men. Among runners,
 prevalence is 5-10%, and some studies report up to 22%.

Describe symptoms and signs of Plantar Fasciopathy.

Symptoms

 

 The most characteristic symptom is intense heel pain with the first steps in the morning
 - so-called start-up pain. The pain occurs because the plantar fascia contracts during the night while the
 foot rests, and the sudden loading when standing up causes stretching pain.

 Typical characteristics

 
 Pain is located on the underside of the heel, often slightly toward the inside

 Tenderness when pressing on the heel attachment (medial calcaneal tuberosity)

 Pain typically improves after a few minutes of walking

 Can worsen again with prolonged activity or standing

 About one third have symptoms in both feet

 

 
 Diagnosis

 The diagnosis is primarily clinical, based on medical history and physical examination. Typical
 localized tenderness over the heel attachment and positive Windlass test (pain when toes are bent
 backward) confirms the diagnosis in most cases. It is important to distinguish the condition from other
 causes of foot pain such as Morton's neuroma or metatarsalgia.

 Imaging is normally not necessary at the start. Ultrasound
 is considered if there is no response after 3 months.

What causes Plantar Fasciopathy?

Causes and Risk Factors

 

 Research has identified several risk factors, ranked by how strongly they affect the chance of developing
 the condition:

 
 
 Limited ankle mobility

 23x increased risk with zero degrees dorsiflexion or less (Riddle et al., JBJS 2003)
 

 

 
 Obesity (BMI > 30)

 5-6x increased risk compared to normal weight

 

 
 Occupations with lots of standing

 4x increased risk when standing most of the workday

 

 
 Foot structure

 Both flat foot and high arch can increase load on the plantar fascia

 

 

 Sudden increase in activity - like starting to run after a long break, or increasing
 training volume too quickly - is a classic triggering factor. This type of overload can also lead to stress fractures in the foot.

Describe The Heel Spur Myth for Plantar Fasciopathy.

The Heel Spur Myth

 

 
 The myth: The heel spur pokes and causes the pain

 Fact: This is not correct. Studies show:

 
 10-16% of symptom-free people have heel spurs

 Up to 55% of adults over 60 have heel spurs without symptoms

 Only about 5% of people with heel spurs have symptoms

 The spurs are a result of chronic loading - not the cause of the problem

 They don't disappear even if the pain goes away

 
 

 Treatment is identical regardless of whether a heel spur is present or not. Surgical removal of the heel
 spur alone does not improve the outcome.

Describe Frequently Asked Questions for Plantar Fasciopathy.

Frequently Asked Questions

 

 
 Can I exercise with plantar fasciopathy?

 Yes, but adapt the activity. Low-impact activities like cycling and swimming are
 often well tolerated. When running or walking: reduce distance and intensity, increase gradually, and
 listen to your body. Pain that worsens during or after activity is a signal to reduce the load.

 

 
 Do heel spur insoles help?

 Insoles can help somewhat in the short term. A meta-analysis from 2017 found
 moderate effect at 6-12 weeks. Interestingly, one study showed that ready-made prefabricated insoles
 combined with stretching were actually more effective than custom-made insoles plus stretching.

 

 
 Should I have the heel spur surgically removed?

 No. The heel spur is not the cause of the pain, and removing the spur alone does
 not improve the outcome. Surgery is only considered in the 5-10% of cases where conservative treatment
 over 6-12 months has not helped, and then usually involves partial release of the plantar fascia - not
 removal of the spur.

 

 
 How long does it take to recover?

 Most experience significant improvement within 3-6 months with proper treatment.
 For some, it takes up to 12 months. Early treatment is associated with faster improvement. Remember that
 recurrence is common (30-50%), so maintenance exercises are important even after recovery.

What is Sever's Disease?

 

 Sever's disease is an overuse condition that affects the growth plate (apophysis) in the heel bone of
 children. The Achilles tendon attaches here, and with repeated stress, the area can become irritated and
 painful. This is different from stress fracture in the foot, which
 involves an actual bone break.

 The condition is named after American physician James Warren Sever who first described it in 1912. Today,
 the more precise name calcaneal apophysitis is often preferred.

Describe What is a stress fracture? for Stress Fracture in the Foot.

What is a stress fracture?

 

 Bone is living tissue that is constantly being broken down and rebuilt. When the load is greater than the
 bone's capacity to repair itself, a "stress reaction" - a precursor to fracture - first occurs. If loading
 continues, a stress fracture develops. This differs from acute injuries like ankle sprains.

 of all sports injuries

 more common in women

 typical healing time

 Navicular
 Approx. 15%

 Approx. 10%
 Low risk
 6-8 weeks
 
 
 

 
 High-risk vs. Low-risk

 High-risk fractures are located in areas with poor blood supply and high loading. They
 require stricter offloading and have higher risk of complications.

RED-S and Female Athlete Triad

 

 Women have 2-3 times higher risk of stress fractures. An important cause is RED-S
 (Relative Energy Deficiency in Sport), previously called the female athlete triad.

 
 The Three Components

 
 Energy deficiency: Too few calories relative to activity level

 Menstrual disturbances: Irregular or absent menstruation

 Low bone density: Increased risk of stress fractures

 
 

 RED-S can also affect men, especially in weight-sensitive sports. With repeated stress fractures,
 underlying causes should always be evaluated.

 
 Important to Know

 Absent menstruation in female athletes is not normal, even with hard training. It is a
 sign of energy deficiency and requires follow-up to prevent serious consequences such as osteoporosis
 and stress fractures.

Describe What is Tibialis Posterior Tendinopathy? for Tibialis Posterior Tendinopathy.

What is Tibialis Posterior Tendinopathy?

 

 Tibialis posterior is a muscle that runs along the inside of the lower leg and attaches under the foot.
 The tendon has an important task: it supports the foot arch and helps turn the foot inward (inversion).
 

 In tibialis posterior tendinopathy (also called PTTD - Posterior Tibial Tendon Dysfunction), the tendon
 gradually becomes weakened, lengthened or torn. This causes the foot arch to collapse and the foot to turn
 outward.

 
 
 3-10%
 of population affected
 

 
 4x
 more common in women
 

 
 40-60
 most common age group
 

 
 90%
 respond to conservative treatment
 

 

 
 The tendon's important function

 The tibialis posterior tendon works as a "winch" that holds the foot arch up. It is activated with
 every step to stabilize the foot during loading. When the tendon fails, other structures (ligaments,
 joint capsule) take over, which gradually become stretched.

Describe symptoms and signs of Tibialis Posterior Tendinopathy.

Symptoms

 

 Symptoms typically develop gradually over time, but can also occur more acutely after injury.

 Common symptoms

 
 Pain on the inside of the ankle - along the tendon's course

 Swelling along the inside of the ankle

 Pain with walking - especially during push-off

 Difficulty standing on toes on one leg

 Gradual flattening of the foot arch

 Foot turns outward - "too many toes" sign when viewed from behind

 

 
 "Too many toes" sign

 When looking at the patient from behind, with advanced PTTD you will see more toes on the affected side
 because the foot has turned outward. Normally you only see the little toe and parts of the 4th toe.

 

 
 Diagnosis

 The diagnosis is made clinically by examining the tendon, foot arch and ability to raise onto toes on
 one leg. Ultrasound or MRI can confirm the diagnosis and show the degree of tendon damage.

 Tibialis posterior tendinopathy is an injury to the tendon that supports the foot
 arch. When the tendon weakens, the foot arch can gradually collapse leading to acquired flat foot. Flat
 foot can also be congenital. PTTD is the most common cause of acquired flat foot in adults.

 Recovery varies depending on stage. Stage 1 can improve in 2-3 months with proper

 training is important to prevent recurrence.

Describe How Common Are Foot Problems? for Foot and Ankle Problems.

How Common Are Foot Problems?

 

 A systematic review from 2011 analysed 31 studies with over 75,000 participants and found that
 24% of adults over 45 report frequent foot problems, and 15% have ankle
 problems. Prevalence increases with age, and women are affected more often than men.

 A large population study from North England found that foot problems in people over 55 double the
 risk of difficulties with standing and walking, and increase the risk of problems with stairs
 by 71%.

 Common Symptoms

 
 Morning stiffness: Pain and stiffness with first steps after rest

 Load-related pain: Worsening with standing, walking or running

 Swelling: Localised or diffuse around foot or ankle

 Instability: Feeling the ankle "gives way"

 Numbness or tingling: In toes or forefoot

Describe What Can You Do Yourself? for Foot and Ankle Problems.

What Can You Do Yourself?

 

 Activity and targeted exercises are often the most important treatment for foot problems. Here are evidence-based exercises for common conditions:

 
 1. Calf Stretching (Plantar Fasciopathy)

 Stand with your forefoot on a step, letting the heel hang over the edge. Lower slowly until you feel a stretch in the calf and Achilles. Hold 30-60 seconds. Repeat 3 times on each side. Do twice daily.

 

 
 2. Eccentric Heel Raises (Achilles Tendinopathy)

 Stand on tiptoes with both feet. Lift one foot and lower slowly on the affected side until the heel is below the step. Use the healthy leg to push up again. 3 sets of 15 repetitions, twice daily for 12 weeks.

 

 
 3. Balance Training (Ankle Instability)

 Stand on one leg with eyes open. Progress to: eyes closed, unstable surface, catching/throwing a ball. 3 sets of 30 seconds on each leg, daily. Reduces re-injury risk by 35%.

 

 
 4. Towel Scrunches (General Foot Strength)

 Sit with a towel under your foot. Use your toes to scrunch the towel towards you. Repeat 10-15 times, 2-3 sets. Strengthens the intrinsic muscles of the foot.

 

 
 The Key: Optimal Loading

 The goal is "optimal loading": enough load to stimulate healing, but not so much that you worsen the injury. Complete rest is rarely the solution. I provide specific advice tailored to your situation.

How is Headache in Back of Head diagnosed?

Diagnosis

 

 Clinical Examination

 A thorough clinical examination is the cornerstone of diagnosis. The chiropractor assesses neck mobility, palpates muscles and joints in the neck and head, and performs neurological tests.

 For cervicogenic headache, the CHISG criteria are used: unilateral headache that doesn't switch sides, pain triggered by neck movements or pressure on the upper neck, reduced neck mobility, and pain that starts in the neck and radiates forward.

 
 When is Imaging Necessary?

 What Can the Chiropractor Do?

 Chiropractic treatment of headache focuses on the neck and upper back. Treatment may include:

 
 Joint mobilization or manipulation

 Soft tissue treatment of tight muscles

 Trigger point treatment in suboccipital muscles

 Exercises to improve function

 
 

 Evidence for Treatment

 Cervicogenic headache: The evidence is strongest here. A meta-analysis analyzed 20 randomized studies with 1,439 patients. Findings showed moderate to large short-term effect on pain intensity and headache frequency. Effects persisted beyond 3 months, but to a lesser degree.

 Tension headache: The evidence is more nuanced. A meta-analysis found that high-velocity manipulation alone was not effective for tension headache, but soft tissue treatment showed good effect. Trigger point treatment in the suboccipital muscles may be useful for chronic tension headache.

 
 Realistic Expectations

 Approximately 50-70% of patients with cervicogenic headache experience clinically meaningful improvement. It's important to be aware that relapse is common - several guidelines point out that cervicogenic headache tends to recur.

 Chin tucks: Pull your chin backward as if making a "double chin," hold for 5 seconds, repeat 10 times. Do this 5-7 times daily.

 Vestibular Migraine - Diagnostic Criteria

 
 At least 5 episodes of vestibular symptoms of moderate to severe intensity

 Dizziness caused by neck problems affects 40% of patients with neck pain. Of these, 59.7% were related to myofascial pain syndrome (muscle tension with trigger points). This often overlaps with cervicogenic headache.

What causes Headache on Top of the Head?

Causes and Risk Factors

 

 
 
 Tension Headache

 Most common - 46% lifetime
 

 Tension headache is by far the most common cause of headache on top of the head. Lifetime prevalence is 46% globally, and Danish studies show up to 78%. Women are affected twice as often as men.

 Typical presentation is bilateral, pressing or tightening pain - often described as a "band around the head" that can focus on the top. The pain is mild to moderate and does not worsen with physical activity.

 Risk factors: Stress, poor sleep, prolonged screen work and static work postures.

 

 
 
 Trigger Points in Neck Musculature

 Referred pain
 

 Muscles in the neck can refer pain to the top of the head through a phenomenon called "referred pain." Read more about trigger points and headache.

 Splenius capitis is the primary muscle that sends pain specifically to the crown. Trigger points in this muscle - located approximately at the C3 level - create a characteristic pain sensation in a 3-5 cm zone in the middle of the top of the head. Patients often describe this as "internal head pain" or "pressure on the crown."

 Suboccipital muscles (the small muscles at the very top of the neck) are found to have active trigger points in 65% of patients with chronic tension headache. These muscles have a direct anatomical connection to the meninges.

 Manual treatment has moderate evidence for short-term effect. A 2022 systematic review with 20 studies and 1439 patients found large effect on pain intensity in the short term compared to placebo.

 For Tension Headache

 Evidence for manual treatment is more limited. 2011 guidelines concluded that manipulation cannot be recommended for episodic tension headache, but that low-intensity mobilization may be useful for chronic problems.

 Gentle stretches and strengthening exercises for the neck have documented effect. Especially exercises that strengthen the deep neck flexors can be useful.

 For tension headache, relaxation, mindfulness or other stress management techniques can help.

Prognosis

 Short-term

 Good probability of improvement with treatment - one study found that 72% of patients with cervicogenic headache maintained at least 50% reduction in headache frequency after 12 months.

 Long-term

 Evidence suggests that different treatments often give similar results over time. The most important factor for sustained improvement appears to be regular exercises and lifestyle changes.

Describe What is hormonal headache? for Hormonal Headache and Menstrual Migraine.

What is hormonal headache?

 

 Hormonal headache is a collective term for headaches triggered or worsened by hormonal fluctuations. The most common form is menstrual migraine, but hormones can also affect tension headache and other headache types.

 
 Why hormones trigger headache

 The main culprit is estrogen - or more precisely: the rapid drop in estrogen levels just before menstruation. This hormonal shift affects neurotransmitters in the brain, particularly serotonin, and can trigger migraine attacks in women who are genetically predisposed.

 It's not the absolute levels that are the problem, but the fluctuations. That's why stable hormone levels (as in pregnancy or after menopause) can often bring improvement.

Describe Types of hormone-related headache for Hormonal Headache and Menstrual Migraine.

Types of hormone-related headache

 

 
 
 Pure menstrual migraine

 7-14% of migraine women
 

 Migraine attacks that only occur in connection with menstruation (day -2 to +3 of the cycle). No attacks at other times. Often characterized by longer duration and poorer response to triptans than regular migraine.

 

 
 
 Menstrually-related migraine

 Most common - approx. 50%
 

 Migraine attacks that often occur around menstruation, but also occur at other times in the cycle. There must be a clear increase in attack frequency around the period to qualify.

 

 
 
 Hormonal headache from birth control

 

 Headache that occurs during the pill-free week when estrogen levels drop. Can also be experienced when starting or switching contraception.

 

 
 
 Hormonal headache in menopause

 

 Unpredictable hormonal fluctuations in perimenopause can cause irregular headaches. Many experience worsening during this phase, but improvement after menopause. Some develop chronic daily headache during this period.

 

 
 How to know if you have menstrual migraine?

 Keep a headache diary for at least 3 months and note attack days as well as menstruation dates. A clear pattern where attacks consistently occur on days -2 to +3 of the cycle supports the diagnosis.

Describe Headache through the lifespan for Hormonal Headache and Menstrual Migraine.

Headache through the lifespan

 

 Hormonal headache changes throughout life in step with the major hormonal shifts:

 
 
 Menarche (first period)

 Migraine often debuts in puberty. Before puberty, migraine is equally common in boys and girls - afterward it becomes 3x more common in women.

 

 
 Fertile years

 Menstrual migraine is most common. Many experience that attacks are worst during the first days of the period. Birth control can both help and worsen.

 

 
 Pregnancy

 60-70% experience improvement, especially in the 2nd and 3rd trimester when hormone levels are stable and high. Some experience onset or worsening.

 

 
 After birth

 Rapid drop in estrogen can cause migraine relapse shortly after birth. Breastfeeding can provide protection due to stable hormones.

 

 
 Perimenopause

 Often a difficult period with unpredictable fluctuations. Many experience worsening of migraine during this phase.

 

 
 After menopause

 Many experience significant improvement or their migraine disappears when hormone levels stabilize at a lower level.

 Estrogen supplementation: Estrogen gel or patch during pill-free week/around period

Describe What is occipital neuralgia? for Occipital Neuralgia.

What is occipital neuralgia?

 

 Occipital neuralgia is a condition with intense, stabbing or burning pain in the back of the head and neck area. The pain is caused by irritation, inflammation, or damage to the occipital nerves - the nerves that supply the scalp at the back.

 The condition can cause attacks of intense pain lasting from seconds to minutes, or more constant, aching pain with overlying shock-like episodes.

 
 The Anatomy

 There are three occipital nerves on each side:

 
 Greater occipital nerve: Comes from the C2 nerve root. Passes through the neck muscles and supplies the largest part of the back of the head. Most commonly involved in occipital neuralgia.

 Lesser occipital nerve: Comes from C2-C3. Supplies the area behind the ear and lateral part of the back of the head.

 Third occipital nerve: Comes from C3. Supplies the lower part of the back of the head.

 
 

 
 Prevalence

 Occipital neuralgia is relatively rare as an isolated diagnosis - exact prevalence is unknown, but it's considered one of the less common headaches. The condition is somewhat more common in women and usually debuts between ages 30-50.
You are a clinical documentation assistant for chiropractors. Generate professional medical documentation.
Describe symptoms and signs of Occipital Neuralgia.

Symptoms

 

 The typical symptoms of occipital neuralgia are characteristic and differ from other headache types:

 Pain Character

 
 Stabbing, shooting, or burning pain

 Often described as "electric shocks"

 Starts at the neck/back of head junction and radiates upward toward the back of the head

 Can reach all the way to the forehead or behind the eye

 Usually unilateral, but can be bilateral

 

 Attack Pattern

 
 Attacks of intense pain lasting seconds to minutes

 May have underlying aching pain between attacks

 Often triggered by head movements or touching the scalp

 

 Accompanying Symptoms

 
 Allodynia: Scalp becomes tender to touch - even light touch can hurt

 Numbness or tingling in the scalp

 Pain when brushing hair or laying head on pillow

 Light sensitivity (less common than in migraine)

 

 
 Diagnostic Test

 In occipital neuralgia, there is typically tenderness on palpation over the occipital nerve's exit point (approximately midway between the ear and the cervical vertebrae, at the lower border of the back of the head). Pressure here can reproduce or intensify symptoms.
You are a clinical documentation assistant for chiropractors. Generate professional medical documentation.
What causes Occipital Neuralgia?

Causes

 

 Occipital neuralgia can have many causes, but in many cases no clear underlying cause is found (idiopathic). The most common known causes include:

 
 Muscle Tension and Trigger Points (Most Common)

 Tight muscles in the upper neck can compress the occipital nerves where they pass through the musculature. Particularly semispinalis capitis, trapezius, and sternocleidomastoid. Read more about trigger points and headache.

 

 
 Neck Injuries (Whiplash)

 Trauma to the neck can damage or irritate the occipital nerves, either directly or through subsequent muscle spasms and scarring.

 

 
 Osteoarthritis in Upper Cervical Vertebrae

 Degenerative changes in C1-C3 can affect the nerves that form the occipital nerves. Osteoarthritis or bone spurs can compress the nerves.

 

 
 Prolonged Poor Posture

 Forward head posture (e.g., from office work) can over time lead to muscle tension and nerve involvement in the upper neck. This can also contribute to cervicogenic headache.

 

 
 Other Causes

 
 Inflammation (gout, diabetes, vasculitis)

 Infections

 Tumors (rare)

 Complications after neck surgery

How is Occipital Neuralgia diagnosed?

Diagnosis

 

 Occipital neuralgia is diagnosed primarily clinically, based on history and examination:

 ICHD-3 Diagnostic Criteria

 
 Unilateral or bilateral pain in the distribution of the occipital nerves

 The pain has at least two of three characteristics:
 
 Recurring paroxysms (attacks) lasting seconds to minutes

 Severe intensity

 Stabbing, shooting, or sharp quality

 
 

 Tenderness on palpation over the affected nerve

 Pain temporarily relieved by local nerve block

 

 
 Nerve Block as Diagnostic Test

 An injection of local anesthetic at the occipital nerve's exit point that provides significant, albeit temporary, pain relief supports the diagnosis. This test can be performed by a doctor and is both diagnostic and therapeutic.

 

 When is Imaging Necessary?

 MRI of the neck may be appropriate to rule out structural causes such as:

 
 Disc herniation or stenosis in the cervical spine

 Tumors or other space-occupying lesions

 Vascular malformations

What is the prognosis for Occipital Neuralgia?

Prognosis

 

 The prognosis for occipital neuralgia varies depending on the underlying cause:

 
 Muscle-related: Often good prognosis with manual treatment and self-help

 Traumatic: May take longer, but often improves over months

 Idiopathic: Variable course - some experience spontaneous improvement, others develop chronic daily headache

 

 
 Many Get Better

 Most people with occipital neuralgia experience significant improvement with proper treatment. Conservative measures such as manual treatment, self-help, and medications often help. For those who don't respond, more invasive alternatives exist.

Describe The Great Confusion for Sinus Headache or Migraine?.

The Great Confusion

 

 
 
 88%
 have migraine, not sinusitis
 

 
 8 years
 average misdiagnosis time
 

 
 12%

 Similar findings came from the SAMS study in 2007, where only 3% of participants actually had headache from sinusitis. The rest had migraine or other headache types.

 
 Why are they confused?

 The trigeminal nerve supplies both the meninges (where migraine originates) and the sinuses. When migraine activates this nerve, it triggers a reflex causing nasal congestion, watery eyes, and facial pressure - symptoms we associate with a cold or sinusitis.

 Studies show that 40-74% of migraine patients experience at least one such "sinus-like" symptom during attacks.

 Most Common

 Nasal secretion: Thick, yellow-green or greenish mucus - especially from one side.

 Duration: Symptoms persist and worsen over 7-10 days. Often starts after a cold.

Describe When Is It Actually Sinusitis? for Sinus Headache or Migraine?.

When Is It Actually Sinusitis?

 

 True sinusitis is far less common than many believe. 90-95% of acute sinusitis is viral and resolves on its own without antibiotics.

 Bacterial sinusitis requiring treatment is characterized by:

 
 Symptoms that worsen after 5-7 days

 High fever over 39C

 Severe unilateral facial pain

 Purulent (yellow-green) discharge, especially from one side

 Symptoms lasting more than 10 days without improvement

 

 If you have these signs, you should contact a doctor for evaluation of antibiotic treatment.

Describe treatment options for Sinus Headache or Migraine?.

Treatment

 

 How Can the Chiropractor Help?

 
 Neck-Related Headache (Cervicogenic Headache)

 Many people with headache and facial pain have a component from the neck. Cervicogenic headache arises from joints, muscles, or nerves in the upper neck and can cause pain radiating toward the eye, temple, or forehead.

 For this type of headache, there is moderate evidence that manual treatment such as mobilization and manipulation can reduce pain intensity, attack frequency, and disability.

 

 For Migraine

 For migraine, the evidence for manual treatment is more uncertain. This doesn't mean treatment is useless - many experience relief, and neck treatment may be relevant if neck problems contribute to the migraine picture. But expectations should be realistic.

 What Do We Do in Practice?

 During consultation, we conduct a thorough examination to map:

 
 Headache type (migraine, tension headache, cervicogenic, or mixed forms)

 Neck and jaw joint function

 Muscular trigger points

 Need for referral to a doctor

 

 Treatment is tailored to findings and may include joint mobilization, soft tissue treatment, dry needling, and exercises.

Describe What Can You Do Yourself? for Sinus Headache or Migraine?.

What Can You Do Yourself?

 

 For Migraine

 
 Headache diary: Record attacks, triggers, food, sleep, and menstruation. This helps you identify patterns.

 Regularity: Keep fixed times for sleep, meals, and activity. Migraine brains like predictability. Sleep problems can also cause morning headache.

 Trigger control: Avoid known triggers, but be aware that "trigger hunting" can become excessive.

 Acute treatment: Pain relievers work best when taken early in the attack. Overuse (more than 10-15 days per month) can lead to medication overuse headache.

 

 For Suspected Sinusitis

 
 Saline rinse: Nasal irrigation with saline can relieve symptoms.

 Humid air: Steam inhalation or a humidifier can help with dryness.

 Nasal spray: Decongestant nasal spray for short periods (max 7-10 days for decongestant types).

 Wait and see: Most viral sinusitis resolves in 7-10 days without treatment.

What is the prognosis for Sinus Headache or Migraine??

Prognosis

 

 Migraine

 Migraine is a chronic neurological condition that varies throughout life for most people. Many experience fewer attacks with age, especially women after menopause.

 Correct diagnosis is crucial - when patients who were misdiagnosed with sinusitis received migraine treatment, nearly 70% experienced improvement.

 Relapse is common and expected. The goal is to reduce attack frequency and severity, not necessarily to eliminate symptoms completely. For persistent daily symptoms, see chronic daily headache.

 Sinusitis

 Acute viral sinusitis resolves on its own. Bacterial sinusitis treated with antibiotics has a good prognosis. Some develop chronic sinusitis (over 12 weeks), which requires evaluation by an ENT specialist.

Describe Frequently Asked Questions for Sinus Headache or Migraine?.

Frequently Asked Questions

 

 
 Can you have both migraine and sinusitis at the same time?

 Yes, but it's rare for symptoms to coincide. If you have recurring episodes of "sinus headache" without fever and purulent secretion, it's far more likely you have migraine with autonomic symptoms.

 

 
 Why don't antibiotics help my headache?

 Because the headache probably isn't caused by a bacterial infection. Repeated courses of antibiotics for "sinusitis" that don't provide lasting relief is a strong signal that the diagnosis should be reconsidered.

 

 
 Can CT or X-ray show if it's the sinuses?

 Imaging can show swelling in the sinuses, but this is common even with migraine and colds. Findings on CT don't automatically mean the sinuses are causing the headache.

 

 
 Do I need to see a neurologist to get a migraine diagnosis?

 No, the diagnosis is usually made by a GP based on medical history and clinical examination. Referral to a neurologist is relevant for uncertain diagnosis, poor treatment response, or alarm symptoms.

 

 
 Can a chiropractor treat migraine?

 Chiropractors can assess whether the neck contributes to the headache picture and treat any findings. For migraine specifically, the evidence for manual treatment is uncertain, but many experience subjective benefit. The most important thing is to get the correct diagnosis.

 

 
 How many treatments do I need?

Describe What is Tension Headache? for Tension Headache: Everything You Need to Know.

What is Tension Headache?

 

 Tension headache (tension-type headache, TTH) is characterized by a pressing or tightening sensation - like a tight band around the head. Unlike migraine, which is a neurological disease with often one-sided, pulsating pain, tension headache is bilateral and more aching.

 Most people experience this sporadically, but for 2-4% of the population the headache becomes chronic and daily (Bendtsen & Jensen, Lancet Neurology 2006).

 
 
 52.7%
 of Norwegians are affected
 

 
 1.89 billion
 people globally
 

 
 30-39 years
 peak occurrence
 

 
 1.2-1.5:1
 women:men ratio
 

 

 Episodic vs. Chronic

 
 Episodic tension headache: Less than 15 days per month. Most people have this form.

 Chronic tension headache: 15 days or more per month for at least 3 months. Here the pain system has often become "self-sustaining".

Describe symptoms and signs of Tension Headache: Everything You Need to Know.

Symptoms

 

 Tension headache has characteristic features that distinguish it from other headache types. According to ICHD-3 criteria (International Headache Society 2018), at least two of the following must be present:

 
 Bilateral location - the pain sits on both sides of the head, often in the back of the head or forehead

 Pressing or tightening quality - not pulsating

 Mild to moderate intensity - you can usually continue with daily activities

 Not worsened by physical activity - walking stairs or light movement does not make it worse

 

 
 Important difference from migraine

 With tension headache, you typically do not experience nausea or vomiting. Light or sound sensitivity may occur, but never both at the same time.

 

 Tension Headache vs. Migraine

 Headache in the temple or top of the head can occur in both conditions, but the character is different.

What causes Tension Headache: Everything You Need to Know?

Causes and Risk Factors

 

 There is rarely just one cause. Tension headache most often develops through an interplay of several factors:

 
 1. Muscular Tension and Trigger Points

 Tender knots (trigger points) in neck and jaw muscles are the most consistent finding. A meta-analysis from 2022 (Pain Physician) found that chronic patients had significantly increased tenderness in pericranial muscles (SMD 1.57).

 In people with chronic tension headache, research has found an average of 3.9 trigger points per patient, compared to 1.4 in healthy controls (Couppe et al., 2007).

 

 
 2. Stress and Mental Strain

 Stress activates the sympathetic nervous system and automatically increases muscle tension. One study found that headache frequency increased by 4.3% for every 10-point increase on the stress scale. Many recognize that shoulders rise and jaw clenches during demanding periods.

 

 
 3. Sleep Disturbances

 About 50% of patients with tension headache have sleep problems (Odegard et al., 2010). Poor sleep quality lowers the pain threshold and is an independent risk factor for chronification. Many therefore experience morning headache as a result of poor night sleep.

 

 
 4. Central Sensitization

 With prolonged tension headache, changes occur in the central nervous system. The pain system becomes "overactive" - the brain registers pain signals more strongly than normal. This explains why the headache can persist even after the original triggers are gone.

How is Tension Headache: Everything You Need to Know diagnosed?

How is the Diagnosis Made?

 

 Tension headache is diagnosed primarily through medical history and clinical examination. There is no blood test or imaging that confirms the diagnosis.

 Clinical examination includes:

 
 Systematic palpation of neck and head muscles to identify trigger points and tenderness

 Assessment of neck mobility

 Neurological examination to rule out other causes

 Mapping of headache character, frequency, and triggering factors

 

 
 Do I need an MRI?

 Imaging is rarely necessary. MRI or CT is only ordered when underlying disease is suspected - for example with red flags or atypical presentation. It's important to know that findings such as degenerative changes on MRI are very common even in pain-free individuals, and often do not explain the headache.

Describe treatment options for Tension Headache: Everything You Need to Know.

Treatment

 

 What Can the Chiropractor Do?

 Manual treatment has good evidence for tension headache. A systematic review and meta-analysis from 2020/2022 (Kamonseki et al., Disability and Rehabilitation) analyzed 15 randomized controlled trials with over 1100 participants:

 
 Soft tissue treatment showed large effect:

 
 Pain intensity: SMD -0.86 (large effect)

 Headache frequency: SMD -1.45 (large effect)

 
 

 
 Trigger point treatment had particularly good evidence:

 
 Reduction of 3.5 attacks per month

 Pain intensity reduced by 12.8 points (0-100 scale)

 
 (Falsiroli Maistrello et al., Frontiers in Neurology 2018)

 

 In practice, I often combine several approaches: soft tissue treatment of tight muscles, trigger point therapy (manual or with needles), mobilization of stiff joints in the neck and upper back, as well as guidance on ergonomics and exercises.

 What Can You Do Yourself?

 
 Self-help strategies with documented effect

 
 Strength training for neck and shoulders: Moderate effect (SMD -0.84). Training makes the muscles more robust against static strain.

 Stress management and relaxation: EMG biofeedback and relaxation exercises have Level A evidence (EFNS 2010), with 45-60% average reduction in headache frequency.

 Regular breaks: Get up and move your neck regularly during screen work.

 Jaw tension: Be aware - release the jaw, let the tongue rest lightly.

 Prioritize sleep: Poor sleep lowers the pain threshold.

Prognosis - How Does It Go?

 

 Episodic tension headache generally has a good prognosis:

 Risk Factors for Chronification

 
 Medication overuse (strongest predictor)

 Concurrent migraine

 Sleep problems

 Realistic Expectations

Describe Frequently Asked Questions for Tension Headache: Everything You Need to Know.

Frequently Asked Questions

 

 
 Is tension headache dangerous?

 No, tension headache is not dangerous in itself. It is a primary headache - meaning a condition in itself, not a symptom of underlying disease. However, red flags should always be taken seriously.

 

 
 What is the difference between tension headache and migraine?

 Migraine is often one-sided and pulsating, worsens with physical activity, and typically comes with nausea and both light and sound sensitivity. Tension headache is bilateral, pressing/tightening, does not worsen with activity, and rarely causes nausea.

 

 
 Can a chiropractor help with tension headache?

 Yes, there is moderate to good evidence that manual treatment helps with tension headache. Soft tissue treatment and trigger point therapy have shown large effects in systematic reviews (SMD -0.86 to -1.45).

 

 
 How often should I have treatment?

 For active complaints, 1-2 times per week is common initially. Most notice improvement after 4-6 treatments. For chronic headache, it may take longer.

 

 
 Should I get an MRI of my head?

 Usually not. Tension headache is diagnosed clinically, and imaging is only relevant for atypical symptoms or red flags. MRI often shows "normal findings" that do not explain the headache.

Describe What is Vestibular Migraine? for Vestibular Migraine: When Dizziness Takes Over.

What is Vestibular Migraine?

 

 Vestibular migraine is a neurological condition where migraine mechanisms in the brain affect the balance centers in the brainstem and cerebellum. Contrary to what many believe, you do not need to have a headache during an attack. In fact, only about 25% of patients experience headache simultaneously with dizziness.

 The condition affects 1-3% of the population and is far more common than Meniere's disease, which many are mistakenly diagnosed with. In specialized dizziness clinics, vestibular migraine accounts for up to 25% of all newly referred patients. Women are affected more often than men, at a ratio of approximately 3-5:1.

 
 
 1-3%
 of the population
 

 
 7-8 years
 average wait for diagnosis
 

 
 25%
 have headache during attacks
 

 
 3-5x
 more common in women
 

 

 
 Why is the condition so often overlooked?

 Headache and dizziness rarely occur simultaneously. The patient may have had migraine in their youth that "disappeared," only to develop unexplained dizziness 10-20 years later. In an American study, only 10% of patients who met the criteria for vestibular migraine had been told that migraine was the cause.
