What causes Vestibular Migraine: When Dizziness Takes Over?

Causes and Risk Factors

 

 Pathophysiology - What Happens in the Brain?

 During an attack, CGRP (calcitonin gene-related peptide) is released - a signaling molecule that plays a key role in migraine. CGRP is found both in the trigeminal system and in vestibular ganglia. When released, normal signal processing in the balance centers is disrupted.

 Risk Factors (from most to least common)

 
 Previous Migraine (most important)

 With or without aura - the most important risk factor. Many have had migraine in their youth that "disappeared."

 

 
 Female Gender

 3-5 times higher risk than men.

 

 
 Family History

 40-70% have a family history of migraine or vertigo.

 

 
 Anxiety and Depression

 Often concurrent conditions that can worsen symptoms.

 

 
 Previous Head Injury

 Significantly increases the risk.

 

 Triggers That Can Provoke Attacks

 
 Stress: Both acute stress and "let-down" stress (when you finally relax)

 Sleep: Too little, too much, or irregular sleep patterns

 Hormones: Menstrual cycle and menopause

 Food and drink: Red wine, aged cheese, chocolate, caffeine

 Sensory overstimulation: Bright lights, loud sounds, strong smells

Describe symptoms and signs of Vestibular Migraine: When Dizziness Takes Over.

Symptoms - More Than Just Dizziness

 

 Main Dizziness Symptoms

 
 Spontaneous Rotational Vertigo (45%)

 The room spins, typically lasting 1-4 hours. So intense that you cannot continue activities.

 

 
 Position-Triggered Dizziness (25%)

 Triggered by head movement, but lasts minutes to hours (not seconds as with BPPV/crystals in the ear).

 

 
 Visually Triggered Dizziness (40%)

 Worsens in busy visual environments (shopping centers, escalators). Scrolling on screens triggers symptoms.

 

 Accompanying Symptoms

 
 Nausea (72% of patients)

 Light and sound sensitivity

 Pressure in the head or ears

 Tinnitus (ringing in the ears) - often high-frequency

 Neck pain and stiffness - very common!

How is Vestibular Migraine: When Dizziness Takes Over diagnosed?

Diagnosis

 

 Barany Society/IHS Diagnostic Criteria

 For a diagnosis of "Definite Vestibular Migraine," the following must be met:

 
 At least 5 episodes with vestibular symptoms of moderate to severe intensity

 Duration from 5 minutes to 72 hours

 Current or previous history of migraine (with or without aura)

 At least 50% of attacks must have at least one migraine feature: headache, light/sound sensitivity, or visual aura

 Symptoms cannot be better explained by another diagnosis

 

 Differential Diagnosis

Describe treatment options for Vestibular Migraine: When Dizziness Takes Over.

Treatment

 

 Preventive Medications

 A systematic review ranked effectiveness as follows (Frontiers in Pharmacology, 2023):

 
 First-Line Options

 
 Propranolol (beta-blocker): 60% achieve complete symptom control

 Topiramate (antiepileptic): Moderate evidence

 
 

 
 Second-Line Options

 Venlafaxine, Valproate, Amitriptyline

 

 CGRP Inhibitors - New Treatment Option

 The new CGRP monoclonal antibodies (erenumab, galcanezumab, fremanezumab) show promising results. A prospective study showed that 90% achieved at least 50% reduction in vertigo frequency. Average number of dizziness days fell from 10.3 to 0.8 days per month after 12 months.

 Vestibular Rehabilitation

 Vestibular rehabilitation provides significant improvement and includes:

 
 Eye movement exercises (VOR training)

 Balance training

 Habituation for visual hypersensitivity

 Gradual exposure to trigger situations

 
 Important: Training must be dosed carefully. Too intense training can actually trigger new attacks.

 Manual Treatment and the Neck

 Neck pain is very common in patients with vestibular migraine. A case series from 2024 showed that manual treatment of upper cervical vertebrae provided rapid and lasting improvement. The basis is trigeminocervical convergence - nerve pathways from the upper neck (C1-C3) converge with pathways from the vestibular system.

What is the prognosis for Vestibular Migraine: When Dizziness Takes Over?

Prognosis - How Does It Progress?

 

 With proper treatment, most experience significant improvement. Patients on preventive treatment see reduction in both frequency, intensity, and duration of attacks.

 Realistic Expectations

 
 Relapses are common: Even with good treatment, many will experience periods with more attacks

 Treatment takes time: It may take 2-3 months before preventive medications have full effect

 Individual variation: What works for one person does not necessarily work for another

 

 The positive news is that many find that attacks become less intense and less frequent over the years, especially with good treatment and trigger management. In some cases, prolonged vestibular migraine can develop into PPPD (persistent postural-perceptual dizziness), which requires a different treatment approach.

 What is vestibular migraine?

Describe Muscles and Headache  Trigger Points for Headaches and Migraines  Causes, Types and Treatment.

2Muscles and Headache  Trigger Points

 Muscle tension in neck, shoulder and jaw can cause referred pain to the head. Research shows trigger points (tender knots in muscles) reproduce headache in over 90% of patients with chronic tension headache.

 
 Most Common Muscles That Cause Headache

 
 Suboccipital muscles (92%): Pain inside head, forehead and behind eyes

 Upper trapezius (44-85%): Temple, back of head and eyebrow

 SCM  neck muscle (60-80%): Forehead, around eye, can also cause dizziness

 Masseter and temporalis (36-60%): Temple, cheek, "sinus-like" pain

 Splenius capitis (30-50%): Top of head, behind eye

 
 

 
 Where Does It Hurt? Possible Causes:

 
 Back of head: Often neck-related, suboccipital trigger points, occipital neuralgia

 Temple: Tension headache, trapezius trigger points, TMJ/jaw joint

 Top of head: Tension headache, splenius and semispinalis muscles

 Around eye/forehead: Migraine, cluster headache, sinuses, suboccipital muscles

 Whole head: Tension headache ("band around head")

4Treatment of Headache

 Chiropractic Treatment

 Chiropractic care has documented effect for cervicogenic headache and tension headache with muscular component. A systematic review and meta-analysis showed moderate evidence for spinal manipulation in neck headache.

 
 What I Do

 
 Thorough examination of neck, jaw and shoulder

 Joint mobilization and correction of upper cervical vertebrae

 Soft tissue treatment of trigger points and tight muscles

 Exercises for neck and posture

 Ergonomic advice and preventive strategies

 
 

 Medical Treatment of Migraine

 Migraine often requires medical treatment from a doctor or neurologist.

 
 Acute treatment: Triptans (like sumatriptan) are standard treatment for moderate to severe attacks

 Preventive: Beta-blockers, candesartan, topiramate, amitriptyline

 For chronic migraine: Botox or CGRP inhibitors

6Frequently Asked Questions

 
 
 Can a chiropractor treat headaches?

 Yes, chiropractic care has documented effect for neck headache (cervicogenic headache) and tension headache with muscular component.

 

 
 What is cervicogenic headache?

 Cervicogenic headache is headache caused by dysfunction in the cervical vertebrae (C1-C3) or soft tissue in the neck. Pain starts in the neck and radiates toward forehead, temple or around the eye.

 

 
 Can muscle tension cause headaches?

 Yes, trigger points in neck, shoulder and jaw can cause referred pain to the head. Research shows trigger points reproduce headache in over 90% of patients with chronic tension headache.

 

 
 Can dehydration cause headaches?

 Yes, dehydration is a common headache trigger. When the body lacks sufficient fluids, the brain can temporarily shrink and pull away from the skull, causing pain. Drinking adequate water throughout the day can help prevent dehydration-related headaches.

Who is affected by athletic pubalgia?

 

 Groin injuries account for 5-28% of all sports injuries. Athletic pubalgia specifically accounts for
 about 5% of all groin injuries in athletes. Among athletes with prolonged, unexplained groin pain, 50-80%
 have athletic pubalgia as the underlying cause.

 Men account for over 90% of cases, with a male-to-female risk ratio of approximately
 2.4:1. This difference is likely due to anatomical factors: women have larger and more robust attachment
 points for the rectus abdominis at the symphysis. Peak incidence is between ages 26-28.

Describe symptoms and signs of Athletic Pubalgia (Sports Hernia).

Symptoms

 

 The typical course is insidious onset of pain - not an acute event. The pain is felt deep in the groin or
 lower abdomen and worsens with activity. It improves with rest but returns when training resumes.

 
 Characteristic features

 
 Deep, aching pain in the groin that worsens with sprinting, kicking, direction changes

 Pain with coughing or sneezing (increased abdominal pressure)

 Vague, diffuse pain that can be difficult to localize precisely

 Radiation to the inner thigh, perineum, or testicles in men

 Morning stiffness after activity

 Loss of function that forces the athlete to reduce or stop activity

 
 

 The pain usually starts on one side but can develop on both sides in up to 43% of cases.

How is Athletic Pubalgia (Sports Hernia) diagnosed?

Diagnosis

 

 Clinical examination

 The diagnosis is primarily clinical. Five findings that support athletic pubalgia:

 
 Deep groin/lower abdominal pain that worsens with sports activity and improves with rest

 Palpation tenderness over the pubic ramus at the rectus abdominis attachment

 Pain with resisted hip adduction

 Pain with resisted sit-up

 No palpable inguinal hernia

 

 
 Resisted adduction sit-up test (RASUT)

 78% sensitivity and 88% negative predictive value. A valuable test to support the
 diagnosis in a clinical setting.

 

 Imaging

 MRI is the standard imaging modality when confirmation is needed. MRI has 68%
 sensitivity and 100% specificity for rectus abdominis injury, and 86% sensitivity and 89% specificity for
 adductor tendon injury.

 
 Important to remember

 MRI findings must be interpreted cautiously. Studies have shown that asymptomatic ice hockey players
 often have MRI changes resembling athletic pubalgia.

Describe treatment options for Athletic Pubalgia (Sports Hernia).

Treatment

 

 Conservative treatment is the first choice for everyone with suspected athletic pubalgia. Success rates
 vary from 14-100% depending on protocol quality.

 The critical distinction: active vs. passive approach. A landmark study showed 79%
 success with structured exercise therapy versus only 14% with passive physiotherapy (massage, stretching,
 electrotherapy).

 
 What can a chiropractor do?

 
 Thorough examination to distinguish athletic pubalgia from other causes of groin
 pain

 Manual treatment of adjacent areas: hip, lower back, pelvis - which often have
 reduced mobility

 Guidance in the exercise program with focus on correct execution

 Soft tissue treatment as a supplement to active rehabilitation

 Assessment of when further referral is necessary

 
 

 What can you do yourself? (Modified Holmich protocol)

 
 Phase 1 (weeks 0-4)

 Rest from triggering activities, pain relief, gentle mobility exercises, core awareness, and
 transversus abdominis activation.

 

 
 Phase 2 (weeks 4-8)

 Progressive strength training of adductors, abdominal muscles, and hip muscles. Balance and
 coordination exercises. Gradual jogging.

 

 
 Phase 3 (weeks 8-12)

 Sport-specific training, rotational exercises, single-leg exercises, plyometrics and speed training.
 Gradual return to full activity.

Frequently Asked Questions

 

 
 Can I continue training with athletic pubalgia?

 It is not recommended to train through the pain. Continued activity worsens the
 condition and prolongs rehabilitation time. A modified training plan that avoids triggering movements
 (kicking, rapid turns) is necessary at first.

 

 
 What is the difference between athletic pubalgia and a regular groin strain?
 

 Groin strain (adductor strain) affects the muscle tissue and usually resolves
 within 3-4 weeks. Athletic pubalgia involves the tendon-bone attachment at the pubic bone and has a more
 prolonged course. Adductor strain accounts for 62% of groin injuries in soccer.

 

 
 Do I need an MRI to get a diagnosis?

 Not necessarily. Clinical examination is often sufficient to make the diagnosis.
 MRI is useful to confirm suspicion, rule out other causes, and plan any surgery - but changes on MRI are
 also found in asymptomatic athletes.

 

 
 How long does it take to recover?

 With structured conservative treatment: 9-18.5 weeks to return to sport. After

Patient asks: "How do I know if the pain is coming from my back or hip?"

Hip pain is typically felt in the groin and front of the thigh, and worsens with hip rotation. Back pain often sits lower in the back and can radiate down the back of the leg. Bending forward often worsens back pain, while hip flexion worsens hip pain. A clinical examination is necessary for accurate diagnosis.
You are a clinical documentation assistant for chiropractors. Generate professional medical documentation.
Patient asks: "Can I have both back and hip problems at the same time?"

Yes, this is actually common and is called 'hip-spine syndrome'. Studies show that up to 30% of patients with hip osteoarthritis also have significant spinal disease. The problems can also affect each other - hip problems can change gait and put more stress on the back, and vice versa.
You are a clinical documentation assistant for chiropractors. Generate professional medical documentation.
Patient asks: "What is the difference between sciatica and piriformis syndrome?"

Sciatica is caused by compression of the nerve root in the spine (often from a disc herniation), while piriformis syndrome is caused by compression of the sciatic nerve where it passes through the buttock muscles. The symptoms can be similar, but piriformis syndrome rarely causes neurological deficits and often worsens with prolonged sitting.
You are a clinical documentation assistant for chiropractors. Generate professional medical documentation.
Patient asks: "Do I need an MRI to find out what's wrong?"

Not necessarily. A thorough clinical examination can often distinguish between back and hip problems. MRI is indicated when there is suspicion of serious pathology, neurological deficits, or when conservative treatment doesn't improve symptoms after 6-8 weeks. Many MRI findings (such as degenerative changes) are also found in symptom-free individuals.

Identify red flags for Back, Hip or Sciatica?:

A Common and Complex Picture

 Up to 30% of patients with hip osteoarthritis have simultaneous
 significant spinal disease. This is called "hip-spine syndrome" and complicates both
 diagnosis and treatment.

 Why Does This Occur?

 
 Biomechanical coupling: A stiff hip increases load on the back
 

 Compensatory patterns: Altered gait affects the entire kinetic
 chain

 Common risk factors: Age, overweight, physical inactivity

 Sensitization: Chronic pain can make the entire region
 hypersensitive

 

 Treatment Implications:

 When both back and hip are involved, both must be addressed to achieve improvement. A
 hip replacement, for example, cannot solve a simultaneous back problem, and vice
 versa.

 from the hip joint, from the back via the nerves, or from both places simultaneously.
 Research shows that almost half of all patients with hip problems are first given a
 wrong diagnosis - often treated for back problems they don't have.

 This article helps you understand the most important differences and why a thorough
 examination is so important.

Describe Hip-Spine Syndrome for Back, Hip or Sciatica?.

Hip-Spine Syndrome

 

 
 A Common and Complex Picture

 Up to 30% of patients with hip osteoarthritis have simultaneous
 significant spinal disease. This is called "hip-spine syndrome" and complicates both
 diagnosis and treatment.

 Why Does This Occur?

 
 Biomechanical coupling: A stiff hip increases load on the back
 

 Compensatory patterns: Altered gait affects the entire kinetic
 chain

 Common risk factors: Age, overweight, physical inactivity

 Sensitization: Chronic pain can make the entire region
 hypersensitive

 

 Treatment Implications:

 When both back and hip are involved, both must be addressed to achieve improvement. A
 hip replacement, for example, cannot solve a simultaneous back problem, and vice
 versa.

How is Back, Hip or Sciatica? diagnosed?

Important Clinical Tests

 

 
 Straight Leg Raise (SLR): Lifting of straight leg while lying on
 back. Positive when pain radiates past the knee at 30-70 degree lift - suggests
 nerve root involvement.

 FADIR test: Flexion, adduction and internal rotation of the hip.
 Positive with groin pain - suggests intra-articular hip pathology.

 FABER test: Flexion, abduction and external rotation (figure-4
 position). Pain in groin suggests hip, pain in back suggests SI joint.

 Log Roll test: Passive rolling of the leg inward/outward while
 lying on back. The only isolated hip joint test - positive with groin pain.

 Trendelenburg test: Standing on one leg. Pelvic drop on the
 opposite side indicates weak gluteus medius.

 

 
 Red Flags - Seek Medical Help Immediately

 
 Loss of bladder or bowel control (cauda equina)

 Progressive weakness in the leg/foot

 Numbness in the "saddle area"

 Unexplained weight loss and night sweats

 Fever combined with back/hip pain

Treatment Approach

 

 Treatment depends entirely on correct diagnosis. This is why a thorough examination is so
 important:

 For back pain/sciatica:

 
 Manual treatment of the back

 Exercises to reduce nerve pressure

 Core muscle strengthening

 Ergonomic adjustments

 Possibly injections or surgery in severe cases

 

 For hip pain:

 
 Manual treatment of hip and pelvis

 Strength training for hip muscles

 Mobility exercises

 Activity modification

 Possibly injections or surgery for osteoarthritis/FAI

 

 For combined hip-spine syndrome:

 
 Treat both problems in parallel

 Focus on global movement and function

 Gradual progression of exercises

 Often longer treatment course necessary

 As a chiropractor with specialized competence in the musculoskeletal system, I am

 diagnosis. The goal is to avoid the misdiagnosis that affects so many, and provide
 targeted treatment from the first consultation.

Describe Frequently Asked Questions for Back, Hip or Sciatica?.

Frequently Asked Questions

 

 
 How do I know if the pain is coming from my back or hip?

 Hip pain is typically felt in the groin and front of the thigh,
 and worsens with hip rotation. Back pain often sits lower in the back and can
 radiate down the back of the leg. Bending forward often worsens back pain, while hip
 flexion worsens hip pain. A clinical examination is necessary for accurate
 diagnosis.

 

 
 Can I have both back and hip problems at the same time?

 Yes, this is actually common and is called "hip-spine syndrome".
 Studies show that up to 30% of patients with hip osteoarthritis also have
 significant spinal disease. The problems can also affect each other - hip problems
 can change gait and put more stress on the back, and vice versa.

 

 
 What is the difference between sciatica and piriformis
 syndrome?

 Sciatica is caused by compression of the nerve root in the spine
 (often from a disc herniation), while piriformis syndrome is caused by compression
 of the sciatic nerve where it passes through the buttock muscles. The symptoms can
 be similar, but piriformis syndrome rarely causes neurological deficits and often
 worsens with prolonged sitting.

 

 
 Do I need an MRI to find out what's wrong?

 Not necessarily. A thorough clinical examination can often

 of serious pathology, neurological deficits, or when conservative treatment doesn't

Describe GTPS - The Modern Understanding for Why Bursitis Is Rarely the Problem.

GTPS - The Modern Understanding

 

 Experts now use the term GTPS - Greater Trochanteric Pain Syndrome as an umbrella term
 for pain on the outside of the hip. This includes:

 
 Gluteal tendinopathy

 Degenerative changes in the tendons of the gluteus medius and/or minimus. This is the most common
 cause.

 

 
 Gluteal tendon tears

 Partial or complete tendon ruptures that can develop over time.

 

 
 Bursitis

 Inflammation in the bursa - but this is only a small proportion of cases.

 

 
 External snapping hip

 The IT band "clicks" over the trochanter during movement.

 

 
 Why It Matters

 Calling the condition "bursitis" leads to wrong treatment. Cortisone injections for inflammation don't
 make sense when the problem is degenerative tendons. In fact, cortisone can further weaken tendons and
 worsen the problem long-term.

 Key Findings

Describe Why Cortisone Isn't the Solution for Why Bursitis Is Rarely the Problem.

Why Cortisone Isn't the Solution

 

 
 Problems with Cortisone Injections

 
 Short-term effect: Often relieves for 4-8 weeks, then the pain returns

 Tendon weakness: Cortisone can weaken tendons and increase risk of rupture

 Not addressing the cause: Doesn't tackle underlying muscle weakness

 Repeated injections: Many patients end up with serial injections

 Fat tissue atrophy: Can cause sunken skin and altered tissue quality

 
 

 This doesn't mean cortisone never has a place. For patients with very severe pain, a single injection can
 provide a "window" where exercises can be started. But cortisone alone is not the solution.

Describe What Actually Helps for Why Bursitis Is Rarely the Problem.

What Actually Helps

 

 
 Evidence-Based Treatment of GTPS

 
 Load management: Avoid provocations that worsen symptoms

 Progressive strength training: Exercises for gluteal muscles

 Patient education: Understanding the condition and prognosis

 Manual therapy: Can help as a supplement to exercises

 Patience: Tendons need time to heal (months, not weeks)

 
 

 Load Management: Avoiding Provocations

 The first step is to reduce loads that irritate the tendons:

 
 Avoid lying on the painful side - use a pillow between your knees

 Don't cross your legs when sitting

 Avoid standing on one leg with the hip pushed out to the side

 Be careful with stretching - many stretches compress the tendons

 Limit stairs/hills in the acute phase

 

 Progressive Strength Training

 
 Phase 1: Isometric Exercises (weeks 1-3)

 Static muscle contractions without movement. For example: Stand by a wall and press the outer leg out
 against the wall for 30-45 seconds. Minimal provocation, initiates tendon healing.

 

 
 Phase 2: Isotonic Exercises (weeks 3-8)

 Exercises with movement under load. Side-lying leg raises, standing hip abduction with resistance band,
 "clamshell" exercises. Gradual increase in resistance over time.

 

 
 Phase 3: Functional Exercises (week 8+)

 Exercises that mimic daily activities and sports. Single-leg exercises, lunges in various directions,
 stair walking, possibly running.

Describe What is FAI? for FAI - Hip Impingement.

What is FAI?

 

 FAI (Femoroacetabular Impingement), often called "hip impingement," is a
 common cause of hip pain. It is a condition where the
 shape of the hip joint leads to bone-on-bone contact in certain positions. This can
 irritate cartilage and the labrum over time.

 FAI is not a disease, but an anatomical variant. Many people have FAI
 morphology without having pain. The problem arises when this shape is combined with
 activities requiring large hip movements.

 
 
 10-15%
 of population
 

 
 20-40
 most common age
 

 
 2:1
 men vs women (cam)
 

 
 60-70%
 better without surgery
 

 

 The Three Types of FAI

 
 
 Cam Type

 A bump on the femoral head that impinges against the hip socket during flexion.
 Most common in men and athletes. Often develops during adolescence.

 

 
 Pincer Type

 The hip socket extends too far out and covers too much of the femoral head. More
 common in women. Causes the labrum to be pinched, which can develop into a labral tear.

 

 
 Mixed Type

 A combination of cam and pincer. The most common form. Approx. 70% of FAI
 patients have both.
You are a clinical documentation assistant for chiropractors. Generate professional medical documentation.
What causes FAI - Hip Impingement?

Causes and Development

 

 How Does FAI Develop?

 FAI morphology typically develops during adolescence (12-18 years),
 during the period of rapid bone growth. Intensive sports during this period can affect
 how the hip forms.

 
 Genetics - hereditary component

 Sports in adolescence - especially soccer, hockey, dance

 Repetitive hip movements during bone growth

 Load before growth plates close

 

 Why Do Some Get Pain?

 Many have FAI shape without knowing it. Pain arises when:

 
 Activity level increases suddenly

 Participating in sports with large hip range of motion

 Labrum or cartilage becomes irritated/damaged over time

 Muscle strength and control are insufficient

 

 
 Important to Understand

 FAI shape on X-ray does not automatically mean you need treatment. Many live
 perfectly fine with FAI morphology. It is symptoms and function that matter, not
 images.

 When Should You Seek Help?

How is FAI - Hip Impingement diagnosed?

Diagnosis

 

 FAI is diagnosed through a combination of history, clinical examination, and imaging.

 Clinical Tests

 
 FADIR test - flexion, adduction, internal rotation (highest
 sensitivity)

 FABER test - flexion, abduction, external rotation

 Movement assessment - often reduced internal rotation

 Strength and control testing

 

 Imaging

 
 X-ray - shows cam and pincer morphology, alpha angle

 MRI - shows labrum, cartilage, and bone marrow

 CT - detailed 3D image of bone shape

 

 
 Alpha Angle

 On X-ray, the alpha angle is measured to assess cam morphology. Over 55-60 degrees is
 considered elevated. But remember: An elevated angle alone does not mean you need
 treatment - only if you have symptoms.

Describe treatment options for FAI - Hip Impingement.

Treatment

 

 Conservative Treatment (First Choice)

 The important UK FASHIoN study (2018) compared surgery with physical
 therapy for FAI. After 12 months, the difference was minimal - both groups improved.

 
 Conservative Treatment Includes:

 
 Activity modification - avoid provocative movements temporarily
 

 Strength training - hip muscles, core, pelvis

 Mobility training - within pain-free ranges

 Motor control - movement quality

 Gradual return to activity

 
 

 Chiropractic Treatment

 As a chiropractor, I can help with:

 
 Thorough hip examination

 Mobilization of hip, pelvis, and lower back

 Soft tissue treatment of tight hip muscles

 Individually tailored strength program

 Activity adaptation

 

 Exercises to Avoid/Modify

 
 Deep squats - limit depth

 Wide lunges - keep narrower

 Hip flexor stretches - avoid extreme positions

 Kickbacks in end-range

 

 Surgery (Hip Arthroscopy)

 Surgery is considered when:

 
 3-6 months of conservative treatment does not provide sufficient improvement

 Significant cam/pincer morphology

 Labral tear requiring repair

 High activity demands (elite sports)

 

 
 Important on Surgery

 
 Even after successful surgery, rehabilitation takes 6-12 months

 Results are best in patients without osteoarthritis

 Training and rehabilitation are equally important after surgery

What is the prognosis for FAI - Hip Impingement?

Prognosis

 

 With Conservative Treatment:

 
 60-70% achieve satisfactory function

 Many return to full activity (with modifications)

 Rehabilitation typically takes 3-6 months

 

 With Surgery:

 
 80-90% report improvement

 Return to sport: 6-12 months

 Good results in patients under 40 without osteoarthritis

 

 Long-term Perspective

 It is still unclear whether FAI treatment prevents osteoarthritis in the long term.
 Studies are ongoing. The most important thing is to maintain good hip function and
 muscle strength.

 
 FAI and Osteoarthritis

 FAI is a risk factor for hip osteoarthritis,
 but most people with FAI do not develop osteoarthritis. Good muscle strength and
 control can reduce load on the joint and protect the cartilage.

Describe Frequently Asked Questions for FAI - Hip Impingement.

Frequently Asked Questions

 

 
 What is the difference between cam and pincer?

 Cam FAI is caused by a bump on the femoral head impinging
 against the socket. Pincer FAI is caused by the socket extending too far out. Cam is
 most common in men, pincer in women. most have a combination (mixed type).

 

 
 Does FAI need surgery?

 No, most people with FAI do not need surgery. The UK FASHIoN
 study showed that physical therapy was almost as effective as surgery after 12
 months. Surgery is considered only after 3-6 months without sufficient improvement
 from conservative treatment.

 

 
 Can I continue to exercise?

 Yes, but with modifications. Avoid exercises that cause pain,
 especially deep squats and extreme hip positions. Many activities can continue with
 modifications. Hip strength training is actually important for improvement.

 

 
 Will FAI lead to osteoarthritis?

 FAI is a risk factor for hip
 osteoarthritis, but most do not develop osteoarthritis. Good muscle strength
 and control can reduce risk. It is unclear if treatment prevents osteoarthritis
 long-term.

 

 
 Why did I get FAI?

 FAI morphology typically develops in adolescence during bone
 growth. Genetics play a role, and intensive sports in adolescence (especially
 soccer, hockey, dance) can affect hip shape. It's not something you "did wrong".

Patient asks: "How long does it take to recover from GTPS?"

GTPS often takes 6-9 months to treat effectively. The LEAP study showed that 79% were better after 1 year with proper exercise treatment. Getting worse before better is not unusual - many experience increased pain in the first weeks before improvement.

What is GTPS?

 

 GTPS (Greater Trochanteric Pain Syndrome) is an umbrella term for pain on the outside
 of the hip around the greater trochanter - the bony prominence you can feel on the outside of your hip.
 It is one of the most common forms of hip pain.

 Previously, this condition was often called "trochanteric bursitis", but research has shown that the
 pain is rarely caused by inflammation in the bursae. In 90% of cases, the pain is caused by
 tendinopathy (tendon problems) in the gluteus medius and/or gluteus minimus tendons.

 Why does it affect women more often?

 Women have wider pelvises, which creates a larger angle in the hip joint. This increases compression
 of the gluteal tendons against the greater trochanter, especially during activities like walking,
 standing on one leg, or lying on the side.

Causes and Risk Factors

 

 Compression is the Main Problem

 The gluteal tendons become compressed against the greater trochanter in certain positions and

 Side-lying - especially on the affected side

 Standing with hip pushed out to the side ("hanging on one hip")

 Overweight - increases the load

How is GTPS - Pain on the Outside of the Hip diagnosed?

Diagnosis

 

 The diagnosis is primarily made clinically through history and physical examination.

 Clinical Tests

 
 Palpation of the greater trochanter - tenderness over the bony prominence

 FABER test - reproduces lateral hip pain

 Single leg stance - pain after 30 seconds

 Resisted hip abduction - pain with resistance

 

 Imaging

 MRI can show tendon degeneration, partial tears, or bursitis, but is rarely necessary
 to make the diagnosis. Clinical examination is often sufficient.

 X-ray can rule out osteoarthritis and other bone changes.

Describe treatment options for GTPS - Pain on the Outside of the Hip.

Treatment

 

 First-line Treatment: Exercise

 The most important study on GTPS treatment is the LEAP study (Mellor et al., BMJ
 2018), which compared exercise, cortisone, and "wait and see".

 
 Results after 1 year (LEAP study)

 
 Exercise: 79% reported global improvement

 Cortisone: 58% reported global improvement

 Wait and see: 52% reported global improvement

 
 Exercise was clearly well-suited - and the effect lasted!

 

 Exercise Principles

 
 Isometric exercises first - holding the position without movement

 Gradual progression - from isometric to isotonic to functional

 Focus on gluteus medius and minimus

 Avoid compression positions during training

 Train 3-4 times per week for at least 12 weeks

 

 Chiropractic Treatment

 I often combine:

 
 Soft tissue treatment of gluteal muscles and ITB

 Manual therapy of hip and pelvis

 Individually tailored exercise program

 Advice on load management

 

 What About Cortisone?

 Cortisone provides rapid pain relief in the first weeks, but the LEAP study showed that the effect does
 not last. After 1 year, the cortisone group was no better than the "wait and see" group. Additionally,
 repeated injections can damage tendon tissue.

 
 When to consider cortisone?

 Cortisone may be appropriate as a "breathing space" to get started with exercise if the pain is so
 severe that exercise is not possible. But it should never be the a key treatment approach.

Describe Myth: "It's bursitis" in the context of Hip Pain?.

Pain on the OUTSIDE of the hip

 Very common
 

 Typical signs: Pain over the large bony prominence on the outside of the hip. Hurts
 to lie on that side at night. Gets worse with stairs, longer walks or getting up from a chair. Can
 radiate down the outside of the thigh toward the knee.

 
 Myth: "It's bursitis"

 No, it almost never is. Studies show that less than 5% actually have inflammation in the bursa. In
 85-98%, the problem is in the tendons of the gluteal muscles - gluteus medius and minimus. This is
 called gluteal tendinopathy or GTPS, and requires completely different treatment
 than cortisone.

 

 Who is affected? GTPS occurs in 15% of women and 6-8% of men between 50-79 years.
 Women are affected over 3 times as often. The condition accounts for 10-20% of all hip pain at the GP.
 

 Prognosis: The LEAP study showed that exercise + education gave 78.6%
 success rate after one year - better than cortisone (58%) and "wait and see" (52%).
 Improvement takes time (6-9 months), but most get better without injections.

 

 
 
 
 Pain in the GROIN (front of hip)

 Complex
 

 Typical signs: Deep pain at the front of the hip or groin. Worst when bending the
 hip far (putting on shoes, sitting for long periods, climbing stairs). May feel stiff in the morning.
 Some experience clicking or catching.

 Groin pain can have several causes - and age and activity level provide important clues:

 
 Hip osteoarthritis: Most common in those over 55-60 years. 10-15% of people over
 65 have symptomatic hip osteoarthritis. Causes gradually increasing stiffness, especially with
 internal rotation. Exercise is the first choice.

 FAI (femoroacetabular impingement): Pinching in the hip joint due to bone shape.
 Common in young, active people. Causes pain with deep flexion + internal rotation. 37% of pain-free
 people have FAI morphology on MRI - so images must be interpreted carefully.

 Labral tear: Damage to the cartilage ring around the hip. Often causes clicking,
 catching or feeling that the hip "pops out." 69% of pain-free adults have labral tears on
 MRI - so not every tear needs treatment.

 Iliopsoas tendinopathy: Pain when lifting the leg, often with "snapping" at the
 front of the hip. Common in runners, dancers and soccer players.

 
 

 
 
 
 Pain in the BUTTOCK or back

 Difficult to sort out
 

 Typical signs: Pain in the buttock, lower back or behind the hip. Can radiate down
 the thigh. Often worse when sitting, standing on one leg or turning in bed.

 Buttock pain can come from the hip, back OR pelvis. Here are some clues:

 
 SI joint ("pelvic loosening"): If you can point with one finger to where it hurts
 - right at the "dimple" at the top of the buttock - it's often the SI joint. SI joint problems
 account for 15-30% of all chronic low back pain.

 Piriformis syndrome: Deep buttock pain that can radiate down the back of the
 thigh. Mimics sciatica, but comes from a tight muscle - not the back.

 Sit bone (proximal hamstring): Painful to sit, especially on hard chairs? Pain
 where "buttock meets thigh"? This could be tendinopathy at the hamstring attachment.
 Important: don't stretch the hamstrings - it makes it worse.
 

 Referred pain from the back: Problems in the low back can cause pain that feels
 like it's in the buttock or hip. Studies show that 71% of patients with hip problems actually have
 buttock pain as their dominant symptom.

 
 

 
 
 
 Numbness, tingling or burning pain

 Nerve involvement
 

 Typical signs: Burning, tingling or numb feeling. Can be on the outside of the
 thigh, or radiate from back/buttock down the leg.

 
 Meralgia paresthetica: Compression of a nerve causing numbness or burning on the
 outside of the thigh. Common with overweight, pregnancy or tight pants/belts. 85% get better
 without surgery.

 Sciatica/lumbar radiculopathy: Radiation from back/buttock down the back or
 outside of the leg - often past the knee to the foot. Usually caused by an irritated nerve root in
 the back.

What is a Hip Pointer?

 

 A hip pointer is an injury where you get a bruise or blood collection (hematoma) on the iliac crest - the
 curved bony ridge you can feel on the side of your hip. The injury occurs when the iliac crest receives a
 direct blow, typically from a fall, tackle, or collision with an opponent.

 
 Prevalence

 Hip injuries account for 5-10% of all sports injuries, and hip pointer is a subset of these. In NFL
 data from 1997-2006, hip pointer accounted for 0.3% of all injuries and led to an average of 5.6 days
 away from training.

 The injury is most common in contact sports such as football, ice hockey, rugby, and
 handball.

Treatment

 

 
 What Can a Chiropractor Do?

 The chiropractor can play a role in the subacute phase and rehabilitation:

 
 Thorough examination - assess severity and rule out fractures/other diagnoses

 Important: Manual treatment is contraindicated in the acute phase (first 48-72 hours).

 Self-Care

 PRICE protocol (first 48-72 hours):

 
 Protection - avoid activities that worsen pain

 Rest - relative rest, not necessarily complete immobilization

 Ice - 15-20 minutes every 2-3 hours, never directly on skin

 Compression - elastic bandage if possible

 Elevation - lie with hip elevated when possible

 

 "NO HARM" rule for the first days: No heat, no alcohol, no running, no massage.

 Degeneration - natural aging

Diagnosis

 

 Diagnosis of labral tear requires a combination of medical history, clinical tests and often imaging.
 

 Clinical tests

 No, most labral tears can be treated without surgery. Research shows that 50-80%

 Can the labrum heal on its own?

 The labrum has limited blood supply and therefore heals poorly on its own.
 However, symptoms can often improve significantly with proper exercise. By strengthening the muscles
 around the hip, the load on the labrum is reduced, and many become nearly symptom-free.

 

 
 Can I continue to exercise with a labral tear?

 Yes, but you need to modify your training. Avoid exercises that cause pain,
 especially deep squatting and rotation under load. Many activities like cycling, swimming and strength
 training can be performed with modifications.

 

 
 How do I know if I have a labral tear?

 Typical signs are deep groin pain, clicking in the hip and pain with rotation. A
 chiropractor can perform specific tests. MRI with contrast (arthrography) can confirm the diagnosis,
 but is often not necessary if conservative treatment works.

 

 
 Is a labral tear the same as hip osteoarthritis?

 No, but they can be related. Labral tear affects the cartilage rim around the
 hip socket, while osteoarthritis is wear of the joint cartilage.

Describe What is meralgia paresthetica? for Meralgia Paresthetica.

What is meralgia paresthetica?

 

 Meralgia paresthetica (MP) is a condition where the lateral femoral cutaneous
 nerve becomes compressed or irritated. This causes burning pain, numbness or tingling on the
 outer thigh. The condition is one of several causes of hip pain that can be
 treated conservatively.

 The affected nerve:

 
 Comes from spinal levels L2-L3

 Runs through the pelvis and exits under the inguinal ligament

 Is a purely sensory nerve - only causes sensory symptoms

 Supplies the skin on the outer and front of the thigh

 

 The nerve is particularly vulnerable to compression where it passes under the inguinal ligament near
 the hip bone.

 
 
 4.3/10000
 incidence per year
 

 
 85%
 recover without surgery
 

 
 7x
 increased risk with diabetes
 

 
 30-40 years
 most common age
 

 

 
 Why is it called meralgia paresthetica?

 Meralgia comes from Greek "meros" (thigh) + "algos" (pain).
 Paresthetica means abnormal sensations. So: "painful sensory disturbances in the
 thigh".

Causes and risk factors

 

 Common causes

 
 Tight clothing - pants, belts, corsets, spandex

 Obesity - fatty tissue puts pressure on the nerve

 Pregnancy - growing abdomen and hormonal changes (see also pelvic pain in pregnancy)

 Prolonged standing - increases stretch on the nerve

 Diabetes - makes nerves more vulnerable

 Surgery/trauma - in the pelvic or groin area

 

 Mechanical causes

 
 Tool belts - police equipment, carpenter belts

 Car seats - seat belt pressure on long drives

 Sports equipment - cycling shorts, climbing harnesses

 Hip surgery - positioning during surgery

 

 Medical causes

 
 Diabetes mellitus - 7 times increased risk

 Ascites - fluid in the abdomen

 Pelvic tumor - rare, but must be ruled out

 Scoliosis or pelvic asymmetry - can also cause SI
 joint problems

 

 
 Note for diabetes

 
 Diabetics have 7 times increased risk for meralgia paresthetica

 Poor blood sugar control damages nerves in general

 With diabetes and MP - check blood sugar control

Describe symptoms and signs of Meralgia Paresthetica.

Symptoms

 

 Typical symptoms

 
 Burning pain on the outer thigh

 Numbness - reduced skin sensation

 Tingling or prickling - "ants crawling"

 Hyperesthesia - hypersensitivity, pain with light touch

 Symptoms in a defined area - approximately 15x20 cm on the thigh

 

 Important characteristics

 
 Only sensory symptoms - never muscle weakness

 One-sided - usually affects only one thigh (in 80%)

 Worsens with standing/walking - improves with sitting

 No back or groin pain

 

 Symptoms worsen with:

 
 Prolonged standing

 Extended walking

 Hip extension (stretching hip backward)

 Tight pants or belt

 Lying on stomach

 

 Symptoms improve with:

 
 Sitting - especially with bent hip

 Loose clothing

 Bending hip forward

 

 
 How to distinguish from other conditions?

 Meralgia paresthetica causes no weakness in the leg. If you have weakness in thigh
 or hip, the symptoms are likely from the spine or another nerve. Sciatica causes symptoms on the
 back of the leg, not the front. Pain on the outside of the hip can also be caused by
 GTPS/gluteal tendinopathy, while deep buttock pain may
 indicate piriformis syndrome.

What is osteitis pubis?

 

 The symphysis pubis is the anchoring point for two muscle groups that pull in opposite directions: rectus
 abdominis (abdominal muscles pulling upward) and the adductors (inner thigh muscles pulling downward).
 When these muscles become imbalanced, abnormal shear forces occur through the joint.

 The condition is 2-5 times more common in men than women. Average age at diagnosis is
 30-50 years for men and mid-30s for women.

 prevalence in athletes

 of groin pain in athletes
 

 
 2-5x
 more common in men

What causes Osteitis Pubis - Chiropractor in Oslo?

Causes and risk factors

 

 From most to least common:

 
 1. Sports-related overuse (most common)

 Football, ice hockey, rugby, long-distance running and other sports with kicking, direction changes or
 repetitive loading. Football players have the highest risk at 10-18% of injuries annually.

 

 
 2. Pregnancy and childbirth

 During pregnancy, pelvic joints loosen due to the hormone relaxin. After prolonged or complicated
 delivery, inflammation can occur, especially combined with muscular imbalance.

 

 
 3. Pelvic surgery (least common)

 Urological or gynecological procedures can trigger the condition. Incidence after urethropexy surgery
 is 0.7-2.5%.

 

 Risk factors

 
 Weak core and pelvic muscles

 Limited hip mobility

 Rapid increase in training load

 Previous groin injuries

 Imbalance between adductor and abdominal strength

How is Osteitis Pubis - Chiropractor in Oslo diagnosed?

Diagnostics

 

 Diagnosis is made primarily through medical history and clinical examination. Imaging is used to confirm
 suspicion or rule out other conditions.

 Clinical examination

 
 Pubic spring test

 Direct pressure over the pubic symphysis and lateral pressure on the pubic rami. Reproduction of
 familiar pain is considered the most specific test.

 

 
 Squeeze test (adduction test)

 The patient lies on their back and squeezes knees together against resistance. The test correlates well
 with bone marrow edema on MRI.

 

 Imaging

 MRI is the gold standard and effectively distinguishes between acute and chronic
 changes. Acute findings include bone marrow edema and joint fluid, while chronic changes show sclerosis,
 cysts and osteophytes.

 
 Important to remember

 MRI and X-ray findings don't always correlate with symptoms. Many athletes have imaging findings
 without having any problems.

Describe treatment options for Osteitis Pubis - Chiropractor in Oslo.

Treatment

 

 Conservative treatment is the first choice and gives good results in most cases. A systematic review
 found that 97.6% of patients in case series returned to sport with conservative approach.
 Surgery is rarely necessary.

 
 What can the chiropractor do?

 The evidence base for chiropractic treatment of osteitis pubis is limited to case reports. Clinical
 experience suggests that a combination of several approaches often works well:

 
 Mobilization of pelvic and hip joints

 Treatment of muscular trigger points in adductors, hip flexors and abdominal muscles

 Assessment and treatment of SI joint (posterior pelvic joint)

 Individually tailored exercise program focusing on core stability

 Guidance on load management and gradual return to sport

 
 

 What can you do yourself?

 
 Reduce provocative activity: Avoid kicking, jumping and rapid direction changes in
 the acute phase

 Alternative training: Swimming and cycling can often be continued pain-free

 Core stabilization: Exercises for transversus abdominis and pelvic floor. The
 Copenhagen exercise has strong Scandinavian evidence

 Adduction exercises: Gradual strength training of the inner thigh muscles

 Ice/heat: Can provide temporary symptom relief

 

 Treatment course

 With structured rehabilitation, most return to full activity within 9.5 weeks average
 (4-14 weeks). Rest alone without structured program can take 8 months, often with relapses.

Describe What is pelvic girdle pain in pregnancy? for Pelvic Girdle Pain in Pregnancy.

What is pelvic girdle pain in pregnancy?

 

 Pelvic girdle pain in pregnancy (PGP - Pelvic Girdle Pain) is pain in the pelvic
 region that occurs during pregnancy. It is one of the most common hip and
 pelvic problems pregnant women experience.

 The pelvis consists of three joints that can be affected:

 
 Two SI joints (sacroiliac joints) - at the
 back, between the sacrum and hip

 Symphysis - at the front, where the two hip bones meet

 

 During pregnancy, these joints become more mobile to prepare the body for childbirth. This is normal
 and necessary but can lead to pain and instability.

 
 
 45-80%
 of pregnant women get pain
 

 
 25%
 have severe problems
 

 
 7%
 have persistent problems
 

 
 6-12 mo
 recovery after birth
 

 

 
 Symphysis Pubis Dysfunction (SPD)

 SPD is pain in the symphysis - the joint at the front of the pelvis. Symptoms include pain in the
 groin area, pain when walking, and difficulty spreading the legs. Treatment is similar to other pelvic
 pain.
You are a clinical documentation assistant for chiropractors. Generate professional medical documentation.
What causes Pelvic Girdle Pain in Pregnancy?

Causes

 

 Hormonal changes

 During pregnancy, the body produces hormones that make the ligaments more elastic:

 
 Relaxin - increases 10-fold, makes ligaments more elastic

 Estrogen and progesterone - contribute to softer connective tissue

 
 This is necessary for the pelvis to expand during childbirth, but also makes the joints less stable.
 

 Mechanical changes

 
 Weight gain - typically 10-15 kg increases the load on the pelvis

 Changed center of gravity - the belly pulls forward

 Increased curve in the back (lordosis) - compensation for the belly

 Changed gait pattern - wider gait

 

 When does the pain occur?

 
 
 1st trimester

 Some experience early pain due to hormonal changes. Less common.

 

 
 2nd trimester

 Pain often begins now - the belly grows and the center of gravity changes.

 

 
 3rd trimester

 Most common period for pelvic pain. Maximum load on the pelvis.

 

 

 Risk factors

 
 Previous pelvic pain - in previous pregnancy or generally

 Heavy physical work

 Back problems before pregnancy

 Previous injuries to pelvis or back

 Twin pregnancy

 Existing hip osteoarthritis - can worsen
 during pregnancy

What causes Proximal Hamstring Tendinopathy?

Causes and Risk Factors

 

 Overload is the main cause

 PHT typically develops over time due to:

 
 Too much, too fast - rapid increase in training load

 Compression + stretch - the tendon is squeezed against the bone with hip flexion

 Repetitive loading - running, cycling, rowing

 Prolonged sitting - constant pressure on the tendon

 

 Typical triggering activities

 
 Activities that increase risk

 
 Hill running - especially uphill

 Interval training - high speed demands

 Cycling - especially with low saddle height

 Yoga and Pilates - lots of hamstring stretching

 Rowing - repetitive hip flexion under load

 
 

 Biomechanical risk factors

 
 Weak gluteal muscles - gluteus must compensate (see also gluteal tendinopathy)

Describe symptoms and signs of Proximal Hamstring Tendinopathy.

Symptoms

 

 Typical symptoms

 
 Localized pain at the sit bone - where "the buttock meets the thigh"

 Pain with sitting - especially on hard surfaces

 Pain with running - especially speed and hills

 Pain with hamstring stretching

How is Proximal Hamstring Tendinopathy diagnosed?

Diagnosis

 

 The diagnosis is primarily made through history and clinical examination.

 Typical history

 
 Gradual onset - not acute injury

 Pain at the sit bone

 Pain with sitting, especially on hard chairs

 Increased running load beforehand

 Attempts at stretching have made things worse

 

 Clinical tests

 
 Common tests

 
 Palpation of sit bone - tenderness with pressure

 Bent-knee stretch - pain with stretching with bent knee

 Puranen-Orava test - active hamstring contraction

 Single leg bridge - often reproduces the pain

 
 

 Imaging

 
 MRI - can show tendon thickening and edema

 Ultrasound - useful for seeing tendon changes

 Differential diagnoses

 
 Sciatica - from the spine

Describe treatment options for Proximal Hamstring Tendinopathy.

Treatment

 

 Progressive strength training is key

 Research shows that heavy, progressive strength training is the well-documented treatment
 for PHT.

 
 Treatment principles:

 
 Start with isometric exercises (holding position)

 Gradually build up to heavier loads

 Focus on strength, NOT stretching

 Be patient - this takes time

 
 

 Phase 1: Pain control (weeks 1-2)

 
 Reduce compression - avoid prolonged sitting on hard chairs

 Use a cushion - relieve the sit bone

 Isometric exercises - hamstring activation without movement

 Avoid stretching!

 

 Phase 2: Strength building (weeks 2-8)

 
 Bridging progressions - from two-leg to single-leg

 Romanian deadlift - controlled hip flexion

 Nordic hamstring curl - eccentric strength

 Hip thrust - gluteal activation

 

 Phase 3: Functional training (weeks 8-12+)

 
 High loads - 80-90% of maximum strength

 Explosive training - jumps, sprints

 Running-specific training - gradual return

 

 Manual treatment

 
 Soft tissue treatment - can relieve muscle tension

 Pelvic and hip mobilization

 Nerve mobilization - for nerve irritation

 

 When is injection/surgery considered?

 
 Cortisone injection - can provide short-term relief, not first choice

 PRP injection - uncertain effect

 Surgery - rare, only for long-term failure of conservative treatment

Prognosis

 

 PHT is known to be a long-lasting condition, but most recover with patience and proper
 treatment.

 What can you expect?

 
 Weeks 1-4: Pain reduction with load management

 Months 1-3: Gradual strength building

 Months 3-6: Return to activity

 Up to 12 months: For long-standing cases

 

 Factors that affect prognosis

 
 Duration before treatment - early diagnosis gives better prognosis

 Compliance with strength program - necessary for recovery

 Avoiding stretching - many set themselves back by stretching

 Gradual return - too rapid progression causes relapse

 

 
 Relapses are common

 Many experience relapses, especially with too rapid progression of training. This is normal and does
 not mean treatment has failed. Adjust down, build up again - patience is key.

Describe Frequently Asked Questions for Proximal Hamstring Tendinopathy.

Frequently Asked Questions

 

 
 Should I stretch my hamstrings?

 NO - this is a common mistake. Stretching compresses the tendon against the sit
 bone and often makes things worse. Focus on strength training instead. Gentle dynamic mobility is fine,
 but avoid prolonged static stretching.

 

 
 Can I continue running?

 Often you need to significantly reduce volume initially. Flat running at low
 intensity is tolerated better than hills and intervals. Build up gradually as pain subsides. Running
 should not cause more than 3/10 pain.

 

 
 How long does it take to recover?

 PHT is often long-lasting. Expect 3-6 months of proper treatment for significant
 improvement. Some need up to 12 months. Early diagnosis and treatment give better prognosis. Patience is
 key.

 

 
 Does cortisone help?

 Cortisone injection can provide short-term pain relief, but is not first choice.
 Research shows it does not improve long-term outcomes and can weaken tendon tissue. Strength training is
 more effective for lasting improvement.

 

 
 How should I sit?

 Avoid hard chairs. Use a seat cushion that relieves the sit bone - either a
 wedge-shaped cushion or one with a cutout at the back. Get up and move regularly. Consider a standing
 desk for periods.

What causes SI Joint Problems and Pelvic Dysfunction?

Causes and Risk Factors

 

 Common Causes

 Risk Factors

 increases further to prepare the body for childbirth. This increased mobility can lead to irritation and
 pain.

How is SI Joint Problems and Pelvic Dysfunction diagnosed?

Diagnosis

 

 SI joint pain is primarily diagnosed clinically. There is no single test that is 100% accurate, so we use
 a combination of several tests.

 Clinical Provocation Tests

 
 Distraction test - pressure outward on the hip bones

 Compression test - pressure inward on the hip bones

 FABER/Patrick's test - stress on the SI joint via the hip

 Thigh thrust - pressure through the thigh

 Gaenslen's test - one leg over the edge of the bed

 

 
 The 3 of 5 rule

 If 3 or more of these 5 tests are positive, there is over 90% probability that the pain originates from
 the SI joint.

 

 Imaging

 X-ray and MRI rarely show anything with functional SI joint problems. Imaging is most
 useful to rule out other conditions such as:

 
 Arthritis in the SI joint

 Inflammatory disease (Ankylosing spondylitis)

 Fractures

 Infection

 Up to 80% of pregnant women experience pelvic or back pain, and the SI joint is often involved. Learn

 Why does the pain occur?

 Safe Treatment During Pregnancy

Describe Frequently Asked Questions for SI Joint Problems and Pelvic Dysfunction.

Frequently Asked Questions

 

 
 Can the SI joint really "go out of place"?

 No, the SI joint cannot physically go out of place. It is one of the body's most
 stable joints with very strong ligaments. What happens is that the joint becomes irritated, stiff or
 develops altered movement - not that it moves. The term "pelvic locking" is colloquially used but is not
 medically correct.

 

 
 Why does manipulation help when the joint is not out of place?

 Manipulation affects the nervous system and muscles around the joint. It can
 reduce pain, decrease muscle tension and restore normal movement in a stiff joint. The effect is
 neurological and biomechanical - not that something is "put back in place".

 

 
 How long does it take to recover?

 Most people with acute SI joint problems improve significantly within 4-8 weeks
 with proper treatment. Chronic cases may take longer. Maintenance exercises are important to prevent
 recurrence.

 

 
 Should I use an SI belt?

 An SI belt can provide temporary support in the acute phase, but should not be
 used for long periods. The goal is to build up the body's own stability through exercise, not to become
 dependent on external support.

 

 
 Can I exercise with SI joint pain?

 Yes, adapted exercise is important! Avoid exercises that provoke pain, but stay
 active. Swimming, walking and specific stabilization exercises are often well tolerated. Your
 chiropractor can give you an individually tailored program.

Describe Three Types of Snapping Hip for Snapping Hip - When Your Hip Clicks and Pops.

Three Types of Snapping Hip

 

 The condition is divided into three main categories based on where in the hip the problem is located:

 
 External Snapping Hip (most common)

 The external variant is most prevalent. Here, the iliotibial band (IT band) or the front part of the
 gluteus maximus tendon slides over the greater trochanter - the large bony prominence on the outside of
 the thigh.

 
 The snap is felt on the outside of the hip

 Often visible externally - you can see something "jumping"

 Many can produce the snap voluntarily

 Typical description: "It feels like the hip is going out of joint"

 
 

 
 Internal Snapping Hip

 The internal variant involves the iliopsoas tendon (hip flexor) sliding over bone structures at the
 front of the hip - either the femoral head or the pelvic rim.

 
 The snap is felt at the front of the hip, often in the groin

 Typically occurs at 30-45 degrees of hip flexion

 Strong female predominance: 62.5-86% of surgical cases are women

 About 50% have concurrent damage inside the hip joint

 
 

 
 Intraarticular Snapping Hip (rarest)

 The rarest variant is caused by problems inside the hip joint itself - most often a labral tear (80% of
 cases) or loose fragments.

 
 Often occurs after an acute injury

 More clicking, catching or locking than a distinct snap

 Pain is the main symptom, not the sound

 Usually requires imaging to clarify

Describe treatment options for Hip Sports Injuries.

Acute Treatment - PRICE Principle

 

 For acute injuries, rapid and correct first aid is crucial for optimal healing:

 
 P - Protection: Avoid activities that provoke pain

 R - Rest: Relative rest - not complete immobilization

 I - Ice: 15-20 minutes every 2-3 hours for the first 48-72 hours

 C - Compression: Elastic bandage if needed

 E - Elevation: Less relevant for hip than for ankle

Describe Return-to-Sport for Hip Sports Injuries.

Return-to-Sport

 

 A gradual, criteria-based return to sport significantly reduces the risk of re-injury. Here
 are the typical phases:

 
 
 Acute Phase (0-72 hours): PRICE, pain control, diagnosis

 Subacute Phase (3 days - 2 weeks): Pain-free movement, light
 strength training, maintain fitness

 Rehabilitation Phase (2-6 weeks): Progressive strength training,
 mobility training, functional training

 Return-to-Sport Phase: Sport-specific training, gradual increase in
 intensity, functional tests

 Full Activity: Training and competition without restrictions,
 maintenance program

Prevention

 

 
 Adequate warm-up: Minimum 15-20 minutes before intense activity

 Progressive load increase: Don't increase volume/intensity more than
 10% per week

 Strength training: Focus on hip muscles, especially adductors and
 gluteus

 Mobility: Maintain good hip mobility in all planes

 Copenhagen Adductor Protocol

 A specific exercise that has been shown to reduce groin injuries by up to 41% in
 football. The exercise is done in a side-lying position where a partner holds the top
 leg, and the athlete lifts the body up with the bottom leg. Start with 2x5 repetitions
 and gradually increase to 3x15.

Describe What Is a Stress Fracture? for Hip Stress Fracture.

What Is a Stress Fracture?

 

 Stress fractures occur when cumulative loading on the bone exceeds its ability to repair itself. In the
 hip region, stress fractures can occur in:

 
 Femoral Neck (collum femoris)

 High-risk location. Can develop into a complete fracture and require surgical
 treatment.

 

 
 Pelvis (os pubis, ramus)

 Common in runners. Causes pain in the groin/lower abdomen. Good prognosis with conservative treatment.
 

 

 
 Sacrum

 Often overlooked. Causes diffuse lower back pain that worsens with sitting and running.

 

 
 Femoral Shaft

 Less common. Causes pain on the outside of the thigh that worsens with loading.

Describe Risk Factors for Hip Stress Fracture.

Risk Factors

 

 Training-Related Factors

 
 Too rapid increase in volume/intensity

 Insufficient recovery

 Repetitive loading (running)

 Hard surfaces

 Worn or incorrect footwear

 
 Bone-Related Factors

 
 Low bone mineral density

 Vitamin D deficiency

 Calcium deficiency

 Previous stress fracture

 Osteoporosis/osteopenia

 
 Biomechanical Factors

 
 Leg length difference

 Overpronation

 Muscle weakness (especially hip)

 Reduced flexibility

 Poor running technique

 
 
 Female Athlete Triad / RED-S

 Women with stress fractures should be screened for RED-S (Relative Energy Deficiency in Sport). This
 includes low energy availability, menstrual disturbances and low bone mineral density.

How is Hip Stress Fracture diagnosed?

Diagnosis

 

 Clinical Examination

 
 Hop Test

 Hopping on one leg provokes pain. Simple but sensitive test.

 

 
 Fulcrum Test

 Pain with pressure while bending the thigh. Specific for femoral shaft.

 

 Imaging

 
 MRI (Gold Standard)

 High sensitivity, shows bone marrow edema and stress fracture early. Ordered when suspected.

 

 
 X-ray: May be negative for the first 2-6 weeks.

 CT: Good for characterizing fracture lines.

 Bone scan: Sensitive, but less specific than MRI.

Describe treatment options for Hip Stress Fracture.

Treatment

 

 Phase 1: Acute Phase - Offloading

 Immediate cessation of loading activity. For high-risk stress fractures, crutches may be necessary.

 Phase 2: Healing Phase (6-12 weeks)

 Gradual increase in loading. Cross-training (swimming, cycling, pool running).

 Phase 3: Rehabilitation and Strength

 Strength training for hip muscles once pain-free.

 Phase 4: Gradual Return to Activity

 Structured progression program. 10% increase per week as a general rule.

 
 Surgery for High-Risk Stress Fractures

 Stress fractures on the compression side of the femoral neck may require surgical stabilization with
 screws.

 

 
 The Chiropractor's Role

 Identify risk factors such as muscle weakness and biomechanical deviations. Refer for imaging when
 suspected.

Patient asks: "What is the difference between trigger points and fibromyalgia?"

Trigger points are localized, palpable knots in muscles with predictable referred pain patterns. Fibromyalgia is a systemic condition with widespread pain, sleep disturbances, and other symptoms. Many fibromyalgia patients also have trigger points, but trigger points alone do not meet the criteria for fibromyalgia.

Yes, trigger points in gluteus minimus and piriformis can cause pain down the leg resembling sciatica. The difference is that true sciatica often has neurological findings like reduced strength or reflexes, while trigger point-referred pain does not produce such findings.

Describe What Are Trigger Points? for Trigger Points in Hip and Pelvis.

What Are Trigger Points?

 

 Trigger points are localized, hyperirritable spots within taut bands of skeletal
 muscle. They are characterized by local tenderness and can produce referred pain in predictable patterns
 when compressed.

 In the hip and pelvic region, trigger points can cause pain that mimics other conditions such as piriformis syndrome, sciatica, hip osteoarthritis, or GTPS. This makes accurate diagnosis important.

Common Locations

Where Does It Hurt? Find Your Pain Type

 

 Instead of listing diagnoses, I'll start with what you actually notice: where is the pain located? This often gives the best clue to what's wrong.

 
 
 
 1
 Pain on the OUTSIDE of the hip

 

 
 
 
 
 Condition
 Key Symptoms
 Tests & Differentiation
 
 
 
 
 
 GTPS (Gluteal Tendinopathy)
 Very Common
 
 
 Pain when lying on side at night.
 Pain with stairs, uphill walking.
 Tender over the bony prominence (trochanter).
 
 
 Single-leg stance test: Standing on one leg for 30 seconds reproduces the familiar pain.
 Read more about GTPS ?
 
 
 
 
 Referred Back Pain
 Common
 
 
 Pain radiates from lower back.
 Often goes past the knee.
 Variable pain pattern (good/bad days).
 
 
 Slump test: Stretching the nerve pathway reproduces the pain.
 Pain often triggered by bending the back (not the hip).
 
 
 
 
 Trochanteric Bursitis
 Rare (<10%)
 
 
 Acute swelling, redness and warmth.
 Pain with ANY movement of the leg.
 
 
 Most "bursitis" diagnoses are actually tendon injuries (GTPS). True bursitis shows signs of inflammation.
 
 
 
 
 

 
 Who is affected? GTPS occurs in 15% of women and 6-8% of men between 50-79 years. Women are affected over 3 times as often.

What causes Hip Pain? - Complete Guide?

Common Causes of Hip Pain

 

 
 
 1
 GTPS (Gluteal Tendinopathy)

 

 
 Previously misdiagnosed as "bursitis" - studies show that less than 5% actually have inflammation in the bursa. In 85-98%, the problem is in the gluteal tendons. This is the most common cause of pain on the outside of the hip.

 

 

 
 
 2
 Hip Osteoarthritis

 

 
 Wear and tear in the hip joint, most common after 55-60. Causes gradually increasing stiffness, especially with internal rotation. Exercise is the first-choice treatment.

 

 

 
 
 3
 FAI (Femoroacetabular Impingement)

 

 
 Pinching in the hip joint due to bone shape. Common in young, active people. 37% of pain-free people have FAI morphology on MRI - so images must be interpreted with caution.

 

 

 
 The MRI Trap

 MRI shows everything - including things that are normal age-related changes. 69% of pain-free people have labral tears on MRI. A "tear" doesn't necessarily mean it's the source of your pain. I treat people, not images.

Describe Frequently Asked Questions for Hip Pain? - Complete Guide.

Frequently Asked Questions

 

 
 Is it dangerous if my hip "clicks" or "snaps"?

 Usually not. "Snapping hip" is very common - affecting 5-10% of the population - and is rarely dangerous as long as it doesn't hurt. It only becomes concerning if accompanied by pain or locking.

 

 
 Does stretching the hip help?

 Be careful. For GTPS or proximal hamstring tendinopathy, aggressive stretching can make pain worse. Focus instead on strength training and mobility within pain limits.

 

 
 Does cortisone help?

 Short-term relief yes, but long-term effect is poor. Exercise gives better results after 1 year. Read more about treatment.

 

 
 Can I exercise with hip pain?

 Yes, and you should! Research shows that exercise is more effective than passive treatment for most hip pain. But train smart: avoid activities that cause severe pain.

 

 
 Do I need an MRI or X-ray?

 Not always - and often not initially. A thorough clinical examination often provides enough information. Imaging is relevant if symptoms don't improve as expected.

 

 
 How long until I get better?

 This varies greatly. Acute muscle problems: 2-4 weeks. GTPS: 6-9 months with proper treatment. Hip osteoarthritis: most notice effects from exercise within 8-12 weeks.

Describe How common are bite deviations and jaw problems? for Bite Problems and Jaw Pain - Myths vs Facts.

How common are bite deviations and jaw problems?

 

 Malocclusion (deviation from "ideal" bite) is extremely common. A meta-analysis of 77 studies showed that approximately 56% of the world's population has some form of malocclusion. Among children, around 90% have some degree of malocclusion, but only 10-15% have severe cases requiring treatment.

 Temporomandibular dysfunction (TMD) - jaw joint problems - affects fewer people. NIDCR estimates 5-12% in the USA, while global studies show 29-34% depending on how the condition is defined. Women are affected at least twice as often as men.

 
 
 56%
 have malocclusion
 

 
 5-12%
 have TMD
 

 
 2:1
 women vs men
 

 

 
 Important point

 Even though 56% have bite deviation and only 5-12% have TMD, this doesn't mean bite deviation causes TMD. Most people with "wrong bite" never have jaw problems. The body is remarkably good at adapting.

What causes Bite Problems and Jaw Pain - Myths vs Facts?

Causes of jaw pain - from most to least common

 

 Modern research shows that TMD has multifactorial causes. Here are the factors ranked by how big a role they play:

 Most common causes (well documented)

 
 Muscle tension and myofascial pain

 Tight chewing muscles are the most common cause of jaw pain.

 

 
 Stress, anxiety, and sleep problems

 Psychological factors are strongly associated with TMD. See our article on stress and jaw pain.

 

 
 Bruxism (teeth grinding/clenching)

 Often nocturnal and unconscious, especially during stress. Read more about teeth grinding.

 

 
 Neck problems (cervicogenic component)

 Close connection between neck and jaw.

 

 Less common causes

 
 Dental problems: Cavities, abscess, cracked teeth can cause referred pain to the jaw

 TMJ osteoarthritis: Degenerative changes in the joint itself

 Disc displacement in the TMJ: Can cause clicking and locking

 

 Rare causes

 
 Trigeminal neuralgia: Intense, electric shock-like pain

 Giant cell arteritis: Inflammation in blood vessels, primarily in elderly

 Malocclusion as primary cause: Cochrane review and AADR conclude with weak/no evidence

Describe The scientific paradigm shift for Bite Problems and Jaw Pain - Myths vs Facts.

The scientific paradigm shift

 

 For decades it was assumed that "wrong bite" was the main cause of jaw problems. This view has been fundamentally challenged by modern research.

 
 What the research says

 
 Manfredini et al. (2017): "Clinicians are encouraged to abandon the old gnathological paradigm in TMD practice."

 Cochrane review (2024): No evidence that occlusion treatment treats or prevents TMD.

 NIDCR (USA): "For many years it was believed that malocclusion causes TMD; however, there is no evidence supporting this view."

 
 

 An interesting finding is reversed causality: Several studies show that bite deviations can be consequences of TMD, not causes. For example, open bite can develop from internal TMJ dysfunction.

 Norwegian guidelines from the Norwegian Directorate of Health (2016) are clear: "So far, no clear connection has been found between dental occlusion and development of TMD symptoms."

Describe What about headache and bite? for Bite Problems and Jaw Pain - Myths vs Facts.

What about headache and bite?

 

 The connection between malocclusion and headache is also poorly documented. Van der Meer and colleagues concluded in Cephalalgia (2019) that primary headaches like tension headache and migraine "are not caused by musculoskeletal dysfunction" - even though they may be associated with such symptoms.

 The International Classification of Headache Disorders (ICHD-3) recognizes "headache attributed to temporomandibular dysfunction" as secondary headache. But this relates to TMD itself - not to bite deviation directly.

Symptoms of TMJ disorders

 

 TMD can cause a wide range of symptoms:

 
 Pain in jaw, face, or in front of the ear

 Clicking or crunching when opening mouth/chewing

 Limited jaw opening or jaw locking

 Fatigue in the chewing muscles

 Headache, especially in the temples

 Ear pain or feeling of "blocked" ear (without infection)

 Neck pain and stiffness

 

 Symptoms vary from mild to significantly disabling. Many experience symptoms that come and go, often in connection with stressful periods.

How is Bite Problems and Jaw Pain - Myths vs Facts diagnosed?

Diagnosis

 

 TMD is primarily diagnosed through clinical examination. The chiropractor will examine the jaw joint, chewing muscles, neck, and head movement. Jaw opening is measured, and we listen for sounds from the joint.

 Imaging (MRI/X-ray) is rarely necessary for typical TMD symptoms. Studies show that imaging findings often don't correlate with symptoms - many without problems have "abnormal" findings on MRI, and many with problems have normal images. Clinical examination is therefore more important than images in most cases.

 
 When is imaging relevant?

 Imaging may be relevant when structural changes are suspected, after trauma, or if conservative treatment doesn't work over time.

 The combination of manual treatment and therapeutic exercises gives the good results according to systematic reviews.

 What can you do yourself?

 
 Home remedies

Describe Common myths about bite and jaw pain for Bite Problems and Jaw Pain - Myths vs Facts.

Common myths about bite and jaw pain

 

 
 Myth 1: "Bad bite causes jaw pain"

 Truth: Weak and inconsistent association - no causal connection has been proven. NIDCR states that this belief is not supported by evidence.

 

 
 Myth 2: "Orthodontics prevents or cures TMJ problems"

 Truth: Orthodontic treatment has "Neutral effect" - neither prevents nor causes TMD. Norwegian guidelines clearly state that TMD is not an indication for orthodontics.

 

 
 Myth 3: "Perfect bite is necessary"

 Truth: The body has significant adaptive capacity. Most people with malocclusion never develop TMD. As McNamara wrote already in 1997: "Not achieving ideal occlusion does not result in TMD symptoms."

 

 
 Myth 4: "TMJ problems require aggressive treatment"

 Truth: 90-95% improve with conservative treatment or without treatment. BMJ guidelines strongly recommend against irreversible interventions.

What is the prognosis for Bite Problems and Jaw Pain - Myths vs Facts?

Prognosis

 

 The prognosis for TMD is generally good. Most people experience significant improvement with conservative treatment, and many cases resolve on their own. The biopsychosocial model - which considers physical, psychological, and social factors - provides the most suitable understanding and treatment outcomes.

 Relapses are common, however, especially with increased stress or lifestyle changes. Long-term results are often similar for different treatment approaches after 6-12 months. The most important thing is therefore to learn self-management strategies that can be used for any relapses.

Describe Frequently Asked Questions for Bite Problems and Jaw Pain - Myths vs Facts.

Frequently Asked Questions

 

 
 Can an overbite cause headaches?

 Research shows weak to no connection between overbite and headaches. Headaches associated with the jaw are usually caused by muscle tension, not the bite relationship itself. If you have headaches and suspect the jaw, it's more likely that tension in the chewing and neck muscles is the cause.

 

 
 Should I get braces to prevent jaw problems?

 No, this is not recommended based on research. Orthodontic treatment has shown neither to prevent nor cure TMD. Braces may be relevant for cosmetic or functional reasons, but not to prevent TMJ problems.

 

 
 Does a bite splint help with jaw pain?

 The evidence is conflicting. Cochrane found "insufficient evidence" for effectiveness. Bite splints may help some, especially those with limited jaw opening or nighttime teeth grinding, but should not be the a key treatment approach. Combination with exercises and possibly manual therapy gives better results.

 

 
 How long does it take for TMJ problems to resolve?

 This varies greatly. Acute cases may improve in days to weeks with proper treatment. Subacute problems (6-12 weeks) often require a more systematic approach. Chronic cases (>3 months) may take longer and often require focus on multiple factors, including stress management.

 

 
 Is jaw clicking dangerous?

 Clicking in the jaw joint is common and often harmless. Many have clicking without pain or functional impairment. It usually doesn't require treatmen...

Identify red flags for Teeth Grinding (Bruxism):

SSRI-Induced Bruxism

 
 20-24% of SSRI users develop bruxism (vs 2-10% in general population)

 Symptom onset typically 3-4 weeks after starting medication

 All SSRIs can cause it, but sertraline and fluoxetine are most commonly reported

 Mechanism: SSRI affects serotonin which in turn affects dopamine in areas controlling jaw muscles

Describe The Two Types of Bruxism for Teeth Grinding (Bruxism).

The Two Types of Bruxism

 

 
 Sleep Bruxism

 This is the classic "nighttime teeth grinding" most people think of:

 
 Rhythmic movements: The jaw moves in repetitive patterns

 Occurs in light sleep: Especially in transitions between sleep stages

 Enormous forces: Can generate 50-80 kg pressure - far above normal chewing force of 10-15 kg

 Sound: Partner often hears loud grinding noise

 Morning symptoms: Headache, sore jaw, tired chewing muscles

 
 Important: Sleep bruxism is classified as a sleep-related movement disorder and is often linked to other sleep problems.

 

 
 Awake Bruxism

 This type occurs while you're awake and is fundamentally different:

 
 Static clenching: You press teeth together without movement

 Stress trigger: Triggered by concentration, stress, frustration

 Semi-conscious: You can learn to become aware of it

 Daytime symptoms: Jaw pain that increases throughout the day

 More common in women: Studies show higher prevalence

 
 

 
 Why the Distinction Matters

 Awake bruxism can be treated with awareness training and biofeedback - you can learn to stop. Sleep bruxism happens unconsciously and requires other approaches like sleep hygiene, stress management and protective measures.

SSRI and Bruxism

 

 Do you use antidepressants? Then you should know this:

 
 SSRI-Induced Bruxism

 
 20-24% of SSRI users develop bruxism (vs 2-10% in general population)

 Symptom onset typically 3-4 weeks after starting medication
