Describe Important to Understand for Nociplastic Pain: When the Nervous System Becomes Oversensitive.

Important to Understand

 

 
 THIS IS IMPORTANT

 
 Your pain is real. Nociplastic pain is not imaginary, psychosomatic, or "just in your head."

 It's not your fault. You haven't "chosen" to have this type of pain.

 It can get better. The nervous system has the ability to change back (neuroplasticity).

 Treatment takes time. This is a gradual process, not a quick fix.

 
 

 Common Misconceptions

 
 "The doctors can't find anything, so it must be psychological"

 Wrong. Nociplastic pain is a neurological condition. That the MRI is "normal" only means the cause of the pain isn't visible on the images - not that the pain is imaginary.

 

 
 "I just need to find the right practitioner who can fix me"

 With nociplastic pain, there's nothing to "fix" in the traditional sense. Treatment is about helping the nervous system function differently, and this requires active participation from you.

 

 
 "I need to rest until the pain goes away"

 Wrong approach. Prolonged rest and avoidance often reinforce sensitization. Graded, safe movement is necessary for improvement.

What is Pregnancy-Related Back Pain?

 

 Back and pelvic pain during pregnancy is so common that it's almost considered a normal part of
 pregnancy. A large meta-analysis from 2023 found that approximately 40% of pregnant women
 experience lower back pain. When pelvic pain is included, the figure rises to around 63%.

 
 
 ~50%

 63%

 75%

 Improve within 3 months after delivery

 

 

 You may have heard that "9 out of 10 pregnant women get back pain." This is exaggerated - research

Describe Pelvic Girdle Pain vs. SI Joint Dysfunction for Pregnant with Back Pain? How a Chiropractor Can Help.

Pelvic Girdle Pain vs. SI Joint Dysfunction

 

 Many use "pelvic girdle pain" as a catch-all term, but there are actually two different conditions that
 require different approaches.

 
 Pelvic Girdle Pain (symphysis pubis dysfunction)

 This is the most common variant during pregnancy and is caused by the hormone relaxin making the
 ligaments in the pelvis more elastic. The body prepares for delivery, but the increased mobility can
 cause pain.

 
 Diffuse, often bilateral pain in the front of the pelvis (over the symphysis)

 "Waddling gait"

 About 20% of pregnant women experience troublesome pelvic pain

 
 

 
 SI Joint Dysfunction

 Here the problem is the opposite - one or more joints in the pelvis have reduced mobility.

 
 Often one-sided, sharp pain in the back of the pelvis

 Typically localized to one sacroiliac joint

 Pain may radiate to the buttock, groin, or thigh

 
 

 
 Why is this important?

 Treatment differs. For pelvic girdle pain, I focus on stabilizing exercises, while SI joint
 dysfunction often responds well to joint mobilization.

What causes Pregnant with Back Pain? How a Chiropractor Can Help?

Causes and Risk Factors

 

 Pregnancy-related back pain has several intertwined causes:

 Hormonal Changes

 The hormone relaxin loosens ligaments and connective tissue to prepare the body for delivery. This
 makes the pelvic joints more unstable and can cause pain.

 Changed Posture

 As the belly grows, the center of gravity shifts forward. Many compensate by arching the lower back
 more, which increases the load on facet joints and muscles.

 Increased Weight and Load

 Weight gain of 10-15 kg during pregnancy means significantly increased load on the lower back and
 pelvis.

 
 Who is at highest risk?

 
 Previous back pain: 85% chance of experiencing it again in a new pregnancy

 Back problems before pregnancy: Twice the risk

 Overweight: BMI over 25 increases risk

 Heavy physical work: Norwegian studies show a connection

 Multiple pregnancies: Risk increases with each pregnancy

 
 

 Sciatica during pregnancy is rarer than many think - only about 1% of pregnant women
 have confirmed sciatica. Much of what is called "sciatica" is actually referred pain from the pelvis or
 muscles.

Cauda Equina Syndrome - Emergency Situation

 

 Cauda equina syndrome (CES) occurs when the nerve bundle at the bottom of the spinal cord becomes
 compressed, usually by a large disc herniation. The condition affects
 approximately 1.6 per 100,000 per year - rare, but very serious.

 
 
 1.6
 per 100,000 per year
 

 
 48h
 critical time window
 

 
 84%
 have bladder symptoms
 

 

 Symptoms to Watch For

 
 Cauda Equina Symptoms

 
 Bladder dysfunction (84%): Difficulty starting urination, weak stream, feeling of
 incomplete emptying, or urinary incontinence

 Saddle anesthesia (71%): Numbness or altered sensation around the rectum, genitals,
 and inner thighs

 Bowel dysfunction (62%): Altered bowel control

 Bilateral leg weakness: Weakness in both legs that develops rapidly

 
 

 
 Why is it urgent?

 Deterioration can occur at approximately 1% per hour. Delay beyond 48 hours was associated with 9.6
 times increased mortality. There is no "safe" waiting time.

Describe What is Sciatica? for Sciatica: Everything You Need to Know.

What is Sciatica?

 

 Sciatica (also called lumbar radiculopathy) describes pain that occurs when the sciatic nerve or the
 nerve roots that form it become irritated, inflamed or compressed. The sciatic nerve is the body's longest
 and thickest nerve with a diameter of up to 2 cm. It starts in the lower back and runs through the buttock
 all the way down to the foot (StatPearls, 2024).

 The important thing to understand is that "sciatica" is a symptom, not a diagnosis in
 itself. It describes where the pain is felt, but doesn't necessarily say what's causing it.

 How common is sciatica?

 Despite many believing sciatica is common, true sciatica actually only accounts for 3-5% of all
 back pain cases (StatPearls, 2024). The vast majority with back pain have non-specific or
 muscular causes (80-90%).

 
 
 3-5%
 of back problems are true sciatica
 

 
 10-40%
 lifetime incidence
 

 
 30-50 yrs
 most common age group

Describe True Sciatica vs. False Sciatica for Sciatica: Everything You Need to Know.

True Sciatica vs. False Sciatica

 

 This distinction is crucial for correct treatment.

 True sciatica (lumbar radiculopathy)

 In true sciatica, there is actual irritation or compression of the nerve root in the spine. The most
 common causes, ranked from most to least frequent:

 
 1. Disc herniation (~90% of cases)

 The gel material from the disc bulges out and presses on the nerve. About 95% of all lumbar herniations occur at L4-L5 or L5-S1 level (StatPearls, 2023).

 
 
 
 

 
 2. Spinal stenosis

 Narrowing of the spinal canal, more common in older people. Can cause bilateral symptoms and worsens
 with walking. Read more about spinal stenosis.

 

 
 3. Foraminal stenosis

 Narrowing at the nerve exit from the vertebrae. Often age-related degeneration.

 

 
 4. Spondylolisthesis

 Slippage of one vertebra in relation to another. Particularly common at L5-S1.

 

 False sciatica (pseudosciatica)

 In false sciatica, the nerve itself is not being compressed. Pain is referred from other structures that
 mimic sciatica:

 
 1. Trigger points and muscular causes (most common)

 Tender knots in gluteal muscles, quadratus lumborum or hamstrings can cause referred pain down the leg.
 

 

 
 2. SI joint dysfunction

 Referred pain from the back of the pelvis. Often causes pain to the buttock and back of the thigh.

 

 
 3. Facet joint syndrome

 Referred pain from the joints between the vertebrae. Typically worsened by extension and rotation.

 

 
 4. Piriformis syndrome...

Describe symptoms and signs of Sciatica: Everything You Need to Know.

Symptoms of True Sciatica

 

 Classic symptoms include pain from the lower back/buttock, down the back of the thigh, below the knee,
 potentially to the foot and toes. The pain pattern depends on which nerve root is affected:

 
 L4 root

 
 Pain to the front of the thigh and inner calf

 Weakened knee extension

 
 

 
 L5 root (L4-L5 herniation)

 
 Pain to the outer calf and top of the foot

 Weakened toe dorsiflexion

 
 

 
 S1 root (L5-S1 herniation)

 
 Pain to the back of the calf and outer foot

 Weakened toe plantar flexion, reduced Achilles reflex

 
 

 Pain quality and provocation

 
 Pain quality: Sharp, burning, electric. Often described as "current" through the leg.
 

 Worsening: Coughing, sneezing, straining, sitting, forward bending typically
 increases pain.

 Relief: Lying on your back with bent knees, gentle movement.

Describe How Long Does Sciatica Really Last? for Sciatica: Everything You Need to Know.

How Long Does Sciatica Really Last?

 

 There's a widespread belief that "90% recover within 6 weeks." Newer research shows this is too
 optimistic. Here's what studies actually show:

 
 At 4 weeks

 About 50% experience significant improvement in symptoms (Koes et al., BMJ 2007). Half
 still have symptoms.

 

 
 At 6 weeks

 Around 50% show clinically meaningful improvement in both pain and function
 (StatPearls, 2024). Far from "90% recovered."

 

 
 At 12 weeks (3 months)

 The ATLAS cohort study from the UK found that 55% had achieved at least 30% reduction
 in disability. Median time to improvement is 10-12 weeks.

 

 
 At 6-12 months

 A Norwegian multicenter study found success rates of 49-58% at 6 months. At 12 months,
 55-70% have recovered.
 

 

 
 What affects recovery time?

 Strongest predictor: The patient's own belief that symptoms will become chronic. Those
 who believe they will recover have nearly four times higher chance of actually doing so.

 
 Long symptom duration before treatment

 High pain intensity at onset

 Psychosomatic comorbidities

 
 

 Recurrence is common

 Even after successful treatment, many experience recurrence:

 
 24% have recurrence within 4 years after non-operative treatment

 25% of those who were recovered at 2 years had recurrence by 4 years

 Recurring back pain (43%) is more common than recurring leg radiation

 
 This underscores the importance of preventive exercises and good ergonomics - even after recovery.

How is Sciatica: Everything You Need to Know diagnosed?

Diagnosis

 

 Clinical examination

 Diagnosis is primarily based on medical history and clinical examination. A thorough neurological
 examination can often locate which level in the spine is affected.

 Straight leg raise test is the most predictive test for identifying candidates for
 surgery. The test is positive when it reproduces the patient's pain with a leg raise under 45 degrees with
 radiation below the knee (StatPearls, 2023).

 Imaging

 MRI or CT is not routinely recommended. Danish national guidelines discourage routine
 imaging for new-onset sciatica (European Spine Journal, 2018).

 
 Important to understand

 Imaging often shows normal findings like wear and degenerative changes that don't explain the pain.
 Studies show that up to 20-80% of symptom-free people have MRI findings like disc bulging, degeneration
 or protrusion (StatPearls, 2023).

 

 Imaging is indicated for:

 
 Suspicion of serious pathology (red flags)

 Persistent symptoms after 6-8 weeks of conservative treatment

 When considering surgery

 Conservative treatment (first choice)

 Danish national guidelines recommend manual therapy (including spinal manipulation) combined with guided
 exercise for lumbar radiculopathy (Stochkendahl et al., European Spine Journal, 2018).

 
 What can the chiropractor do?

 
 Manual therapy: Spinal manipulation and mobilization can relieve pain and improve
 mobility

 Soft tissue treatment: Muscle work on piriformis, gluteal muscles and hamstrings
 for false sciatica

 Neural mobilization: Nerve-glide exercises to improve nerve mobility

 Exercise guidance: Core muscle training and graded activity tailored to your
 situation

 
 

 
 What can you do yourself?

 
 Stay active - avoid prolonged bed rest. Gentle movement is important.

 Nerve-glide exercises - gentle stretching that mobilizes the nerve without
 irritating it.

 Ergonomic adjustments - avoid prolonged sitting, take breaks.

 Pain relief as needed in the acute phase.

 Be patient - improvement often takes 10-12 weeks.

 
 

 Surgery

 Surgery is only considered when:

 
 Serious conservative treatment for 6-12 weeks doesn't provide sufficient improvement

 There are progressive neurological deficits (increasing muscle weakness)

 For cauda equina syndrome (acute surgical condition)

 

 
 Important about surgery

 Surgery provides faster improvement in the short term, but after 1-2 years results are equally
 good with conservative treatment. A Dutch study showed no significant difference in function

Frequently Asked Questions

 

 
 Can sciatica resolve on its own?

 Yes, many cases improve spontaneously over time. However, early treatment can lead
 to faster recovery and reduce the risk of chronic symptoms.

 

 
 Do I need an MRI?

 Not routinely. MRI is indicated when serious pathology is suspected, when there's
 no improvement after 6-8 weeks, or when surgery is being considered. Many normal age-related changes
 appear on MRI without explaining the pain.

 

 
 Should I rest?

 No. Prolonged bed rest is discouraged. Gentle movement and activity as tolerated
 is important for recovery.

 

 
 What is the difference between sciatica and back pain?

 Sciatica is pain that radiates down the leg from nerve root irritation. Common
 back pain (which accounts for 80-90% of cases) mainly causes pain in the back itself, without nerve
 involvement.

 

 
 How many treatments are needed?

 This varies. Median time to improvement is 10-12 weeks. I evaluate progress
 throughout and adjust the plan accordingly.

 

 
 Can a disc herniation shrink?

 Yes. The body has a remarkable ability for self-healing. Disc herniations can
 shrink and be reabsorbed over time, and the inflammation irritating the nerve gradually subsides.

Describe What is the SI Joint? for SI Joint Pain and Pelvic Dysfunction.

What is the SI Joint?

 

 The SI joint is a unique joint - part synovial joint (movable), part fibrous joint (stable). Normal
 movement is very limited: only 2-4 mm rotation and 1-2 mm gliding. Nevertheless, these minimal movements
 are essential for normal walking function and for absorbing shock.

 
 Why does the SI joint cause pain in the back, buttocks and thigh?

 The SI joint receives sensory innervation from both anterior (L2-S2) and posterior (L4-S3) nerve roots.
 This complex innervation explains why SI joint pain can produce varying referral patterns - from lower
 back to buttocks, groin, thigh and sometimes down toward the foot.

 

 How common is SI joint pain?

 International consensus guidelines from 2025, developed in collaboration between 27 organizations,
 establish that the SI joint is the cause of 15-30% of chronic lower back pain without
 radiation down the leg (Pain Medicine, 2025). A systematic review by Simopoulos et al. found point
 prevalence of approximately 25%.

 of chronic lower back pain
 

 
 60-65%
 of patients are women

Describe Pelvic Locking vs. Pelvic Loosening for SI Joint Pain and Pelvic Dysfunction.

Pelvic Locking vs. Pelvic Loosening

 

 The terms "pelvic locking" and "pelvic loosening" describe two completely different conditions that
 require different treatment approaches:

 
 Pelvic Locking (Hypomobility)

 Occurs when the SI joint becomes too stiff or "locks up". The joint doesn't move as it should, causing
 sharp, localized pain with certain movements and a feeling that the pelvis "gets stuck".

 

 
 Pelvic Loosening (Hypermobility)

 Occurs when the joints become too loose and unstable. Typical during pregnancy due to the hormone
 relaxin. Causes diffuse, aching pain that is difficult to localize, and a feeling of instability in the
 pelvis.

Causes and Risk Factors

 

 Pain from the SI joint can have both intra-articular (inside the joint) and extra-articular (around the
 joint) causes. Here are the most common, ranked from most to least frequent:

 1. Biomechanical Overload and Microtrauma (88%)

 By far the most common cause (StatPearls, 2024). This includes repetitive stress from work or sports,
 asymmetric standing or sitting over time, heavy lifting with twisting, ligament injury and myofascial
 trigger points.

 
 Athletes have increased risk

 
 Rowing gives 54% prevalence in elite athletes

 Golf and tennis create risk through rotation with axial loading

 Football/rugby through contact injuries

 
 

 2. Pregnancy and Childbirth

 45-50% of pregnant women experience pelvic pain. Filipec et al. (2018) found that 78.7% of
 first-time pregnant women develop SI joint dysfunction. Most improve within 3-4 months after
 delivery, but 8-10% have persistent problems 1-2 years later.

 3. Previous Spinal Surgery (15-33%)

 When vertebrae are surgically fused, the load on adjacent segments increases. 15.8% develop SI joint pain
 after lumbar fusion, and as many as 32.9% when the fusion includes the sacrum.

 4. Trauma and Falls

 44% of patients with confirmed SI joint pain have identifiable traumatic events. In car accident-related
 chronic lower back pain, the SI joint is the pain source in 26% of cases.

Describe symptoms and signs of SI Joint Pain and Pelvic Dysfunction.

Symptoms - What SI Joint Pain Feels Like

 

 Pain Location

 The pain is usually located right over the SI joint - slightly to the side from the midline, just below
 the hip crest. Most experience one-sided pain localized to the area around or just below
 the posterior superior iliac spine (PSIS). In 94% of cases, the patient can point to the pain within 10 cm
 below and 3 cm lateral to the PSIS.

 
 Fortin's Finger Test - A Simple Self-Test

 Point with one finger to where it hurts most. Patients with SI joint pain typically point to an area
 within 1 cm of the posterior iliac spine. This test has shown 77% sensitivity and 100% specificity in
 studies.

 

 Referred Pain

 The pain can radiate to:

 
 Buttocks (most common)

 Groin (14%)

 Back and outside of thigh (50%)

 Below the knee (28%) - but rarely further down

 

 Important: With pure SI joint pain, the pain usually doesn't go below the
 knee - unlike true sciatica/radiculopathy.

 Aggravating Factors

 
 Getting up from a seated position

 Walking stairs (especially up)

 Standing on one leg

 Turning over in bed

 Driving (asymmetric pedal use)

 Prolonged sitting or standing

How is SI Joint Pain and Pelvic Dysfunction diagnosed?

Diagnosis - How is the Diagnosis Made?

 

 Clinical Examination is the Gold Standard

 SI joint problems cannot be seen on X-ray or MRI. The diagnosis is made primarily clinically through pain
 location, provocation tests, and palpation. Individual tests have limited value - therefore a
 cluster of provocation tests is used. Three or more positive tests give 94% sensitivity
 and 78% specificity.

 
 The Five Most Important Provocation Tests

 Distraction test, compression test, thigh thrust, Gaenslen's test, and sacral thrust are used in
 combination to make the diagnosis.

 Stabilization exercises are crucial for lasting improvement. Norwegian research from Britt Stuge at OUS
 showed that specific stabilization exercises gave 68% success rate versus only 23% for general
 physiotherapy - with effects that held at 2-year follow-up.

 
 Pelvic Bridge

 
 Lie on your back with bent knees

 Draw your navel in toward your spine

 Lift your buttocks calmly toward the ceiling, hold 5-10 seconds

 3 sets x 10 repetitions

 
 

 
 Bird Dog

 
 Start on all fours, tighten your stomach lightly

 Lift opposite arm and leg, keep your body stable

 Hold 10 seconds, 3 sets x 8 repetitions each side

Describe What is Spinal Stenosis? for Spinal Stenosis - Narrowing in the Spine.

What is Spinal Stenosis?

 

 Spinal stenosis is a condition where the spinal canal (where the spinal cord and nerves run) or nerve
 exits (foramen) become narrower. This can lead to pressure on nerves and cause symptoms like pain,
 numbness or weakness in the legs.

 The most important thing to understand is that stenosis on MRI images doesn't necessarily mean you have
 problems. Many people have narrowing in their spine without noticing anything at all.

 
 
 11%
 of the general population
 

 
 47%
 of people aged 60-69
 

 
 78%
 have stenosis on MRI without symptoms
 

 

 
 Important Point

 The Wakayama Spine Study found that 77.9% of participants had moderate central stenosis on imaging,
 but only 17.5% of those with severe stenosis actually had symptoms. This means MRI images should never
 guide treatment alone.
You are a clinical documentation assistant for chiropractors. Generate professional medical documentation.
What causes Spinal Stenosis - Narrowing in the Spine?

Causes and Risk Factors

 

 Spinal stenosis is almost always caused by age-related changes in the spine. Over 95% of cases are
 degenerative stenosis.

 
 Facet Joint Osteoarthritis

 Wear in the small joints at the back of the spine leading to thickening and bone spurs.

 

 
 Thickening of Ligamentum Flavum

 The yellow ligament located behind the spinal canal can become thicker with age and take up space
 from the nerves.

 

 
 Disc Degeneration

 The discs between the vertebrae lose height and can bulge into the canal. This can also lead to herniation.

 

 
 Osteophytes

 Bone spurs that grow into the spinal canal or nerve exits.

 

 Risk Factors with Documented Association

 
 Age over 60: 3-5 times higher prevalence

 Obesity: BMI over 30 gives more than double the risk

 Diabetes: Found in 29% of stenosis patients vs 10% in the general population

 Spondylolisthesis: Vertebral slippage can
 contribute to stenosis

Describe symptoms and signs of Spinal Stenosis - Narrowing in the Spine.

Symptoms

 

 The classic symptom of lumbar spinal stenosis is called neurogenic claudication - a
 term describing the typical pattern many experience:

 
 Pain, heaviness or numbness in one or both legs

 Symptoms come gradually when walking or standing upright

 Relief when sitting down, bending forward or leaning on a shopping cart

 Often easier to cycle than walk (because you sit slightly forward-leaning)

 

 These symptoms can resemble sciatica, but with stenosis the typical pattern
 is that symptoms worsen with walking and improve with rest in a forward-bent position.

 
 The Shopping Cart Sign

 This is so characteristic that it's used diagnostically worldwide. Many patients report they can walk
 much further when leaning on a shopping cart. This is because leaning forward expands the spinal canal
 and gives more room for the nerves.

How is Spinal Stenosis - Narrowing in the Spine diagnosed?

Diagnosis

 

 Clinical Examination

 As a chiropractor, I perform a thorough examination including assessment of gait pattern and posture,
 testing of reflexes, strength and sensation in the legs, and provocation of symptoms in different
 positions.

 Imaging - An Important Caveat

 MRI is the first-choice examination when imaging is indicated. But here's a very important point:
 There is often poor correlation between MRI findings and symptoms.

 
 MRI Findings in Symptom-Free People

 Studies show that 21% of symptom-free people over 60 have stenosis on MRI, and that 65% of healthy
 volunteers received a stenosis diagnosis from radiologists. This means MRI images should never guide
 treatment alone.

 

 Imaging is most relevant for:

 
 Suspicion of serious pathology (red flags)

 Persistent symptoms after 6-8 weeks of conservative treatment

 When considering surgery

Describe treatment options for Spinal Stenosis - Narrowing in the Spine.

Treatment

 

 What Can the Chiropractor Do?

 There is moderate evidence that conservative treatment with manual therapy and targeted exercises helps
 with lumbar spinal stenosis.

 
 A large randomized study (Whitman, Spine 2006) showed that 79% achieved improvement after 6
 weeks of treatment with manual therapy and exercises, compared to 41% in the group that
 only received flexion exercises.

 

 
 Treatment May Include

 
 Manual therapy to improve joint mobility

 Flexion-distraction that increases space in the spinal canal

 Myofascial techniques

 Individually tailored exercise program

 
 

 What Can You Do Yourself?

 Flexion-based exercises have moderate evidence and utilize the simple mechanism that
 leaning forward gives more room for the nerves:

 
 Knee-to-Chest Stretch

 
 Lying on your back, pull one or both knees toward your chest

 Hold for 20-30 seconds

 Repeat 3-5 times

 
 

 
 Core Stabilization

 
 Exercises for abdominal and back muscles

 Bridge, plank, bird-dog

 Focus on controlled movement

 
 

 Treatment Course

 Based on available literature, a trial period of 8-12 treatments over 6-12 weeks is
 usually recommended. Many experience first signs of improvement after 2-4 weeks and significant progress
 in function after 6-12 weeks.

What is the prognosis for Spinal Stenosis - Narrowing in the Spine?

Prognosis - What Happens Long Term?

 

 Here I have good news: The natural course of spinal stenosis is often more favorable than many think.
 

 
 Without Treatment (JAMA Review 2022)

 About 33% report spontaneous improvement, 50% remain stable, and 10-20% experience worsening over 3
 years.

 

 Surgery vs Conservative Treatment

 
 The large SPORT study showed that surgery had somewhat better results in the short term, but
 after 6-8 years there was no significant difference between surgical and conservative
 treatment.

 

 Recurrence: It's important to be realistic - this is a condition related to aging of
 the spine, and recurrence can occur. Regular maintenance exercise is important to maintain function.

 Yes, most people with spinal stenosis manage well without surgery. Long-term

 When you bend your back forward, the spinal canal expands and gives more room

 to cycle than to walk.

 Not necessarily. Clinical examination is often sufficient to make the diagnosis
 and start treatment. Remember that MRI findings often don't correlate with symptoms.

 

 
 How long does a treatment series last?

 Usually 8-12 treatments over 6-12 weeks are recommended as an initial trial
 period. Then the need for maintenance treatment or self-exercise is evaluated.

 

 
 Can I continue exercising with spinal stenosis?

 Absolutely! Activity is important. Cycling, swimming and water aerobics are
 often well tolerated because the body is in a forward-leaning position that opens up the spinal canal.

Pregnancy and Lower Back Pain

 

 Go to full article on pregnancy and back pain ?

 Approximately 50% of pregnant women experience lower back pain (Wu et al., European Spine Journal 2004). For some, the problems start early; for others, not until the last trimester.

 
 Why Do Pregnant Women Get Back Pain?

 Hormonal changes:

 
 Relaxin loosens ligaments and joints  provides less stability

 Muscles have to work harder to compensate

 
 Mechanical changes:

 
 Center of gravity shifts forward

 Increased curve in the lower back (hyperlordosis)

 Weight gain of 1015 kg

 
 

 Types of Pain During Pregnancy

 
 Lumbar pain: Central in the lower back, similar to regular lower back pain

 Pelvic pain: Four times more common. Over the SI joints and/or pubic symphysis.

 Symphysis dysfunction: Pronounced pain over the pubic symphysis, difficulty walking

 

 
 Treatment During Pregnancy

 Chiropractic treatment is safe during pregnancy:

 
 Adapted joint treatment

 Soft tissue therapy

 Pelvic belts for pelvic pain

 Exercises and ergonomic advice

Prognosis and Recurrence

 

 For acute lower back pain, 39% are pain-free after 6 weeks, 73% after 1 year (Henschke, BMJ 2008). For chronic pain, 67.2% had the same pain level after 4 years (Peng, 2012).

 
 Recurrence is Common

 JAMA 2017: Manipulation provides ~10 points improvement on 100-point scale  equivalent to NSAIDs

 BMJ 2019: High-quality evidence for effect in chronic pain

 CCGPP (2016) recommends 612 treatments over 24 weeks as a starting point

Describe What is C5-C6 Disc Herniation? for C5-C6 Disc Herniation: Thumb and Index Finger Numbness.

What is C5-C6 Disc Herniation?

 

 C5-C6 refers to the level in the neck where the herniation occurs, between the fifth and sixth cervical
 vertebrae. When the disc between these vertebrae bulges out or ruptures, it can press on the nerve root
 that exits at this level: the C6 nerve.

 Cervical radiculopathy (nerve root involvement in the neck) affects approximately 83 per 100,000 people
 annually. The C5-C6 level is involved in about 25% of cases, making it the second most common level
 after C6-C7.

 
 Anatomy: The C6 Nerve Root

 The C6 nerve supplies specific areas in the arm and hand:

 
 Sensory: The thumb, index finger, and outer forearm

 Motor: Biceps (bends the elbow) and wrist extensor muscles

 Reflex: The brachioradialis reflex (tested on the outer forearm)

 
 

 Why Does Herniation Occur at the C5-C6 Level?

 The C5-C6 segment is one of the most mobile areas in the neck. This high mobility makes the disc more
 susceptible to wear and injury over time. Risk factors include:

 
 Prolonged sedentary work with forward head posture

 Previous neck injuries (e.g., whiplash)

 Genetic predisposition to disc degeneration

 Age (most common between 40-50 years)

 Smoking (reduces blood supply to the discs)

 of cervical radiculopathy
 

 
 85%
 recover without surgery

 weeks typical recovery time

Describe symptoms and signs of C5-C6 Disc Herniation: Thumb and Index Finger Numbness.

Symptoms of C5-C6 Disc Herniation

 

 The symptoms of C5-C6 disc herniation are quite specific and follow the distribution of the C6 nerve.
 They can vary in intensity from mild numbness to significant pain and weakness.

 
 Typical C6 Symptoms

 
 Pain: Radiates from the neck, out to the shoulder, down the outer upper arm to
 the thumb and index finger

 Numbness/tingling: Thumb and index finger,
 sometimes the middle finger

 Weakness: Difficulty bending the elbow (biceps) or extending the wrist

 Reflex change: Reduced brachioradialis reflex

 
 

 Pain Provocation

 Symptoms typically worsen with:

 
 Turning the head toward the affected side

 Bending the neck backward (extension)

 Coughing or sneezing

 Pressing down on the head (Spurling's test)

 

 
 Bakody's Sign - Relief from Raising the Arm

 A characteristic finding in cervical radiculopathy is that pain is relieved when you place your hand
 on your head. This reduces tension on the nerve root and is a useful diagnostic sign.

 

 Pain Pattern Throughout the Day

 With cervical radiculopathy, pain is often worst at night and early morning. This is because the neck
 remains in a static position for a long time, and any swelling around the nerve has time to accumulate.

Describe Is It C5-C6 Disc Herniation or Carpal Tunnel Syndrome? for C5-C6 Disc Herniation: Thumb and Index Finger Numbness.

Is It C5-C6 Disc Herniation or Carpal Tunnel Syndrome?

 

 This is one of the most important questions to clarify, because the treatment is very different. Both
 conditions cause numbness in the fingers, but the causes and patterns are different.

 
 
 
 Characteristic
 C5-C6 Herniation (C6 Radiculopathy)
 Carpal Tunnel Syndrome
 
 
 
 
 Numbness
 Thumb and index finger
 Thumb, index finger, middle finger, half of ring finger
 
 
 Pain location
 Neck, shoulder, arm
 Wrist, palm
 
 
 Worsened by
 Neck movements, Spurling's test
 Repetitive hand work, bent wrist at night
 
 
 Relieved by
 Arm over head (Bakody's sign)
 Shaking the hand (Flick sign)
 
 
 Weakness
 Biceps, wrist extension
 Thumb grip (thenar atrophy in severe cases)
 
 
 Worst when
 Morning, after static neck position
 At night, early morning
 
 
 

 
 Double Crush Syndrome

 In some cases, you can have both conditions simultaneously. The nerve can be irritated both in the
 neck and at the wrist. This is called "double crush syndrome" and requires treatment of both locations
 for optimal recovery.

 

 Other Conditions to Rule Out

 
 Thoracic Outlet Syndrome (TOS)

 The nerve is compressed between neck muscles and ribs. Symptoms can be similar, but often worsen when
 raising the arm overhead (opposite of Bakody's sign).

 

 
 Shoulder Pathology

 Rotator cuff injuries or impingement can cause radiation to the arm. Shoulder mobility is usually
 normal with pure neck problems.

Prognosis: How Long Does It Take?

 

 The prognosis for C5-C6 disc herniation is generally good. Research shows that the vast majority
 recover with conservative treatment, without the need for surgery.

 
 
 85%
 significant improvement without surgery
 

 
 2-4
 weeks to first noticeable improvement
 

 
 8-12
 weeks median time to significant improvement
 

 

 What Affects Prognosis?

 
 Good Prognostic Factors

 
 Early treatment initiation

 Younger age (under 50)

 Predominantly radicular pain (arm pain dominates)

 No serious neurological deficits

 Good daily function despite pain

 
 

 
 Factors That May Prolong Recovery

 
 Delayed treatment initiation

 Concurrent depression or anxiety

 Catastrophic thinking about the pain

 Passive coping strategies (avoidance, bed rest)

 Prolonged neck stiffness before symptom onset

 
 

 Can the Herniation Shrink?

 Yes. Disc herniations can actually be reabsorbed over time. The body has a remarkable ability to break
 down and remove the protruding disc material. Inflammation around the nerve gradually decreases, and
 symptoms often improve before the herniation itself is completely gone.

 Studies show that larger herniations (sequestered) actually have better reabsorption rates than smaller
 bulges, because the immune system more easily "discovers" and breaks down the loose disc material.

Describe treatment options for C5-C6 Disc Herniation: Thumb and Index Finger Numbness.

Treatment for C5-C6 Disc Herniation

 

 Treatment of C5-C6 disc herniation is in the vast majority of cases conservative (non-surgical). The
 goal is to reduce pain, preserve function, and support the body's natural healing process.

 Acute Phase (Week 1-2)

 
 Pain Management and Modified Activity

 
 Avoid provoking positions (backward bending, rotation toward painful side)

 Short-term use of pain medication as needed

 Ice or heat according to preference

 Maintain as normal activity as possible without provoking pain

 
 

 Subacute Phase (Week 2-8)

 
 Manual Treatment

 Chiropractic treatment may include:

 
 Joint mobilization of the cervical spine

 Myofascial release of neck and shoulder muscles

 Nerve mobilization (gentle nerve gliding)

 Thoracic manipulation (often well tolerated and effective)

 
 

 
 Exercises

 
 Isometric neck exercises: Strengthening without movement

 Neck retractions: The "chin tuck" exercise

 Scapular stabilization: Important for relieving the neck

 Nerve gliding exercises: Gentle mobilization of the C6 nerve

 
 

 When Is Surgery Considered?

 Surgery is rarely necessary and is only considered for:

 
 Surgical Indications

 
 Progressive motor weakness despite conservative treatment

 Myelopathy (spinal cord involvement with gait and balance problems)

 Persistent disabling pain after 6-12 weeks of adequate treatment

 Significant impact on daily function

 
 Most patients (85-90%) never need surgery.

 Most cases of C5-C6 disc herniation are harmless and resolve on their own. But some symptoms require
 prompt medical evaluation. See our article on red flags for more

 Seek Medical Attention Immediately For:

 
 Myelopathy signs: Problems with balance and gait, "clumsy" hands, difficulty
 buttoning buttons

 Progressive weakness: Increasing muscle weakness in arm or hand over days

 Bladder/bowel disturbances: Difficulty urinating or controlling urine/stool

 Bilateral symptoms: Numbness or weakness in both arms

 Fever combined with neck stiffness: May indicate infection

 
 These symptoms are rare but require prompt evaluation.

 

 Cervical Myelopathy

 Myelopathy occurs when the herniation or degenerative changes press on the spinal cord itself, not just

 Signs of Myelopathy

 
 Unsteady gait, especially in the dark

 Difficulty with fine motor skills (writing, buttoning buttons)

 Lhermitte's sign: Electric shock sensation down the spine with neck flexion

 Hyperactive reflexes in the legs

Describe Frequently Asked Questions for C5-C6 Disc Herniation: Thumb and Index Finger Numbness.

Frequently Asked Questions

 

 
 What is the difference between C5-C6 disc herniation and carpal tunnel
 syndrome?

 With carpal tunnel syndrome, symptoms are often worst at night and improve when
 you shake your hand. Numbness affects the thumb, index finger, middle finger, and half of the ring
 finger. With C5-C6 disc herniation, symptoms worsen with neck movements, and only the thumb and index
 finger are affected. The biceps may also be weak.

 

 
 Do I need an MRI for C5-C6 disc herniation?

 Not routinely. MRI is only indicated for serious neurological deficits,
 suspected serious underlying pathology, or if you haven't improved after 6-8 weeks of conservative
 treatment. Many normal age-related changes appear on MRI without explaining the symptoms.

 

 
 How long does it take for C5-C6 disc herniation to heal?

 About 85% experience significant improvement within 8-12 weeks with conservative
 treatment. Most notice progress within 2-4 weeks. Full recovery can take up to 6 months, and the
 herniation can shrink and be reabsorbed over time.

 

 
 Can I exercise with C5-C6 disc herniation?

 Yes, adapted activity is important. Avoid extreme neck extension and heavy
 overhead lifting during the acute phase. Light neck mobility exercises, isometric exercises, and
 general low-intensity training are recommended. A chiropractor can guide you with specific exercises.
 

 

 
 When should I contact a doctor immediately?

Describe What is C6-C7 Disc Herniation? for C6-C7 Disc Herniation: Middle Finger Numbness.

What is C6-C7 Disc Herniation?

 

 C6-C7 refers to the level between the sixth and seventh cervical vertebrae, where the disc herniation
 occurs. When the disc at this level bulges out, it can press on the C7 nerve root,
 which exits the spine at this level.

 This is the most common site for cervical disc herniation, which is no coincidence: The C6-C7 segment
 combines high mobility with significant load. It's the neck's "workhorse" - and the most vulnerable
 point.

 
 Anatomy: The C7 Nerve Root

 The C7 nerve supplies specific areas:

 
 Sensory: Middle finger, partially index and ring finger

 Motor: Triceps (extends the elbow), wrist flexors

 Reflex: Triceps reflex

 
 

 Why Is C6-C7 So Vulnerable?

 Several factors make this level particularly susceptible:

 
 Highest mobility: This is the most mobile segment in the neck

 Heavy load: Bears the weight of the head through all movements

 Biomechanics: Transition between more and less mobile areas

 Early degeneration: Often begins showing wear already in the 30s

 

 
 
 ~60%
 of cervical radiculopathy
 

 
 85-90%
 recover without surgery
 

 
 40-50 years
 most common age group

Describe symptoms and signs of C6-C7 Disc Herniation: Middle Finger Numbness.

Symptoms of C6-C7 Disc Herniation

 

 The symptoms of C6-C7 disc herniation follow the C7 nerve's distribution area and are often more
 distinct than at other levels.

 
 Typical C7 Symptoms

 
 Pain: Radiates from neck and shoulder, down the back of the upper arm to the
 middle finger

 Numbness/tingling: Middle finger is most
 affected, may include parts of index and ring finger

 Weakness: Triceps (difficulty straightening elbow against resistance), finger
 flexion

 Reflex change: Reduced or absent triceps reflex

 
 

 The Classic Pain Pattern

 C7 radiculopathy has a characteristic pattern:

 
 Pain Progression

 
 Often starts with neck stiffness or headache

 Develops into shoulder pain over days to weeks

 Gradually radiates down the arm to the hand

 Finger numbness typically comes last

 
 

 Aggravating and Relieving Factors

 
 Typically worsened by:

 
 Turning the head toward the affected side

 Backward bending of the neck (extension)

 Coughing, sneezing, or straining

 Prolonged sitting with forward head posture

 
 

 
 Typically relieved by:

 
 Placing the hand on the head (Bakody's sign)

 Slight forward neck flexion

 Supporting the arm on a pillow

 Movement and gentle activity

Describe C6-C7 vs. C5-C6: How to Tell Them Apart? for C6-C7 Disc Herniation: Middle Finger Numbness.

C6-C7 vs. C5-C6: How to Tell Them Apart?

 

 The two most common cervical herniation levels have overlapping but distinct symptom patterns.
 Distinguishing them is important for accurate diagnosis. See also our article on C5-C6 disc herniation.

 
 
 
 Characteristic
 C6-C7 (C7 root)
 C5-C6 (C6 root)
 
 
 
 
 Frequency
 Up to 60% of cases
 25% of cases
 
 
 Numbness
 Middle finger (+ partially 2nd and 4th)
 Thumb and index finger
 
 
 Weakness
 Triceps (straightening elbow)
 Biceps (bending elbow)
 
 
 Reflex
 Triceps reflex reduced
 Brachioradialis reflex reduced
 
 
 Pain path
 Back of arm to middle finger
 Outer arm to thumb
 
 
 

 
 Multi-level Involvement

 In some cases, multiple levels can be affected simultaneously. This produces a more complex symptom
 picture with overlapping signs from both nerve roots. A thorough clinical examination is necessary to
 map the complete picture.

 

 Other Differential Diagnoses

 
 Cubital Tunnel Syndrome (Ulnar Neuropathy)

 The ulnar nerve is compressed at the elbow. Causes numbness in the little finger and ring finger, not
 the middle finger. Often worsened by prolonged elbow bending.

 

 
 Shoulder Pain with Referred Pattern

 Rotator cuff injuries can cause radiation to the arm, but finger numbness is rare. Shoulder mobility
 is typically reduced.

What is the prognosis for C6-C7 Disc Herniation: Middle Finger Numbness?

Prognosis: How Long Does It Take?

 

 The prognosis for C6-C7 disc herniation is generally very good. Research consistently shows that the
 vast majority recover with conservative treatment.

 
 
 85-90%
 significant improvement conservatively
 

 
 2-4 weeks
 first noticeable improvement
 

 
 8-12 weeks
 median time to significant improvement
 

 

 Typical Course

 
 Week 1-2: Acute Phase

 Pain is often at its worst. Numbness and possible weakness may be evident. Focus on pain relief and
 avoiding provoking activities.

 

 
 Week 2-6: Subacute Phase

 Gradual improvement. Pain decreases and range of motion increases. Treatment and exercises have the
 best effect during this phase.

 

 
 Week 6-12: Rehabilitation Phase

 Most experience significant improvement. Numbness may persist longer than pain. Focus on regaining
 full function and preventing recurrence.

 

 The Disc Herniation Can Shrink

 An important point: disc herniations are often reabsorbed over time. The body treats the protruding
 disc material as a "foreign body" and gradually breaks it down. Studies show that larger herniations
 (sequestered) actually have better reabsorption rates than smaller bulges.

 
 Centripetal Pain Pattern

 A good prognostic sign is when pain "retreats inward" - from fingers toward shoulder and neck. This
 indicates that the nerve root is becoming less irritated and the herniation is receding.

Treatment for C6-C7 Disc Herniation

 

 Conservative treatment is the first choice and produces excellent results for the vast majority. The
 goal is to reduce pain, preserve function, and support the body's natural healing process.

 Phase 1: Acute Pain Management (Week 1-2)

 
 Activity Modification

 
 Avoid neck extension and rotation toward painful side

 Use neck support during sleep if needed

 Maintain as normal activity as possible

 Short rest periods are fine, but avoid prolonged inactivity

 
 

 
 Pain Relief

 
 NSAIDs (ibuprofen, naproxen) can reduce inflammation

 Ice or heat according to preference

 For severe pain: contact doctor for prescription pain relief

 
 

 Phase 2: Manual Treatment and Mobilization (Week 2-8)

 
 Chiropractic treatment may include:

 
 Joint mobilization: Gentle restoration of movement in neck segments

 Myofascial treatment: Release tight muscles in neck, shoulder, and chest

 Nerve mobilization: Gentle gliding of C7 nerve to reduce irritation

 Thoracic manipulation: Often well-tolerated and provides neck relief

 
 

 Phase 3: Exercises and Rehabilitation

 
 Important Exercise Types

 
 Neck retractions: The "chin tuck" exercise strengthens deep neck muscles

 Isometric exercises: Strengthening without movement in acute phase

 Scapular stabilization: Strengthening around shoulder blades relieves neck

 Nerve gliding: Gentle mobilization of nerve tissue

 Posture correction: Reduce forward head position

Describe What is Cervical Foraminal Stenosis? for Cervical Foraminal Stenosis - Narrowed Nerve Canal in Neck.

What is Cervical Foraminal Stenosis?

 

 Cervical foraminal stenosis means that the nerve openings on the sides of the cervical vertebrae have
 become narrower. These openings are called "foramen" (plural: foramina) and are where the spinal nerves
 leave the spine to supply the arms and hands with sensation and movement.

 When the foramen becomes narrower - either due to wear, disc bulging, or bone spurs - the nerve passing
 through can become irritated or compressed. This causes symptoms that radiate from the neck down to the
 shoulder, arm, or hand.

 
 Understanding the Anatomy

 Think of the foramen as a tunnel through which the nerve
 travels. The tunnel is formed by:

 
 The vertebral arch above and below - forming the roof and floor

 The facet joint - forming the back wall

 The intervertebral disc - forming the front wall

 
 Changes in any of these structures can make the tunnel
 narrower and irritate the nerve.

 

 Most Common Levels

 Foraminal stenosis is most common at the following levels in the neck:

 
 C5-C6: Affects the C6 nerve - symptoms to
 thumb and index finger

 C6-C7: Affects the C7 nerve - symptoms to
 middle and ring finger

 C4-C5: Affects the C5 nerve - symptoms to shoulder and upper arm
You are a clinical documentation assistant for chiropractors. Generate professional medical documentation.
What causes Cervical Foraminal Stenosis - Narrowed Nerve Canal in Neck?

Causes of Foraminal Stenosis

 

 
 Spondylosis (Wear and Tear)

 The most common cause. Over time, the vertebrae can develop bone spurs (osteophytes) that grow into
 the foramen and make the opening narrower.

 

 
 Disc Changes

 Disc bulging or herniation can press on the nerve root. A
 "hard" herniation with bone spurs is more common in stenosis than "soft" disc herniation.

 

 
 Facet Joint Osteoarthritis

 Wear in the facet joints leads to thickening of the joint capsule and bone spurs that reduce space in
 the foramen.

 

 Risk Factors

 
 Age: Risk increases significantly after 50

 Previous neck injury: Whiplash or other trauma

 Neck-straining work: Prolonged work with head forward or in rotation

 Genetics: Some naturally have smaller foramen

 Smoking: Accelerates degenerative changes in the spine

Describe symptoms and signs of Cervical Foraminal Stenosis - Narrowed Nerve Canal in Neck.

Symptoms

 

 Typical Symptoms

 
 Radicular pain: Sharp, burning, or electric pain that radiates from neck to arm
 

 Numbness and tingling: Often in specific fingers depending on which nerve is
 affected

 Weakness: Reduced strength in specific arm or hand muscles

 Neck stiffness: Especially with movements that close the foramen (extension +
 rotation toward painful side)

 

 
 Spurling's Test

 A classic test for foraminal stenosis: The head
 is bent backward and rotated toward the painful side, then light pressure is applied downward. A
 positive test reproduces radiation to the arm. This "closes" the foramen and provokes symptoms.

Describe treatment options for Cervical Foraminal Stenosis - Narrowed Nerve Canal in Neck.

Treatment

 

 Most people with cervical foraminal stenosis respond well to conservative treatment. Studies show that
 75-90% achieve good symptom control without surgery.

 
 Chiropractic treatment may include:

 
 Manual mobilization: Gentle mobilization of neck joints to improve mobility

 Manual traction: "Stretching" of the neck that opens the foramen and provides
 nerve relief

 Soft tissue treatment: Treatment of tight muscles around neck and shoulder

 Nerve mobilization: Gentle techniques to improve nerve gliding

 Posture correction: Advice on ergonomics and positional changes

 
 

 Exercises That Often Help

 
 Cervical Retractions (Chin Tuck)

 Pull your chin straight back as if making a "double chin." Hold for 5 seconds. This exercise
 centralizes neck discs and can open the foramen.

 

 
 Side Bend Away from Painful Side

 Gently bend your head toward the shoulder on the pain-free side. This opens the foramen on the
 painful side and can provide immediate relief.

 

 
 Prognosis

 With proper treatment and exercises, most achieve
 significant improvement within 6-12 weeks. Some experience periods of worsening, but the long-term
 prognosis is generally good with conservative treatment.

Frequently Asked Questions

 

 
 What is the difference between foraminal
 stenosis and central stenosis?

 Foraminal stenosis affects the
 nerve openings on the sides of the spine where nerves exit, causing symptoms in the arm/hand. Central
 stenosis affects the spinal canal itself and can cause symptoms in both arms and legs, as well as gait
 disturbances.

 

 
 Can cervical foraminal stenosis be treated
 without surgery?

 Yes, most people with cervical
 foraminal stenosis respond well to conservative treatment. Studies show that 75-90% get good relief
 without surgery through manual treatment, traction exercises, and strength training.

 

 
 What exercises help with foraminal stenosis in
 the neck?

 Cervical retraction exercises
 (chin tucks), neck traction exercises, and scapular stabilization are often effective. Exercises that
 open the foramen (gentle side bending away from the painful side) can provide immediate relief.

 

 
 Is cervical foraminal stenosis dangerous?

 Foraminal stenosis itself is
 not dangerous, but untreated it can lead to progressive nerve damage. Seek medical attention for
 increasing weakness, muscle wasting, or problems with fine motor skills.

Describe 1. Cavitation (gas bubbles) in the context of Is Neck Cracking Dangerous?.

1. Cavitation (gas bubbles)

 When a joint is stretched, the pressure in the joint capsule drops. This causes gases dissolved in
 the joint fluid to be released as bubbles, creating an audible "pop" or click sound. This is the same
 mechanism as when a chiropractor adjusts a joint.
You are a clinical documentation assistant for chiropractors. Generate professional medical documentation.
Describe 2. Tendons and ligaments in the context of Is Neck Cracking Dangerous?.

2. Tendons and ligaments

 Tendons and ligaments can slide over bony structures or each other during movement. This often
 creates a "snapping" or sliding sound, especially when the neck has been in the same position for a
 long time.
You are a clinical documentation assistant for chiropractors. Generate professional medical documentation.
Describe 3. Facet joints in the context of Is Neck Cracking Dangerous?.

3. Facet joints

 The neck has many small joints (facet joints) between the vertebrae. When these joints move, they can
 produce sounds - especially if the joints are stiff or there is slight asymmetry in movement.
You are a clinical documentation assistant for chiropractors. Generate professional medical documentation.
Describe 4. Age-related changes in the context of Is Neck Cracking Dangerous?.

4. Age-related changes

 With age, the cartilage surface in joints becomes slightly rougher, and this can cause a grinding or
 crunching sound during movement. This is normal and does not mean you have "worn out" your neck.

 

 When Can It Be More Than Normal?

 In rare cases, neck cracking can be related to underlying conditions:

 
 Osteoarthritis: Wear and tear in the joints
 can cause grinding, but this is usually accompanied by stiffness and pain

 Disc degeneration: When the discs between the vertebrae lose height, it can affect
 joint mechanics

 Instability: With hypermobility, the joints can move more than normal and make
 sounds

 
 

 
 
 3
 When Is It Harmless?

 

 In the vast majority of cases, neck cracking is completely harmless. Here are signs that you don't need
 to worry:

 
 Safe sign - You can relax if:

 
 - The cracking is not accompanied by pain
 - You have full mobility in your neck
 - There is no swelling or warmth
 - You have no radiating symptoms to your arms
 - The cracking has been there for a long time without worsening

Describe What are degenerative changes? for Neck Degeneration - What MRI Findings Really Mean.

What are degenerative changes?

 

 Degenerative changes - also called spondylosis, degeneration, or osteoarthritis - describe normal
 age-related changes in the spine. This includes changes in the intervertebral discs, facet joints, and
 ligaments that occur gradually throughout life.

 Think of it as "gray hair" in the spine. Just as hair turns gray and skin gets wrinkles, the spine will
 show age-related changes over time. This is a natural process and does not automatically mean you
 have pain or will develop problems.

 
 The Gray Hair Analogy

 Neck degeneration is like gray hair: Almost everyone gets it with age, it's completely normal, and it
 doesn't mean something is wrong. You wouldn't go to the doctor because you got gray hair - and
 degeneration on MRI is also nothing to worry about in itself.

 

 Common MRI Descriptions

 
 Disc Degeneration

 The intervertebral discs lose fluid and height over time. This is normal and starts already in your
 20s.

 

 
 Osteophytes (Bone Spurs)

 Small bone spurs that form along the edges of the vertebrae. The body's way of stabilizing.

 

 
 Facet Joint Osteoarthritis

 Wear in the small joints on the back of the vertebrae. Very common with increasing age.

 

 
 Disc Protrusion/Bulging

 The disc bulges out slightly. Found in most adults and is often completely asymptomatic.

Describe What Research Shows for Neck Degeneration - What MRI Findings Really Mean.

What Research Shows

 

 Studies that have taken MRI scans of healthy people without symptoms show surprising findings:

 
 
 98%
 of 50-year-olds have disc degeneration
 

 
 84%
 of 50-year-olds have disc bulging
 

 
 36%
 of 20-year-olds have disc degeneration
 

 
 0
 of these had pain
 

 

 
 Important Research

 A systematic review in Radiology (Nakashima et al., 2015) of MRI in asymptomatic individuals showed
 that degenerative changes are so common they must be considered normal age-related changes, not
 pathology.

 

 Correlation Between MRI and Pain

 Several large studies have shown that there is very poor correlation between MRI findings and
 symptoms:

 
 Many with significant degeneration on MRI have no pain

 Many with pain have minimal findings on MRI

 MRI findings cannot predict who will develop pain

 MRI findings don't disappear even when the pain goes away

Describe The Problem with MRI Descriptions for Neck Degeneration - What MRI Findings Really Mean.

The Problem with MRI Descriptions

 

 The way MRI findings are described can create unnecessary fear and worry. Words like "degeneration,"
 "wear," and "osteoarthritis" sound serious but actually describe normal age-related changes.

 
 The Nocebo Effect

 Scary MRI descriptions can actually make pain worse. Research shows that patients who receive negative
 descriptions of their MRI findings often experience more pain, more fear of movement, and worse
 prognosis than those who receive neutral information.

 

 Common Misconceptions

 
 "My back is ruined"

 Fact: The spine is robust and adaptable. Degenerative changes are normal and don't
 mean the spine is "ruined."

 

 
 "I must avoid movement"

 Fact: Movement is medicine for the spine. Inactivity often worsens symptoms, while
 adapted activity improves them.

 

 
 "It's only going to get worse"

 Fact: Symptoms can be treated and improved even with degeneration. Many live well with
 degenerative changes for many decades.

Describe treatment options for Neck Degeneration - What MRI Findings Really Mean.

Treatment and What You Can Do

 

 Although the degeneration itself cannot be reversed, symptoms can often be treated very effectively.
 Focus should be on function and symptoms - not on the MRI images.

 
 Chiropractic treatment can help with:

 
 Better mobility: Mobilization of stiff joints

 Pain relief: Treatment of muscular components

 Posture correction: Reduce strain on the neck

 Exercise instruction: Strength and stretching exercises

 Proper information: Reduce unnecessary fear

 
 

 Exercises and Lifestyle

 
 Stay active: Regular movement is important for the neck

 Strength training: Strong neck and shoulder support muscles protect

 Good posture: Avoid prolonged forward head position

 Screen breaks: Vary positions throughout the day

 

 
 Prognosis

 Most people with neck pain and degenerative changes experience good
 improvement with treatment. The degeneration doesn't disappear, but symptoms can be effectively
 controlled. Many live symptom-free for long periods.

Describe Frequently Asked Questions for Neck Degeneration - What MRI Findings Really Mean.

Frequently Asked Questions

 

 
 Is neck degeneration dangerous?

 No, degenerative changes are a normal part of aging and are usually not dangerous.
 Most people over 50 have some degree of degeneration on MRI, and many have no symptoms.

 

 
 Can degeneration be treated?

 The degeneration itself cannot be reversed, but symptoms can often be treated
 effectively. Chiropractic treatment, exercises, and lifestyle changes can provide significant symptom
 relief and improved function.

 

 
 Does degeneration on MRI mean I have pain?

 Not necessarily. Studies show poor correlation between MRI findings and symptoms.
 Many with significant degeneration on MRI have no pain, while others with minimal findings may have
 significant problems.

 

 
 Do I need surgery for degeneration?

 Very rarely. Surgery is considered only in specific situations such as progressive
 nerve damage or myelopathy. The vast majority are treated effectively without surgery.

 

 
 Should I avoid movement and exercise?

 No, quite the opposite! Movement is important for the neck. Adapted strength
 training and activity protects and can reduce symptoms. Inactivity often worsens problems.

What causes Finger Numbness - Neck or Hand??

Neck Causes (Cervical Radiculopathy)

 

 When a nerve root in the neck becomes compressed or irritated, it's called cervical radiculopathy. This
 can be caused by disc herniation, foraminal stenosis (narrow nerve canal), or degenerative
 changes.

 Characteristics of Neck Cause

 
 Neck pain that often worsens with movement

 Radiation from neck, down into shoulder and arm

 Symptoms follow a dermatome pattern (see below)

 Can worsen when tilting head backward or toward the affected side

 Often better at night compared to carpal tunnel

 

 
 Dermatome Distribution - Which Nerve Root is Affected?

 
 C5: Numbness over shoulder and upper arm (outer side)

 C6: Numbness in thumb and index finger, outer forearm

 C7: Numbness in middle finger, often with weakness when straightening elbow

 C8: Numbness in ring and little finger (similar to ulnar nerve)

 T1: Numbness on inner forearm

 
 

 
 Typical Presentation of C6 Radiculopathy

 Pain from neck radiating into shoulder, upper arm and forearm to thumb and index finger. Numbness in
 these fingers. May have weakness in biceps and wrist extension. Biceps reflex may be diminished.

 

 
 Typical Presentation of C7 Radiculopathy

 The most common cervical radiculopathy. Pain and numbness in middle finger. May have weakness when
 straightening elbow (triceps). Triceps reflex may be diminished.

How is Finger Numbness - Neck or Hand? diagnosed?

How is the Diagnosis Made?

 

 Clinical Examination

 A thorough clinical examination can often distinguish between neck and hand causes:

 
 The examination includes:

 
 Medical history: Where are the symptoms? What worsens/relieves?

 Neck examination: Mobility, pain provocation, Spurling's test

 Neurological examination: Sensation, strength, reflexes

 Specific tests: Tinel's sign, Phalen's test (for carpal tunnel)

 Dermatome mapping: Which fingers and areas are affected?

 
 

 Imaging and Nerve Studies

 
 MRI of neck: Can show disc herniation, stenosis or other structural causes

 Nerve conduction study (EMG/NCV): Can confirm carpal tunnel or show where nerve is
 damaged

 Ultrasound: Can visualize the median nerve in the carpal tunnel

 For Neck Cause (Cervical Radiculopathy)

 
 Treatment options:

 
 Chiropractic treatment: Manual therapy, mobilization, nerve mobilization

Describe What is disc herniation and cervical radiculopathy? for Cervical Disc Herniation and Pinched Nerve in the Neck.

What is disc herniation and cervical radiculopathy?

 

 Cervical radiculopathy means a nerve root in the neck is irritated or compressed. This
 causes symptoms radiating to the shoulder, arm or hand - often called "nerve root involvement,"
 "brachialgia" or colloquially: "pinched nerve in the neck."

 Cervical disc herniation (cervical disc prolapse) occurs when the soft core of an
 intervertebral disc bulges out or ruptures through the outer ring. When this material presses on a nerve
 root, you get radiculopathy.

 
 Important distinction

 You can have a herniation on MRI without symptoms, and you can have radiculopathy without a clear
 herniation. A Japanese study of 1211 healthy people found disc bulging in 87.6% (Nakashima, Spine
 2015). Imaging must always be interpreted together with clinical findings.

What causes Cervical Disc Herniation and Pinched Nerve in the Neck?

Causes and risk factors

 

 Interestingly, only 14.8% had physical exertion or trauma just before symptom onset in the Rochester
 study. Most cases develop gradually without a specific triggering event.

 Causes ranked from most to least common

 
 Spondylosis and foraminal stenosis (68-75%)

 Age-related changes gradually lead to narrowing of the opening where the nerve passes. Dominant cause
 in people over 50.

 

 
 Disc herniation (20-25%)

 Acute bulging of the intervertebral disc pressing on the nerve root. Most common in younger patients
 in their 20s-40s.

 

 
 Injury/trauma (~15%)

 Whiplash-type injuries or other neck trauma.

 

 
 Myofascial trigger points

 Active trigger points in the upper trapezius occur in 30-40% of patients with chronic neck pain. Causes radiation that can mimic radiculopathy.

 

 Risk factors

 
 Age over 50

 Heavy physical work with lifting over 25 kg

 Work with vibrating equipment

 Prolonged driving

 Smoking (affects blood supply to discs)

 Sedentary work with poor ergonomics

 Previous back pain (41% have had lumbar radiculopathy)

Describe Which nerves are affected - and what characterizes each? for Cervical Disc Herniation and Pinched Nerve in the Neck.

Which nerves are affected - and what characterizes each?

 

 The neck has seven cervical vertebrae, and the nerves exiting between them are named after the vertebra
 above. Note: Only 62.6% of patients have standard dermatome patterns, and 67.3% show typical myotome
 patterns (Neurospine 2022). About one-third have atypical symptoms.

 
 C7 radiculopathy (most common - 60-70% of cases)

 
 Disc level: C6-C7

 Sensory: Tingling, numbness in the middle

Carpal tunnel or neck? How to tell the difference

 

 Numbness in the hand can come from the neck (cervical radiculopathy) or from the wrist (carpal tunnel
 syndrome). Symptoms can be similar, but there are important differences. One study showed that 62.2% of
 patients with cervical radiculopathy also have carpal tunnel syndrome - so-called "double crush
 syndrome."

 
 
 
 Characteristic
 Carpal tunnel syndrome
 Cervical radiculopathy
 
 
 
 
 Which fingers?
 Thumb, index, middle finger
 Depends on nerve root
 
 
 When worst?
 At night, wake up numb
 With neck movement
 
 
 What gives relief?
 Shaking the hand
 Arm over head (Bakody's sign)
 
 
 Pain location
 Wrist and hand
 Neck -> shoulder -> arm -> hand
 
 
 One or both sides?
 Often bilateral
 Usually unilateral
 
 
 

 
 Bakody's sign

 If symptoms are relieved when you place your hand on your head (shoulder in abduction), it strongly
 suggests the problem comes from the neck. The test has 80-100% specificity for cervical radiculopathy.

How is Cervical Disc Herniation and Pinched Nerve in the Neck diagnosed?

Diagnosis

 

 Clinical tests

 A thorough clinical examination is often more important than imaging. The chiropractor assesses neck
 mobility, muscle strength, sensation and reflexes.

 
 Spurling's test

 The neck is extended, side-flexed and rotated toward the symptomatic side, then pressure is applied.
 High specificity of 92%, but sensitivity of only 53%. A positive test strongly increases suspicion,
 but a negative test does not rule out the condition.

 

 
 Upper Limb Tension Test (ULTT)

 97% sensitivity - a negative test makes the diagnosis unlikely. Many false positives (22%
 specificity).

 

 
 Arm Squeeze Test

 96.7% sensitivity for distinguishing neck problems from shoulder problems. Squeezing the middle of
 the upper arm causes pain in neck pathology, but not in pure shoulder pathology.

 

 Imaging

 MRI is not routine and should be reserved for: persistent symptoms after 4-6 weeks of conservative
 treatment, progressive neurological deficit, suspicion of serious underlying disease, or before surgical
 evaluation.

 
 MRI findings in symptom-free people (Brinjikji, AJNR 2015)

 At age 30: 52% have disc degeneration, 40% disc bulging
 At age 50: 80% have disc degeneration, 60% disc bulging
 At age 70: 93% have disc degeneration, 77% disc bulging

Patient asks: "Do trigger points actually exist?"

There is ongoing professional debate about the exact nature and pathophysiology of trigger points. What we know is that many patients have tender points in their muscles that produce recognizable radiation patterns, and that treatment targeting these points often provides symptom relief. Norwegian researchers have noted that the diagnostics have limited reliability, but this doesn't mean your pain isn't real.

Patient asks: "What's the difference between trigger points and fibromyalgia?"

Trigger points cause localized pain with specific radiation from defined points in muscles. Fibromyalgia is a condition with widespread pain across large parts of the body for more than 3 months, often combined with fatigue, sleep problems and cognitive fog. The two conditions can also occur together.

Patient asks: "Can trigger points cause dizziness?"

Yes, trigger points in the sternocleidomastoid (SCM) can cause dizziness, balance disturbances and a feeling that surroundings are moving. This is likely due to effects on proprioceptors (position sense) in the neck muscles. We always investigate other causes of dizziness before concluding it's due to trigger points.

What causes Trigger Points in the Neck - Muscle Knots and Referred Pain?

Causes and Risk Factors

 

 Trigger points develop near muscle fibers that become overloaded or damaged. The most common causes,
 ranked by frequency:

 
 Static Loading and Poor Ergonomics (Most Common)

 Prolonged desk work, screen use with forward head position, and repetitive work are by far the most
 common causes. Office workers and manual laborers have similar trigger point distribution, with an
 average of 6 active and 10-11 latent trigger points (Fernandez-De-Las-Penas 2012).

 

 
 Muscular Overload

 Repetitive movements, heavy lifting, or sudden increased training load.

 

 
 Stress and Tension

 Psychological stress often leads to chronic muscle tension, especially in the neck and shoulders.

 

 
 Other Factors

 
 Sleep problems and fatigue: Poor sleep reduces the muscles' ability to recover

 Vitamin D deficiency: About one-third of MPS patients have low vitamin D levels
 (StatPearls 2025)

 Trauma: Whiplash and other injuries. Among whiplash patients, 55-65% have trigger
 points in levator scapulae

 
 

 
 Who is affected?

 MPS occurs most often in the 27-50 age group. Women are affected more often than men - 65% versus 37%
 among middle-aged adults (Steen, Muscle & Nerve 2025).

How is Trigger Points in the Neck - Muscle Knots and Referred Pain diagnosed?

Diagnosis

 

 Diagnosis is made through clinical examination. An international Delphi study from 2018 with 60 experts
 from 12 countries concluded that the most important diagnostic criteria are: a taut band in the muscle, a
 hypersensitive point, and reproduction of referred pain with pressure (Fernandez-de-las-Penas & Dommerholt
 2018).

 
 Important to know

 There are no internationally validated diagnostic criteria for MPS. Inter-examiner reliability is only
 moderate. This means that two practitioners examining the same patient may find trigger points in
 slightly different locations. We therefore use the clinical examination as a starting point, but also
 emphasize your experience and response to treatment.

 

 Imaging

 MRI and X-ray are rarely necessary for trigger points. Images often show age-related changes (wear,
 degeneration) that don't explain your pain. Ultrasound can detect trigger points as darker areas with
 increased stiffness, but this is currently mostly used in research.

Describe Differential Diagnoses for Trigger Points in the Neck - Muscle Knots and Referred Pain.

Differential Diagnoses

 

 It's important to distinguish trigger points from other conditions that can cause similar symptoms:

 
 Cervical Radiculopathy (Nerve Root Involvement)

 Follows dermatomal patterns (specific skin areas), often with tingling/numbness and weakness. Trigger
 points follow muscle-specific radiation patterns.

 

 
 Fibromyalgia

 Widespread pain for more than 3 months, with tenderness in many areas of the body, often with fatigue
 and sleep problems.

 

 
 Cervical Facet Joint Arthrosis

 Pain from the joints between vertebrae, often with morning stiffness that improves throughout the day.

Treatment

 

 What can the chiropractor do?

 A network meta-analysis from 2024 including 40 randomized studies and 2227 participants shows that manual
 treatment provides short-term improvement in pain, pressure sensitivity and function (Liu et al. 2024).
 Evidence quality is classified as low according to the GRADE system, but the effects are clinically
 relevant for many patients.

 
 Treatment I offer includes:

 
 Ischemic compression: Sustained pressure on the trigger point. A 2022 meta-analysis
 shows significant improvement in pressure pain threshold (Lu et al. 2022)

 Dry needling: Thin needles are inserted directly into the trigger point. Equally
 effective as manual trigger point treatment in short and medium term (Lew et al. 2021)

 Myofascial techniques and mobilization: Soft tissue treatment of muscles and fascia
 

 Joint mobilization/manipulation: For concurrent joint dysfunction in the neck or
 thoracic spine

 Exercise-based rehabilitation: The most important for lasting improvement

 
 

 
 Honest expectations

 Short-term treatment effects are well documented. Long-term effects (6-12 months) are less well
 studied, and at this time horizon there is little difference between different treatment methods. What
 gives the best lasting effect is combining treatment with self-exercise and addressing underlying
 factors like stress, ergonomics and sleep.

Prognosis

 

 Most people with trigger points in the neck experience good improvement with treatment and self-exercise.
 Short-term treatment effects are well documented in research.

 
 Recurrence is common

 Without addressing underlying factors like ergonomics, stress, inactivity and potential nutritional

 used. What appears most important for lasting improvement is the combination of treatment, exercises and
 adjustment of activity and ergonomics.

Describe Cervical Artery Dissection (CAD) for Red Flags for Neck Pain - When to See a Doctor.

Cervical Artery Dissection (CAD)

 

 Cervical artery dissection occurs when a tear forms in the inner wall of one of the blood vessels
 supplying the brain - either the carotid artery (arteria carotis interna) or the vertebral artery (arteria
 vertebralis). Blood can enter the vessel wall and form a blood collection that narrows or blocks blood
 flow to the brain.

 CAD is rare in the general population - historically estimated at 2.6-3.0 per 100,000 per year (Lee et
 al., Neurology 2006). But the condition is one of the most important causes of stroke in younger adults:
 Data from the Helsinki Young Stroke Registry shows that CAD accounts for approximately 15% of all
 ischemic strokes in patients under 50 years (Putaala et al., Stroke 2009).

 
 
 2.6-3

 15%
 of strokes under 50
 

 
 40-55 years
 typical age group
 

 

 Risk Factors for CAD

 Over half of cases are classified as "spontaneous" - without clear triggering trauma. Documented risk
 factors include:

 
 Connective Tissue Disorders

 Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, Marfan syndrome, and fibromuscular dysplasia (1-5% of cases)

 

 
 Recent Infection

 Increases risk nearly 3 times in the first week (Grau et al., Arch Neurol 1999)

 

 
 Migraine

 Moderate association demonstrated (Jacobs et al., 2025)

 

 
 High Blood Pressure

 Odds ratio 1.4-2.2

 

 
 Minor Traumas

 Including sports, hairdresser visits with head tilted back, roller coaster rides

Symptoms of CAD

 

 The most common symptom is headache and/or neck pain (65-95% of
 patients). But CAD-related pain has characteristics that distinguish it from common muscle problems:

 
 Warning Signs of CAD

 
 Sudden onset: Pain comes abruptly, often over minutes

 One-sided: 74% have pain on the same side as the dissection (Thomas et al., 2023)
 

 "Different from anything else": 75% describe the pain as unlike any previous
 headache (Mayer-Suess et al., 2022)

 Does not respond to treatment: Pain does not ease with movement, position, or
 painkillers

 Cannot be reproduced: Examination of the neck does not provoke the pain

 
 

 Neurological Signs of CAD

 
 Horner's syndrome (25-44%): Constricted pupil and drooping eyelid on one side

 Cranial nerve involvement (12%): Tongue deviation, hoarseness, swallowing
 difficulties

 Pulsatile tinnitus (8-10%): Rhythmic sound in ear synchronous with pulse

 

 
 The Critical Time Window

 Data from Biousse et al. (Stroke 1995) showed that 82% of strokes occur within 7 days
 after symptoms started. This means early recognition can prevent stroke.

Describe Cervical Myelopathy for Red Flags for Neck Pain - When to See a Doctor.

Cervical Myelopathy

 

 Cervical myelopathy occurs when the spinal cord in the neck becomes compressed or pressed on. This
 differs from ordinary neck pain or nerve root irritation in that the spinal cord itself - not just the
 nerves exiting from it - is affected. The condition is considered the most common cause of spinal cord
 dysfunction in adults (Lancet Neurology, 2019).

 The prevalence increases with age. Approximately 1-5% of adults over 40 years have
 symptomatic cervical myelopathy, and average age at diagnosis is 56-64 years (AOSpine, 2015). Men are
 affected 2-3 times more often than women.

 Causes of Myelopathy

 
 Degenerative Causes (80-90%)

 
 Cervical spondylosis: Wear changes with disc bulging and bone spurs. C5-C6 level
 most common (StatPearls, 2025)

 Thickened ligaments: Ligamentum flavum hypertrophy

 Congenitally narrow spinal canal: Most important anatomical risk factor

 
 

 
 Less Common Causes

 Disc herniation with central compression, tumors, infections,
 trauma

Describe symptoms and signs of Red Flags for Neck Pain - When to See a Doctor.

Symptoms of Myelopathy

 

 Cervical myelopathy has a characteristic symptom triad (AAFP, 2020):

 
 The Three Main Symptoms

 
 Walking difficulties: The most important symptom. Unsteadiness, balance problems,
 difficulties on stairs, unexplained falls

 Clumsiness in hands ("myelopathy hand"): Difficulty buttoning, problems writing,
 dropping things

 Bilateral numbness: Symptoms on both sides,
 often in both hands and feet

 
 

 
 Important

 Neck pain is surprisingly rarely the dominant symptom in myelopathy. Many patients have little or no
 pain, which can delay diagnosis. About 50% are initially misdiagnosed as carpal tunnel syndrome (Kim et
 al., 2013).

 

 Clinical Findings

 On examination, we look for upper motor neuron signs:

 
 Hoffman's sign: Sensitivity 48-59%, specificity 67-78%

 Babinski's sign: Low sensitivity (13%), but nearly 100% specificity

 Hyperreflexia: Increased reflexes in arms and legs

 Clonus: Sustained rhythmic muscle contractions

 

 Important clinical point: Normal findings on examination do not rule out myelopathy.
 Tests are specific but not sensitive - positive findings give strong suspicion, but negative findings do
 not provide reassurance.

 Complete normalization never occurs without treatment

 Without surgery, 20-62% of patients worsen within 6 months (StatPearls, AAFP)

Describe What is stress neck? for Stress Neck and Trigger Points.

What is stress neck?

 

 Stress neck describes a condition where psychological stress manifests as physical tension in the neck
 and shoulder muscles. When we experience stress, the body activates the "fight-or-flight" response which
 increases muscle tension - especially in the neck, shoulders and jaw.

 
 The Stress-Tension-Pain Cycle

 Many get caught in a vicious cycle:

 
 Stress - increased muscle tension

 Tension - trigger points and pain

 Pain - more stress and worry

 More stress - even more tension

 
 Treatment often needs to address multiple links in this cycle for lasting improvement.

 

 What are trigger points?

 Trigger points are hypersensitive areas in muscle tissue that feel like hard knots when palpated. They
 have two important characteristics:

 
 Local tenderness: The point is painful when pressed

 Referred pain: Pressing the point can trigger pain in other areas - e.g., trigger
 points in the trapezius can cause headache
You are a clinical documentation assistant for chiropractors. Generate professional medical documentation.
What causes Stress Neck and Trigger Points?

Causes and Risk Factors

 

 
 Psychosocial stress

 Work pressure, conflicts, financial worries and other stressors activate the body's stress response
 and increase muscle tension.

 

 
 Poor work posture

 Forward head position in front of screens, raised shoulders at keyboard work, and lack of movement
 throughout the day.

 

 
 Sleep deprivation

 Poor sleep reduces muscles' ability to recover and increases sensitivity to pain.

 

 
 Inactivity

 Lack of physical activity weakens muscles and makes them more vulnerable to overload.

 

 Common trigger point locations

 
 Upper trapezius: Between neck and shoulder - causes referred pain to temple and eye
 

 Levator scapulae: From neck to shoulder blade - causes stiff neck and pain with
 rotation

 Suboccipital muscles: At the base of skull - causes headache behind the eye

 Sternocleidomastoid: Front of neck - causes dizziness, blurred vision and headache
 

 

 
 Trigger points and headache

 Trigger points in the neck muscles are an underdiagnosed cause of tension headache and migraine-like symptoms. Treatment of these can
 often provide significant headache relief.

Treatment

 

 
 Chiropractic treatment may include:
