 Manual mobilization: Restore normal joint mobility in neck

 Soft tissue treatment: Massage and myofascial techniques

 Dry needling: Needle treatment of trigger points

 Exercises you can do yourself

 
 Neck stretches

 Gently tilt your head toward one shoulder. Hold for 30 seconds. Repeat to the opposite side. Do 3
 times each side, several times daily.

 

 
 Shoulder rolls

 Roll your shoulders slowly backward in large circles. Do 10 repetitions. This loosens tension in the
 upper trapezius.

 Pull your chin straight back as if making a "double chin." Hold for 5 seconds. Repeat 10 times.
 Corrects forward head posture.

 Workplace ergonomics

 
 Screen height: Top of screen at eye level

 Every 20 minutes, look at something 20 meters away for 20 seconds. This reduces strain on eyes and
 neck during screen work.

Symptoms of text neck

 

 Text neck produces a characteristic symptom pattern that develops gradually over time:

 
 Neck pain and stiffness

 Most common
 Aching, dull pain in the lower neck and the transition to shoulders. Stiffness that worsens
 throughout the day, especially after longer periods of mobile use.

 

 
 Tension headache

 Headache that starts in the neck and radiates up to the back of the head, temples and forehead. Often
 described as "tightness" around the head.

 

 
 Pain between shoulder blades

 Burning or aching discomfort in upper back, between and under the shoulder blades. Caused by muscles
 here working overtime to hold the head up.

 

 
 Forward head posture

 Numbness and tingling

 Toward end of workday after lots of screen work

 In the morning after sleeping with stiff neck

 During stress periods (stress worsens muscle tension)

Describe Exercises for text neck for Text Neck: From Mobile Use to Neck Pain.

Exercises for text neck

 

 These exercises counteract forward head posture and strengthen the muscles that hold the head in
 neutral position. Do them daily for best effect.

 
 1. Chin Tucks ("Double Chin")

 
 Sit or stand with straight back

 Pull chin straight back (as if making a double chin)

 Hold position for 5 seconds

 Release slowly

 Repeat 10-15 times, 3-4 times daily

 
 This is the most important exercise - it strengthens the deep neck stabilizers and
 counteracts forward head position.

 

 
 2. Doorway Chest Stretch

 
 Stand in a doorway with forearms against the door frame

 Elbows should be at shoulder height, 90 degree angle

 Take a step forward and lean gently into the stretch

 Feel stretch across chest and front of shoulders

 Hold for 30-60 seconds, repeat 2-3 times

 
 

 
 3. Shoulder Blade Squeeze

 
 Sit or stand with arms at sides

 Pull shoulder blades together and down (as if putting them in back pockets)

 Hold for 5-10 seconds

 Release slowly

 Repeat 10-15 times, several times daily

 
 

 
 4. Wall Angels

 
 Stand with back against wall, heels 5-10 cm from wall

 Lower back, upper back and back of head should touch wall

 Raise arms to sides with elbows bent 90 degrees ("stick em up")

 Push forearms and back of hands against wall

 Slowly slide arms up and down along wall

 10-15 repetitions, 2-3 sets

 
 This exercise strengthens back muscles and improves shoulder mobility simultaneously.

 The recommended treatment is prevention. Here are concrete measures to reduce the load:

 
 Posture during mobile use

 Support elbows: Use a table or pillow to support arms

 Maintain neck curve: Keep head in neutral position over shoulders

 
 

 
 Take breaks

 Micro-breaks: Every 30 minutes, stand up and stretch

 Variation breaks: Switch between sitting and standing work

 
 

 
 Ergonomics at PC/laptop

 
 Top of screen at eye level

 Screen an arm's length away

Describe Frequently Asked Questions for Text Neck: From Mobile Use to Neck Pain.

Frequently Asked Questions

 

 What is text neck?

 Text neck is a collective term for neck pain and problems that arise from prolonged mobile phone use
 with head bent forward. When head is 60 degrees forward, load on neck increases from about 5 kg to 27
 kg.

 Can text neck cause headache?

 Yes, text neck is a common cause of cervicogenic headache. The constant load on neck muscles and joints
 can cause tension headache that starts in neck and radiates to forehead and temples.

 How long does it take to get rid of text neck?

 With the right measures, most see improvement within 2-4 weeks. Key is to change mobile habits, do
 regular exercises, and possibly get treatment. Long-standing cases may require longer rehabilitation.
 

 Which exercises help with text neck?

 The most important exercises are chin tucks (double chin), chest stretches, and shoulder blade
 squeezes. These counteract forward head posture and strengthen muscles that hold head in neutral
 position.

 Is text neck dangerous?

 Text neck is not dangerous in itself, but prolonged strain can contribute to earlier degenerative
 changes in neck. It's important to address the problem early to avoid it becoming chronic.

Describe What is post-traumatic headache after whiplash? for Headache After Whiplash - Post-Traumatic Headache.

What is post-traumatic headache after whiplash?

 

 Post-traumatic headache (PTH) is headache that develops after an injury to the head or neck. In whiplash, this typically occurs after an acceleration-deceleration mechanism
 - such as rear-end collision, falls, or sports injuries.

 Between 30-90% of all who experience whiplash develop headache in the acute phase (Al-Khazali et al.,
 2020). A meta-analysis from 2023 showed that 47% still have headache one year after the injury (Herrero
 Babiloni et al., Pain 2023).

 In Northern Sweden, approximately 235 whiplash injuries per 100,000 inhabitants are reported annually
 (Styrke et al., Spine 2012).

 The International Headache Classification (ICHD-3, 2018) distinguishes between:

 
 Acute PTH

 Headache that starts within 7 days of injury and lasts less than 3 months.

 

 
 Persistent (chronic) PTH

 Headache that continues beyond 3 months after the injury.

 

 The Quebec Task Force classifies whiplash (WAD) into grades from 0-IV, where grades I-II make up
 approximately 90% of all cases. Grade II - with neck pain and reduced mobility - has the highest risk of
 developing chronic symptoms.
You are a clinical documentation assistant for chiropractors. Generate professional medical documentation.
Describe Why do you get headache after whiplash? for Headache After Whiplash - Post-Traumatic Headache.

Why do you get headache after whiplash?

 

 Most common causes - from most to least common

 
 1. Facet joint injuries (approx. 60% of chronic cases)

 Studies with diagnostic blocks show that the facet joints in the neck are the main source of pain in
 the majority with chronic whiplash (Lord & Barnsley, Spine 1996). The most frequently affected levels
 are C2-C3 (36%) and C5-C6 (35%).

 

 
 2. Muscle and ligament injuries

 The deep neck muscles and ligaments - especially around the upper cervical joints (C1-C2) - often
 sustain microtrauma. MRI studies have shown fatty infiltration in these muscles after whiplash.

 

 
 3. Trigeminocervical convergence

 Pain nerves from the neck (C1-C3) meet the trigeminal nerve in the brainstem. This explains why neck
 injury causes headache - pain signals from the neck are "misinterpreted" as headache.

 

 
 4. Central sensitization

 In chronic whiplash, the nervous system can become hypersensitive. Systematic reviews confirm that
 chronic WAD involves central sensitization with lower pain thresholds and enhanced pain perception
 (Van Oosterwijck et al., 2013).

 Most common headache types (Ashina et al., 2020)

 
 Migraine-like headache (31-61%)

 Pulsating pain, often unilateral, with nausea, light and sound sensitivity. Many experience this for
 the first time after the injury.

 

 
 Tension-type headache (21-40%)

 Pressing, squeezing pain like a band around the head.

 

 
 Cervicogenic headache

 Pain that starts in the neck and radiates up toward the back of the head and temples.

How is Headache After Whiplash - Post-Traumatic Headache diagnosed?

Diagnosis

 

 Clinical examination is most important

 For whiplash, we always start with a thorough clinical examination. We examine neck mobility, joint
 function, muscles and neurological status. The Canadian C-Spine Rule is used to assess whether imaging
 is necessary.

 When is imaging needed?

 X-ray or CT is only necessary when fracture or dislocation is suspected. Indications include: age over
 65, dangerous injury mechanism, tingling/numbness in arms or legs, or inability to actively move the
 neck.

 
 MRI - often misunderstood

 MRI in whiplash often shows normal findings or age-related wear that doesn't explain the pain.
 Studies show that MRI findings in people with whiplash often don't differ from healthy individuals.
 Clinical examination usually provides better information than imaging.

Describe treatment options for Headache After Whiplash - Post-Traumatic Headache.

Treatment

 

 What can the chiropractor do?

 A Cochrane review from 2007 reviewed 23 studies with over 2,300 participants. The main conclusion was
 clear: Early active mobilization is clearly better than rest and neck collar.

 
 We use gentle techniques adapted to the injury phase:

 
 Mobilization: Soft techniques to restore movement in locked joints. In acute
 whiplash, we avoid forceful manipulation.

 Soft tissue treatment: Treatment of tight muscles that try to "protect" the neck.
 

 Vestibular rehabilitation: Many become dizzy after whiplash. We provide exercises
 to train balance and coordination between eyes, ears and neck.

 
 

 A meta-analysis from 2022 (Bini et al., Chiropractic & Manual Therapies) showed moderate to large
 short-term effects on headache intensity in cervicogenic headache treated with manual therapy.

 What can you do yourself?

 Norwegian health authorities recommend that exercise should start within 4 days after the injury. Neck
 collar is unnecessary in most cases and can actually prolong symptoms if used for more than 48 hours.
 

 
 Early movement

 Repeated, gentle neck and head movements provide more relief than rest.

 

 
 Deep neck muscles

 Exercises for the deep neck flexors are important. These muscles often "shut off" after whiplash, and
 the larger superficial muscles take over - which can cause more headache.

 

 
 Avoid inactivity

 Those who rest and use collar have twice the risk of persistent symptoms as those who move ea...

What is the prognosis for Headache After Whiplash - Post-Traumatic Headache?

Prognosis - What happens?

 

 The first 3 months are crucial

 Research shows that improvement mainly occurs during the first 3 months after the injury. After this,
 the improvement curve flattens dramatically. A study found that 86% of those who were still symptomatic
 at 3 months remained symptomatic after 2 years.

 Three typical courses (Sterling et al., JOSPT 2016)

 
 
 ~50%
 Mild course: Full recovery
 

 
 ~30%
 Moderate course: Persistent moderate symptoms
 

 
 ~20%
 Severe course: Chronic disability
 

 

 Risk factors for poor outcome

 High initial pain intensity, high functional disability from the start, cold sensitivity, pain
 catastrophizing and post-traumatic stress symptoms increase the risk of chronicity. Low expectations of
 improvement is a strong negative prognostic factor.

 Relapse is common

 Even among those who recover, many experience relapse. Long-term studies show that only about 35% are
 fully recovered after 5 years. This underscores the importance of learning self-management strategies.

Describe What is whiplash? for Whiplash.

What is whiplash?

 

 Whiplash describes an injury mechanism where the head is suddenly thrown forward and backward. The term
 "whiplash-associated disorders" (WAD) is used for symptoms that occur after such an injury. It is
 therefore not a diagnosis in itself, but a description of how the injury occurred.

 Rear-end collision in a car is the most common cause, but whiplash can also occur during sports
 accidents, falls, or other situations with rapid movement of the neck. 83% of people involved in
 car accidents experience some degree of whiplash injury (PMC, 2009).

 
 Cervical sprain, cervical strain and whiplash - the same condition

 The terms "cervical sprain" and "cervical strain" are often used interchangeably. The Quebec Task
 Force acknowledged as early as 1995 that these conditions cannot be distinguished through clinical
 examination or standard imaging. Theoretically, "sprain" refers to ligament damage, while "strain"
 describes muscle-tendon injury. In practice, this distinction has no significance for treatment.

 

 Prevalence

 Norway has the world's highest prevalence of neck pain, with 6,151 cases per 100,000 inhabitants
 according to the Global Burden of Disease study. In the Nordic countries, approximately 235-383 people
 per 100,000 are affected by whiplash annually. Women have approximately twice the risk of men for
 developing symptoms after rear-end collision.

 get whiplash injury in car accident

 cases per 100,000 in Nordic...

Describe WAD Classification (Quebec Task Force) for Whiplash.

WAD Classification (Quebec Task Force)

 

 
 
 
 Grade
 Description
 
 
 
 
 WAD 0
 No neck complaints or clinical findings
 
 
 WAD I
 Neck complaints (pain, stiffness, tenderness) without clinical findings
 
 
 WAD II
 Neck complaints with musculoskeletal findings (reduced mobility, point tenderness) - most common
 (~82%)
 
 
 WAD III
 Neck complaints with neurological findings (reduced reflexes, weakness, sensory deficits)
 
 
 WAD IV
 Fracture or dislocation - requires immediate medical evaluation
 
 
 
 The vast majority have WAD grade II. Headache, dizziness, tinnitus, and jaw problems can occur at all
 grades.

What causes Whiplash?

Causes and risk factors

 

 Most common causes

 
 Car accidents (whiplash)

 The classic cause. During rear-end collision, the neck is exposed to rapid acceleration-deceleration
 that can damage soft tissues.

 

 
 Sports injuries

 Contact sports such as football, rugby, and martial arts increase risk through direct impacts or
 falls.

 

 
 Falls and accidents

 Falls from height or sudden movements can cause soft tissue injuries.

 

 Risk factors for prolonged symptoms

 Research has identified several factors that increase the risk of chronic symptoms (Walton et al.,
 2013):

 
 High pain intensity from the start (above 5.5/10)

 High functional disability from the start

 Catastrophizing (excessive worry about symptoms)

 Fear of movement

 Previous neck problems

 Post-traumatic stress symptoms

 

 
 Interesting finding

 Research shows that the collision itself (direction, speed, headrest type) does not significantly
 affect prognosis. Imaging findings also do not predict prognosis - psychosocial factors matter far
 more.

Describe symptoms and signs of Whiplash.

Symptoms

 

 Main symptoms

 
 Neck pain and stiffness - 62-100% (the most common symptom)

 Headache - 60-88%, often originating from the neck

 Shoulder and upper back stiffness - approx. 72%

 Fatigue - 70-80%

 Dizziness - 25-50% (up to 85% in some studies)

 Concentration difficulties - approx. 41%

 

 
 Delayed symptom onset is common

 Symptoms don't need to appear immediately. Many experience delayed onset from 12 hours to several
 days after the accident. This delay of 12-72 hours is characteristic and is due in part to adrenaline
 and endorphins masking pain in the acute phase.

Describe treatment options for Whiplash.

Treatment

 

 What can the chiropractor do?

 Systematic reviews show that multimodal treatment - the combination of manual therapy and exercises -
 gives better results than single interventions alone (Hidalgo et al., 2017).

 
 Treatment may include:

 
 Manual treatment: Gentle mobilization of neck joints and muscles

 Soft tissue treatment: Trigger point
 therapy, muscle stretching and fascial treatment

 Active rehabilitation: Specific exercises for strength, stability and mobility
 

 Advice and guidance: Information about the condition and what you can do yourself
 

 
 

 Early mobilization - not rest

 One of the most important findings from whiplash research is that early activity gives better
 results than rest and neck collar. A study by McKinney (1989) showed that 46% of those who
 were told to rest with a neck collar still had symptoms after two years, compared to only 23% of those
 who received advice about early mobilization.

 
 Neck collar is not recommended

 Neck collar and prolonged rest are not recommended in modern guidelines. International guidelines
 give Grade A recommendation against the use of neck collar.

 

 What can you do yourself?

 
 Stay active: Avoid prolonged rest and bed rest - gradual return to normal
 activities promotes healing

 Move neck gently: Calm movements in all directions several times daily, within
 comfort zone

 Avoid neck collar: Unless a doctor has specifically prescribed it

What is the prognosis for Whiplash?

Prognosis - What can you expect?

 

 Three typical courses (Sterling et al., Pain, 2010)

 
 Mild course (~45-50%)

 Full recovery within 2-3 months with minimal residual symptoms.

 

 
 Moderate course (~30-40%)

 Partial recovery with persistent mild to moderate symptoms.

 

 
 Severe course (~15-20%)

 Poor recovery with chronic moderate to severe symptoms.

 

 
 The first three months are crucial

 An important finding is that the first three months are decisive for long-term prognosis. A study
 showed that 93% of those who were symptom-free at three months remained symptom-free after two years.
 Conversely, 86% of those with symptoms at three months still had symptoms after two years.

 

 
 
 ~50%
 recover within 3 months
 

 
 53%
 reduced relapse risk with exercise
 

 
 93%
 symptom-free at 3 months stay well
 

 

 Preventing relapse

 Exercise reduces the risk of new episodes by 53% (RR 0.47) according to a
 meta-analysis from 2023 (Campos, JOSPT, 2023). This is the most important preventive factor. Regular
 exercise - especially neck and shoulder stabilizing exercises - is highly recommended.

Frequently Asked Questions

 

 How long does whiplash take to heal?

 Most people experience significant improvement within 2-3 months. About half recover fully, while

 Should I use a neck collar?

 as 1995. Treatment is identical.

 Can symptoms appear several days after the accident?

 Yes, this is common. Symptoms can appear from 12 hours to several days (typically 12-72 hours) after

 How can I prevent new episodes?

 Regular exercise - especially neck and shoulder stabilizing exercises - reduces the risk of relapse by

What causes Neck Pain - Complete Guide to Causes, Treatment and Red Flags?

1What Causes Neck Pain?

 
 Non-specific neck pain (80-90% of cases)

 Between 80 and 90 percent of all neck pain has no specific cause detectable on X-ray or MRI. This doesn't mean the pain is imaginary - it can be very troublesome.

 Typical characteristics: Stiffness, soreness and heaviness in neck and shoulders. Pain often comes gradually and may be related to sedentary work, stress, poor sleep or one-sided strain.

 

 
 Myofascial pain syndrome (88.9% have trigger points)

 Tight muscles with trigger points - tender knots - are very common with neck pain. A study found that 88.9% of patients with chronic non-specific neck pain had at least one trigger point.

 

 
 Facet joint pain (54-60% of chronic cases)

 The facet joints are the small joints on the back of neck vertebrae. In chronic neck pain, studies show facet joints are the pain source in 54-60% of patients.

 

 
 Text neck and forward head posture

 Modern smartphone use puts significant strain on the neck. At 60 degrees forward (typical phone position), the neck bears 27 kg of load instead of the normal 4.5-5 kg head weight.
You are a clinical documentation assistant for chiropractors. Generate professional medical documentation.
Describe Cervical Radiculopathy - Nerve Root Pain for Neck Pain - Complete Guide to Causes, Treatment and Red Flags.

2Cervical Radiculopathy - Nerve Root Pain

 When a nerve in the neck gets pinched, it can cause radiation down the arm with tingling, numbness or weakness. This affects approximately 0.8-1.8 per 1000 people annually. The good news: 75-90% improve with conservative treatment.

 
 Which nerve is affected?

 
 C6 nerve: Numbness in thumb and index finger, weak biceps

 C7 nerve: Most common (60-70%). Numbness in middle finger, weak triceps

 C8 nerve: Numbness in ring/little finger, weak grip

 
 

 
 Bakody's sign

 If symptoms improve when you place your hand on your head (shoulder in abduction), it strongly suggests the problem comes from the neck. This test has 80-100% specificity for cervical radiculopathy.

Describe Conditions That Often Accompany Neck Pain for Neck Pain - Complete Guide to Causes, Treatment and Red Flags.

3Conditions That Often Accompany Neck Pain

 
 Cervicogenic dizziness (43% of patients)

 43% of patients with prolonged neck pain also report dizziness. The neck has a high density of position sensors - when these malfunction due to muscle tightness or joint dysfunction, a sensory conflict occurs creating dizziness.

 

 
 Cervicogenic headache (15-20% of all headaches)

 Headache originating from the neck affects approximately 2.2% of the population. Typically starts in the neck and radiates toward forehead or eye - often one-sided.

Describe MRI and Degeneration - "Gray Hair for the Spine" for Neck Pain - Complete Guide to Causes, Treatment and Red Flags.

5MRI and Degeneration - "Gray Hair for the Spine"

 Many become worried when MRI shows "wear and tear" or "degeneration". But such findings are normal in adults and rarely explain your pain.

 
 88.5% of healthy volunteers have cervical degenerative changes

 52% of asymptomatic adults have disc bulging

 86% over 60 have disc signal loss

 
 
 When is imaging necessary?

 For ordinary neck pain, imaging is usually not necessary. Only relevant when there's suspicion of serious underlying disease, after significant trauma, or if you don't respond to treatment over time.

Describe treatment options for Neck Pain - Complete Guide to Causes, Treatment and Red Flags.

6Treatment of Neck Pain

 The combination of manual treatment and exercises has documented effect for neck pain. A 2023 meta-analysis found that manipulative therapy gave better results on pain and function compared to control groups.

 
 Why early treatment pays off

 A 2016 study showed early treatment gave twice the chance of clinically meaningful improvement in both pain and function. Early intervention was also more cost-effective.

 

 Treatment course expectations

 
 Acute neck pain (under 6 weeks): 2-3 treatments/week for 2-4 weeks, total 6-12 treatments

 Chronic problems (over 12 weeks): 1-2 treatments/week over longer period with home exercises

 
 Prognosis

 
 50-85% experience recurrence within 1-5 years

 About 30% of acute cases develop chronic problems

 For cervical radiculopathy: 43% become symptom-free, 29% mild problems, 27% persistent

 How long do typical neck pains last?

No, early treatment often gives better results. Treatment within 4 weeks doubles the chance of significant improvement.

For ordinary neck pain, MRI is rarely necessary. 88.5% of healthy people have degenerative changes without symptoms.

Describe What is the AC Joint and AC Joint Osteoarthritis? for AC Joint Osteoarthritis: Everything You Need to Know.

What is the AC Joint and AC Joint Osteoarthritis?

 

 
 Anatomy

 The AC joint (acromioclavicular joint) is a small joint at the top of the shoulder where:

 
 The collarbone (clavicle) meets

 The acromion - a projection from the shoulder blade

 
 The joint has a small cartilage disc (discus) and is stabilized by several ligaments. It allows
 movement when you lift your arm and is involved in most shoulder movements.

 

 AC joint osteoarthritis is wear (degeneration) of the cartilage and structures in this joint. The
 changes include:

 
 Cartilage that becomes thinner and more uneven

 Bone spurs (osteophytes) that form

 Joint space that becomes narrower

 Subchondral sclerosis (thickening of the bone under the cartilage)

 

 
 
 75%
 over 40 have MRI findings
 

 
 10%
 actually have symptoms
 

 
 40-50 yrs
 typical onset age
 

 

 
 Important Perspective

 Degenerative changes in the AC joint are normal age-related changes. Most people who
 have such findings on X-ray or MRI have no symptoms. Focus on your symptoms, not the image.

What causes AC Joint Osteoarthritis: Everything You Need to Know?

Causes and Risk Factors

 

 Primary Causes

 
 
 Age-Related Wear

 Most Common
 

 Normal degeneration over time. The AC joint is one of the first joints in the body to show
 age-related changes, often from the 20-30 age range.

 

 
 
 Overload and Repetitive Activity

 

 Occupations or sports with lots of overhead work or heavy lifting put extra stress on the joint.
 Common in:

 
 Powerlifters and crossfitters

 Carpenters and painters

 Overhead athletes (volleyball, handball, tennis)

 
 

 
 
 Previous Injury

 

 An AC joint separation or collarbone fracture increases the risk of later osteoarthritis in the
 joint.

How is AC Joint Osteoarthritis: Everything You Need to Know diagnosed?

Diagnosis

 

 Diagnosis is made based on medical history, clinical examination and possibly imaging.

 Clinical Tests

 
 Cross-body adduction: Moving the arm across toward the opposite shoulder. Positive
 if pain in the AC joint.

 Palpation: Direct tenderness over the AC joint

 O'Brien's test: Can be positive, but also with SLAP

 AC joint injection test: Pain relief after anesthetic injection confirms the AC
 joint as the pain source

 

 Imaging

 
 X-ray

 First choice. Shows:

 
 Narrowed joint space

 Bone spurs (osteophytes)

 Subchondral sclerosis

 Rarely necessary for AC joint osteoarthritis alone. Most useful for ruling out concurrent pathology
 (rotator cuff, etc.).

 clinical findings.

Describe What is Calcific Tendinitis? for Calcific Tendinitis: Everything You Need to Know.

What is Calcific Tendinitis?

 

 Calcific tendinitis is a condition where calcium crystals deposit in the rotator cuff tendons, most
 commonly in the supraspinatus tendon. The deposits vary in size from small dots to lumps several
 centimeters large.

 The condition goes through several phases and is self-limiting - meaning the calcium
 will eventually be reabsorbed by the body. The problem is that this can take anywhere from a few months
 to several years, and in the meantime, the pain can be significant.

 How common is calcific tendinitis?

 Calcific tendinitis is one of the most common causes of shoulder pain:

 
 
 2.7-7.8%
 prevalence in population
 

 
 2x
 women affected more often
 

 
 40-60 years
 typical age group
 

 
 10-20%
 have it in both shoulders
 

 

 
 Who gets calcific tendinitis?

 
 Women are affected twice as often as men

 Most common between 40 and 60 years

 Often the non-dominant shoulder (left for right-handed people)

 Increased prevalence with metabolic disorders (diabetes, thyroid)

 Sedentary work may be a risk factor

Describe The Three Phases for Calcific Tendinitis: Everything You Need to Know.

The Three Phases

 

 Calcific tendinitis follows a characteristic course in three phases. Understanding which phase you are
 in helps both predict the course and choose the right treatment.

 
 Phase 1: Pre-calcification and Formation (Formative phase)

 In this phase, normal tendon tissue transforms into fibrocartilage, and calcium begins to deposit.
 The process can take weeks to months.

 
 Symptoms: Mild to moderate pain, often vague and diffuse

 X-ray: The calcium looks "fluffy" or unclear

 Duration: Varies from weeks to months

 
 

 
 Phase 2: Resting Phase (Resting/Chronic phase)

 The calcium is fully formed and lies relatively stable in the tendon. This is often the longest phase
 and can last for years.

 
 Symptoms: Variable - can be almost symptom-free or cause persistent problems

 X-ray: The calcium looks dense and well-defined

 Duration: Months to years

 
 

 
 Phase 3: Resorption (Resorptive phase)

 The body begins actively breaking down the calcium. Paradoxically, this is the most painful phase,
 but signals that the condition is resolving.

 
 Symptoms: Intense, acute pain - often at night. Dramatically reduced mobility
 

 X-ray: The calcium looks "fluffy" with unclear borders

 Duration: Days to weeks

 
 

 
 Important to understand

 Many patients become worried when the pain suddenly becomes much worse. But this worsening is often a
 good sign - it means the body is actively breaking down the calcium. The resorptive phase is usually
 short-lived...

Describe symptoms and signs of Calcific Tendinitis: Everything You Need to Know.

Symptoms

 

 Symptoms of calcific tendinitis vary significantly depending on which phase the condition is in:

 Typical symptoms

 
 Pain: Localized to the outside of the shoulder/upper arm. May radiate down to the
 elbow.

 Night pain: Common, especially when lying on the affected side. Read more about sleep and shoulder pain

 Restricted movement: Difficulty lifting the arm to the side and overhead

 Sudden worsening: Acute, intense pain during transition to the resorptive phase
 

 

 
 Acute presentation (resorptive phase)

 Sudden onset of intense pain, often at night. The shoulder may be very tender to touch, and the
 patient often holds the arm completely still to avoid pain. The condition can resemble septic
 arthritis or gout.

 

 
 Chronic presentation (resting/formation phase)

 Gradually increasing pain over time. The pain worsens with activity, especially movements above
 shoulder height. May resemble impingement syndrome.

 

 
 Clinical tests

 On examination, we often find:

 
 Painful arc during abduction (60-120 degrees)

 Positive Neer's and/or Hawkins test

 Point tenderness over the supraspinatus attachment

 In acute phase: Heat, swelling, marked tenderness

How is Calcific Tendinitis: Everything You Need to Know diagnosed?

Diagnosis

 

 Calcific tendinitis is usually easily diagnosed with X-ray, which clearly shows the calcium deposits.
 

 X-ray

 X-ray is the first choice and shows calcium deposits well. The appearance of the calcium can provide
 information about which phase the condition is in:

 
 Formative phase: Unclear, "fluffy" calcium

 Resting phase: Dense, well-defined calcium with sharp borders

 Resorptive phase: The calcium becomes "fluffy" with unclear borders again

 

 Ultrasound

 Ultrasound can also detect calcium deposits and assess the condition of the tendon. The advantage is
 that you can assess the entire rotator cuff without radiation.

 MRI

 MRI is rarely necessary, but may be useful for:

 
 Uncertain diagnosis

 Suspected concurrent rotator cuff tear

 Preparation for possible surgery

 

 
 Incidental findings

 Calcium deposits are found incidentally in many people without symptoms. Studies show that up to 20%
 of asymptomatic individuals have calcium in the shoulder on X-ray. Not all calcium causes problems.

Identify red flags for Calcific Tendinitis: Everything You Need to Know.

Red Flags and Differential Diagnoses

 

 Although calcific tendinitis is usually a benign condition, it is important to rule out other causes of
 shoulder pain.

 
 Seek medical attention if you experience:

 
 Fever combined with intense shoulder pain and swelling (may be infection)

 Significant unexplained weight loss

 Previous cancer history with new pain

 Trauma with sudden loss of strength in the arm

 General feeling of illness

 
 Acute calcific tendinitis in the resorptive phase can mimic septic arthritis. When in doubt, seek
 medical attention to rule out infection.

 

 Conditions that may resemble calcific tendinitis

 
 Rotator cuff tendinopathy/tear

 Similar symptom picture, but X-ray will not show calcium. Ultrasound or MRI can distinguish between
 the conditions.

 

 
 Impingement syndrome

 Overlapping symptoms with painful arc. Calcific tendinitis can cause secondary impingement.

 

 
 Frozen shoulder (adhesive capsulitis)

 Also causes significant restriction of movement, but with a different pattern (stiffness in all
 directions).

 

 
 AC joint arthritis

 Pain localized more to the top of the shoulder. X-ray shows changes in the AC joint, not calcium in
 the tendon.

Describe treatment options for Calcific Tendinitis: Everything You Need to Know.

Treatment

 

 Treatment of calcific tendinitis depends on symptom intensity and phase. Because the condition is
 self-limiting, the goal is to relieve symptoms while the body takes care of the calcium itself.

 Conservative treatment (first choice)

 
 What can the chiropractor/physiotherapist do?

 
 Manual therapy: Mobilization of shoulder and thoracic spine

 Soft tissue treatment: Work on tight muscles around the shoulder

 Exercise guidance: Tailored exercises to maintain mobility and strength

 Ergonomic advice: Adaptation of work tasks during acute phase. See ergonomics and shoulder problems

 
 

 Shockwave Therapy (ESWT)

 ESWT (Extracorporeal Shock Wave Therapy) has Level I evidence for treating calcific
 tendinitis. Shock waves are sent toward the calcium deposit to stimulate resorption and relieve pain.
 

 
 The KALK Study (BMJ 2023)

 A Norwegian study (the KALK study) compared ESWT with placebo. Interestingly, the study showed no
 significant difference between groups at 4 and 12 months. This may be because patients with shorter
 symptom duration were included - where the condition might have resolved anyway.

 Other studies with longer symptom duration have shown better effect of ESWT. The treatment may be
 most useful for patients with long-term symptoms that show no signs of spontaneous improvement.

 

 Other treatment options

 
 Ultrasound-guided barbotage (needling)

 A needle is inserted into the calcium deposit under ultrasound guidance. Calcium slur...

What is the prognosis for Calcific Tendinitis: Everything You Need to Know?

Prognosis

 

 The prognosis for calcific tendinitis is generally good. The condition is self-limiting, meaning the
 calcium will eventually disappear on its own.

 
 The positives:

 
 80-99% recover without surgery

 The calcium is naturally reabsorbed in most cases

 Intense pain in the resorptive phase is short-lived (days to weeks)

 Recurrence is rare once the calcium is gone

 
 

 
 The realistic:

 
 The course can take months to years

 Symptoms can vary significantly in intensity

 Some experience long-term problems despite treatment

 About 10-20% have bilateral involvement

 
 

 Factors affecting prognosis

 
 Phase: Patients in the resorptive phase often recover faster

 Size: Large calcium deposits can take longer

 Location: Calcium near the tendon attachment can be more problematic

 Activity level: Adapted activity promotes recovery

What You Can Do Yourself

 

 
 In acute phase (resorption)

 
 Ice or cold can relieve pain and swelling

 Avoid movements that provoke pain

 Use pain relievers/anti-inflammatories as needed

 Sleep with a pillow under your arm for support

 Be patient - this intense phase is short-lived

 
 

 
 In chronic phase

 
 Keep the shoulder moving within pain-free limits

 Gradual strength training of the rotator cuff

 Avoid prolonged static positions

 Ergonomic adaptation of workstation

 
 

 Exercises

 Gentle mobility and strength exercises can help maintain function and prevent stiffness. Important to
 adapt intensity to symptoms:

 
 Pendulum exercises: Let the arm hang and swing gently in circles

 Wall climbing: Use your fingers to "climb" up a wall in front of you

 External rotation with elastic: When pain level allows

 Scapula exercises: Shoulder blade squeeze and retraction

Describe Frequently Asked Questions for Calcific Tendinitis: Everything You Need to Know.

Frequently Asked Questions

 

 
 Can calcific tendinitis go away on its own?

 Yes. Calcific tendinitis is a self-limiting condition. The calcium will eventually be reabsorbed
 naturally, but this can take anywhere from a few months to several years. Treatment can speed up the
 process and relieve symptoms in the meantime.

 

 
 Does shockwave therapy (ESWT) help with calcific tendinitis?

 ESWT has Level I evidence for calcific tendinitis. The KALK study (BMJ 2023) showed no difference
 from placebo for patients with shorter symptom duration. The treatment appears to be most useful for
 patients with long-term symptoms.

 

 
 Do I need surgery for calcific tendinitis?

 Rarely. 80-99% of patients recover without surgery. Surgery is only considered for long-term symptoms
 (over 6-12 months) after failed conservative treatment.

 

 
 Why does the pain suddenly go from bad to very bad?

 This happens in the resorptive phase when the body breaks down the calcium. The immune system
 activates, inflammation occurs, and this causes intense pain. Paradoxically, this is often a sign that
 the body is resolving the problem.

 

 
 Can calcific tendinitis come back?

 The recurrence rate is low once the calcium is fully reabsorbed. However, in rare cases, calcific
 tendinitis can occur in the other shoulder.

 

 
 Should I avoid all activity?

 No. In the acute phase, you should avoid movements that provoke pain, but complete rest is not
 recommended. Adapted activity within pain...

Describe What is Cortisone and How Does it Work? for Cortisone Injection in Shoulder: Friend or Foe?.

What is Cortisone and How Does it Work?

 

 Cortisone (corticosteroids) are synthetic versions of cortisol - a hormone the body produces itself.
 When injected locally, it has a powerful anti-inflammatory effect.

 How cortisone works

 
 Reduces inflammation: Inhibits inflammatory processes locally in the tissue

 Reduces pain: Less inflammation = less pain

 Reduces swelling: Reduces fluid accumulation in the area

 

 
 Common cortisone preparations

 There are different types of cortisone with varying strength and duration:

 
 Triamcinolone (Kenacort): Medium strength, commonly used in shoulder

 Methylprednisolone (Depo-Medrol): Medium strength

 Betamethasone (Celestone): Stronger, faster effect

 
 Cortisone is often combined with local anesthetic for immediate pain relief.

 

 Where is the injection given?

 For shoulder problems, cortisone can be injected in several places depending on the diagnosis:

 
 Subacromial (under the acromion)

 The most common injection site for shoulder pain. Reaches the bursa or rotator cuff. Used for
 impingement, bursitis and rotator cuff tendinopathy.

 

 
 In the shoulder joint (glenohumeral)

 Injection directly into the shoulder joint itself. Used for frozen shoulder, arthritis and rheumatoid arthritis.

 

 
 In the AC joint

 The small joint between the collarbone and shoulder blade. Used for AC joint arthritis.

 At 6-8 weeks, the effect begins to wear off in most people

 At 3 months, there's often no difference from placebo

Describe When Should You Avoid Cortisone? for Cortisone Injection in Shoulder: Friend or Foe?.

When Should You Avoid Cortisone?

 

 Based on current knowledge, there are some situations where cortisone is generally not recommended:

 
 
 Chronic tendinopathy

 Avoid
 

 For long-term tendon problems without acute inflammation, exercises and graded loading are better.
 Cortisone can actually worsen the prognosis long-term.

 

 
 
 Partial tendon tears

 Avoid
 

 Cortisone can further weaken already damaged tendon tissue and increase the risk of complete rupture.
 

 

 
 
 Repeated injections

 Caution
 

 More than 3-4 injections in the same area per year is discouraged. Repeated injections significantly
 increase the risk of tissue damage.

 

 
 
 When exercises haven't been tried

 Caution
 

 Cortisone should rarely be the first choice. Structured rehabilitation should be attempted first in
 most cases.

 

 
 Absolute contraindications

 
 Active infection in or near the injection area

 Known allergy to cortisone or local anesthetic

 Uncontrolled diabetes (cortisone raises blood sugar)

 Blood thinning medication (increased bleeding risk)

Alternatives to Cortisone

 

 There are several effective alternatives that often provide better long-term results:

 
 Structured rehabilitation (first choice)

 For most shoulder conditions, exercise-based treatment is well-documented long-term:

 
 Eccentric exercises for tendinopathy

 Graded loading that stimulates tissue adaptation

 Strength training for rotator cuff and scapula stabilizers

 Takes longer but provides more lasting results

 
 

 
 
 Manual therapy / Chiropractic

 Recommended
 

 Combination of joint mobilization, soft tissue treatment and exercise guidance. Can provide good pain
 relief without the risks of cortisone.

 

 
 
 Shockwave therapy (ESWT)

 Recommended for calcific tendinitis
 

 Level I evidence for calcific tendinitis. Stimulates
 biological healing without weakening tissue. Can also be used for chronic tendinopathy.

 

 
 
 PRP injection

 Variable evidence
 

 Platelet-rich plasma from the patient's own blood. Theoretically stimulates healing. Evidence is
 mixed, but some studies show promising results for certain conditions.

 

 
 NSAIDs as an alternative

 For acute inflammation, anti-inflammatory tablets (ibuprofen, diclofenac) can provide similar effect
 to cortisone for some, without the risk of local tissue damage. Should be used short-term and in
 consultation with a doctor.

Diagnosis

 

 Clinical examination

 
 Range of motion assessment: Compare internal rotation on both sides (GIRD)

 Infraspinatus test: External rotation against resistance

 Internal impingement test: Pain in abducted/externally rotated position

What causes Shoulder-Friendly Workspace: How to Set Up Your Workstation?

Why office work causes shoulder pain

 

 The body was not designed to sit still in the same position for hours. When we do, several things
 happen that strain the shoulders:

 
 Static muscle work

 When you hold your arms in front of you to use the keyboard and mouse, the shoulder muscles
 constantly work to stabilize. Without rest, this leads to fatigue, tension and eventually pain.

 

 
 Forward-leaning posture

 Many lean forward toward the screen. This causes the head to come in front of the shoulders, which
 significantly increases the load on neck and shoulder muscles.

 

 
 Raised shoulders

 Stress, concentration or incorrect desk height causes us to unconsciously raise our shoulders. Over
 time, this leads to chronic tension in the trapezius muscle. This can also affect sleep quality.

 

 
 One-sided strain

 Using the mouse with the same arm all day, the keyboard too far to one side - such asymmetries strain
 one shoulder more than the other. Over time, this can contribute to conditions like biceps tendinopathy or AC
 joint arthritis.

Describe Screen Setup for Shoulder-Friendly Workspace: How to Set Up Your Workstation.

Screen Setup

 

 Screen placement has great significance for neck and shoulder position:

 
 Correct screen height

 
 Top of the screen should be at eye level or slightly below

 You should look straight ahead or slightly down (approx. 10-20 degrees)

 Use a screen stand, books or adjustable arm to achieve the correct height

 For laptop: external screen or laptop stand is almost necessary

 
 

 
 Correct distance

 
 The screen should be about an arm's length away (50-70 cm)

 You should be able to read text without leaning forward

 Adjust font size rather than moving the screen closer

 
 

 
 Avoid this

 
 Screen too low (laptop on lap/table) - forces head down

 Screen to the side - causes neck rotation and asymmetric shoulder load

 Screen too far away - makes you lean forward

 Two screens where you primarily use one - place main screen directly in front

 
 

 
 The laptop problem

 Laptops are ergonomically challenging because the screen and keyboard are connected. When the screen
 is at the right height, the keyboard is too high - and vice versa. The solution is an external
 keyboard/mouse combined with a laptop stand, or an external monitor.

Keyboard and Mouse

 

 Keyboard and mouse placement is often underestimated, but has great significance for shoulder strain:
 

 
 Keyboard placement

 
 The keyboard should be directly in front of you, not angled

 Place it so that upper arms hang straight down along the body

 Forearms should be approximately parallel to the floor (90 degree angle at the elbow)

 Wrists should be in neutral position - not bent up or down

 
 

 
 Mouse placement

 
 The mouse should be right next to the keyboard, not further out

 You should not have to reach for the mouse

 Keep the elbow close to the body when using the mouse

 Consider an ergonomic mouse or vertical mouse with heavy mouse use

 
 

 
 
 Compact keyboard

 Recommended
 

 A keyboard without a numeric keypad (tenkeyless) allows you to place the mouse closer to the midline.
 This reduces how far you have to extend your arm to the side, which significantly relieves the
 shoulder.

 

 
 Common mistakes

 
 Mouse too far to the side - forces you to abduct (lift out) the arm

 Keyboard/mouse too high - causes you to raise your shoulders

 Too much angle in the wrist - can cause tension up through the arm

Chair and Sitting Position

 

 A good chair and correct adjustment lays the foundation for a relaxed shoulder position:

 
 Chair height

 
 Feet should be flat on the floor (or on a footrest)

 Knees should be at approximately 90 degree angle or slightly more

 Thighs should be approximately parallel to the floor

 
 

 
 Armrests

 
 Armrests should support forearms so shoulders can be relaxed

 Adjust height so shoulders are neither raised nor pulled down

 Armrests should not prevent you from getting close enough to the desk

 Some prefer no armrests - then they avoid sitting too far from the desk

 
 

 
 Back support

 The backrest should support the lower back (lumbar region). Good lumbar support helps you maintain
 natural curvature in the back, which in turn makes it easier to maintain a relaxed shoulder position.
 

 

 
 The best sitting position

 More important than "perfect" posture is variation. There is no position that is
 ideal for hours. Alternate between leaning forward, leaning back, and upright. Stand up and move
 regularly. The next position is always the best position. For persistent pain, consider whether there
 may be an underlying condition like calcific tendinitis or TOS (thoracic outlet syndrome).

Variation and Breaks

 

 No matter how perfect the ergonomics are, the body is not made for prolonged stillness. Variation and
 breaks are more important than the "perfect" setup:

 
 Break structure

 
 Micro-breaks (30 sec - 1 min): Every 20-30 minutes. Straighten up, roll
 shoulders, look away from the screen.

 Short breaks (5-10 min): Every hour. Stand up, walk a few steps, stretch.

 Longer breaks (15-30 min): Lunch etc. Get away from the workstation completely.
 

 
 

 
 Sit-stand desk

 A sit-stand desk allows you to alternate between sitting and standing work. It's not about standing
 all day (that's not good either), but about variation.

 
 Start with short standing periods (15-30 min)

 Alternate between sitting and standing several times a day

 Remember that ergonomics must also be correct in standing position

 
 

 
 Tips to remember breaks

 
 Use app or timer to remind you of breaks

 Drink plenty of water - then you also have to get up more often

 Place the printer, coffee machine etc. so you have to walk

 Take phone calls standing or walking

Describe Exercises at the Desk for Shoulder-Friendly Workspace: How to Set Up Your Workstation.

Exercises at the Desk

 

 These simple exercises can be done sitting at the desk or standing beside it. They only take 30-60
 seconds each:

 
 1. Shoulder rolls

 Roll your shoulders backward in large circles. Start by raising your shoulders toward your ears, then
 pull them back, down and forward again. Repeat 10 times.

 30 seconds
 

 
 2. Neck stretch

 Gently tilt your head to one side (ear toward shoulder). Hold for 15-20 seconds. Repeat on the other
 side. Don't rotate your head, just side bending.

 40 seconds
 

 
 3. Chest opening

 Lean back in the chair, open your arms out to the sides and push your chest forward. Squeeze your
 shoulder blades together. Hold for 10 seconds, repeat 3 times.

 30 seconds
 

 
 4. Shoulder blade squeeze

 Pull your shoulder blades together as if trying to hold a pencil between them. Hold for 5 seconds,
 release. Repeat 10 times.

 50 seconds
 

 
 5. Chin tuck

 Pull your chin straight back (double chin movement) while looking straight ahead. Hold for 5 seconds.
 This counteracts forward head posture. Repeat 10 times.

 50 seconds
 

 
 6. Arms overhead

 Stretch both arms straight up above your head. Breathe in, stretch as high as you can. Breathe out,
 lower your arms. Repeat 5 times.

 30 seconds
 

 
 Make this a habit

 Choose 2-3 of the exercises and do them every time you take a micro-break. Over time it becomes
 automatic, and your shoulders will thank you.

Describe Frequently Asked Questions for Shoulder-Friendly Workspace: How to Set Up Your Workstation.

Frequently Asked Questions

 

 
 How high should the screen be to avoid shoulder pain?

 The top of the screen should be at eye level or slightly below. This means you
 look straight ahead or slightly down, which provides a relaxed neck and shoulder position.

 

 
 Can mouse use cause shoulder pain?

 Yes. If the mouse is placed too far out to the side or too high, you have to
 extend your arm and raise your shoulder. Over time, this can cause tension and pain in the shoulder
 and neck.

 

 
 How often should I take breaks from computer work?

 Ideally, you should take a micro-break (30-60 seconds) every 20-30 minutes, and
 a longer break (5-10 minutes) every hour. Movement and variation are key.

 

 
 Is a standing desk better for the shoulders?

 Variation is more important than whether you sit or stand. A sit-stand desk
 allows you to alternate between positions throughout the day, which is beneficial for both shoulder,
 neck and back.

 

 
 What exercises can I do at my desk?

 Good exercises include shoulder rolls, neck stretches, chest opening and
 shoulder blade squeeze. These only take a few seconds and can be done sitting at your desk.

 

 
 Does ergonomic equipment help?

 Ergonomic equipment (mouse, keyboard, chair) can help, but it's not magic. The
 most important thing is correct setup of what you have, and above all breaks and movement. Expensive
 equipment doesn't replace good habits.

Describe What is a SLAP lesion? for SLAP Lesion: Everything You Need to Know.

What is a SLAP lesion?

 

 A SLAP lesion is an injury to the upper part of the labrum (joint rim) in the shoulder joint, where the
 long biceps tendon attaches. "SLAP" stands for "Superior Labrum Anterior to Posterior" - meaning an
 injury that extends from front to back on the upper joint rim.

 The labrum is a cartilage ring that surrounds the socket in the shoulder and contributes to stability.
 The long biceps tendon attaches at the top of this ring, and this is where SLAP lesions occur.

 Classification

 SLAP lesions are classified into four main types:

 
 
 Type I - Degenerative changes

 

 Wear and fraying in the labrum without detachment. Common age-related change. Rarely requires
 treatment.

 

 
 
 Type II - Detachment of labrum and biceps attachment

 Most common
 

 The labrum and biceps attachment detach from the socket. This is the most clinically relevant type
 and the one most often discussed in relation to surgery.

 

 
 
 Type III - "Bucket handle" tear

 

 A part of the labrum tears off and can hang down into the joint like a bucket handle. Can cause
 mechanical symptoms.

 

 
 
 Type IV - Tear involving the biceps tendon

 

 Combination of type III where the tear extends into the biceps tendon.

 of shoulder arthroscopies
 

 
 Type II
 most common type

What causes SLAP Lesion: Everything You Need to Know?

Causes and risk factors

 

 SLAP lesions can occur in several ways:

 Acute injury

 
 Fall on outstretched arm: Compression forces push the upper arm bone up against the
 labrum

 Direct trauma: Blow to the shoulder

 Sudden pull: Heavy lifting or jerking of the arm

 

 Overload (most common)

 
 
 Repetitive overhead activity

 Main cause
 

 Throwing movements and overhead sports expose the biceps attachment to repeated pulling forces. Over
 time, this can lead to SLAP lesion. Common in:

 
 Handball players (see thrower's shoulder)

 Volleyball players

 Baseball pitchers

 Swimmers

 Tennis players

 
 

 Risk factors

 
 Overhead sports, especially throwing sports

 Age 20-40 years for traumatic lesions

 Age over 40 for degenerative changes (type I)

 Glenohumeral internal rotation deficit (GIRD)

 Weak scapula control

 Previous shoulder instability

 

 
 Important perspective

 Many have SLAP lesions on MRI without symptoms. A study found that up to 55% of asymptomatic
 shoulders in people over 45 years had labrum changes. This means an MRI finding does not necessarily
 explain your pain.

Symptoms

 

 Symptoms of SLAP lesion can be vague and overlap with many other shoulder conditions:

 Common symptoms

 Diagnostic challenge

 SLAP lesions are notoriously difficult to diagnose clinically. Symptoms overlap with many conditions
 (impingement, rotator cuff problems, biceps tendinopathy), and no single test is sufficiently
 reliable. Shoulder pain can also be worsened by poor ergonomics.

How is SLAP Lesion: Everything You Need to Know diagnosed?

Diagnosis

 

 Diagnosing SLAP lesion is challenging and often requires a combination of clinical findings and
 imaging.

 Clinical tests

 Several tests have been described, but none have high enough accuracy alone:

 
 O'Brien's test (Active compression): Most used, but moderate sensitivity

 Biceps load test: Positive with external rotation against resistance

 Anterior slide test

 Crank test

 

 
 Limitations of tests

 A meta-analysis showed that even the best clinical tests have limited accuracy. Combination of
 several positive tests increases the probability, but the diagnosis can rarely be made clinically
 alone.

 

 Imaging

 
 MR arthrography (gold standard)

 MRI with contrast injected into the joint. Provides the best visualization of the labrum and can
 distinguish between different types of SLAP lesions. Sensitivity around 80-90%.

 

 
 Regular MRI

 Can detect SLAP lesions, but has lower sensitivity than MR arthrography. Useful for looking for
 concomitant pathology (rotator cuff, etc.).

 

 
 Important caveats

 
 Even MR arthrography has false-positive findings

 SLAP changes are common in asymptomatic individuals

 MRI findings must always be correlated with clinical findings

 Age over 40: Type I changes are often normal findings

Describe What does the research say? for SLAP Lesion: Everything You Need to Know.

What does the research say?

 

 Research on SLAP lesions has provided important corrections to previous treatment practices:

 
 The Norwegian SLAP Study (BMJ 2017)

 This study is a turning point in understanding SLAP treatment. Researchers compared SLAP repair with
 sham surgery (the patient was put under anesthesia and incisions were made, but no actual repair was
 performed).

 
 Result: No significant difference between repair and sham

 Conclusion: Arthroscopic SLAP repair is no better than placebo surgery for type
 II SLAP lesions

 Implication: Strengthens the argument for conservative treatment as first choice
 

 
 

 Other important findings

 
 
 78%
 return to sports conservatively
 

 
 63%
 return to same level after surgery
 

 
 25-30%
 complications/dissatisfaction after op
 

 

 
 What does this mean?

 
 Conservative treatment should be first choice for most SLAP lesions

 Surgery gives no better results than sham in many patients

 Rehabilitation and strength training are likely the key components

 Surgery may still have a role in selected cases (mechanical symptoms, significant instability)

Describe treatment options for SLAP Lesion: Everything You Need to Know.

Treatment

 

 Based on the latest research, conservative treatment should be first choice for the vast majority with
 SLAP lesion.

 Conservative treatment (first choice)

 
 Rehabilitation program

 
 Phase 1 (0-4 weeks): Pain relief, restore mobility, avoid provoking activities
 

 Phase 2 (4-8 weeks): Strengthening of rotator cuff and scapula stabilizers

 Phase 3 (8-12 weeks): Functional training, gradual return to activity

 Phase 4 (12+ weeks): Sport-specific training, gradual return to throwing

 
 

 
 Focus areas in rehabilitation

 
 Rotator cuff strength: Especially external rotators and scapula muscles

 Scapula control: Improve shoulder blade movement and stability

 Posterior capsule stretching: Treat any GIRD

 Kinetic chain training: Strengthen the entire chain from legs to arm

 Throwing mechanics: Optimize technique to reduce load

 
 

 Surgery - when?

 Surgery is only considered in selected cases:

 
 Possible indications for surgery

 
 Significant mechanical symptoms (locking, clicking affecting function)

 Type III/IV lesions with free fragment in the joint

 Concomitant shoulder instability requiring surgical treatment

 No improvement after 3-6 months of proper rehabilitation

 Elite athletes where marginal improvement may be decisive

 
 

 
 Surgical options

 
 SLAP repair: Labrum is sewn back to the socket. Traditional approach.

 Biceps tenodesis: Biceps tendon is moved and attached to the upper arm bone.
 Often preferred in older patients.

SLAP tests

 O'Brien's test, anterior slide, biceps load II to assess labral pathology.

 

 Imaging

 Imaging is rarely necessary to diagnose GIRD, but may be relevant for:

 
 Suspected structural damage (SLAP, rotator cuff tear)

 Acute injury or trauma

 6
 Treatment of Thrower's Shoulder

 

 Conservative treatment is very effective for thrower's shoulder, with over 90% success rate. The main
 goals are to restore normal movement and strength.

 
 Treatment principles

 
 Posterior capsule stretching: Sleeper stretch is the main intervention

 Posterior rotator cuff strengthening: Infraspinatus, teres minor

 Scapular stabilization: Shoulder blade control

 Gradual return to throwing: Structured throwing program

 
 

 Phase 1: Acute phase (0-2 weeks)

 
 Relative rest from throwing

 Daily posterior capsule stretching

 Soft tissue treatment of infraspinatus and teres minor

 Ice after activity as needed

 

 Phase 2: Rehabilitation phase (2-6 weeks)

 
 Continued stretching with focus on reaching normal values

 Progressive strength training for rotator cuff

 Scapula exercises (serratus anterior, lower trapezius)

 General shoulder and core training

 

 Phase 3: Return to throwing (6-12 weeks)

 
 Structured throwing program with gradual progression

 Start with short distances and low intensity

 Increase distance and power over several weeks

 Full maintenance program to prevent recurrence

 

 Main exercises

 
 Sleeper Stretch (main exercise for GIRD)

 
 Lie on the affected side with shoulder at 90 degrees flexion

 Elbow bent 90 degrees, forearm pointing up

 Use opposite hand to gently press forearm down toward floor

 Hold stretch for 30-60 seconds

 Repeat 3-4 times, 2-3 times daily

 
 Important: Avoid letting the shoulder roll backward. Keep shoulder blade stable
 against the surface.

Describe Rotator Cuff-Related Shoulder Pain (RCRSP) for Shoulder Pain - Complete Guide.

Rotator Cuff-Related Shoulder Pain (RCRSP)

 

 The most common cause - about 70-85% of all shoulder pain

 RCRSP (Rotator Cuff-Related Shoulder Pain) is the modern umbrella term that replaces the outdated "impingement syndrome." The rotator cuff consists of four small muscles that keep the upper arm bone stable in the socket.

 
 Why was the name changed?

 Research has shown that the old "pinching theory" - that tendons get pinched under the shoulder's roof - isn't accurate. Large surgical studies from 2018 (CSAW, FIMPACT) showed that surgery to remove bone spurs didn't give better results than placebo surgery.

 

 Under the RCRSP umbrella you'll find:

 
 Rotator cuff tendinopathy (tendon inflammation) - most common in supraspinatus

 Subacromial bursitis (bursa inflammation)

 Partial and complete tendon tears

 Calcific tendinitis (calcium deposits in tendon)

 

 
 Typical Symptoms

 
 Pain when lifting the arm, especially to the side or overhead

 "Painful arc" - pain between 60-120 degrees of lift

 Aching night pain that disturbs sleep

 Feeling of weakness in the arm

 
 

 
 Prognosis: 73-80% achieve good improvement with structured exercises and manual treatment. Surgery is rarely necessary.
You are a clinical documentation assistant for chiropractors. Generate professional medical documentation.
Describe Frozen Shoulder (Adhesive Capsulitis) for Shoulder Pain - Complete Guide.

Frozen Shoulder (Adhesive Capsulitis)

 

 Frozen shoulder is a condition where the joint capsule around the shoulder becomes thick, inflamed and tight. This leads to gradually increasing stiffness and pain. The condition goes through three characteristic phases:

 
 Freezing Phase (2-9 months)

 Gradually increasing pain and stiffness. Night pain can be intense.

 

 
 Frozen Phase (4-12 months)

 Pain decreases somewhat, but stiffness is at its worst. Daily activities become difficult.

 

 
 Thawing Phase (6-24 months)

 Movement gradually returns. Full recovery can take 1-3 years.

 

 
 Who gets frozen shoulder?

 Diabetes significantly increases the risk - diabetics have 5 times higher probability of developing frozen shoulder. Other risk factors are thyroid disorders and prolonged inactivity after injury or surgery.

 

 
 Prognosis: Although it takes time, 80% of patients regain good shoulder function with proper follow-up. Early treatment can reduce severity and duration.

Describe Referred Pain from Neck and Thoracic Spine for Shoulder Pain - Complete Guide.

Referred Pain from Neck and Thoracic Spine

 

 Many shoulder problems are related to stiffness or dysfunction in the neck and thoracic spine. The nerves that supply the shoulder come from the neck (C4-C6), and irritation here can cause pain that feels like it comes from the shoulder itself.

 
 Holistic Approach

 That's why I always examine the neck and thoracic spine when you come with shoulder problems - not just the shoulder in isolation. Often, treating stiffness in the thoracic spine and neck gives rapid improvement in shoulder pain.

Describe What Can You Do Yourself? for Shoulder Pain - Complete Guide.

What Can You Do Yourself?

 

 While waiting for an appointment, or if problems are mild:

 
 Keep Moving

 Complete rest is rarely the most suitable solution. Move your shoulder gently within what's comfortable. Avoid activities that cause severe worsening, but don't be afraid to use your arm.

 

 Simple Exercises You Can Start With

 
 Pendulum Exercise

 Lean forward with your healthy arm supported on a table. Let the painful arm hang down. Make small circles with the arm - 10 each direction, 3-4 times daily.

 

 
 Shoulder Blade Squeezes

 Sit or stand straight. Pull your shoulder blades back and down toward each other. Hold 5 seconds, release. 10 repetitions, 3 times daily.

 

 
 Important

 Stop if exercises cause severe worsening. Some discomfort is normal, but pain that doesn't subside is a sign that you should seek help.

Describe Types of Sports Injuries for Sports Injuries - Complete Guide.

Types of Sports Injuries

 

 Acute vs. Overuse Injuries

 Sports injuries fall into two main categories, each requiring different treatment approaches:

 
 Acute Injuries

 Result from a single traumatic event - a fall, collision, or sudden movement. Examples include ankle sprains, muscle tears, and ligament ruptures. These typically cause immediate pain and swelling.

 

 
 Overuse Injuries

 Develop gradually from repetitive stress over time. Examples include tendinopathies (Achilles, patellar), stress fractures, and shin splints. Pain often starts mild and worsens if training continues unchanged.

 

 Common Sports Injuries

 
 Muscle strains: Tears in muscle fibers, often in hamstrings, quads, or calves

 Ligament sprains: Stretching or tearing of ligaments, commonly ankle or knee

 Tendinopathies: Degeneration of tendons from repetitive loading

 Stress fractures: Small cracks in bone from cumulative overload

 Joint injuries: Cartilage damage, labral tears, meniscus injuries
You are a clinical documentation assistant for chiropractors. Generate professional medical documentation.
What causes Sports Injuries - Complete Guide?

Causes and Risk Factors

 

 
 Training Errors (Most Common)

 Rapid increases in training volume, intensity, or frequency are responsible for most overuse injuries. The "10% rule" - increasing weekly load by no more than 10% - helps prevent this.

 

 
 Biomechanical Factors

 Poor movement patterns, muscle imbalances, weakness, and lack of flexibility can increase injury risk. These are often correctable with targeted exercise.

 

 
 Equipment and Environment

 Worn-out footwear, inappropriate equipment, poor playing surfaces, and inadequate protective gear all contribute to injury risk.

 

 
 Previous Injury

 A history of previous injury is one of the strongest predictors of future injury. Incomplete rehabilitation and premature return to sport significantly increase re-injury risk.

What is the prognosis for Sports Injuries - Complete Guide?

Recovery Timeline

 

 Recovery time varies significantly based on injury type and severity:

 
 Muscle Strains

 Grade 1 (mild): 1-2 weeks. Grade 2 (moderate): 3-6 weeks. Grade 3 (severe/complete): 3-6 months. Proper rehabilitation reduces re-injury risk.

 

 
 Ligament Sprains

 Grade 1: 1-2 weeks. Grade 2: 4-8 weeks. Grade 3: 8-12 weeks or longer. Some severe sprains may require surgical consultation.

 

 
 Tendinopathies

 Often require 3-6 months of consistent loading exercises. Quick fixes are rare - patience and progressive loading are key.

 

 
 Key Principle: The goal isn't just pain relief - it's returning to sport with reduced re-injury risk. Rushing back before full rehabilitation is complete significantly increases the chance of re-injury.

Describe Injury Prevention for Sports Injuries - Complete Guide.

Injury Prevention

 

 
 Progressive Training

 Follow the 10% rule for weekly increases. Allow adequate recovery between hard sessions. Include rest days and easier weeks in your program.

 

 
 Strength and Conditioning

 Regular strength training protects against injury. Focus on sport-specific movements and addressing muscle imbalances. 2-3 sessions per week is effective.

 

 
 Proper Warm-Up

 Dynamic warm-up before activity prepares muscles and joints. Include sport-specific movements. Save static stretching for after activity.

 

 
 Equipment and Technique

 
 Replace running shoes every 500-800 km

 Use sport-appropriate protective equipment

 Get coaching to improve technique

 Ensure equipment is properly fitted

Describe Frequently Asked Questions for Sports Injuries - Complete Guide.

Frequently Asked Questions

 

 
 How soon after injury should I seek treatment?

 For acute injuries, assessment within the first few days is ideal. Early intervention can speed recovery and prevent complications. For overuse injuries, seek help when pain affects your training or doesn't improve with modified activity.

 

 
 Can I continue training with a sports injury?

 Often yes, with modifications. Many injuries allow continued training at reduced intensity or with alternative activities. Complete rest is rarely necessary and can actually delay recovery. A chiropractor can guide appropriate modifications.

 

 
 Should I use ice or heat on my injury?

 For acute injuries (first 48-72 hours), ice can help manage pain and swelling. After the acute phase, heat may help with muscle relaxation. However, active movement and appropriate loading are more important than either.

 

 
 Do I need imaging for my sports injury?

 Not always. A thorough clinical examination often provides sufficient information to start treatment. Imaging may be recommended if there's suspected fracture, complete ligament tear, or if symptoms don't improve as expected.

 

 
 How do I know when I'm ready to return to sport?

 Return to sport should be based on function, not time. You should have full pain-free range of motion, adequate strength (usually 90%+ of uninjured side), and be able to perform sport-specific movements without symptoms.

 

 
 How can I prevent re-injury?

 Complete your rehab...

What causes Pain Between Shoulder Blades?

Causes and Risk Factors

 

 The causes of pain between the shoulder blades can be divided from most common to rarest:

 Muscular causes (most common)

 
 Myofascial pain with trigger points

 Myofascial pain with trigger points in the musculature is by far the most common cause of acute pain
 between the shoulder blades. A study in Pain Medicine (2016) found that 93% of patients with chronic
 neck pain had trigger points in the trapezius.

 The muscles between the shoulder blades - especially the rhomboids and middle trapezius - often become
 overloaded from prolonged sitting with forward-leaning posture.

 

 Referred pain from the neck

 
 Cervicogenic pain

 French orthopedist Robert Maigne described how up to 70% of "common" pain between the shoulder blades
 actually originates from the lower neck (C5-C7). The facet joints in the neck can refer pain to the area
 along the medial border of the shoulder blade.

 This explains why many experience improvement in shoulder blade pain when the neck is treated.
 

 

 Thoracic facet joints

 
 Facet joint problems

 Facet joints in the chest contribute to 34-48% of chronic chest pain according to studies with
 diagnostic blocks (Manchikanti, Pain Physician, 2004; 2020). These small joints between the vertebrae
 can become irritated or worn, especially with repetitive movements or prolonged poor posture. In more
 severe cases, it may involve thoracic disc herniation.

 Dreyfuss and colleagues (Spine, 1994) mapped how these joint...

 With muscular causes

How is Pain Between Shoulder Blades diagnosed?

Diagnosis

 

 A thorough clinical examination is far more important than imaging for most people with pain between the
 shoulder blades.

 
 Chiropractic examination

 The chiropractor conducts a systematic examination that includes detailed history, assessment of range
 of motion in the neck and chest, specific tests for facet joints and musculature, and neurological
 screening. Palpation (examination with hands) often reveals tender points, tight muscles or joints with
 reduced mobility.

 

 
 Imaging is rarely necessary

 MRI and X-ray often show age-related changes - such as disc degeneration or facet joint arthritis - in
 people without pain. A study found that 89% of people between 60 and 69 years have facet joint arthritis
 on MRI without having symptoms (Wood and colleagues).

 The images can therefore be misleading. Clinical examination often provides more relevant
 information than what the images can tell.

 Imaging is indicated when there is suspicion of serious pathology, after trauma, or with neurological
 deficits that do not improve.

Describe treatment options for Pain Between Shoulder Blades.

Treatment

 

 What can the chiropractor do?

 Chiropractic treatment of pain between the shoulder blades is usually comprehensive and tailored to the
 individual's situation.

 
 Manipulation and mobilization

 A systematic review and meta-analysis by Masaracchio and colleagues (PLOS ONE, 2019) found that
 thoracic manipulation provided significantly better pain relief than standard treatment in the short
 term, with an average improvement of 13 points on a 100-point scale. Compared to placebo, the effect was
 less clear. The evidence level is rated as moderate.

 

 
 Soft tissue treatment

 Techniques such as trigger point treatment, dry needling and instrument-assisted soft tissue treatment
 (like Graston) are used to loosen tight muscles and reduce trigger points in the area.

 

 
 Combination treatment gives good results: Hidalgo and colleagues found moderate to
 strong evidence that the combination of manual treatment and exercise gives better results than each
 intervention alone.

 

 
 Important: Early treatment

 Early treatment is associated with better outcomes. Pain that has lasted more than three months before
 starting treatment gives significantly worse prognosis (Knecht, 2020).

 

 What can you do yourself?

 
 Regular movement: Avoid prolonged sitting which can lead to stiff back. Get up and move at least every 20-30 minutes. Cornell
 University research shows that seated work increases the load on back muscles by 90% compared to
 standing.

Red Flags - When to See a Doctor

 

 
 Seek medical help immediately for the following symptoms:

 Previous cancer history

 Pain that worsens with eating - may indicate gallbladder or pancreatic problems

What is the prognosis for Pain Between Shoulder Blades?

Prognosis

 

 The outlook for most people with pain between the shoulder blades is good. Knecht and colleagues (BMC
 Musculoskeletal Disorders, 2020) followed 90 patients with chest pain for one year and found that 80% had
 a favorable course with rapid improvement within the first month.

 
 Recurrence is common

 At the same time, research shows that recurrence is common. Studies on back pain in general show that
 24-80% experience at least one recurrence within 12 months (da Silva, Journal of Physiotherapy, 2019).
 Previous episodes increase the risk of new ones - if you have had more than two episodes, the chance of
 recurrence triples.

 

 
 The single most important factor for prognosis is how long you have had the symptoms.
 Pain that has lasted more than three months at the start of treatment gives significantly worse outlook.
 This underscores the value of early intervention.

 Prolonged forward-leaning posture overloads the muscles between the shoulder blades and is a common

 and flat back.

Give a brief summary of Pain Between Shoulder Blades.

Brief Summary

 
 What it is: Pain in the area between the shoulder blades, often related to muscle
 or joint problems in the chest or neck.

 Most common causes: Muscle tension and trigger points (most common), referred pain
 from the neck, thoracic facet joints, posture-related problems.

 Chiropractic treatment: Moderate evidence for short-term effect of manipulation
 combined with exercise.

 Red flags: Sudden tearing pain, chest pain, breathing difficulties, arm numbness -
 require medical evaluation.

 Consultation: 45 min first visit, 30 min follow-up.

Describe Myofascial pain with trigger points in the context of Pain Between Shoulder Blades.

Myofascial pain with trigger points

 Myofascial pain with trigger points in the musculature is by far the most common cause of acute pain
 between the shoulder blades. A study in Pain Medicine (2016) found that 93% of patients with chronic
 neck pain had trigger points in the trapezius.

 The muscles between the shoulder blades - especially the rhomboids and middle trapezius - often become
 overloaded from prolonged sitting with forward-leaning posture.

 

 Referred pain from the neck

 
 Cervicogenic pain

 French orthopedist Robert Maigne described how up to 70% of "common" pain between the shoulder blades
 actually originates from the lower neck (C5-C7). The facet joints in the neck can refer pain to the area
 along the medial border of the shoulder blade.

 This explains why many experience improvement in shoulder blade pain when the neck is treated.
 

 

 Thoracic facet joints

 
 Facet joint problems

 Facet joints in the chest contribute to 34-48% of chronic chest pain according to studies with
 diagnostic blocks (Manchikanti, Pain Physician, 2004; 2020). These small joints between the vertebrae
 can become irritated or worn, especially with repetitive movements or prolonged poor posture. In more
 severe cases, it may involve thoracic disc herniation.

 Dreyfuss and colleagues (Spine, 1994) mapped how these joints typically produce pain one segment down
 and slightly to the side.

 

 Posture-related problems

 
 Upper crossed syndrome

 Vladimir Janda described in the 1980s what he called "upper crossed syndrome": an imbalance where
 anterior muscles (chest, neck) become tight while posterior muscles (rhomboids, middle trapezius) become
 weak and stretched. This pattern can be reinforced by rounded back
 (hyperkyphosis) or conversely by flat back (hypokyphosis).

 This pattern is often seen in office workers and creates increased stress in the area between the
 shoulder blades.

 

 Dorsal scapular nerve

 
 An often overlooked cause

 Sultan and colleagues (Archives of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation, 2013) found that 52-62% of
 patients with unilateral pain between the shoulder blades had signs of involvement of this nerve. The
 nerve can become trapped where it passes through the musculature in the neck.

 

 Visceral referred pain (less common)

 
 Internal organs can refer pain

 Internal organs can refer pain to the area between the shoulder blades. Gallbladder problems typically
 produce pain to the right shoulder blade, while the pancreas can produce pain to the left. Heart attack
 - especially in women - can present with pain between the shoulder blades rather than classic chest
 pain. For chest pain in front, see also costochondritis.

 

 Serious pathology (rare)

 About 1% of chest pain is due to serious underlying disease. The chest, however, has a higher probability
 of serious pathology than the neck or lower back, making good screening important. In elderly patients, osteoporosis and compression fractures should always be considered, as well
 as Scheuermann's disease in younger people.

 Bra strap syndrome primarily affects women with larger breasts who wear bras daily over extended periods.
 The condition is especially common in women with D-cup or larger.

You are a clinical documentation assistant for chiropractors. Generate professional medical documentation.
What causes Bra Strap Syndrome and Shoulder Pain?

Causes and Risk Factors

 

 From most common to least common:

 
 Wrong Bra Size (most common)

 A full 80% of women wear the wrong size - 70% too small, 10% too large (Greenbaum et al., 2003). When
 the band is too large, more weight ends up on the straps.

 

 
 Large Breasts (D-cup or larger)

 Studies show a significant correlation between cup size and shoulder/neck pain (p<0.05). Women with the
 largest breasts have up to 12 times higher odds of back pain.

 

 
 Narrow Bra Straps

 Research from University of Wollongong (2015) shows that wide straps (4.5 cm) reduce peak pressure by
 approximately 35% compared to standard 2.5 cm straps.

 

 Other Factors

 
 Long daily wear time: Most women wear bras 12-14 hours daily. Pressure of just 9 kPa
 over 2 hours can cause skin and muscle damage.

 Poor posture: Rounded shoulders increase the load on the straps and can increase
 compression.

 Racerback bras: Bring straps closer to the neck and can increase pressure on
 sensitive areas.
