What can the chiropractor do?

 

 We must be honest about the evidence base: There are currently no randomized controlled
 trials on chiropractic treatment specifically for Scheuermann's disease. The available
 research consists of case reports.

 That does not mean treatment is without value. Based on clinical experience and general back
 research, chiropractic treatment can contribute to:

 
 Chiropractic Treatment Can Contribute To

 
 Improved mobility in stiff thoracic segments

 Reduction of muscle tension and trigger points

 Improved rib movement and breathing mechanics

 Pain relief through joint mobilization

 Guidance on exercises and ergonomics

 Functional improvement even if structure remains

 
 

 
 Important Expectation Management

 Chiropractic treatment can NOT "straighten out" a structural kyphosis in adults. The goal
 is symptom relief and better function, not structural change.

 

 Treatment Course

 For adults with symptomatic Scheuermann's disease, a typical course will involve a trial
 period of 6-8 treatments over 4-6 weeks to assess response. Most who respond to treatment
 experience improvement in pain and function within this period. With good response,
 maintenance treatment with 4-8 week intervals may be useful for some.

 Response varies significantly from person to person. Some have good and lasting effect,
 others experience only short-term relief, and some do not respond noticeably. An honest
 evaluation after the trial period is importan...

 mobilization of thoracic spine

Describe Surgery - when is it relevant? for Scheuermann's Disease.

Surgery - when is it relevant?

 

 Surgery is reserved for the most severe cases. Indications include:

 
 Surgical Indications

 
 Kyphosis over 75 degrees that progresses

 Curves 60-75 degrees with significant pain not responding to 6+ months conservative
 treatment

 Neurological symptoms (rare)

 Severely reduced lung function

 
 

 A study by Tsirikos and Carter (Bone Joint J, 2021) followed 88 patients and showed average
 correction from 94.5 degrees to 47.5 degrees with significant improvement in quality of
 life. Complication rate was 12.5%, and 12-21% need revision long-term.

What is the prognosis for Scheuermann's Disease?

Prognosis

 

 The most important long-term study is Murray et al. (J Bone Joint Surg Am, 1993) which
 followed 67 patients for 32 years. Main findings were:

 
 Main Findings from Long-Term Study (32 years)

 
 Persons with untreated Scheuermann's experienced slightly more back pain than
 control group

 No difference in education level, sick leave, or ability to perform daily activities
 

 Restrictive lung disease occurred only with curves over 100 degrees

 
 

 Progression after Skeletal Maturity

 Curves continue to increase slowly also in adulthood - approx. 0.45 degrees per year
 according to Garrido et al. (Spine Deform, 2021). This means an 18-year-old with 60 degrees
 kyphosis can have around 75 degrees at age 50 if the curve is not stabilized. In older age,
 osteoporosis can further alleviate the kyphosis.

 Generally good prognosis with minimal complaints

 Can develop chronic pain; often responds well to conservative treatment
 
 
 Over 75 degrees
 Reduced exercise capacity; surgical assessment may be relevant
 
 
 Over 100 degrees
 Risk of restrictive lung disease; requires specialist follow-up

Patient asks: "How do I know if my thoracic spine is stiff?"

Sit on a chair with your arms crossed over your chest. Rotate your upper body as far as you can to each side without moving your hips. Normal thoracic rotation is around 40-45 degrees to each side. If you notice a clear limitation, especially to one side, it may indicate stiffness.

Patient asks: "Can a stiff thoracic spine be the cause of my shoulder pain?"

Yes, this is a common connection. When the thoracic spine doesn't contribute sufficiently to movement, the shoulder must compensate. Research shows that thoracic mobilization often provides immediate improvement in shoulder mobility.

Patient asks: "How long does it take before I notice improvement?"
Most people notice some improvement after 2-4 weeks of regular training and/or treatment. Significant improvement in sports performance typically takes 6-8 weeks, based on available research.

Patient asks: "Can I continue playing golf/tennis while being treated?"
Yes, in most cases. The goal is to improve function while maintaining your activity level. I may adjust training intensity for a period and focus on exercises that support treatment.

Rarely. Imaging is usually unnecessary for functional stiffness without red flags. Clinical examination provides sufficient information to start treatment.

Thoracic spine stiffness is often a chronic problem that requires maintenance. Lifestyle factors such as prolonged sitting, one-sided training, and poor posture contribute to the problem recurring. A good home exercise program is the key to long-term success.

Key Statistics About Thoracic Spine and Sports

 

 The thoracic spine contributes most of the rotation in the upper body. When this becomes stiff, other
 structures must compensate - often with negative consequences.

 
 
 15-55%
 Golfers with lower back pain

Describe The Golfer: When the Lower Back Takes the Hit for How a Stiff Back Ruins Your Golf Swing and Tennis Serve.

The Golfer: When the Lower Back Takes the Hit

 

 The power of the golf swing comes from what researchers call the "kinetic chain" - a coordinated transfer
 of energy from the ground, through the legs, hips, and trunk, and out to the arms and club. A study by
 Nesbit and Serrano from 2005 showed that the back and hip joints together account for 68-72% of
 the total work in a golf swing.

 Modern golf technique is built on what is called the "X-factor" - the angle between shoulders and pelvis
 at the top of the backswing. Skilled golfers create around 30-60 degrees of separation between upper and
 lower body, depending on measurement method (Cole and Grimshaw, 2016). This "coils" the muscles and stores
 elastic energy that is released in the downswing.

 
 But what happens when the thoracic spine is stiff?

 Then the lumbar spine must compensate with more rotation than it is designed for. And the lumbar spine
 has only 1-2 degrees of rotational capacity per vertebra - compared to the thoracic vertebrae's 4-9
 degrees.

 

 The result is predictable: Lower back pain is the most common injury among golfers.
 Epidemiological studies show that 15-34% of amateurs and 22-24% of professionals experience golf-related
 back injury (McHardy et al., 2007). Combined, lower back problems account for 18-54% of all golf-related
 complaints.

 
 3x Higher Lifetime Risk

 Professional golfers have three times higher lifetime risk of lower back injury compared to amateurs
 (Kay et al., 2024).

Describe The Tennis Player: The Serve That Reveals the Stiffness for How a Stiff Back Ruins Your Golf Swing and Tennis Serve.

The Tennis Player: The Serve That Reveals the Stiffness

 

 The tennis serve is one of the most demanding movements in sports. Kibler and colleagues established as
 early as 1995 that legs, hips, and trunk together contribute approximately 51% of kinetic energy
 and 54% of total force in a serve. The rest comes from shoulder, arm, and wrist.

 A stiff thoracic spine limits how much energy can be generated and transferred through this chain. The
 shoulder must then compensate with higher velocity to achieve the same result - and this increases load
 and injury risk.

 
 The Good News from Research

 A study published in Frontiers in Sports and Active Living (Le Solliec et al., 2023) followed 22
 competitive tennis players through an 8-week program of stretching, strength, and mobilization
 exercises:

 
 The percentage of successful serves increased from 41% to 55%

 Serve velocity and accuracy improved significantly (effect size 0.54-0.65)

 Shoulder mobility increased markedly, especially external rotation (effect size 1.49)

 
 The program focused on thoracic and shoulder mobility combined with strength exercises - four
 sessions per week for eight weeks. And this was without any form of manual treatment.

Describe The Runner: When Breathing Becomes Limited for How a Stiff Back Ruins Your Golf Swing and Tennis Serve.

The Runner: When Breathing Becomes Limited

 

 Hyperkyphosis - excessive curvature of the thoracic spine - affects not only movement but also breathing
 capacity. Learn more about the connection between breathing, stress,
 and back. The Framingham Study, which followed participants over 16 years, found that women with
 pronounced kyphosis had measurably greater decline in lung function over time compared to those with
 normal posture (Lorbergs et al., 2017).

 For athletes with severe hyperkyphosis (over 75 degrees) - as seen in Scheuermann's disease - a study by Barrios et al. (2019) showed
 that VO2max - a measure of maximum oxygen uptake - was significantly lower than in the
 control group. This can directly affect endurance and performance.

 
 Posture Affects Breathing Function

 A recent study from 2025 (Chiba et al., Cureus) tested the effect of simulated kyphotic posture during
 running. Even in healthy young men, respiratory load increased measurably - higher carbon dioxide
 production and respiratory quotient - even though oxygen consumption was the same.

Describe Why Compensation Leads to Injury for How a Stiff Back Ruins Your Golf Swing and Tennis Serve.

Why Compensation Leads to Injury

 

 The body is remarkably good at finding detours when the main road is blocked. The problem is that these
 detours often have lower capacity and higher "tolls." With prolonged thoracic pain, the musculature between the shoulder blades can become overloaded.

 A study by Wasser and colleagues (2018) analyzed 187 baseball pitchers and found that college pitchers on
 average had -25 degrees of lumbar extension (backward bend in the lower back) at maximum arm rotation.
 Most pitchers spent 45% of the pitch with more than 30 degrees of lumbar extension.

 
 
 27.6%
 Baseball pitchers with pars defects
 

 
 3-7%
 Prevalence in general population
 

 

 Specifically among baseball pitchers, Wasser et al. (2018) found a spondylolysis (stress fracture in the pars) prevalence of approximately 27%. In the general athletic population, the prevalence is estimated at 8-15%.
 

 
 The Mechanism Summarized

 Kim et al. (2016) summarized the mechanism clearly: "Excessive movements in the lumbar spine
 are due to limited movements in the thoracic vertebrae." When the thoracic spine doesn't
 rotate sufficiently, the lower back must take over - and it isn't built for the job.

What Can Be Done?

 

 What Can the Chiropractor Do?

 Treatment of stiff thoracic spine focuses on restoring normal mobility through a combination of manual
 techniques and exercises. A systematic review in BMJ Open Sport & Exercise Medicine (Spencer et al., 2020)
 identified 38 different thoracic exercises used in sports settings, but noted that randomized controlled
 studies specifically for athletes are lacking.

 The available research shows moderate effect of mobilization and manipulation for
 improving thoracic rotation and flexibility. For rib problems,
 treatment may also include the costovertebral joints. One study found that thoracic rotation increased
 from 50 to 55 degrees after treatment - while lumbar rotation was reduced, suggesting better distribution
 of load.

 
 In Clinical Practice I Often Combine:

 
 Joint mobilization and manipulation of stiff segments in the thoracic spine

 Soft tissue treatment of shortened muscles (chest muscles, upper trapezius)

 Specific exercises to maintain and improve mobility

 Review of technique and posture in daily life

 
 

 What Can You Do Yourself?

 Based on the Le Solliec study and other research, the following exercises can help:

 
 
 Thoracic Extension Over Foam Roller

 Lie with the roller across your upper back and gently extend backward. Hold for 30 seconds, repeat at
 three different heights.

 

 
 Thread the Needle

 Start on all fours, thread one arm under your body and rotate your upper body. Hold for 5 ...

What is the prognosis for How a Stiff Back Ruins Your Golf Swing and Tennis Serve?

Prognosis

 

 Most people who address thoracic stiffness early experience good improvement. The Le Solliec study showed
 measurable improvements after just 8 weeks of dedicated training.

 At the same time, it's important to be realistic: Stiffness in the thoracic spine is often something that
 develops over years, and maintenance requires continuous effort. Research shows that the effect gradually
 diminishes if exercises are not maintained.

 For athletes, early intervention is particularly important. Younger athletes generally respond better to
 treatment than older ones, according to meta-analyses that have examined age-stratified results.

Describe Frequently Asked Questions for How a Stiff Back Ruins Your Golf Swing and Tennis Serve.

Frequently Asked Questions

 

 
 How do I know if my thoracic spine is stiff?

 A simple test: Sit on a chair with your arms crossed over your chest. Rotate your
 upper body as far as you can to each side without moving your hips. Normal thoracic rotation is around
 40-45 degrees to each side. If you notice a clear limitation, especially to one side, it may indicate
 stiffness.

 

 
 Can a stiff thoracic spine be the cause of my shoulder pain?

 Yes, this is a common connection. When the thoracic spine doesn't contribute
 sufficiently to movement, the shoulder must compensate. Research shows that thoracic mobilization often
 provides immediate improvement in shoulder mobility.

 

 
 How long does it take before I notice improvement?

 Most people notice some improvement after 2-4 weeks of regular training and/or
 treatment. Significant improvement in sports performance typically takes 6-8 weeks, based on available
 research.

 

 
 Do I need X-rays or MRI?

 Rarely. Imaging is usually unnecessary for functional stiffness without red flags.
 Clinical examination provides sufficient information to start treatment. Imaging is considered if
 symptoms don't respond as expected or if structural changes are suspected.

 

 
 Can I continue playing golf/tennis while being treated?

 Yes, in most cases. The goal is to improve function while maintaining your
 activity level. I may adjust training intensity for a period and focus on exercises that support
 treatment.

What causes T4 Syndrome: When Upper Thoracic Spine Causes Hand Symptoms?

Causes and Risk Factors

 

 Since T4 syndrome is poorly defined in research, we don't have reliable data on causation. The leading
 theory involves the sympathetic nervous system:

 Sympathetic Nerve Theory (Theoretical)

 Sympathetic nerve fibers supplying the upper extremities originate from spinal cord levels T2-T5. The
 sympathetic ganglia are located directly in front of the costovertebral joints. The theory is that
 stiffness or dysfunction in these joints can irritate sympathetic structures and cause referred symptoms
 to the hands (Evans, 1997; Maitland, 1986).

 Risk Factors Based on Case Reports

 From available case descriptions, we see some patterns:

 
 Prolonged sitting and office work

 Forward head posture ("computer neck"), which can also contribute to kyphosis

 Women are affected more often than men - case reports suggest a ratio of 3:1 to 4:1
 (DeFranca & Levine, 1995)

 The 30-50 age group is most represented in the literature

 

 It must be emphasized that these figures come from individual case reports with very few patients,
 not from epidemiological studies.

Describe symptoms and signs of T4 Syndrome: When Upper Thoracic Spine Causes Hand Symptoms.

Symptoms

 

 The most characteristic feature of T4 syndrome is the bilateral, "glove-like"
 distribution of symptoms. Unlike carpal tunnel syndrome or nerve root compression from the
 neck, the symptoms do not follow a specific dermatomal pattern.

 
 
 Typical Symptoms

 
 Tingling or numbness in both hands - entire hand and fingers, like a "glove"

 Feeling of swelling or heaviness in the hands (often without visible swelling)

 Altered temperature sensation - hands may feel cold or warm without objective change

 Stiffness and discomfort in the upper thoracic spine (see also pain between shoulder blades)

 Headache, often originating from the back of the head

 Neck pain

 
 

 
 Time Pattern

 
 Symptoms are often worse in the evening or early morning

 Prolonged sitting often worsens symptoms

 Forward leaning posture worsens symptoms

 
 

 

 
 Important

 With T4 syndrome, neurological examination is normal - there is no weakness, reflexes are normal, and
 there are no dermatomal deficits. If you have clear neurological findings, other diagnoses must be ruled
 out.
You are a clinical documentation assistant for chiropractors. Generate professional medical documentation.
How is T4 Syndrome: When Upper Thoracic Spine Causes Hand Symptoms diagnosed?

Diagnosis

 

 T4 syndrome is a diagnosis of exclusion. There are no validated diagnostic criteria or
 specific tests that can confirm the diagnosis (Karas & Pannone, 2017; NHS Scotland, 2019). The
 diagnosis is made by:

 
 Ruling out other conditions - especially neurological and vascular causes

 Recognizing the symptom pattern - bilateral, non-dermatomal distribution

 Reproducing the symptoms - through palpation and mobilization of the upper thoracic
 spine

 

 Imaging

 MRI and X-ray are usually normal with T4 syndrome. Images may show age-related changes such as wear or
 degeneration, but these rarely explain the symptoms. Imaging is primarily used to rule out other
 conditions - not to confirm T4 syndrome (DeFranca & Levine, 1995).

 Differential Diagnoses to Consider

 
 
 
 
 Condition
 Key Differences from T4 Syndrome
 
 
 
 
 Carpal Tunnel Syndrome
 Median nerve area (thumb to middle finger), positive Tinel/Phalen, pathological nerve conduction
 
 
 
 Cervical Radiculopathy
 Dermatomal pattern, unilateral, neurological deficits, positive Spurling
 
 
 Thoracic Disc Herniation / Thoracic Outlet
 Syndrome
 Usually unilateral, ulnar distribution, vascular signs
 
 
 Peripheral Polyneuropathy
 "Stocking-glove" pattern, begins in feet, systemic associations
 
 
 Multiple Sclerosis
 Other neurological symptoms, MRI findings, variable course

Treatment

 

 What Can the Chiropractor Do?

 Treatment of T4 syndrome focuses on restoring mobility in the upper thoracic spine. It's important to be
 clear that all treatment evidence comes from case reports (evidence level 5) - there are no randomized
 controlled trials on patients with T4 syndrome (Karas & Pannone, 2017).

 
 Techniques Described in Literature

 
 1

 
 Joint Mobilization of Upper Thoracic Spine (T2-T7)

 Gentle mobilization to restore normal mobility

 

 

 
 2

 
 Manipulation Treatment

 High velocity, low amplitude - several case reports report immediate symptom relief

 

 

 
 3

 
 Soft Tissue Treatment

 Treatment of surrounding musculature

 

 

 
 4

 
 Neurodynamic Mobilization

 Techniques to improve nerve gliding

 

 

 

 
 Expectations

 Case reports often describe rapid and significant improvement after few treatments. In clinical
 practice, we see that many patients experience noticeable improvement after the first treatment. NHS
 Scotland recommends that the patient should show progression within up to 3 treatments - if not, the
 diagnosis should be reconsidered (NHS Scotland, 2019).

 Self-treatment and prevention focus on posture and mobility. Also read about breathing, stress and back for more tips:

 Lie back over a foam roller or towel in the upper back, 1-2 minutes daily

 

 
 Posture Correction

What is the prognosis for T4 Syndrome: When Upper Thoracic Spine Causes Hand Symptoms?

Prognosis

 

 There are no published data on long-term prognosis or recurrence rates for T4 syndrome. What is known is
 based on case reports and clinical experience:

 
 What We Know

 
 Short-term Prognosis

 Case reports often describe rapid symptom relief after manual treatment - some patients experience
 immediate improvement, others gradual improvement over weeks. Hirai & Thomson (2016) reported
 complete symptom resolution after manipulation treatment.

 

 
 Recurrence Risk

 NHS Scotland suggests that the clinical course probably resembles back and neck complaints in general
 - meaning recurrence is common, and symptoms may have an episodic pattern. Continued attention to
 posture and ergonomics is probably important for preventing recurrence.

 

 
 Realistic Expectations

 Most patients who actually have T4 syndrome respond well to treatment. But it's important to remember
 that the diagnosis is uncertain - if treatment doesn't produce results, it may be because the symptoms
 have another cause.

 Acute pain with movement or deep breathing? Rib dislocation occurs when a rib becomes locked in the

 Diagnosis
 Scheuermann's Disease

 Developmental disorder causing increased kyphosis (rounded back) in adolescents. Affects 4-8% of the
 population. Early detection is important for best outcome.

 Diagnosis
 Flat Back (Hypokyphosis)

 Too little curve in the thoracic spine can surprisingly cause more issues than rounded back.
 Especially affects people with rigid posture and can cause compensatory problems.

 Diagnosis
 Costochondritis

 Inflammation of the cartilage between ribs and breastbone. Often gives frightening chest pain that
 can be mistaken for heart disease. Common and benign condition.

 Read more
 

 
 Diagnosis
 Kyphosis (Rounded Back)

 Increased curvature in the thoracic spine - from functional postural failure to structural changes.
 Important to distinguish between types for correct treatment.

Describe Frequently Asked Questions for Thoracic Back Pain.

Frequently Asked Questions

 

 
 What are the most common causes of thoracic back pain?

 The most common causes are muscular tension (especially between shoulder blades), joint dysfunction in the thoracic
 vertebrae, rib dislocation, costochondritis, and posture-related problems like rounded back. In rare cases, it can differ more serious conditions like thoracic disc herniation that require investigation.

 

 
 Can thoracic back pain come from the heart?

 Yes, chest pain can in some cases be heart-related, especially in women where
 symptoms are often atypical. With sudden pain combined with breathing difficulties, nausea, radiation to
 arm or cold sweats you should seek emergency help.

 

 
 Can a chiropractor help with thoracic back pain?

 Yes, chiropractic treatment has moderate to good evidence for thoracic conditions.
 Manual treatment combined with targeted exercises often gives good results. Most people experience
 improvement within 4-6 weeks.

 

 
 When should I see a doctor for thoracic back pain?

 Seek medical attention for: sudden intense pain, pain radiating to the chest or
 arm, breathing difficulties, fever, unexplained weight loss, night pain that wakes you, or pain after
 trauma. Also for symptoms like numbness or weakness in the legs.

Patient asks: "How common is thoracic disc herniation?"
Very rare. Only 0.25-0.75% of all symptomatic disc herniations occur in the thoracic spine. In comparison, the lumbar spine accounts for about 90% and the cervical spine for about 8%.

Patient asks: "Can a chiropractor treat thoracic disc herniation?"

The chiropractor's main role is to identify the condition and assess severity. For confirmed herniation without neurological deficits, gentle treatment of surrounding structures may be considered. With myelopathic signs, the patient is referred onward.

Patient asks: "Do I need surgery for thoracic disc herniation?"
Most people don't need surgery. About 73-80% recover with conservative treatment. Surgery is indicated for progressive neurological symptoms or lack of improvement after 6-12 weeks.
You are a clinical documentation assistant for chiropractors. Generate professional medical documentation.

Describe Prevalence and Statistics for Thoracic Disc Herniation.

Prevalence and Statistics

 

 Thoracic disc herniation is very rare. Only 0.25-0.75% of all symptomatic disc
 herniations occur in the thoracic spine. In comparison, the lumbar spine accounts for about 90% and the
 cervical spine for about 8%.

 
 
 0.25-0.75%
 of all symptomatic herniations
 

 
 70%
 develop myelopathy
 

 
 73-80%
 recover without surgery
 

 

 
 Prevalence and Demographics

 MRI studies show that 11-37% of healthy people have asymptomatic thoracic disc bulges
 (Wood et al., 1995). Symptomatic cases requiring treatment occur in approximately 1 per million per year
 (Shirzadi et al., 2013).

 Average age at diagnosis is 48 years, with highest prevalence between 40 and 60 years.
 Gender distribution is approximately equal (European Spine Journal, 2012).

What causes Thoracic Disc Herniation?

Causes and Risk Factors

 

 Causes are ranked from most to least common:

 
 1. Degenerative Changes (Most Common)

 The most common underlying cause. Disc material loses water content and elasticity over time.

 

 
 2. Trauma

 37-49% of patients have previous injury such as fall, car accident, or sports mishap (StatPearls,
 2024).

 

 
 3. Scheuermann's Disease

 Juvenile kyphosis with altered spinal morphology increases risk (P<0.01) (EFORT Open Reviews, 2021).
 Read more about Scheuermann's disease.
 

 

 
 4. Smoking

 Associated with 18% reduction in disc height over time (EFORT Open Reviews, 2021).

 

 
 5. Repetitive Rotational Loading

 Sports like golf, softball, and baseball with repeated twisting.

 

 Approximately 75% of thoracic herniations occur below the T8 level, with T11-T12 being
 the most common location, followed by T7-T8 (21.8%) and T8-T9 (15%) (Sarsilmaz et al., 2018).

Describe symptoms and signs of Thoracic Disc Herniation.

Symptoms

 

 The symptom picture varies depending on whether the herniation presses on nerve roots, spinal cord, or
 both.

 
 Most Common Symptoms

 
 Back pain: Occurs in 92% of patients with symptomatic thoracic herniation (PMC,
 2025). See also thoracic pain for other causes.

 Radicular pain: Band-like pain following a rib space, which may resemble rib dysfunction. Occurs in about 52%.

 Sensory disturbances: Numbness, tingling, or altered sensation in chest, abdomen,
 or legs (59%).

 Motor deficits: Weakness, especially in legs (37%).

 
 

 
 Diagnostic Delay

 Because symptoms can resemble heart, lung, or gastrointestinal disease (including costochondritis), it takes an average of 14-16 months
 from symptom onset to correct diagnosis (European Spine Journal, 2012).

 

 
 Myelopathy (Spinal Cord Involvement)

 In symptomatic patients, about 70% develop myelopathy - involvement of the spinal cord
 itself (Barrow Neurological Institute, 2024). This is because the spinal canal in the thoracic spine is
 particularly narrow, and 70% of thoracic herniations are calcified (StatPearls, 2024).

 MRI is the gold standard with approximately 81% sensitivity and specificity for disc
 herniation (PMC, 2018). If calcified herniation is suspected, CT can provide additional information.

 
 Important About MRI Findings

 73% of asymptomatic people have positive MRI findings in the thoracic spine, and 37% have disc bulges
 without symptoms (Wood et al., 1995). Imaging findings must always be interpreted in the context of

Describe treatment options for Thoracic Disc Herniation.

Treatment

 

 What Can the Chiropractor Do?

 The chiropractor's primary role in thoracic disc herniation is differential diagnosis -
 identifying the condition and assessing severity.

 
 Evidence Base

 There are no randomized controlled trials (RCTs) examining chiropractic or manual treatment
 specifically for thoracic disc herniation (ScienceDirect, 2006). Published case reports document serious
 complications after manipulation with known thoracic herniation (JAMA Neurology, 1987).

 

 For confirmed herniation without myelopathy, gentle soft tissue treatment and mobilization of surrounding
 areas may potentially relieve muscular compensation pain. High-velocity manipulation should be
 avoided when disc pathology in the thoracic spine is suspected.

 With signs of myelopathy or progressive neurological deficits, the patient should be referred
 immediately.

 
 Conservative Treatment Generally

 For patients without myelopathy, conservative treatment is recommended as first choice:

 
 Rest and activity modification: Short rest period (1-2 days) followed by gradual
 increase in activity

 Medication: Anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) after medical evaluation

 Physical therapy: Structured treatment for 4-6 weeks

 
 

 About 80% of patients return to previous activity level with conservative treatment
 (StatPearls, 2024). The classic study by Brown et al. (1992) followed 55 patients - 73% never needed
 surgery.

2 Symptoms of Thoracic Back Pain

 Thoracic back pain can manifest in many different ways depending on the cause. Here are the most common symptoms:

 
 
 
 
 Local stiffness and aching pain
 Feeling of tightness between the shoulder blades, often worse in the morning or after prolonged sitting in the same position.
 

 

 
 
 
 Sharp, stabbing pain
 Sudden pain with certain movements, deep breathing, coughing or sneezing.
 

 

 
 
 
 Radiation around the ribs
 Pain that follows the ribs from the back and around toward the chest or abdomen.
 

 

 
 
 
 Pain with rotation
 Pain when turning, reaching, or twisting the upper body.
 

 

 
 
 
 Breathing-related pain
 Pain that worsens with deep inhalation because the ribs move.
 

 

 

 
 Did you know?

 Because the nerves from the thoracic spine innervate the chest and abdominal region, thoracic back pain can sometimes feel like chest pain, abdominal pain, or even heart problems. This is a common cause of concern, but most cases are due to harmless musculoskeletal problems.

What causes Thoracic Back Pain  Causes, Symptoms and Treatment?

3 Common Causes of Thoracic Back Pain

 Most thoracic back pain is caused by mechanical issues that can be effectively treated by a chiropractor:

 
 Rib Joint Dysfunction (Costovertebral Dysfunction)

 The most common cause of thoracic back pain. Occurs when the joints between the ribs and vertebrae become stiff or "locked."

 
 Sharp pain with breathing and movement

 Point tenderness at the rib attachment

 Often triggered by twisting or lifting

 Responds very well to chiropractic treatment

 
 

 
 Costochondritis

 Inflammation in the cartilage connecting the ribs to the breastbone. Causes pain at the front of the chest but often related to thoracic dysfunction.

 
 Tender to touch at the breastbone

 Can mimic heart pain

 Worse with coughing and deep breathing

 Often self-limiting, but treatment helps

 
 

 
 Thoracic Facet Joint Dysfunction

 Stiffness or irritation in the small joints between the vertebrae in the thoracic spine.

 
 Stiff and aching pain between the shoulder blades

 Worse with extension (bending backward)

 Often related to poor posture

 Common in office workers

 
 

 
 Myofascial Trigger Points

 Painful knots in the muscles, especially in the rhomboids, trapezius, and erector spinae.

 
 Often refer pain to other areas

 Can cause headaches and neck pain

 Often related to stress and overload

 Treated effectively with soft tissue treatment

What causes Thoracic Back Pain  Causes, Symptoms and Treatment?

4 Less Common Causes

 Some conditions are rarer but important to be aware of:

 
 Scheuermann's Disease

 A developmental disorder causing increased kyphosis (rounding) in the thoracic spine, usually discovered in adolescence.

 
 Abnormal rounding of the upper back

 Stiffness and aching pain

 Wedged vertebrae visible on X-ray

 Can be treated conservatively in most cases

 
 

 
 Thoracic Disc Herniation

 Rarer than in the neck and lower back, but can occur. Accounts for only 1-2% of all disc herniations.

 
 Often asymptomatic even when found on MRI

 Can cause radiation around the ribs

 Rarely requires surgery

 
 

 
 Ankylosing Spondylitis

 Rheumatic disease causing inflammation and gradual stiffening of the spine.

 
 Morning stiffness over 30 minutes

 Improves with activity

 Often onset before age 40

 Requires referral to rheumatologist

 Many worry that chest pain could be heart-related. Here's how to tell the difference:

 
 
 Heart Pain (typical signs)

 
 Squeezing, pressing sensation

 Diffuse pain, hard to point to

 Radiation to left arm, jaw, or back

 Accompanied by breathing difficulty, sweating, nausea

 Worsens with exertion

 Not affected by pressure or movement

 Persistent over time

 
 

 
 Musculoskeletal Pain (typical signs)

 
 Sharp, stabbing, or aching

 Can point to exactly where it hurts

 Reproducible with pressure or movement

 Worsens with breathing, coughing, rotation

 Varies with position and activity

 Tender to palpation

 Comes and goes

7 Treatment of Thoracic Back Pain

 Chiropractic treatment is very effective for most mechanical thoracic back pain:

 
 Chiropractic Treatment

 Includes joint mobilization and manipulation of the thoracic spine and costovertebral joints. Particularly effective for rib dysfunction and thoracic stiffness. Most notice improvement after 2-4 treatments.

 

 
 Soft Tissue Treatment

 Massage, trigger point treatment, and myofascial release for tight muscles in the upper back and shoulder blade area. Effective for muscle tension and trigger points.

 

 
 Exercises and Rehabilitation

 Tailored exercises to increase mobility, strength, and prevent recurrence. Focus on thoracic mobility and posture-correcting exercises.

 

 
 Ergonomic Advice

 Guidance on workplace setup, break routines, and daily activities to reduce strain on the thoracic spine.

Describe 8 Exercises for Thoracic Back Pain for Thoracic Back Pain  Causes, Symptoms and Treatment.

8 Exercises for Thoracic Back Pain

 These exercises can help reduce stiffness and improve mobility in the thoracic spine:

 
 1. Cat-Camel

 A gentle mobilization exercise for the entire spine:

 
 Start on all fours with hands under shoulders and knees under hips

 Round your back up toward the ceiling like an angry cat, let your head drop

 Lower your back down and lift your head, creating a sway

 Move slowly and controlled between positions

 Focus on movement in the thoracic spine area

 
 10-15 repetitions, 2-3 times daily

 

 
 2. Thread the Needle

 Excellent for increasing rotational ability in the thoracic spine:

 
 Start on all fours

 Lift your right arm out to the side and rotate your upper body up toward the ceiling

 Then thread the arm under your body and extend it out on your left side

 Let your head rest on the floor in the rotation

 Return to start and repeat

 
 8-10 repetitions on each side, 2 times daily

 

 
 3. Thoracic Extension over Foam Roller

 Effective for counteracting forward-leaning posture and stiffness:

 
 Lie on your back with a foam roller under your thoracic spine

 Support your head with your hands, keep elbows out to the side

 Let your thoracic spine extend backward over the roller

 Hold the position for 5-10 seconds

 Move the roller slightly up or down to work different levels

 
 5-10 repetitions at each level, 1-2 times daily

 

 
 Important about exercises

 Stop the exercise if you experience increased pain. These exerci...

9 Frequently Asked Questions About Thoracic Back Pain

 
 What does thoracic back pain feel like?

 
 Thoracic back pain can vary from aching and stiff sensations to sharp, stabbing pain. You may experience pain between the shoulder blades, around the ribs, or pain radiating to the chest. Pain often worsens with deep breathing, coughing, or rotating movements.
 

 

 
 Can thoracic back pain cause chest pain?

 
 Yes, thoracic back pain can definitely cause chest pain. The nerve roots exiting from the thoracic spine innervate the area around the ribs and chest. Conditions like costochondritis, rib dysfunction, or thoracic dysfunction can all cause pain felt in the chest but originating in the back.
 

 

 
 How do you distinguish thoracic back pain from heart problems?

 
 Musculoskeletal chest pain is often reproducible with pressure or movement, localized to one point, and worsens with breathing or rotation. Heart pain is often diffuse, accompanied by breathing difficulty, sweating or nausea, and is not related to movement. When in doubt, seek medical attention immediately.
 

 

 
 Is thoracic back pain dangerous?

 
 Most thoracic back pain is caused by harmless muscle and joint problems like rib dysfunction or muscle tension. However, you should see a doctor if you have unexplained weight loss, fever, nighttime pain that wakes you, numbness/weakness in the legs, or previous cancer history.

Describe symptoms and signs of Thoracic Back Pain: Causes, Symptoms and Treatment.

Symptoms of Thoracic Back Pain

 

 Symptoms vary depending on the underlying cause, but the most common are:

 
 Aching pain between the shoulder blades - Often worst after prolonged sitting or one-sided work. May feel like tiredness or a burning sensation in the muscles.

 Sharp pain with movement or breathing - Typical for rib dysfunction or irritation in the joints between ribs and spine. Can make it painful to take deep breaths.

 Morning stiffness - Feeling of reduced mobility, especially with rotation. Often improves after you've moved around a bit.

 Radiation along the ribs - Pain that follows the rib course from the back and forward towards the sternum. This can be frightening but usually has a harmless cause.

 Feeling of not getting enough air - When the thoracic spine is stiff, rib movement is restricted. This can give a feeling of tightness in the chest without anything being wrong with the lungs.
You are a clinical documentation assistant for chiropractors. Generate professional medical documentation.
What causes Thoracic Back Pain: Causes, Symptoms and Treatment?

Causes of Thoracic Back Pain

 

 The vast majority of thoracic back pain is caused by problems in muscles, joints or connective tissue - so-called musculoskeletal complaints. Here I review the causes from most to least common:

 Common Causes (90%+ of cases)

 
 Prolonged Sitting and "Office Back"

 People sit more than ever. Studies show that prolonged sitting (over 7 hours daily) is associated with reduced mobility in the thoracic spine and increased risk of pain. A forward-leaning posture in front of a PC or mobile phone significantly increases the load on the upper back muscles.

 Among office workers, up to 34% report upper back complaints within a year (Briggs et al., 2009).

 

 
 Stress and Breathing Patterns - The "Invisible" Cause

 Stress often manifests physically in the body. With high stress, breathing patterns change to become more shallow - so-called chest breathing. This overloads the accessory muscles in the neck and thoracic spine.

 The result is a vicious cycle: Tension leads to pain, pain leads to altered breathing patterns, altered breathing leads to more tension.

Identify red flags for Thoracic Back Pain: Causes, Symptoms and Treatment.

Red Flags - When to Seek Medical Attention

 

 
 Call 113 or Visit A&E Immediately For:

 
 Severe chest pain radiating to left arm, jaw or neck

 Breathing difficulties, shortness of breath or clammy sweating

 Sudden, intense "tearing" pain in the back

 Weakness or paralysis in the legs, loss of bladder/bowel control

 Fever combined with back pain

 Unexplained weight loss combined with persistent back pain

 
 

 
 Heart Pain vs. Rib Pain - How to Tell the Difference

 Heart pain: Often diffuse/pressing, often comes with exertion, accompanied by sweating, nausea, breathing difficulties. Often radiates to arm, jaw or back. Does NOT change with movement or pressure on the chest.

 Rib/muscle pain: Often sharp/stabbing, comes with certain movements or breathing. You can often point to exactly where it hurts. Worsens with pressure on the spot, rotation or deep breathing.

 If in doubt? It's always safe to call 113 or A&E for an assessment. Better one trip too many than one too few.

Describe treatment options for Thoracic Back Pain: Causes, Symptoms and Treatment.

Treatment at the Chiropractor

 

 As a chiropractor, I am a licensed healthcare professional with specialist expertise in musculoskeletal complaints. You can come directly to me without a GP referral.

 Examination

 The first consultation always starts with a thorough review of your medical history and a clinical examination. I map mobility, muscle tension and neurological conditions to find the cause of the pain and rule out conditions requiring other follow-up.

 Treatment Methods

 Treatment is tailored to the individual, but may include:

 
 Joint Manipulation/Mobilisation

 Specific techniques to restore normal joint function. A systematic review (Gevers-Montoro et al., 2022) shows that thoracic manipulation has significant effect on pain and function compared to mobilisation alone.

 

 
 Soft Tissue Treatment

 Massage, trigger point treatment or instrument-assisted treatment to loosen tight muscles.

 

 
 Exercises and Guidance

 Specific exercises to strengthen and stabilise, as well as advice on ergonomics and work posture.

 

 
 Breathing Guidance

 For stress-related complaints, conscious work on breathing patterns can be an important part of treatment.

 

 
 What can you expect? Many experience improvement within 3-6 treatments, but this varies based on how long you've had complaints and your general health. It's important to have realistic expectations - some complaints require time and self-effort to improve.

Describe What Can You Do Yourself? for Thoracic Back Pain: Causes, Symptoms and Treatment.

What Can You Do Yourself?

 

 Activity is often the best medicine. Here are three exercises that can relieve stiffness in the thoracic spine:

 
 1. Cat-Camel

 Start on all fours. Round your back up while exhaling (like an angry cat), then arch your back while inhaling. Repeat calmly 10-15 times. Good for mobility throughout the spine.

 

 
 2. Thread the Needle

 Lie on your side with bent knees. Stretch your top arm forward, then guide it in an arc over your head and backwards while following your hand with your gaze. Hold for a few seconds and feel the stretch in your chest. 10 repetitions on each side.

 

 
 3. Thoracic Extension Over Foam Roller

 Lie with your thoracic spine over a foam roller (avoid the lower back). Hold your hands behind your head and lean back gently. Roll carefully back and forth. 1-2 minutes daily.

 

 
 Tips

 Do the exercises daily for 2-3 weeks for best effect. Stop if the exercises worsen your pain.

Describe Frequently Asked Questions for Thoracic Back Pain: Causes, Symptoms and Treatment.

Frequently Asked Questions

 

 
 Is it dangerous when my back cracks?

 No. The sound during manipulation is due to the release of gas bubbles in the joint fluid - completely harmless and usually painless.

 

 
 Can thoracic back pain come from the heart?

 Pain from the heart can be felt in the chest and back, but is usually accompanied by other symptoms such as breathing difficulties, nausea or radiation to arm/jaw. When in doubt, contact a doctor.

 

 
 Do I need X-ray or MRI?

 Rarely. Imaging is only necessary when there's suspicion of serious underlying cause (red flags). For most musculoskeletal complaints, clinical examination provides sufficient information.

 

 
 How long do the complaints last?

 Acute complaints often improve within 2-6 weeks. For chronic complaints (over 12 weeks), it may take longer, and a combination of treatment and self-effort is important.

 

 
 Can stress cause back pain?

 Yes, absolutely. Mental stress leads to increased muscle tension and altered breathing patterns, which in turn can cause physical pain in the neck and thoracic spine. The connection is well documented.

 

 
 Should I rest or be active?

 Moderate activity is usually better than bed rest. Movement promotes blood circulation and prevents muscles from stiffening further.

Describe Prolonged Sitting and "Office Back" in the context of Thoracic Back Pain: Causes, Symptoms and Treatment.

Prolonged Sitting and "Office Back"

 People sit more than ever. Studies show that prolonged sitting (over 7 hours daily) is associated with reduced mobility in the thoracic spine and increased risk of pain. A forward-leaning posture in front of a PC or mobile phone significantly increases the load on the upper back muscles.

 Among office workers, up to 34% report upper back complaints within a year (Briggs et al., 2009).

Describe Posture-Related Problems in the context of Thoracic Back Pain: Causes, Symptoms and Treatment.

Posture-Related Problems

 Increased kyphosis (forward-leaning posture) puts unnecessary strain on the thoracic spine. Screen work, mobile use and prolonged sitting are common triggering factors.

 

 Less Common Causes

 
 Costochondritis and Tietze's Syndrome

 Inflammation of the cartilage connecting the ribs to the sternum. Causes pain at the front of the chest that can mimic heart disease, but has a musculoskeletal cause.

 A developmental disorder causing increased kyphosis in adolescents. Affects 1-8% of the population. Usually diagnosed between ages 12-17.

Describe T4 Syndrome in the context of Thoracic Back Pain: Causes, Symptoms and Treatment.

T4 Syndrome

 Dysfunction in the upper thoracic spine that can cause radiation to arms and hands, often together with numbness or tingling. Usually responds well to manipulation.

 

 Rare Causes (under 1%)

 
 Thoracic Disc Herniation

 Accounts for only 0.25-1% of all disc herniations. Most are asymptomatic and discovered incidentally on MRI. Symptomatic cases are very rare - about 1 per million per year.
